ìJimmy, weíve been the victims of a contemptible, dirty, lowdown, doublecrossing trick.î His eyes dilated with fury. ìWeíve been cheated, robbed-,î words failed him but he kept on uttering meaningless sounds, indicative mainly of devouring rage.
Jimmy was cooler, but none the less vindictive, ìYouíre right, Roy; McCutcheon has done us dirty. He has plumbed the depths of human iniquity. But weíll get even. When we get through in 6300 odd minutes, we will have a score to settle with Mr. McCutcheon.î
ìWhat are we going to do?î Royís eyes were filled with a bloodthirsty joy.
ìOn the spur of the moment, I suggest that we simply tear into him and rend him into tiny, little pieces.î
ìNot gruesome enough. How about boiling him in oil?î
ìThatís reasonable, yes; but it might take too long. Letís give him a good old-fashioned beating-with brass knuckles.î
Roy rubbed his hands. ìWeíll have lots of time to think up some really adequate measures. The dirty. God-forsaken, yellow-livered, leprous-î The rest verged fluently into the unprintable.
And for four more days, the temperature dove. It was on the fourteenth and last day that the mercury froze, the solid red shaft pointed its congealed finger at forty below.
On this terrible last day, they had lit the oil-burner, using their entire scanty supply of oil. Shivering and more than half frozen, they crouched close, attempting to extract every last drop of heat.
Jimmy had found a pair of ear-muffs several days before in some obscure corner, and it now changed hands at the end of every hour. Both sat buried under a small mountain of blankets, chafing chilled hands and feet. With every passing minute, their conversation, concerning McCutcheon almost exclusively, grew more vitriolic.
ìAlways quoting that triply-damned slogan of the Space Mail: ëOur flight through sp-í ì Jimmy choked with impotent fury.
ìYes, and always rubbing holes in chairs instead of coming out here and doing something like a manís work, the rotten so-and-so,î agreed Roy.
ìWell, weíre due to pass out of the deflection zone in two hours. Then three weeks and weíll be on Venus,î said Jimmy, sneezing.
ìThat canít be too soon for me,î answered Sneed, who had been sniffling for the last two days. ìIím never taking another space trip except maybe the one that takes me back to Earth. After this, I make my living growing bananas in Central America. A fellow can be decently warm out there at least.î
ìWe might not get off Venus, after what weíre going to do to McCutcheon.î
ìNo, youíre right there. But thatís all right. Venus is even warmer than Central America and thatís all I care about.î
ìWe have no legal worries either,î Jimmy sneezed again. ìOn Venus, life imprisonmentís the limit for first-degree murder. A nice,-warm dry cell for the rest of my life. What could be sweeter?î
The second hand on the chronometer whirled at its even pace; the minutes ticked off. Royís hands hovered lovingly over the lever that would set off the right rear blasts which would drive the Helios out away from the sun and from that terrible Deflection Zone.
And at last, ìGo!î shouted Jimmy eagerly. ìLet her blast!î
With a deep reverberating roar, the rockets fired. The Helios trembled from stem to stern. The pilots felt the acceleration press them back into their seats and were happy. In a matter of minutes, the sun would shine again and they would be warm, feel the blessed heat once more.
It happened before they were aware of it. There was a momentary flash of light and then a grinding and a click, as the sunward portholes closed.
ìLook,î cried Roy, ìthe stars! Weíre out of it!î He cast an ecstatically happy glance at the thermometer. ìWell, old boy, from now on we go up again.î He pulled the blankets about him closer, for the cold still lingered.
There were two men in Frank McCutcheonís office at the Venus branch of the United Space Mail: McCutcheon himself and the elderly, white-haired Zebulon Smith, inventor of the Deflection Field. Smith was talking.
ìBut Mr. McCutcheon, it is really of great importance that I learn exactly how my Deflection Field worked. Surely they have transmitted all possible information to you.î
McCutcheonís face was a study in dourness as he bit the edge off one of his two-for-five cigars and lit it.
ìThat, my dear Mr. Smith,î he said, ìis exactly what they did not do. Ever since they have receded far enough from the sun to render communication possible, I have been sending requests for information regarding the practicability of the Field. They just refuse to answer. They say it worked and that theyíre alive and that theyíll give the details when they reach Venus. Thatís all!î
Zebulon Smith sighed in disappointment. ìIsnít that a bit unusual; insubordination, so to speak? I thought they were required to be complete in their reports and to give any requested details.î
ìSo they are. But these are my ace pilots and rather temperamental. We have to extend some leeway. Besides, I tricked them into going on this trip, a very hazardous one, as you know, and so am inclined to be lenient.î
ìWell, then, I suppose I must wait.î
ìOh, it wonít be for long,î McCutcheon assured him. ìTheyíre due today, and I assure you that as soon as I get in touch with them, I shall send you the full details. After all, they survived for two weeks at a distance of twenty million miles from the sun, so your invention is a success. That should satisfy you.î
Smith had scarcely left when McCutcheonís secretary entered with a puzzled frown on her face.
ìSomething is wrong with the two pilots of the Helios , Mr. McCutcheon,î she informed him. ìI have just received a bulletin from Major Wade at Pallas City, where they landed. They have refused to attend the celebration prepared for them, but instead immediately chartered a rocket to come here, refusing to state the reason. When Major Wade tried to stop them, they became violent, he says.î She laid the communication down on his desk.
McCutcheon glanced at it perfunctorily. ìHmm! they do seem confoundedly temperamental. Well, send them to me when they come. Iíll snap them out of it.î
It was perhaps three hours later that the problem of the two misbehaving pilots again forced itself upon his mind, this time by a sudden commotion that had arisen in the reception room. He heard the deep angry tones of two men and then the shrill remonstrances of his secretary. Suddenly the door burst open and Jim Turner and Roy Snead strode in.
Roy coolly closed the door and planted his back against it.
ìDonít let anyone disturb me until Iím through,î Jimmy told him.
ìNo oneís getting through this door for a while,î Roy answered grimly, ìbut remember, you promised to leave some for me.î
McCutcheon said nothing during all this, but when he saw Turner casually draw a pair of brass knuckles from his pocket and put them on with a determined air, he decided that it was time to call a halt to the comedy.
ìHello, boys,î he said, with a heartiness unusual in him. ìGlad to see you again. Take a seat.î
Jimmy ignored the offer. ìHave you anything to say, any last request, before I start operations?î He gritted his teeth with an unpleasant scraping noise.
ìWell, if you put it that way,î said McCutcheon, ìI might ask exactly what this is all about-if Iím not being too unreasonable. Perhaps the Deflector was inefficient and you had a hot trip.î
The only answer to that was a loud snort from Roy and a cold stare on the part of Jimmy.
ìFirst,î said the latter, ìwhat was the idea of that filthy, disgusting cheat you pulled on us?î
McCutcheonís eyebrows raised in surprise. ìDo you mean the little white lies I told you in order to get you to go? Why, that was nothing. Common business practice, thatís all. Why, I pull worse things than that every day and people consider it just routine. Besides, what harm did it do you?î
ìTell him about our ëpleasant trip,í Jimmy,î urged Roy.
ìThatís exactly what Iím going to do,î was the response. He turned to McCutcheon and assumed a martyr-like air. ìFirst, on this blasted trip, we fried in a temperature that reached 150 but that was to be expected and weíre not complaining; we were half Mercuryís distance from the sun.
ìBut after that, we entered this zone where the light bends around us; incoming radiation sank to zero and we started losing heat and not just a degree a day the way we learned it in pilot school.î He paused to breathe a few novel curses he had just thought of, then continued.
ììIn three days, we were down to a hundred and in a week down to freezing. Then for one entire week, seven long days, we drove through our course at sub-freezing temperature. It was so cold the last day that the mercury froze.î Turnerís voice rose till it cracked, and at the door, a fit of self-pity caused Roy to catch his breath with an audible gulp. McCutcheon remained inscrutable.
Jimmy continued. ìThere we were without a heating system, in fact, no heat of any kind, not even any warm clothing. We froze, damn it; we had to thaw out our food and melt our water. We were stiff, couldnít move. It was hell, I tell you, in reverse temperature.î He paused, at a loss for words.
Roy Snead took up the burden. ìWe were twenty million miles away from the sun and I had a case of frost-bitten ears. Frost-bitten, I say.î He shook his fist viciously under McCutcheonís nose. ìAnd it was your fault. You tricked us into it! While we were freezing, we promised ourselves that weíd come back and get you and weíre going to keep that promise.î He turned to Jimmy. ìGo ahead, start it, will you? Weíve wasted enough time.î
ìHold it, hoys,î McCutcheon spoke at last. ìLet me get this straight. You mean to say that the Deflection Field worked so well that it kept all the radiation away and sucked out what heat there was in the ship in the first place?î Jimmy grunted a curt assent.
ìAnd you froze for a week because of that?î McCutcheon continued.
Again the grunt.
And then a very strange and unusual thing happened. McCutcheon, ìOld, Sourpuss,î the man without the ìrisusî muscle, smiled. He actually bared his teeth in a grin. And whatís more, the grin grew wider and wider until finally a rusty, long-unused chuckle was heard louder and louder, until it developed into a full-fledged laugh, and the laugh into a bellow. In one stentorian burst, McCutcheon made up for a lifetime of sour gloom.
The walls reverberated, the windowpanes rattled, and still the Homeric laughter continued. Roy and Jimmy stood openmouthed, entirely non-plussed. A puzzled bookkeeper thrust his head inside the door in a fit of temerity and remained frozen in his tracks. Others crowded about the door, conversing in awed whispers. McCutcheon had laughed!
Gradually, the risibilities of the old General Manager subsided. He ended in a fit of choking and finally turned a purple face towards his ace pilots, whose surprise had long since given way to indignation.
ìBoys,î he told them, ìthat was the best joke I ever heard. You can consider your pay doubled, both of you.î He was still grinning away like clockwork and had developed a beautiful case of hiccoughs.
The two pilots were left cold at the handsome proposal. ìWhatís so killingly funny?î Jimmy wanted to know, ìI donít see anything to laugh at, myself.î
McClutcheonís voice dripped honey, ìNow, fellows, before I left I gave each of you several mimeographed sheets containing special instructions. What happened to them?î
There was sudden embarrassment in the air.
ìI donít know. I must have mislaid mine,î gulped Roy.
ìI never looked at mine; I forgot about it.î Jimmy was genuinely dismayed.
ìYou see,î exclaimed McCutcheon triumphantly, ìit was all the fault of your own stupidity.î
ìHow do you figure that out?î Jimmy wanted to know. ìMajor Wade told us all we had to know about the ship, and besides, I guess thereís nothing you could tell us about running one.î
ìOh, isnít there? Wade evidently forgot to inform you of one minor point which you would have found on my instructions. The strength of the Deflection Field was adjustable. It happened to be set at maximum strength when you started, thatís all.î He was now beginning to chuckle faintly once more. ìNow, if you had taken the trouble to read the sheets, you would have known that a simple movement of a small lever,î he made the appropriate gesture with his thumb, ìwould have weakened the Field any desired amount and allowed as much radiation to leak through as was wanted.î
And now the chuckle was becoming louder. ìAnd you froze for a week because you didnít have the brains to pull a lever. And then you ace pilots come here and blame me. What a laugh!î and off he went again while a pair of very sheepish young men glanced askance at each other.
When McCutcheon came around to normal, Jimmy and Roy were gone.
Down in an alley adjoining the building, a little ten-year-old boy watched, with open mouth and intense absorption, two young men who were engaged in the strange and rather startling occupation of kicking each other alternately. They were vicious kicks, too.



***



When I wrote ìRing Around the Sunî I was much taken by the two protagonists. Turner and Snead. It was in my mind, I recall, to write other stories about the pair. This was a natural thought, for in the late 1930s there were a number of ìseriesî of stories about a given character or characters. Campbell himself had written some delightful stories featuring two men named Penton and Blake, and I longed to do a Penton-Blake imitation.
There was a practical value to writing a ìseries.î For one thing, you had a definite background that was carried on from story to story, so that half your work was done for you. Secondly, if the ìseriesî became popular, it would be difficult to reject new stories that fit into it.
I didnít make it with Turner and Snead. In fact, I never tried. The time was to come, two years later, when I was to have a pair of very similar characters, Powell and Donovan, who were to be in four stories and who were to be part of a very successful ìseriesî indeed.
By the end of August 1938, then, I had written five stories, of which three were eventually published. Not bad!
However, there followed a dry spell. I was finishing my third year of college and was trying, without success, to get admission into medical school. The situation in Europe was disturbing. It was the time of the surrender at Munich, and for a Jewish teen-ager there was something unsettling about the rapid, sure-fire victories of Hitler.
The next three stories took not one month, as had the previous three, but three months. And all were clearly well below the limits of salability even in the most permissive market. They were ìThe Weapon,î ìPaths of Destiny,î and ìKnossos in Its Glory.î Campbell rejected each one in very short order, and all made the rounds without luck. There came a time, nearly three years later, when Astonishing seemed interested in ìThe Weapon,î but that fell through and the other two didnít even come that close.
All three stories are now gone forever. I remember nothing at all about two of them, but ìKnossos in Its Gloryî was an ambitious attempt to retell the Theseus myth in science fiction terms. The minotaur was an extraterrestrial who landed in ancient Crete with only the kindliest of intentions, and I remember writing terribly stilted prose in an attempt to make my Cretans sound as I imagined characters in Homer ought to sound. Campbell, always kind, said in rejecting it that my work ìwas definitely improving, especially where I was not straining for effect.î
By the time I was writing ìKnossos in Its Gloryî I had just received my check for ìMarooned off Vestaî and I was a professional. My spirits rose accordingly, and toward the end of November I wrote ìAmmonium,î which was another attempt (like ìRing Around the Sunî) at humor.
I had a pretty good notion that Campbell wouldnít like it, however, and I never showed it to him. I sent it to Thrilling Wonder Stories instead. When they rejected it, I lost heart and retired it. It was only after Future Fiction had taken ìRing Around the Sunî that I thought I would chance this other one, too.
On August 23, 1939, I sent it in to Future Fiction , which took it, altering its name to ìThe Magnificent Possession.î








The Magnificent Possession


Walter Sills reflected now, as he had reflected often before, that life was hard and joyless. He surveyed his dingy chemical laboratory and grinned cynically-working in a dirty hole of a place, living on occasional ore analyses that barely paid for absolutely indispensable equipment, while others, not half his worth perhaps, were working for big industrial concerns and taking life easy.
He looked out the window at the Hudson River, ruddied in the flame of the dying sun, and wondered moodily whether these last experiments would finally bring him the fame and success he was after, or if they were merely some more false alarms.
The unlocked door creaked open a crack and the cheerful face of Eugene Taylor burst into view. Sills waved and Taylorís body followed his head and entered the laboratory.
ìHello, old soak,î came the loud and carefree hail. ìHow go things?î
Sills shook his head at the otherís exuberance. ìI wish I had your foolish outlook on life. Gene. For your information, things are bad. I need money, and the more I need it, the less I have.î
ìWell, I havenít any money either, have I?î demanded Taylor. ìBut why worry about it? Youíre fifty, and worry hasnít got you anything except a bald head. Iím thirty, and I want to keep my beautiful brown hair.î
The chemist grinned. ìIíll get my money yet. Gene. Just leave it to me.î
ìYour new ideas shaping out well?î
ìAre they? I havenít told you much about it, have I? Well, come here and Iíll show you what progress Iíve made.î
Taylor followed Sills to a small table, on which stood a rack of test tubes, in one of which was about half an inch of a shiny metallic substance.
ìSodium-mercury mixture, or sodium amalgam, as it is called,î explained Sills pointing to it.
He took a bottle labeled ìAmmonium Chloride Sol.î from the shelf and poured a little into the tube. Immediately the sodium amalgam began changing into a loosely-packed, spongy substance.
ìThat,î observed Sills, ìis ammonium amalgam. The ammonium radical (NH4) acts as a metal here and combines with mercury.î He waited for the action to go to completion and then poured off the supernatant liquid.
ìAmmonium amalgam isnít very stable,î he informed Taylor, ìso Iíll have to work fast.î He grasped a flask of straw-colored, pleasant-smelling liquid and filled the test-tube with it. Upon shaking, the loosely-packed ammonium amalgam vanished and in its stead a small drop of metallic liquid rolled about the bottom.
Taylor gazed at the test-tube, open-mouthed. ìWhat happened?î
ìThis liquid is a complex derivative of hydrazine which Iíve discovered and named Ammonaline. I havenít worked out its formula yet, but that doesnít matter. The point about it is that it has the property of dissolving the ammonium out of the amalgam. Those few drops at the bottom are pure mercury; the ammonium is in solution.î
Taylor remained unresponsive and Sills waxed enthusiastic. ìDonít you see the implications? Iíve gone half way towards isolating pure ammonium, a thing which has never been done before! Once accomplished it means fame, success, the Nobel Prize, and who knows what else.î
ìWow!î Taylorís gaze became more respectful. ìThat yellow stuff doesnít look so important to me.î He snatched for it, but Sills withheld it.
ìI havenít finished, by any means, Gene. Iíve got to get it in its free metallic state, and I canít do that so far. Every time I try to evaporate the Ammonaline, the ammonium breaks down to everlasting ammonia and hydrogenÖ But Iíll get it-Iíll get it!î
Two weeks later, the epilogue to the previous scene was enacted. Taylor received a hurried and emphatic call from his chemist friend and appeared at the laboratory in a flurry of anticipation.
ìYouíve got it?î
ìIíve got it-and itís bigger than I thought! Thereís millions in it, really,î Sillsí eyes shone with rapture.
ìIíve been working from the wrong angle up to now,î he explained. ìHeating the solvent always broke down the dissolved ammonium, so I separated it out by freezing. It works the same way as brine, which, when frozen slowly, freezes into fresh ice, the salt crystallizing out. Luckily, the Ammonaline freezes at 18 degrees Centigrade and doesnít require much cooling.î
He pointed dramatically to a small beaker, inside a glasswalled case. The beaker contained pale, straw-colored, needlelike crystals and, covering the top of this, a thin layer of a dullish, yellow substance.
ìWhy the case?î asked Taylor.
ìIíve got it filled with argon to keep the ammonium (which is the yellow substance on top of the Ammonaline) pure. It is so active that it will react with anything else but a helium-type gas.î
Taylor marveled and pounded his complacently-smiling friend on the back.
ìWait, Gene, the best is yet to come.î
Taylor was led to the other end of the room and Sillsí trembling finger pointed out another airtight case containing a lump of metal of a gleaming, yellow that sparkled and glistened.
ìThat, my friend, is ammonium oxide (NH420), formed by passing absolutely dry air over free ammonium metal. It is perfectly inert (the sealed case contains quite a bit of chlorine, for instance, and yet there is no reaction). It can be made as cheaply as aluminum, if not more so, and yet it looks more like gold than gold does itself. Do you see the possibilities?î
ìDo I?î exploded Taylor. ìIt will sweep the country. You can have ammonium jewelry, and ammonium-plated tableware, and a million other things. Then again, who knows how many countless industrial applications it may have? Youíre rich, Walt-youíre rich.î
ì Weíre rich,î corrected Sills gently. He moved towards the telephone, ìThe newspapers are going to hear of this. Iím going to begin to cash in on fame right now.î
Taylor frowned, ìMaybe youíd better keep it a secret, Walt.î
ìOh, Iím not breathing a hint as to the process. Iíll just give them the general idea. Besides, weíre safe; the patent application is in Washington right now.î
But Sills was wrong! The article in the paper ushered in a very, very hectic two days for the two of them.
J. Throgmorton Bankhead is what is commonly known as a ìcaptain of industry.î As head of the Acme Chromium and Silver Plating Corporation he no doubt deserved the title; but to his patient and long-suffering wife, he was merely a dyspeptic and grouchy husband, especially at the breakfast tableÖ and he was at the breakfast table now.
Rustling his morning paper angrily, he sputtered between bites of buttered toast, ëThis man is ruining the country.î He pointed aghast at big, black headlines. ìI said before and Iíll say again that the man is as crazy as a bedbug. He wonít be satisfiedÖî
ìJoseph, please,î pleaded his wife, ìyouíre getting purple in the face. Remember your high blood pressure. You know the doctor told you to stop reading the news from Washington if it annoys you so. Now, listen dear, about the cook. SheísÖî
ìThe doctorís a damn fool, and so are you,î shouted J. Throgmorton Bankhead. ìIíll read all the news I please and get purple in the face too, if I want to.î
He raised the cup of coffee to his mouth and took a critical sip. While he did so, his eyes fell upon a more insignificant headline towards the bottom of the page: ìSavant Discovers Gold Substitute.î The coffee cup remained in the air while he scanned the article quickly. ìThis new metal,î it ran in part, ìis claimed by its discoverer to be far superior to chromium, nickel, or silver for cheap and beautiful jewelry. The twenty-dollar-a-week clerk,í said Professor Sills, ëwill eat off ammonium plate more impressive in appearance than the gold plate of the Indian Nabob.í There is noÖî
But J. Throgmorton Bankhead had stopped reading. Visions of a ruined Acme Chromium and Silver Plating Corporation danced before his eyes; and as they danced, the cup of coffee dropped from his hand, and splashed hot liquid over his trousers.
His wife rose to her feet in alarm, ìWhat is it, Joseph; what is it?î
ìNothing,î Bankhead shouted. ìNothing. For Godís sake, go away, will you?î
He strode angrily out of the room, leaving his wife to search the paper for anything that could have disturbed him.
ìBobís Tavernî on Fifteenth Street is usually pretty well filled at all times, but on the morning we are speaking of, it was empty except for four or five rather poorly-dressed men who clustered about the portly and dignified form of Peter Q. Hornswoggle, eminent ex-Congressman.
Peter Q. Hornswoggle was, as usual, speaking fluently. His subject, again as usual, concerned the life of a Congressman.
ìI remember a case in point,î he was saying, ìwhen that same argument was brought up in the House, and which I answered as follows: The eminent gentleman from Nevada in his statements overlooks one very important aspect of the problem. He does not realize that it is to the interest of the entire nation that the apple-parers of this country be attended to promptly; for, gentlemen, on the welfare of the apple-parers depends the future of the entire fruit industry and on the fruit-industry is based the entire economy of this great and glorious nation, the United States of America.í ì
Hornswoggle paused, swallowed half a pint of beer at once, and then smiled in triumph, ìI have no hesitation in saying, gentlemen, that at that statement, the entire House burst into wild and tumultuous applause.î
One of the assembled listeners shook his head slowly and marvelled. ìIt must be great to be able to spiel like that, Senator. You musta been a sensation.î
ìYeah,î agreed the bartender, ìitís a dirty shame you were beat last election.î
The ex-Congressman winced and in a very dignified tone began, ìI have been reliably informed that the use of bribery in that campaign reached unprecedented propÖî His voice died away suddenly as he caught sight of a certain article in the newspaper of one of his listeners. He snatched at it and read it through in silence and thereupon his eyes gleamed with a sudden idea.
ìMy friends,î he said turning to them again, ìI find I must leave you. There is pressing work that must be done immediately at City Hall.î He leant over to whisper to the barkeeper, ìYou havenít got twenty-five cents, have you? I find I left my wallet in the Mayorís office by mistake. I will surely repay you tomorrow.î
Clutching the quarter, reluctantly given, Peter Q. Hornswoggle left.
In a small and dimly lit room somewhere in the lower reaches of First Avenue, Michael Maguire, known to the police by the far more euphonious name of Mike the Slug, cleaned his trusty revolver and hummed a tuneless song. The door opened a crack and Mike looked up.
ìThat you, Slappy?î
ìYeh,î a short, wizened person sidled in, ìI brung ye de eveniní sheet. De cops are still tinkiní Bragoni pulled de job.î
ìYeh? Thatís good.î He bent unconcernedly over the revolver. ìAnything else doing?î
ìNaw! Some dippy dame killed herself, but datís all.î
He tossed the newspaper to Mike and left. Mike leaned back and flipped the pages in a bored manner.
A headline attracted his eye and he read the short article that followed. Having finished, he threw aside the paper, lit a cigarette, and did some heavy thinking. Then he opened the door.
ìHey, Slappy, címere. Thereís a job thatís got to be done.î
Walter Sills was happy, deliriously so. He walked about his laboratory king of all he surveyed, strutting like a peacock, basking in his new-found glory. Eugene Taylor sat and watched him, scarcely less happy himself.
ìHow does it feel to be famous?î Taylor wanted to know.
ìLike a million dollars; and thatís what Iím going to sell the secret of ammonium metal for. Itís the fat of the land for me from now on.î
ìYou leave the practical details to me, Walt. Iím getting in touch with Staples of Eagle Steel today. Youíll get a decent price from him.î
The bell rang, and Sills jumped. He ran to open the door.
ìIs this the home of Walter Sills?î The large, scowling visitor gazed about him superciliously.
ìYes, Iím Sills. Do you wish to see me?î
ìYes. My name is J. Throgmorton Bankhead and I represent the Acme Chromium and Silver Plating Corporation. I would like to have a momentís discussion with you.î
ìCome right in. Come right in! This is Eugene Taylor, my associate. You may speak freely before him.î
ìVery well.î Bankhead seated himself heavily. ìI suppose you surmise the reason for my visit.î
ìI take it that you have read of the new ammonium metal in the papers.î
ìThatís right. I have come to see whether there is any truth in the story and to buy your process if there is.î
ìYou can see for yourself, sir,î Sills led the magnate to where the argon-filled container of the few grams of pure ammonium were. ìThat is the metal. Over here to the right, Iíve got the oxide, an oxide which is more metallic than the metal itself, strangely enough. It is the oxide that is what the papers call ësubstitute gold.í ì
Bankheadís face showed not an atom of the sinking feeling within him as he viewed the oxide with dismay. ìTake it out in the open,î he said, ìand letís see it.î
Sills shook his head. ìI canít, Mr. Bankhead. Those are the first samples of ammonium and ammonium-oxide that ever existed. Theyíre museum pieces. I can easily make more for you, if you wish.î
ìYouíll have to, if you expect me to sink my money in it You satisfy me and Iíll be willing to buy your patent for as much as-oh, say a thousand dollars.î
ìA thousand dollars!î exclaimed Sills and Taylor together.
ìA very fair price, gentlemen.î
ìA million would be more like it,î shouted Taylor in an outraged tone. ìThis discovery is a goldmine.î
ìA million, indeed! You are dreaming, gentlemen. The fact of the matter is that my company has been on the track of ammonium for years now, and we are just at the point of solving the problem. Unfortunately you beat us by a week or so, and so I wish to buy up your patent in order to save my company a great deal of annoyance. You realize, of course, that if you refuse my price, I could just go ahead and manufacture the metal, using my own process.î
ìWeíll sue if you do,î said Taylor.
ìHave you got the money for a long, protracted-and expensive-lawsuit?î Bankhead smiled nastily. ìI have, you know. To prove, however, that I am not unreasonable, I will make the price two thousand.î
ìYouíve heard our price,î answered Taylor stonily, ìand we have nothing further to say.î
ìAll right, gentlemen,î Bankhead walked towards the door, ìthink it over. Youíll see it my way, Iím sure.î
He opened the door and revealed the symmetrical form of Peter Q. Hornswoggle bent in rapt concentration at the keyhole. Bankhead sneered audibly and the ex-Congressman jumped to his feet in consternation, bowing rapidly two or three times, for want of anything better to do.
The financier passed by disdainfully and Hornswoggle entered, slammed the door behind him, and faced the two bewildered friends.
ìThat man, my dear sirs, is a malefactor of great wealth, an economic royalist. He is the type of predatory interest that is the ruination of this country. You did quite right in refusing his offer.î He placed his hand on his ample chest and smiled at them benignantly.
ìWho the devil are you?î rasped Taylor, suddenly recovering from his initial surprise.
ìI?î Hornswoggle was taken aback. ìWhy-er-I am Peter Quintus Hornswoggle. Surely you know me. I was in the House of Representatives last year.î
ìNever heard of you. What do you want?î
ìWhy, bless me! I read in the papers of your wonderful discovery and have come to place my services at your feet.î
ìWhat services?î
ìWell, after all, you two are not men of the world. With your new invention, you are prey for every self-seeking unscrupulous person that comes along-like Bankhead, for instance. Now, a practical man of affairs, such as I, one with experience of the world, would be of inestimable use to you. I could handle your affairs, attend to details, see that-î
ìAll for nothing, of course, eh?î Taylor asked, sardonically.
Hornswoggle coughed convulsively. ìWell, naturally, I thought that a small interest in your discovery might fittingly be assigned to me.î
Sills, who had remained silent during all this, rose to his feet suddenly. ìGet out of here! Did you hear me? Get out, before I call the police.î
ìNow, Professor Sills, pray donít get excited,î Hornswoggle retreated towards the door which Taylor held open for him. He passed out, still protesting, and swore softly to himself when the door slammed in his face.
Sills sank wearily into the nearest chair. ìWhat are we to do, Gene? He offers only two thousand. A week ago that would have been beyond anything I could have hoped for, but now-î
ìForget it. The fellow was only bluffing. Listen, Iím going right now to call on Staples. Weíll sell to him for what we can get (it ought to be plenty) and then if thereís any trouble with Bankhead-well, thatís Staplesí worry.î He patted the other on the shoulder. ìOur troubles are practically over.î
Unfortunately, however, Taylor was wrong; their troubles were only beginning.
Across the street, a furtive figure, with beady eyes peering from upturned coat-collar, surveyed the house carefully. A curious policeman might have identified him as ìSlappyî Egan if he had bothered to look, but no one did and ìSlappyî remained unmolested.
ìCripes,î he muttered to himself, ìdis is gonna be a cinch. De whole woiks on ëthe bottom floor, back window can be jimmied wid a tootípick, no alarms, no nuttiní.î He chuckled and walked away.
Nor was ìSlappyî alone with his ideas. Peter Q. Hornswoggle, as he walked away, found strange thoughts wandering through his massive cranium-thoughts which involved a certain amount of unorthodox action.
And J. Throgmorton Bankhead was likewise active. Belonging to that virile class known as ìgo-gettersî and being not at all scrupulous as to how he ìgo-got,î and certainly not intending to pay a million dollars for the secret of Ammonium, he found it necessary to call on a certain one of his acquaintances.
This acquaintance, while a very useful one, was a bit unsavory, and Bankhead found it advisable to be very careful and cautious while visiting him. However, the conversation that ensued ended in a pleasing manner for both of them.
Walter Sills snapped out of an uneasy sleep with startled suddenness. He listened anxiously for a while and then leaned over and nudged Taylor. He was rewarded by a few incoherent snuffles.
ìGene, Gene, wake up! Come on, get up!î
ìEh? What is it? What are you bothering-î
ìShut up! Listen, do you hear it?î
ìI donít hear anything. Leave me alone, will you?î
Sills put his finger on his lips, and the other quieted. There was a distinct shuffling noise down below, in the laboratory.
Taylorís eyes widened and sleep left them entirely. ìBurglars!î he whispered.
The two crept out of bed, donned bathrobe and slippers, and tiptoed to the door. Taylor had a revolver and took the lead in descending the stairs.
They had traversed perhaps half the flight, when there was a sudden, surprised shout from below, followed by a series of loud, threshing noises. This continued for a few moments and then there was a loud crash of glassware.
ìMy ammonium!î cried Sills in a stricken voice and rushed head-long down the stairs evading Taylorís clutching arms.
The chemist burst into the laboratory, followed closely by his cursing associate, and clicked the lights on. Two struggling figures bunked owlishly in the sudden illumination, and separated.
Taylorís gun covered them. ìWell, isnít this nice,î he said.
One of the two lurched to his feet from amid a tangle of broken beakers and flasks, and, nursing a cut on his wrist, bent his portly body in a still dignified bow. It was Peter Q. Hornswoggle.
ìNo doubt,î he said, eyeing the unwavering firearm nervously, ìthe circumstances seem suspicious, but I can explain very easily. You see, in spite of the very rough treatment I received after having made my reasonable proposal, I still felt a great deal of kindly interest in you two.
ìTherefore, being a man of the world, and knowing the iniquities of mankind, I just decided to keep an eye on your house tonight, for I saw you had neglected to take precautions against house-breakers. Judge my surprise to see this dastardly creature,î he pointed to the flat-nosed, plug-ugly, who still remained on the floor in a daze, ìcreeping in at the back window.
ìImmediately, I risked life and limb in following the criminal, attempting desperately to save your great discovery. I really feel I deserve great credit for what I have done. Iím sure you will feel that I am a valuable person to deal with and reconsider your answers to my earlier proposals.î
Taylor listened to all this with a cynical smile. ìYou can certainly lie fluently, canít you P.Q.?î
He would have continued at greater length and with greater forcefulness had not the other burglar suddenly raised his voice in loud protest ìCripes, boss, dis fat slob here is only tryiní to get me in bad. Iím just followiní orders, boss. A fellow hired me to come in here and rifle the safe and Iím just oininí a bit oí honest money. Just plain safe-crackiní, boss, I ainít out to hurt no one.
ìDen, just as I was gettiní down to de job-wanniní up, so to say-in crawls dis little guy wid a chisel and blowtorch and makes for de safe. Well, naturally, I donít like no competition, so I lays for him and then-î
But Hornswoggle had drawn himself up in icy hauteur. ìIt remains to be seen whether the word of a gangster is to be taken before the word of one, who, I may truthfully say, was, in his time, one of the most eminent members of the great-î
ìQuiet, both of you,î shouted Taylor, waving the gun threateningly. ìIím calling the police and you can annoy them with your stories. Say, Walt, is everything all right?î
ìI think so!î Sills returned from his inspection of the laboratory. ìThey only knocked over empty glassware. Everything else is unharmed.î
ìThatís good,î Taylor began, and then choked in dismay.
From the hallway, a cool individual, hat drawn well over his eyes, entered. A revolver; expertly handled, changed the situation considerably.
ìO. K.,î he grunted at Taylor, ìdrop the gat!î The otherís weapon slipped from reluctant fingers and hit the floor with a clank.
The new menace surveyed the four others with a sardonic glance. ìWell! So there were two others trying to beat me to it This seems to be a very popular place.î
Sills and Taylor stared stupidly, while Hornswoggleís teeth chattered energetically. The first mobster moved back uneasily, muttering as he did so, ìFor Peteís sake, itís Mike the Slug.î
ìYeah,î Mike rasped, ìMike the Slug. Thereís lots of guys who know me and who know I ainít afraid to pull the trigger anytime I feel like. Come on, Baldy, hand over the works. You know-the stuff about your fake gold. Come on, before I count five.î
Sills moved slowly toward the old safe in the corner. Mike stepped back carelessly to give him room, and in so doing, his coat sleeve brushed against a shelf. A small vial of sodium sulphate solution tottered and fell.
With sudden inspiration. Sills yelled, ìMy God, watch out! Itís nitroglycerine!î
The vial hit the floor with a smashing tinkle of broken glass, and involuntarily, Mike yelled and jumped in wild dismay. And as he did so, Taylor crashed into him with a beautiful flying tackle. At the same time. Sills lunged for Taylorís fallen weapon to cover the other two. For this, however, there was no longer need. At the very beginning of the confusion, both had faded hurriedly into the night from whence they came.
Taylor and Mike the Slug rolled round and round the laboratory floor, locked in desperate struggle while Sills hopped over and about them, praying for a moment of comparative quiet that he might bring the revolver into sharp and sudden contact with the gangsterís skull.
But no such moment came. Suddenly Mike lunged, caught Taylor stunningly under the chin, and jerked free. Sills yelled in consternation and pulled the trigger at the fleeing figure. The shot was wild and Mike escaped unharmed. Sills made no attempt to follow.
A sluicing stream of cold water brought Taylor back to his senses. He shook his head dazedly as he surveyed the surrounding shambles.
ìWhew!î he said, ìwhat a night!î
Sills groaned, ìWhat are we going to do now. Gene? Our very lives are in danger. I never thought of the possibility of thieves, or I would never have told of the discovery to the newspapers.î
ìOh, well, the harmís done; no use weeping over it Now, listen, the first thing we have to do now is to get back to sleep. They wonít bother us again tonight Tomorrow youíll go to the bank and put the papers outlining the details of the process in the vault (which you should have done long ago). Staples will be here at 3 p.m.; well close the deal, and then, at least, weíll live happily ever after.î
The chemist shook his head dolefully. ìAmmonium has certainly proved to be very upsetting so far. I almost wish I had never heard of it Iíd almost rather be back doing ore analysis.î
As Walter Sills rattled cross-town towards his bank, he found no reason to change his wish. Even the comforting and homely jiggling of his ancient and battered automobile failed to cheer him. From a life characterized by peaceful monotony, he had entered a period of bedlam, and he was not at all satisfied with the change.
ìRiches, like poverty, has its own peculiar problems,î he remarked sententiously to himself as he braked the car before the two-story, marble edifice that was the bank. He stepped out carefully, stretched his cramped legs, and headed for the revolving door.
He didnít get there right away, though. Two husky specimens of the human race stepped up, one at each side, and Sills felt a very hard object pressing with painful intensity against his ribs. He opened his mouth involuntarily, and was rewarded by an icy voice in his ears, ìQuiet, Baldy, or youíll get what you deserve for the damn trick you pulled on me last night.î
Sills shivered and subsided. He recognized Mike the Slugís voice very easily.
ìWhereís the details?î asked Mike, ìand make it quick.î
ìInside jacket pocket,î croaked Sills tremulously.
Mikeís companion passed his hand dexterously into the indicated pocket and flicked out three or four folded sheets of foolscap.
ìDat it, Mike?î
A hasty appraisal and a nod, ìYeh, we got it. All right, Baldy, on your way!î A sudden shove and the two gangsters jumped into their car and drove away rapidly, while the chemist sprawled on the sidewalk. Kindly hands raised him up.
ìItís all right,î he managed to gasp. ìI just tripped, thatís all. Iím not hurt.î He found himself alone again, passed into the bank, and dropped into the nearest bench, in near-collapse. There was no doubt about it; the new life was not for him.
But he should have been prepared for it. Taylor had foreseen a possibility of this sort of thing happening. He, himself, had thought a car had been trailing him. Yet, in his surprise and fright, he had almost ruined everything.
He shrugged his thin shoulders and, taking off his hat, abstracted a few folded sheets of paper from the sweatband. It was the work of five minutes to deposit them in a vault, and see the immensely strong steel door swing shut. He felt relieved.
ìI wonder what theyíll do,î he muttered to himself on the way home, ìwhen they try to follow the instructions on the paper they did get.î He pursed his lips and shook his head. ìIf they do, thereís going to be one heck of an explosion.î
Sills arrived home to find three policemen pacing leisurely up and down the sidewalk in front of the house.
ìPolice guard,î explained Taylor shortly, ìso that we have no more trouble like last night.î
The chemist related the events at the bank and Taylor nodded grimly. ìWell, itís checkmate for them now. Staples will be here in two hours, and until then the police will take care of things. Afterwards,î he shrugged, ìit will be Staplesí affair.î
ìListen, Gene,î the chemist put in suddenly, ìIím worried about the ammonium. I havenít tested its plating abilities and those are the most important things, you know. What if Staples comes, and we find that all we have is pigeon milk.î
ìHmm,î Taylor stroked his chin, ìyouíre right there. But Iíll tell you what we can do. Before Staples comes, letís plate something-a spoon, suppose-for our own satisfaction.î
ìItís really very annoying,î Sills complained fretfully. ìIf it werenít for these troublesome hooligans, we wouldnít have to proceed in this slipshod and unscientific manner.î
ìWell, letís eat dinner firstî
After the mid-day meal, they began. The apparatus was set up in feverish haste. In a cubic vat, a foot each way, a saturated solution of Ammonaline was poured. An old, battered spoon was the cathode and a mass of ammonium amalgam (separated from the rest of the solution by a perforated glass partition) was the anode. Three batteries in series provided the current.
Sills explained animatedly, ìIt works on the same principle as ordinary copper plating. The ammonium ion, once the electric current is run through, is attracted to the cathode, which-is in the spoon. Ordinarily it would break up, being unstable, but this is not the case when it is dissolved in Ammonaline. This Ammonaline is itself very slightly ionized and oxygen is given off at the anode.
ìThis much I know from theory. Let us see what happens in practice.î
He closed the key while Taylor watched with breathless interest. For a moment, no effect was visible. Taylor looked disappointed.
Then Sills grasped his sleeve. ìSee!î he hissed. ìWatch the anode!î
Sure enough, bubbles of gas were slowly forming upon the spongy ammonium amalgam. They shifted their attention to the spoon.
Gradually, they noticed a change. The metallic appearance became dulled, the silver color slowly losing its whiteness. A layer of distinct, if dull, yellow was being built up. For fifteen minutes, the current ran and then Sills broke the circuit with a contented sigh.
ìIt plates perfectly,î he said.
ìGood! Take it out! Letís see it!î
ìWhat?î Sills was aghast. ëTake it out! Why, thatís pure ammonium. If I were to expose it to ordinary air, the water vapor would dissolve it to NH4OH in no time. We canít do that.î
He dragged a rather bulky piece of apparatus to the table. ìThis,î he said, ìis a compressed-air container. I run it through calcium chloride dryers and then bubble the perfectly dry oxygen (safely diluted with four times its own volume of nitrogen) directly into the solvent.î
He introduced the nozzle into the solution just beneath the spoon and turned on a slow stream of air. It worked like magic. With almost lightning speed, the yellow coating began to glitter and gleam, to shine with almost ethereal beauty.
The two men watched it with beating heart and panting breath. Sills shut the air off, and for a while they watched the wonderful spoon and said nothing.
Then Taylor whispered hoarsely, ìTake it out. Let me feel it! My God!-itís beautiful!î
With reverent awe, Sills approached the spoon, grasped it with forceps, and withdrew it from the surrounding liquid.
What followed immediately after that can never be fully described. Later on, when excited newspaper reporters pressed them unmercifully, neither Taylor nor Sills had the least recollection of the happenings of the next few minutes.
What happened was that the moment the ammoniumplated spoon was exposed to open air, the most horrible odor ever conceived assailed their nostrils!-an odor that cannot be described, a terrible broth of Hell that plunged the room into sheer, horrible nightmare.
With one strangled gasp. Sills dropped the spoon. Both were coughing and retching, tearing wildly at their throats and mouths, yelling, weeping, sneezing!
Taylor pounced upon the spoon and looked about wildly. The odor grew steadily more powerful and their wild exertions to escape it had already succeeded in wrecking the laboratory and had upset the vat of Ammonaline. There was only one thing to do, and Sills did it. The spoon went flying out the open window in the middle of Twelfth Avenue. It hit the sidewalk right at the feet of one of the policemen, but Taylor didnít care.
ìTake off your clothes. Weíll have to burn them,î Sills was gasping. ìThen spray something over the laboratory-anything with a strong smell. Burn sulphur. Get some liquid Bromine.î
Both were tearing at their clothes in distraction when they realized that someone had walked in through the unlocked door. The bell had rung, but neither had heard it. It was Staples, six-foot, lion-maned Steel King.
One step into the hall ruined his dignity utterly. He collapsed in one tearing sob and Twelfth Avenue was treated to the spectacle of an elderly, richly-dressed gentleman tearing uptown as fast as his feet would carry him, shedding as much of his clothes as he dared while doing so.
The spoon continued its deadly work. The three policemen had long since retired in abject rout, and now to the numbed and tortured senses of the two innocent and suffering causes of the entire mess came a roaring and confused shouting from the street
Men and women were pouring out of the neighboring houses, horses were bolting. Fire engines clanged down the street, only to be abandoned by their riders. Squadrons of police came-and left.
Sills and Taylor finally gave up, and clad only in trousers, ran pell-mell for the Hudson. They did not stop until they found themselves neck-deep in water, with blessed, pure air above them.
Taylor turned bewildered eyes to Sills. ìBut how could it emit that horrible odor? You said it was stable and stable solids have no odors. It takes vapor for that, doesnít it?î
ìHave you ever smelled musk?î groaned Sills. ìIt will give off an aroma for an indefinite period without losing any appreciable weight. Weíve come up against something like that.î
The two ruminated in silence for a while, wincing whenever the wind brought a vagrant waft of Ammonium vapor to them, and then Taylor said in a low voice, ìWhen they finally trace the trouble to the spoon, and find out who made it, Iím afraid weíll be sued-or maybe thrown in jail.î
Sillsí face lengthened. ìI wish Iíd never seen the damned stuff! Itís brought nothing but trouble.î His tortured spirit gave way and he sobbed loudly.
Taylor patted him on the back mournfully. ìItís not as bad as all that, of course. The discovery will make you famous and youíll be able to demand your own price, working at any industrial lab in the country. Then, too, youíre a cinch to win the Nobel Prize.î
ìThatís right,î Sills smiled again, ìand I may find a way to counteract the odor, too. I hope so.î
ìI hope so, too,î said Taylor feelingly. ìLetís go back. I think theyíve managed to remove the spoon by now.î



***



It should be quite obvious to anyone reading ìThe Magnificent Possessionî that I was majoring in chemistry in college at the time. As supposed humor, it is much more embarrassing on rereading than ìRing Around the Sunî is. Imagine having a Congressman named ìHornswoggleî and having gangsters speak in a ridiculous, misspelled version of Brooklyn slang.
ìThe Magnificent Possessionî was the only one of the first nine stories I wrote that Campbell never saw, and Iím glad of that.
In early December I wrote a story I called ìAd Astra,î and on December 21, 1938 (my fatherís forty-second birthday, though I donít recall thinking of it as an omen one way or the other), I went in to submit it to Campbell. It was my seventh visit to his office, for I had not yet missed a month, and it was the ninth story I submitted to him.
ìAd Astraî is the first story I wrote for which I remember, even after all this time, the exact circumstances of the initiating inspiration. That fall, I applied for and received a National Youth Administration (NYA) job designed to help me through college. I received fifteen dollars a month, if memory serves me, in return for a few hours of typing. The typing I did was for a sociologist who was writing a book on the subject of social resistance to technological innovation. This included everything from the resistance of the early Mesopotamian priesthood to the dissemination of the knowledge of reading and writing among the general population, down to objections to the airplane by those who said heavier-than-air flight was impossible.
Naturally it occurred to me that a story might be written in which social resistance to space flight might play a small part. It was because of that that I used ìAd Astraî as the title. This was from the Latin proverb ìPer aspera ad astraî (ìThrough difficulties to the starsî).
For the first time, Campbell did more than simply send a rejection. On December 29, I received a letter from him asking me to come in for a conference to discuss the story in detail.
On January 5, 1939, I went to see Campbell for the eighth time-and for the first time at his specific request. It turned out that what he liked in the story was the social resistance to space flight-the space flight itself was, of course, run of the mill.
Rather daunted, for I had never before had to revise a story to meet editorial specification, I went to work. I brought in the revised story on January 24, and on January 31 I discovered the system used by Campbell in accepting stories. Though his rejections were usually accompanied by long and useful letters, his acceptances consisted of a check only, without a single accompanying word. It was his feeling that the check was eloquent enough. In this case it was for sixty-nine dollars, since the story was 6,900 words long and Campbell paid one cent a word in those days.
It was my first sale to Campbell, after seven months of trying and after eight consecutive rejections. The story appeared half a year later, and I then found that Campbell had changed the title (on the whole justifiably, I think) to ìTrends.î








Trends


John Harman was sitting at his desk, brooding, when I entered the office that day. It had become a common sight, by then, to see him staring out at the Hudson, head in hand, a scowl contorting his face-all too common. It seemed unfair for the little bantam to be eating his heart out like that day after day, when by rights he should have been receiving the praise and adulation of the world.
I flopped down into a chair. ìDid you see the editorial in todayís Clarion , boss?î
He turned weary, bloodshot eyes to me. ìNo, I havenít. What do they say? Are they calling the vengeance of God down upon me again?î His voice dripped with bitter sarcasm.
ìTheyíre going a little farther now, boss,î I answered. ìListen to this:
ìëTomorrow is the day of John Harmanís attempt at profaning the heavens. Tomorrow, in defiance of world opinion and world conscience, this man will defy God.
ìíIt is not given to man to go wheresoever ambition and desire lead him. There are things forever denied him, and aspiring to the stars is one of these. Like Eve, John Harman wishes to eat of the forbidden fruit, and like Eve he will suffer due punishment therefor.
ìëBut it is not enough, this mere talk. If we allow him thus to brook the vengeance of God, the trespass is mankindís and not Harmanís alone. In allowing him to carry out his evil designs, we make ourselves accessory to the crime, and Divine vengeance will fall on all alike.
ìëIt is, therefore, essential that immediate steps be taken to prevent Harman from taking off in his so-called rocketship tomorrow. The government in refusing to take such steps may force violent action. If it will make no move to confiscate the rocketship, or to imprison Harman, our enraged citizenry may have to take matters into their own hands-íì
Harman sprang from his seat in a rage and, snatching the paper from my hands, threw it into the corner furiously. ìItís an open call to a lynching,î he raved. ìLook at this!î
He cast five or six envelopes in my direction. One glance sufficed to tell what they were.
ìMore death threats?î I ëasked.
ìYes, exactly that. Iíve had to arrange for another increase in the police patrol outside the building and for motorcycle police escort when I cross the river to the testing ground tomorrow.î
He marched up and down the room with agitated stride. ìI donít know what to do, Clifford. Iíve worked on the Prometheus almost ten years. Iíve slaved, spent a fortune of money, given up all that makes life worth while-and for what? So that a bunch of fool revivalists can whip up public sentiment against me until my very life isnít safe.î
ìYouíre in advance of the times, boss,î I shrugged my shoulders in a resigned gesture which made him whirl upon me in a fury.
ìWhat do you mean ëin advance of the timesí? This is 1973. The world has been ready for space travel for half a century now. Fifty years ago, people were talking, dreaming of the day when man could free himself of Earth and plumb the depths of space. For fifty years, science has inched toward, this goal, and nowÖ now I finally have it, and behold! you say the world is not ready for me.î
ìThe ë20s and ë30s were years of anarchy, decadence, and misrule, if you remember your history,î I reminded him gently. ìYou cannot accept them as criteria.î
ìI know, I know. Youíre going to tell me of the First War of 1914, and the Second of 1940. Itís an old story to me; my father fought in the Second and my grandfather in the First. Nevertheless, those were the days when science flourished. Men were not afraid then; somehow they dreamed and dared. There was no such thing as conservatism when it came to matters mechanical and scientific. No theory was too radical to advance, no discovery too revolutionary to publish. Today, dry rot has seized the world when a great vision, such as space travel, is hailed as ëdefiance of God.í ì
His head sank slowly down, and he turned away to hide his trembling lips and the tears in his eyes. Then he suddenly straightened again, eyes blazing: ìBut Iíll show them. Iím going through with it, in spite of Hell, Heaven and Earth. Iíve put too much into it to quit now.î
ìTake it easy, boss,î I advised. ìThis isnít going to do you any good tomorrow, when you get into that ship. Your chances of coming out alive arenít too good now, so what will they be if you start out worn to pieces with excitement and worry?î
ìYouíre right. Letís not think of it any more. Whereís Shelton?î
ìOver at the Institute arranging for the special photographic plates to be sent us.î
ìHeís been gone a long time, hasnít he?î
ìNot especially; but listen, boss, thereís something wrong with him. I donít like him.î
ìPoppycock! Heís been with me two years, and I have no complaints.î
ìAll right.î I spread my hands in resignation. ìIf you wonít listen to me, you wonít. Just the same I caught him reading one of those infernal pamphlets Otis Eldredge puts out. You know the kind: ëBeware, O mankind, for judgment draws near. Punishment for your sins is at hand. Repent and be saved.í And all the rest of the time-honoured junk.î
Harman snorted in disgust. ìCheap tub-thumping revivalist! I suppose the world will never outgrow his type-not while sufficient morons exist. Still you canít condemn Shelton just because he reads it. Iíve read them myself on occasion.î
ìHe says he picked it up on the sidewalk and read it in ëidle curiosity,í but Iím pretty sure that I saw him take it out of his wallet. Besides, he goes to church every Sunday.î
ìIs that a crime? Everyone does, nowadays!î
ìYes, but not to the Twentieth Century Evangelical Society. Thatís Eldredgeís.î
That jolted Harman. Evidently, it was the first he had heard of it. ìSay, that is something, isnít it? Weíll have to keep an eye on him, then.î
But after that, things started to happen, and we forgot all about Shelton-until it was too late.
There was nothing much left to do that last day before the test, and I wandered into the next room, where I went over Harmanís final report to the Institute. It was my job to correct any errors or mistakes that crept in, but Iím afraid I wasnít very thorough. To tell the truth, I couldnít concentrate. Every few minutes, Iíd fall into a brown study.
It seemed queer, all this fuss over a space travel. When Harman had first announced the approaching perfection of the Prometheus, some six months before, scientific circles had been jubilant. Of course, they were cautious in their statements and qualified everything they said, but there was real enthusiasm.
However, the masses didnít take it that way. It seems strange, perhaps, to you of the twenty-first century, but perhaps we should have expected it in those days of ë73. People werenít very progressive then. For years there had been a swing toward religion, and when the churches came out unanimously against Harmanís rocket-well, there you were.
At first, the opposition confined itself to the churches and we thought it might play itself out. But it didnít The papers got hold of it, and literally spread the gospel. Poor Harman became an anathema to the world in a remarkably short time, and then his troubles began.
He received death threats, and warnings of divine vengeance every day. He couldnít walk the streets in safety. Dozens of sects, to none of which he belonged-he was one of the very rare free-thinkers of the day, which was another count against him-excommunicated him and placed him under special interdict. And, worst of all, Otis Eldredge and his Evangelical Society began stirring up the populace.
Eldredge was a queer character-one of those geniuses, in their way, that arise every so often. Gifted with a golden tongue and a sulphurous vocabulary, he could fairly hypnotize a crowd. Twenty thousand people were so much putty in his hands, could he only bring them within earshot And for four months, he thundered against Harman; for four months, a pouring stream of denunciation rolled forth in oratorical frenzy. And for four months, the temper of the world rose.
But Harman was not to be daunted. In his tiny, five-foot-two body, he had enough spirit for five six-footers. The more the wolves howled, the firmer he held his ground. With almost divine-his enemies said, diabolical-obstinacy, he refused to yield an inch. Yet his outward firmness was to me, who knew him, but an imperfect concealment of the great sorrow and bitter disappointment within.
The ring of the doorbell interrupted my thoughts at that point and brought me to my feet in surprise. Visitors were very few those days.
I looked out the window and saw a tall, portly figure talking with Police Sergeant Cassidy. I recognized him at once as Howard Winstead, head of the Institute. Harman was hurrying out to greet him, and after a short exchange of phrases, the two entered the office. I followed them in, being rather curious as to what could have brought Winstead, who was more politician than scientist, here.
Winstead didnít seem very comfortable, at first; not his usual suave self. He avoided Harmanís eyes in an embarrassed manner and mumbled a few conventionalities concerning the weather. Then he came to the point with direct, undiplomatic bluntness.
ìJohn,î he said, ìhow about postponing the trial for a time?î
ìYou really mean abandoning it altogether, donít you? Well, I wonít, and thatís final.î
Winstead lifted his hand. ìWait now, John, donít get excited. Let me state my case. I know the Institute agreed to give you a free hand, and I know that you paid at least half the expenses out of your own pocket, but-you canít go through with it.î
ìOh, canít I, though?î Herman snorted derisively.
ìNow listen, John, you know your science, but you donít know your human nature, and I do. This is not the world of the ëMad Decades,í whether you realize it or not. There have been profound changes since 1940.î He swung into what was evidently a carefully prepared speech.
ìAfter the First World War, you know, the world as a whole swung away from religion and toward freedom from convention. People were disgusted and disillusioned, cynical and sophisticated. Eldredge calls them ëwicked and sinful.í In spite of that, science flourished-some say it always fares best in such an unconventional period. From its standpoint it was a ëGolden Age.í
ìHowever, you know the political and economic history of the period. It was a time of political chaos and international anarchy; a suicidal, brainless, insane period-and it culminated in the Second World War. And just as the First War led to a period of sophistication, so the Second initiated a return to religion.
ìPeople were disgusted with the ëMad Decades.î They had had enough of it, and feared, beyond all else, a return to it To remove that possibility, they put the ways of those decades behind them. Their motives, you see, were understandable and laudable. All the freedom, all the sophistication, all the lack of convention were gone-swept away clean. We are living now in a second Victorian age; and naturally so, because human history goes by swings of the pendulum and this is the swing toward religion and convention.
ìOne thing only is left over since those days of half a century ago. That one thing is the respect of humanity for science. We have prohibition; smoking for women is outlawed; cosmetics are forbidden; low dresses and short skirts are unheard of; divorce is frowned upon. But science has not been confined-as yet.
ìIt behoves science, then, to be circumspect, to refrain from arousing the people. It will be very easy to make them believe-and Otis Eldredge has come perilously close to doing it in some of his speeches-that it was science that brought about the horrors of the Second World War. Science outstripped culture, they will say, technology outstripped sociology, and it was that unbalance that came so near to destroying the world. Somehow, I am inclined to believe they are not so far wrong, at that.
ìBut do you know what would happen, if it ever did come to that? Scientific research may be forbidden; or, if they donít go that far, it will certainly be so strictly regulated as to stifle in its own decay. It will be a calamity from which humanity would not recover for a millennium.
ìAnd it is your trial flight that may precipitate all this. You are arousing the public to a stage where it will be difficult to calm them. I warn you, John. The consequences will be on your head.î
There was absolute silence for a moment and then Harman forced a smile. ìCome, Howard, youíre letting yourself be frightened by shadows on the wall. Are you trying to tell me that it is your serious belief that the world as a whole is ready to plunge into a second Dark Ages? After all, the intelligent men are on the side of science, arenít they?î
ìIf they are, there arenít many of them left from what I see.î Winstead drew a pipe from his pocket and filled it slowly with tobacco as he continued: ìEldredge formed a League of the Righteous two months ago-they call it the L. R.-and it has grown unbelievably. Twenty million is its membership in the United States alone . Eldredge boasts that after the next election Congress will be his; and there seems to be more truth than bluff in that. Already there has been strenuous lobbying in favour of a bill outlawing rocket experiments, and laws of that type have been enacted in Poland, Portugal and Rumania. Yes, John, we are perilously close to open persecution of science.î He was smoking now in rapid, nervous puffs.
ìBut if I succeed, Howard, if I succeed! What then?î
ìBah! You know the chances for that. Your own estimate gives you only one chance in ten of coming out alive.î
ìWhat does that signify? The next experimenter will learn by my mistakes, and the odds will improve. Thatís the scientific method.î
ìThe mob doesnít know anything about the scientific method; and they donít want to know. Well, what do you say? Will you call it off?î
Harman sprang to his feet, his chair tumbling over with a crash. ìDo you know what you ask? Do you want me to give up my lifeís work, my dream, just like that? Do you think Iím going to sit back and wait for your dear public to become benevolent? Do you think theyíll change in my lifetime?
ìHereís my answer: I have an inalienable right to pursue knowledge. Science has an inalienable right to progress and develop without interference. The world, in interfering with me, is wrong; I am right. And it shall go hard; but I -will not abandon my rights.î
Winstead shook his head sorrowfully. ìYouíre wrong, John, when you speak of ëinalienableí rights. What you call a ërightí is merely a privilege, generally agreed upon . What society accepts, is right; what it does not, is wrong.î
ìWould your friend, Eldredge, agree to such a definition of his ërighteousnessí?î questioned Harman bitterly.
ìNo, he would not, but thatís irrelevant. Take the case of those African tribes who used to be cannibals. They were brought up as cannibals, have the long tradition of cannibalism, and their society accepts the practice. To them , cannibalism is right , and why shouldnít it be? So you see how relative the whole notion is, and how inane your conception of ëinalienableí rights to perform experiments is.î
ìYou know, Howard, you missed your calling when you didnít become a lawyer.î Harman was really growing angry. ìYouíve been bringing out every moth-eaten argument you can think of. For Godís sake, man, are you trying to pretend that it is a crime to refuse to run with the crowd? Do you stand for absolute uniformity, ordinariness, orthodoxy, commonplaceness? Science would die far sooner under the programme you outline than under governmental prohibition.î
Harman stood up and pointed an accusing finger at the other. ìYouíre betraying science and the tradition of those glorious rebels: Galileo, Darwin, Einstein and their kind. My rocket leaves tomorrow on schedule in spite of you and every other stuffed shirt in the United States. Thatís that, and I refuse to listen to you any longer. So you can just get out.î
The head of the Institute, red in the face, turned to me. ìYouíre my witness, young man, that I warned this obstinate nitwit, thisÖ this hare-brained fanatic.î He spluttered a bit, and then strode out, the picture of fiery indignation.
Harman turned to me when he hadî gone: ìWell, what do you think? I suppose you agree with him.î
There was only one possible answer and I made it: ìYouíre not paying me to do anything else but follow orders, boss. Iím sticking with you.î
Just then Shelton came in and Harman packed us both off to go over the calculations of the orbit of flight for the umpteenth time, while he himself went off to bed.
The next day, July 15th, dawned in matchless splendour, and Harman, Shelton, and myself were in an almost gay mood as we crossed the Hudson to where the Prometheus -surrounded by an adequate police guard-lay in gleaming grandeur.
Around it, roped off at an apparently safe distance, rolled a crowd of gigantic proportions. Most of them were hostile, raucously so. In fact, for one fleeting moment, as our motorcycle police escort parted the crowds for us, the shouts and imprecations that reached our ears almost convinced me that we should have listened to Winstead.
But Harman paid no attention to them at all, after one supercilious sneer at a shout of: ìThere goes John Harman, son of Belial.î Calmly, he directed us about our task of inspection. I tested the foot-thick outer walls and the air locks for leaks, then made sure the air purifier worked. Shelton checked up on the repellent screen and the fuel tanks. Finally, Hal-man tried on the clumsy spacesuit, found it suitable, and announced himself ready.
The crowd stirred. Upon a hastily erected platform of wooden planks piled in confusion by some in the mob, there rose up a striking figure. Tall and lean; with thin, ascetic countenance; deep-set, burning eyes, peering and half closed; a thick, white mane crowning all-it was Otis Eldredge. The crowd recognized him at once and many cheered. Enthusiasm waxed and soon the entire turbulent mass of people shouted themselves hoarse over him.
He raised a hand for silence, turned to Harman, who regarded him with surprise and distaste, and pointed a long, bony finger at him:
ìJohn, Harman, son of the devil, spawn of Satan, you are here for an evil purpose. You are about to set out upon a blasphemous attempt to pierce the veil beyond which man is forbidden to go. You are tasting of the forbidden fruit of Eden and beware that you taste not of the fruits of sin.î
The crowd cheered him to the echo and he continued: ìThe finger of God is upon you, John Harman. He shall not allow His works to be defiled. You die today, John Harman.î His voice rose in intensity and his last words were uttered in truly prophetlike fervour.
Harman turned away in disdain. In a loud, clear voice, he addressed the police sergeant: ìIs there any way, officer, of removing these spectators. The trial flight may be attended by some destruction because of the rocket blasts, and theyíre crowding too close.î
The policeman answered in a crisp, unfriendly tone: ìIf youíre afraid of being mobbed, say so, Mr. Harman. You donít have to worry, though, weíll hold them back. And as for danger-from that contraption-î He sniffed loudly in the direction of the Prometheus , evoking a torrent of jeers and yells.
Harman said nothing further, but climbed into the ship in silence. And when he did so, a queer sort of stillness fell over the mob; a palpable tension. There was no attempt at rushing the ship, an attempt I had thought inevitable. On the contrary, Otis Eldredge himself shouted to everyone to move back.
ìLeave the sinner to his sins,î he shouted. ì ëVengeance is mine,í saith the Lord.î
As the moment approached, Shelton nudged me. ìLetís get out of here,î he whispered in a strained voice. ìThose rocket blasts are poison.î Saying this, he broke into a run, beckoning anxiously for me to follow.
We had not yet reached the fringes of the crowd when there was a terrific roar behind me. A wave of heated air swept over me. There was the frightening hiss of some speeding object past my ear, and I was thrown violently to the ground. For a few moments I lay dazed, my ears ringing and my head reeling.
When I staggered drunkenly to my feet again, it was to view a dreadful sight. Evidently, the entire fuel supply of the Prometheus had exploded at once, and where it had lain a moment ago there was now only a yawning hole. The ground was strewn with wreckage. The cries of the hurt were heartrending, and the mangled bodies-but I wonít try to describe those.
A weak groan at my feet attracted my attention. One look, and I gasped in horror, for it was Shelton, the back of his head a bloody mass.
ìI did it.î His voice was hoarse and triumphant but withal so low that I could scarcely hear it. ìI did it. I broke open the liquid-oxygen compartments and when the spark went through the acetylide mixture the whole cursed thing exploded.î He gasped a bit and tried to move but failed. ìA piece of wreckage must have hit me, but I donít care. Iíll die knowing that-î
His voice was nothing more than a rasping rattle, and on his face was the ecstatic look of martyr. He died then, and I could not find it in my heart to condemn him.
It was then I first thought of Harman. Ambulances from Manhattan and from Jersey City were on the scene, and one had sped to a wooden patch some five hundred yards distant, where, caught in the treetops, lay a splintered fragment of the Prometheusí forward compartment. I limped there as fast as I could, but they had dragged out Harman and clanged away long before I could reach them.
After that, I didnít stay. The disorganized crowd had no thought but for the dead and wounded now , but when they recovered, and bent their thoughts to revenge, my life would not be worth a straw. I followed the dictates of the better part of valour and quietly disappeared.
The next week was a hectic one for me. During that time, I lay in hiding at the home of a friend, for it would have been more than my life was worth to allow myself to be seen and recognized. Harman, himself, lay in a Jersey City hospital, with nothing more than superficial cuts and bruises-thanks to the backward force of the explosion and the saving clump of trees which cushioned the fall of the Prometheus . It was on him that the brunt of the worldís wrath fell.
New York, and the rest of the world also, just about went crazy. Every last paper in the city came out with gigantic headlines, ì28 Killed, 73 Wounded-the Price of Sin,î printed in blood-red letters. The editorials howled for Harmanís life, demanding he be arrested and tried for first-degree murder.
The dreaded cry of ìLynch him!î was raised throughout the five boroughs, and milling thousands crossed the river and converged on Jersey City. At their head was Otis Eldredge, both legs in splints, addressing the crowd from an open automobile as they marched. It was a veritable army.
Mayor Carson of Jersey City called out every available policeman and phoned frantically to Trenton for the State militia. New York clamped down on every bridge and tunnel leaving the city-but not till after many thousands had left.
There were pitched battles on the Jersey coast that sixteenth of July. The vastly outnumbered police clubbed indiscriminately but were gradually pushed back and back. Mounties rode down upon the mob relentlessly but were swallowed up and pulled down by sheer force of numbers. Not until tear gas was used, did the crowd halt-and even then they did not retreat.
The next day, martial law was declared, and the State militia entered Jersey City. That was the end for the lynchers. Eldredge was called to confer with the mayor, and after the conferences ordered his followers to disperse.
In a statement to the newspapers. Mayor Carson said: ìJohn Harman must needs suffer for his crime, but it is essential that he do so legally. Justice must take its course, and the State of New Jersey will take all necessary measures.î
By the end of the week, normality of a sort had returned and Harman slipped out of the public spotlight. Two more weeks and there was scarcely a word about him in the newspapers, excepting such casual references to him in the discussion of the new Zittman antirocketry bill that had just passed both houses of Congress by unanimous votes.
Yet he remained in the hospital still. No legal action had been taken against him, but it began to appear that a sort of indefinite imprisonment ìfor his own protectionî might be his eventual fate. Therefore, I bestirred myself to action.
Temple Hospital is situated in a lonely and outlying district of Jersey City, and on a dark, moonless night I experienced no difficulty at all in invading the grounds unobserved. With a facility that surprised me, I sneaked in through a basement window, slugged a sleepy interne into insensibility and proceeded to Room 15E, which was listed in the books as Harmanís.
ìWhoís there?î Harmanís surprised shout was music in my ears.
ìSh! Quiet! Itís I, Cliff McKenny.î
ìYou! What are you doing here?î
ìTrying to get you out. If I donít, youíre liable to stay here the rest of your life. Come on, letís go.î
I was hustling him into his clothes while we were speaking, and in no time at all we were sneaking down the corridor. We were out safely and into my waiting car before Harman collected his scattered wits sufficiently to begin asking questions.
ìWhatís happened since that day?î was the first question. ìI donít remember a thing after starting the rocket blasts until I woke up in the hospital.î
ìDidnít they tell you anything?î
ìNot a damn thing,î he swore. ìI asked until I was hoarse.î
