And together with this, there came the more subtle sensation of odor. From a suspicion, a mere trace, it waxed into a phantasmal field of flowers. Delicate spicy scents followed each other in ever stronger succession; in gentle wafts of pleasure.
Yet all this was nothing. Fields knew that. Somehow, he knew that what he saw, heard, and smelt were mere delusions -mirages of a brain that frantically attempted to interpret an entirely new conception in the old, familiar ways.
Gradually, the colors and the sounds and the scents died. His brain was beginning to realize that that which beat upon it was something hitherto unexperienced. The effect of the hormone became stronger, and suddenly-in one burst-Fields realized what it was he sensed.
He didnít see it-nor hear it-nor smell it-nor taste it- nor feel it. He knew what it was but he couldnít think of the word for it. Slowly, he realized that there wasnít any word for it. Even more slowly, he realized that there wasnít even any concept for it.
Yet he knew what it was.
There beat upon his brain something that consisted of pure waves of enjoyment-something that lifted him out of himself and pitched him headlong into a universe unknown to him earlier. He was falling through an endless eternity of- something. It wasnít sound or sight but it was-something. Something that enfolded him and hid his surroundings from him-thatís what it was. It was endless and infinite in its variety, and with each crashing wave, he glimpsed a farther horizon, and the wonderful cloak of sensation became thicker-and softer-and more beautiful.
Then came the discord. Like a little crack at first-marring a perfect beauty. Then spreading and branching and growing wider, until, finally, if split apart thunderously-though without a sound.
Lincoln Fields, dazed and bewildered, found himself back in the concert room again.
He lurched to his feet and grasped Garth Jan by the arm violently, ìGarth! Why did he stop? Tell him to continue! Tell him!î
Garth Janís startled expression faded into pity, ìHe is still playing, Lincoln.î
The Earthmanís befuddled stare showed no signs of understanding. He gazed about him with unseeing eyes. Novi Lonís fingers sped across the keyboard as nimbly as ever; the expression on his face was as rapt as ever. Slowly, the truth seeped in, and the Earthmanís empty eyes filled with horror.
He sat down, uttering one hoarse cry, and buried his head in his hands.
The five minutes had passed! There could be no return!
Garth Jan was smiling-a smile of dreadful malice, ìI had pitied you just a moment ago, Lincoln, but now Iím glad- glad! You forced this out of me-you made me do this. I hope youíre satisfied, because I certainly am. For the rest of your life,î his voice sank to a sibilant whisper, ìyouíll remember these five minutes and know what it is youíre missing-what it is you can never have again. You are blind, Lincoln-blind!î
The Earthman raised a haggard face and grinned, but it was no more than a horrible baring of the teeth. It took every ounce of willpower he possessed to maintain an air of composure.
He did not trust himself to speak. With wavering step, he marched out of the room, head held high to the end.
And within, that tiny, bitter voice, repeating over and over again, ìYou entered a normal man! You leave blind- blind - BLIND.î



***



The summer of 1939 was full of doubts and uncertainty for me.
In June I had graduated from Columbia and obtained my bachelor of science degree. So far, so good. However, my second round of attempts to enter medical school had failed, as the first had. To be sure, I hadnít really been anxious to go to medical school and I had tried only halfheartedly, but it still left me at loose ends..
What did I do now? I did not wish to look for some nondescript job, even if these were to be found, so I had to continue with my schooling. I had been majoring in chemistry, so, failing medical school, the natural next step was to go for my degree of doctor of philosophy in that field.
The first question was whether I would be able to swing this financially. (It would have been the first question, even more so, if I had gotten into medical school.) College itself had been touch and go all four years, and my small writing income of about $200 during my senior year had been a considerable help.
Naturally, I would have to continue writing and, just as naturally, my depression made it very difficult to write. I managed one story during that summer; it was called ìLife Before Birth.î
ìLife Before Birthî was my first attempt at anything other than science fiction. It was in the allied field of fantasy (as imaginative as science fiction, but without the restriction of requiring scientific plausibility).
The reason for my attempting fantasy was that at the beginning of 1939, Street amp; Smith began the publication of a new magazine, Unknown , of which Campbell was editor.
 Unknown caught my fancy at once. It featured stories of what are now called ìadult fantasy,î and the writing seemed to my nineteen-year-old self to be even more advanced and literate than that in Astounding . Of course I wanted desperately to place a story in this new and wonderful magazine.
ìLife Before Birthî was an attempt in this direction, but aside from the mere fact that it was a fantasy, I remember nothing more about it. It was submitted to Campbell on July 11 and was back in my hands on the nineteenth. It never placed anywhere and no longer exists.
August was even worse. All Europe rang with the hideous possibility of war, and on September 1, World War II began with the German Invasion of Poland. I could do nothing during the crisis but listen to the radio. It was not till September 11 that I could settle down long enough to start another story, ìThe Brothers.î
ìThe Brothersî was science fiction, and all I remember is that it was about two brothers, a good one and an evil one, and a scientific invention that one or the other was constructing. On October 5 I submitted it to Campbell, and on October 11 it was rejected. It, too, never placed and no longer exists.
So the summer had passed fruitlessly and now I had to face another problem. Columbia University was not in the least anxious to take me on as a graduate student. They felt I was going to use the position as a mere way of marking time till I could try once more to get into medical school.
I swore that this was not so, but my position was vulnerable because as a premedical student I had not been required to take a course in physical chemistry and had therefore not done so. Physical chemistry was, however, required for graduate work in chemistry.
I persisted, and finally the admissions board made the following suggestion: I would have to take a full yearís selection of graduate courses, and, at the same time , I would have to take physical chemistry and get at least a B in that. If I failed to get the B, I was out on my ear and my tuition money would, of course, not be refunded.
One of the members of the board told me, some years later, that I was offered this in the belief that I would not accept a set of terms so loaded against me. However, since I had never had trouble with passing courses, it never occurred to me that a set of requirements that merely asked that I achieve certain grades, was loaded against me.
I agreed, and when at the end of the first semester there were only three Aís in physical chemistry out of a class of sixty, and I was one of them, the probation was lifted.
By December I had gotten deeply enough into my course work to be quite certain I would fulfill all grade requirements. The only uncertainty remaining was financial. I had to get back to writing.
On December 21 I began ìHomo Solî and completed it on January 1, 1940, the day before my twentieth birthday. I submitted it on January 4, and on that day, in Campbellís office, I met Theodore Sturgeon and L. Ron Hubbard, two established members of Campbellís stable of writers. (Hubbard has since then become world famous, in a fashion, as the originator of the cults of Dianetics and Scientology.)
There is no sign in my diary of any discouragement, but after a year and a half of assiduous efforts, I had failed to sell Campbell more than one story out of the eighteen I had by then written. He had rejected eight stories before buying ìTrends,î and he had rejected seven stories since. (Two stories, which I sold elsewhere, he never saw and had no chance to reject. Had he seen them he would certainly have rejected them.)
One factor in the lack of discouragement was Campbellís unfailing interest. As long as he didnít get tired reading my stories and advising me about them so kindly, why should I get tired writing them? Then, too, my occasional sales to magazines other than Astounding (there had been six by then) and, especially, the opening up of a new and sympathetic market in the form of Pohlís magazines, helped keep my spirits up.
For ìHomo Sol,î my nineteenth story, there was no outright rejection. Again, Campbell asked for revisions. I had to revise it twice, but it was not to be another ìBlack Friar of the Flame.î The second revision was satisfactory, and on April 17, 1940, I received my second check from Campbell (and, by that time, my seventh check, all told). Whatís more, it was for seventy-two dollars, the story being 7,200 words long, and was the largest check I had ever received for a story up to that time.
Oddly enough, the clearest thing I remember about that check is an incident that took place that evening in my fatherís candy store, where I still worked every day and where I was to continue working for two more years. A customer took offense at my neglecting to say ìThank youî after his purchase-a crime I frequently committed because, very often, I was working without conscious attention but was concentrating deeply on the plot permutations that were sounding hollowly within the cavern of my skull.
The customer decided to scold me for my obvious inattention and apparent lack of industry. ìMy son,î he said, ìmade fifty dollars through hard work last week. What do you do to earn a living?î
ìI write,î I said, ìand I got this for a story today,î and I held up the check for him to see.
It was a very satisfactory moment.








Homo Sol


The seven thousand and fifty-fourth session of the Galactic Congress sat in solemn conclave in the vast semicircular hall on Eon, second planet of Arcturus.
Slowly, the president delegate rose to his feet. His broad Arcturian countenance flushed slightly with excitement as he surveyed the surrounding delegates. His sense of the dramatic caused him to pause a moment or so before making the official announcement-for, after all, the entrance of a new planetary system into the great Galactic family is not a thing likely to happen twice in any one manís lifetime.
A dead silence prevailed during that pause. The two hundred and eighty-eight delegates-one from each of the two hundred and eighty-eight oxygen-atmosphere, water-chemistry worlds of the System-waited patiently for him to speak.
Beings of every manlike type and shape were there. Some were tall and pole-like, some broad and burly, some short and stumpy. There were those with long, wiry hair, those with scanty gray fuzz covering head and face, others with thick, blond curls piled high, and still others entirely bald. Some possessed long, hair-covered trumpets of ears, others had tympanum membranes flush with their temples. There were those present with large gazelle-like eyes of a deep-purple luminosity, others with tiny optics of a beady black. There was a delegate with green skin, one with an eight-inch proboscis and one with a vestigial tail Internally, variation was almost infinite.
But all were alike in two things.
They were all Humanoid. They all possessed intelligence.
The president delegateís voice boomed out then: ìDelegates! The system of Sol has discovered the secret of interstellar travel and by that act becomes eligible for entrance into the Galactic Federation.î
A storm of approving shouts arose from those present and the Arcturian raised a hand for silence.
ìI have here,î he continued, ìthe official report from Alpha Centauri, on whose fifth planet the Humanoids of Sol have landed. The report is entirely satisfactory and so the ban upon travel into and communication with the Solarian System is lifted. Sol is free, and open to the ships of the Federation. Even now, there is in preparation an expedition to Sol, under the leadership of Joselin Arn of Alpha Centauri, to tender that System the formal invitation into the Federation.î
He paused, and from two hundred and eighty-eight throats came the stentorian shout: ìHail, Homo Sol! Hail, Homo Sol! Hail!
It was the traditional welcome of the Federation for all new worlds.
Tan Porus raised himself to his full height of five feet two -he was tall for a Rigellian-and his sharp, green eyes snapped with annoyance.
ìThere it is, Lo-fan. For six months that damned freak squid from Beta Draconis IV has stumped me.î
Lo-fan stroked his forehead gently with one long finger, and one hairy ear twitched several times. He had traveled eighty-five light years to be here on Arcturus II with the greatest psychologist of the Federation-and, more specifically, to see this strange mollusk whose reactions had stumped the great Rigellian.
He was seeing it now: a puffy, dull-purple mass of soft flesh that writhed its tentacular form in placid unconcern through the huge tank of water that held it. With unruffled serenity, it fed on the green fronds of an underwater fern.
ìSeems ordinary enough,î said Lo-fan.
ìHa!î snorted Tan Porus. ìWatch this.î
He drew the curtain and plunged the room into darkness. Only a dim blue light shone upon the tank, and in the murk the Draconian squid could barely be discerned.
ìHere goes the stimulus,î grunted Porus. The screen above his head burst into soft green light, focused directly upon the tank. It persisted a moment and gave way to a dull red and then almost at once to a brilliant yellow. For half a minute it shot raggedly through the spectrum and then, with a final glare of glowing white, a clear bell-like tone sounded.
And as the echoes of the note died away, a shudder passed over the squidís body. It relaxed and sank slowly to the bottom of the tank.
Porus pulled aside the curtain. ìItís sound asleep,î he growled. ìHasnít failed yet. Every specimen weíve ever had drops as if shot the moment that note sounds.î
ìAsleep, eh? Thatís strange. Have you got the figures on the stimulus?î
ìCertainly! Right here. The exact wave lengths of the lights required are listed, plus the length of duration of each light unit, plus the exact pitch of the sounded note at the end.î
The other surveyed the figures dubiously. His forehead wrinkled and his ears rose in surprise. From an. inner pocket, he drew forth a slide rule.
ìWhat type nervous system has the animal?î
ìTwo-B. Plain, simple, ordinary Two-B. Iíve had the anatomists, physiologists, and ecologists check that until they were blue in the face. Two-B is all they get. Damn fools!î
Lo-fan said nothing, but pushed the center bar of the rule back and forth carefully. He stopped and peered closely, shrugged his shoulders, and reached for one of the huge volumes on the shelf above his head. He leafed through the pages and picked out numbers from among the close print. Again the slide rule.
Finally he stopped. ìIt doesnít make sense,î he said helplessly.
ìI know that! Iíve tried six times in six different ways to explain that reaction-and I failed each time. Even. if I rig up a system that will explain its going to sleep, I canít get it to explain the specificity of the stimulus.î
ìItís highly specific?î questioned Lo-fan, his voice reaching the higher registers.
ìThatís the worst part of it,î shouted Tan Porus. He leaned forward and tapped the other on the knee. ìIf you shift the wave length of any of the light units by fifty angstroms either way-any one of them-it doesnít sleep. Shift the length of duration of a light unit two seconds either way-it doesnít sleep. Shift the pitch of the tone at the end an eighth of an octave either way-it doesnít sleep. But get the right combination, and it goes straight into a coma.î
Lo-fanís ears were two hairy trumpets, stiffly erect. ìGalaxy!î he whispered. ìHow did you ever stumble on the combination?î
ìI didnít. It happened at Beta Draconis. Some hick college was putting its freshmen through a lab period on light-sound reactions of molluscoids-been doing it for years. Some student runs through his light-sound combinations and his blasted specimen goes to sleep. Naturally, heís scared out of his wits and brings it to the instructor. The instructor tries it again on another squid-it goes to sleep. They shift the combination- nothing happens. They go back to the original-it goes to sleep. After they fooled around with it long enough to know they couldnít make head or tail of it, they sent it to Arcturus and wished it on me. Itís six months since / had a real nightís sleep.î
A musical note sounded and Porus turned impatiently.
ìWhat is it?î
ìMessenger from the president delegate of Congress, sir,î came in metallic tones from the telecaster on his desk.
ìSend him up.î
The messenger stayed only long enough to hand Porus an impressively sealed envelope and to say in hearty tone:
ìGreat news, sir. The system of Sol has qualified for entrance.î
ìSo what?î snorted Porus beneath his breath as the other left ìWe all knew it was coming.î
He ripped off the outer sheath of cello-fiber from the envelope and removed the sheaf of papers from within. He glanced through them and grimaced.
ìOh, Rigel! î
ìWhatís wrong?î asked Lo-fan.
ìThose politicians keep bothering me with the most inconsequential things. Youíd think there wasnít another psychologist on Eron. Look! Weíve been expecting the Solarian System to solve the principle of the hyperatomo any century now. Theyíve finally done it and an expedition of theirs landed on Alpha Centauri. At once, thereís a politiciansí holiday! We must send an expedition of our own to ask them to join the Federation. And, of course, we must have a psychologist along to ask them in a nice way so as to be sure of getting the right reaction, because, to be sure, there isnít a man in the army that ever gets proper training in psychology.î
Lo-fan nodded seriously. ìI know, I know. We have the same trouble out our way. They donít need psychology until they get into trouble and then they come running.î
ìWell, itís a cinch Iím not going to Sol. This sleeping squid is too important to neglect. Itís a routine job, anyway-this business of raking in new worlds; a Type A reaction that any sophomore can handle.î
ìWhom will you send?î
ìI donít know. Iíve got several good juniors under me that can do this sort of thing with their eyes closed. Iíll send one of them. And meanwhile, Iíll be seeing you at the faculty meeting tomorrow, wonít I?î
ìYou will-and hearing me, too. Iím making a speech on the finger-touch stimulus.î
ìGood! Iíve done work on it, so Iíll be interested in hearing what you have to say. Till tomorrow, then.î
Left alone, Porus turned once more to the official report on the Solarian System which the messenger had handed him. He leafed through it leisurely, without particular interest, and finally put it down with a sigh.
ìLor Haridin could do it,î he muttered to himself. ìHeís a good kid-deserves a break.î
He lifted his tiny bulk out of the chair and, with the report under his arm, left his office and trotted down the long corridor outside. As he stopped before a door at the far end, the automatic flash blazed up and a voice within called out to him to enter.
The Rigellian opened the door and poked his head inside. ìBusy, Haridin?î
Lor Haridin looked up and sprang to his feet at once. ìGreat space, boss, no! I havenít had anything to do since I finished work on anger reactions. Youíve got something for me, maybe?î
ìI have-if you think youíre up to it. Youíve heard of the Solarian System, havenít you?î
ìSure! The visors are full of it. Theyíve got interstellar travel, havenít they?î
ìThatís right. An expedition is leaving Alpha Centauri for Sol in a month. Theyíll need a psychologist to do the fine work, and I was thinking of sending you.î
The young scientist reddened with delight to the very top of his hairless dome. ìDo you mean it, boss?î
ìWhy not? That is-if you think you can do it.î
ìOf course I can.î Haridin drew himself up in offended hauteur. ìType A reaction! I canít miss.î
ìYouíll have to learn their language, you know, and administer the stimulus in the Solarian tongue. Itís not always an easy job.î
Haridin shrugged. ìI still canít miss. In a case like this, translation need only be seventy-five percent effective to get ninety-nine and six tenths percent of the desired result. That was one of the problems I had to solve on my qualifying exam. So you canít trip me up that way.î
Porus laughed. ìAll right, Haridin, I know you can do it. Clean up everything here at the university and sign up for indefinite leave. And if you can, Haridin, write some sort of paper on these Solarians. If itís any good, you might get senior status on the basis of it.î
The junior psychologist frowned, ìBut, boss, thatís old stuff. Humanoid reactions are as well known asÖ as- You canít write anything on them.î
ìThereís always something if you look hard enough, Haridin. Nothing is well known; remember that. If youíll look at Sheet 25 of the report, for instance, youíll find an item concerning the care with which the Solarians armed themselves on leaving their ship.î
The other turned to the proper page. ìThatís reasonable,î said he. ìAn entirely normal reaction.î
ìCertainly. But they insisted on retaining their weapons throughout their stay, even when they were greeted and welcomed by fellow Humanoids. Thatís quite a perceptible deviation from the normal. Investigate it-it might be worth while.î
ìAs you say, boss. Thanks a lot for the chance youíre giving me. And say-howís the squid coming along?î
Porus wrinkled his nose. ìMy sixth try folded up and died yesterday. Itís disgusting.î And with that, he was gone.
Tan Porus of Rigel trembled with rage as he folded the handful of papers he held in two and tore them across. He plugged in the telecaster with a jerk.
ìGet me Santins of the math department immediately,î he snapped.
His green eyes shot fire at the placid figure that appeared on the visor almost at once. He shook his fist at the image.
ìWhat on Eronís the idea of that analysis you sent me just now, you Betelgeusian slime worm?î
The imageís eyebrows shot up in mild surprise. ìDonít blame me, Porus. They were your equations, not mine. Where did you get them?î
ìNever mind where I got them. Thatís the business of the psychology department.î
ìAll right! And solving them is the business of the mathematics department. Thatís the seventh set of the damnedest sort of screwy equations Iíve ever seen. It was the worst yet. You made at least seventeen assumptions which you had no right to make. It took us two weeks to straighten you out, and finally we boiled it down-î
Porus jumped as if stung. ìI know what you boiled it down to. I just tore up the sheets. You take eighteen independent variables in twenty equations, representing two months of work, and solve them out at the bottom of the last, last page with that gem of oracular wisdom-íaí equals ëa.í All that work-and all I get is an identity.î
ìItís still not my fault, Porus. You argued in circles, and in mathematics that means an identity and thereís nothing you can do about it.î His lips twitched in a slow smile. ìWhat are you kicking about, anyway? ëAí does equal ëa,í doesnít it?î
ì Shut up! î The telecaster went dead, and the psychologist closed his lips tightly and boiled inwardly. The light signal above the telecaster flashed to life again.
ìWhat do you want now?î
It was the calm, impersonal voice of the receptionist below that answered him. ìA messenger from the government, sir.î
ìDamn the government! Tell them Iím dead.î
ìItís important, sir. Lor Haridin has returned from Sol and wants to see you.î
Porus frowned. ìSol? What Sol? Oh, I remember. Send him up, but tell him to make it snappy.î
ìCome in, Haridin,î he said a little later, voice calmer, as the young Arcturian, a bit thinner, a bit more weary than he had been six months earlier when he left the Arcturian System, entered.
ìWell, young man? Did you write the paper?î
The Arcturian gazed intently upon his fingernails. ìNo, sir!î
ìWhy not?î Porusí green eyes peered narrowly at the other. ìDonít tell me youíve had trouble.î
ìQuite, a bit, boss.î The words came with an effort. ìThe psychological board itself has sent for you after hearing my report. The fact of the matter is that the Solarian System hasÖ has refused to join the Federation.î
Tan Porus shot out of his chair like a jack-in-the-box and landed, purely by chance, on his feet.
ìWhat!!î
Haridin nodded miserably and cleared his throat.
ìNow, by the Great Dark Nebula,î swore the Rigellian, distractedly, ìif this isnít one sweet day! First, they tell me that ëaí equals ëa,í and then you come in and tell me you muffed a Type A reaction- muffed it completely! î
The junior psychologist fired up. ìI didnít muff it. Thereís something wrong with the Solarians themselves. Theyíre not normal. When I landed they went wild over us. There was a fantastic celebration-entirely unrestrained. Nothing was too good for us. I delivered the invitation before their parliament in their own language-a simple one which they call Esperanto. Iíll stake my life that my translation was ninety-five percent effective.î
ìWell? And then?î
ìI canít understand the rest, boss. First, there was a neutral reaction and I was a little surprised, and thenî-he shuddered in retrospect-îin seven days-only seven days, boss-the entire planet had reversed itself completely. I couldnít follow their psychology, not by a hundred miles. Iíve brought home copies of their newspapers of the time in which they objected to joining with ëalien monstrositiesí and refused to be ëruled by inhumans of worlds parsecs away.í I ask you, does that make sense?
ìAnd thatís only the beginning. It was light years worse than that. Why, good Galaxy, I went all the way into Type G reactions, trying to figure them out, and couldnít. In the end, we had to leave. We were in actual physical danger from thoseÖ those Earthmen, as they call themselves.î
Tan Porus chewed his lip a while. ìInteresting! Have you your report with you?î
ìNo. The psychological board has it. Theyíve been going over it with a microscope all day.î
ìAnd what do they say?î
The young Arcturian winced. ìThey donít say it openly, but they leave a strong impression of thinking the report an inaccurate one.î
ìWell, Iíll decide about that after Iíve read it. Meanwhile, come with me to Parliamentary Hall and you can answer a few questions on the way.î
Joselin Arn of Alpha Centauri rubbed stubbled jaws with his huge, six-fingered hand and peered from under beetling brows at the semicircle of diversified faces that stared down upon him. The psychological board was composed of psychologists of a score of worlds, and their united gaze was not the easiest thing in the world to withstand.
ìWe have been informed,î began Frian Obel, head of the board and native of Vega, home of the green-skinned men, ìthat those sections of the report dealing with Solís military state are your work.î
Joselin Arn inclined his head in silent agreement.
ìAnd you are prepared to confirm what you have stated here, in spite of its inherent improbability? You are no psychologist, you know.î
ìNo! But Iím a soldier!î The Centaurianís jaws set stubbornly as his bass voice rumbled through the hall. ìI donít know equations and I donít know graphs-but I do know spaceships. Iíve seen theirs and Iíve seen ours, and theirs are better. Iíve seen their first interstellar ship. Give them a hundred years and theyíll have a better hyperatomos than we have. Iíve seen their weapons. Theyíve got almost everything we have, at a stage in their history millennia before us. What they havenít got-theyíll get, and soon. What they have got, theyíll improve.
ìIíve seen their munitions plants. Ours are more advanced, but theirs are more efficient. Iíve seen their soldiers-and Iíd rather fight with them than against them.
ìIíve said all that in the report. I say it again now.î
His brusque sentences came to an end and Frian Obel waited for the murmur from the men about him to cease.
ìAnd the rest of their science; medicine, chemistry, physics? What of them?î
ìIím not the best judge of those. You have the report there of those who know, however, and to the best of my knowledge I confirm them.î
ìAnd so these Solarians are true Humanoids?î
ìBy the circling worlds of Centauri, yes!î
The old scientist drew himself back in his chair with a peevish gesture and cast a rapid, frowning glance up and down the length of the table.
ìColleagues,î he said, ìwe make little progress by rehashing this mess of impossibilities. We have a race of Humanoids of a superlatively technological turn; possessing at the same time an intrinsically unscientific belief in supernatural forces, an incredibly childish predilection toward individuality, singly and in groups, and, worst of all, lack of sufficient vision to embrace a galaxy-wide culture.î
He glared down upon the lowering Centaurian before him. ìSuch a race must exist if we are to believe the report-and fundamental axioms of psychology must crumble. But I, for one, refuse to believe any such-to be vulgar about it-comet gas. This is plainly a case of mismanagement to be investigated by the proper authorities. I hope you all agree with me when I say that this report be consigned to the scrap heap and that a second expedition led by an expert in his line, not by an inexperienced junior psychologist or a soldier-î
The drone of the scientistís voice was buried suddenly in the crash of an iron fist against the table. Joselin Am, his huge bulk writhing in anger, lost his temper and gave vent to martial wrath.
ìNow, by the writhing spawn of Templis, by the worms that crawl and the gnats that fly, by the cesspools and the plague spots, and by the hooded death itself, I wonít allow this . Are you to sit there with your theories and your long-range wisdom and deny what I have seen with my eyes? Are my eyesî-and they flashed fire as he spoke-îto deny themselves because of a few wriggling marks your palsied hands trace on paper?
ìTo the core of Centauri with these armchair wise men, say I-and the psychologists first of all. Blast these men who bury themselves in their books and their laboratories and are blind to what goes on in the living world outside. Psychology, is it? Rotten, putrid-î
A tap on his belt caused him to whirl, eyes staring, fists clenched. For a moment, he looked about vainly. Then, turning his gaze downward, he found himself looking into the enigmatic green eyes of a pygmy of a man, whose piercing stare seemed to drench his anger with ice water.
ìI know you, Joselin Am,î said Tan Porus slowly, picking his words carefully. ìYouíre a brave man and a good soldier, but you donít like psychologists, I see. That is wrong of you, for it is on psychology that the political success of the Federation rests. Take it away and our Union crumbles, our great Federation melts away, the Galactic System is shattered.î His voice descended into a soft, liquid croon. ìYou have sworn an oath to defend the System against all its enemies, Joselin Am-and you yourself have now become its greatest. You strike at its foundations. You dig at its roots. You poison it at its source. You are dishonored. You are disgraced. You are a traitor.î
The Centaurian soldier shook his head helplessly. As Porus spoke, deep and bitter remorse filled him. Recollection of his words of a moment ago lay heavy on his conscience. When the psychologist finished, Am bent his head and wept. Tears ran down those lined, war-scarred cheeks, to which for forty years now they had been a stranger.
Porus spoke again, and this time his voice boomed like a thunderclap: ìAway with your mewling whine, you coward. Danger is at hand. Man the guns! î
Joselin Am snapped to attention; the sorrow that had filled him a bare second before was gone as if it had never existed.
The room rocked with laughter and the soldier grasped the situation. It had been Porusí way of punishing him. With his complete knowledge of the devious ins and outs of the Humanoid mind, he had only to push the proper button, and-
The Centaurian bit his lip in embarrassment, but said nothing.
But Tan Porus, himself, did not laugh. To tease the soldier was one thing; to humiliate him, quite another. With a bound, he was on a chair and laid his small hand on the otherís massive shoulder.
ìNo offense, my friend-a little lesson, that is all. Fight the sub-humanoids and the hostile environments of fifty worlds. Dare space in a leaky rattletrap of a ship. Defy whatever dangers you wish. But never, never offend a psychologist. He might get angry in earnest the next time.î
Arn bent his head back and laughed-a gigantic roar of mirth that shook the room with its earthquake-like lustiness.
ìYour advice is well taken, psychologist. Bum me with an atomo, if I donít think youíre right.î He strode from the room with his shoulders still heaving with suppressed laughter.
Porus hopped off the chair and turned to face the board.
ìThis is an interesting race of Humanoids we have stumbled upon, colleagues.î
ìAh,î said Obel, dryly, ìthe great Porus feels bound to come to his pupilís defense. Your digestion seems to have improved, since you feel yourself capable of swallowing Haridinís report.î
Haridin, standing, head bowed, in the corner, reddened angrily, but did not move.
Porus frowned, but his voice kept to its even tone. ìI do, and the report, if properly analyzed, will give rise to a revolution in the science. It is a psychological gold mine; and Homo Sol, the find of the millennium.î
ìBe specific. Tan Porus,î drawled someone. ìYour tricks are all very well for a Centaurian blockhead, but we remain unimpressed.î
The fiery little Rigellian emitted a gurgle of anger. He shook one tiny fist in the direction of the last speaker.
ìIíll be more specific, Inar Tubal, you hairy space bug.î Prudence and anger waged a visible battle within him. ìThere is more to a Humanoid than you think-certainly far more than you mental cripples can understand. Just to show you what you donít know, you desiccated group of fossils, Iíll undertake to show you a bit of psycho-technology thatíll knock the guts right out of you. Panic, morons, panic! Worldwide panic!î
There was an awful silence. ìDid you say world-wide panic?î stuttered Frian Obel, his green skin turning gray. ìPanic?î
ìYes, you parrot. Give me six months and fifty assistants and Iíll show you a world of Humanoids in panic.î
Obel attempted vainly to answer. His mouth worked in a heroic attempt to remain serious-and failed. As though by signal, the entire board dropped its dignity and leaned back in a single burst of laughter.
ìI remember,î gasped Inar Tubal of Sirius, his round face streaked with tears of pure joy, ìa student of mine who once claimed to have discovered a stimulus that would induce world-wide panic. When I checked his results, I came across an exponent with a misplaced decimal point. He was only ten orders of magnitude out of the way. How many decimal points have you misplaced, Colleague Porus?î
ìWhat of Krautís Law, Porus, which says you canít panic more than five Humanoids at a time? Shall we pass a resolution repealing it? And maybe the atomic theory as well, while weíre about it?î and Semper Gor of Capella cackled gleefully.
Porus climbed onto the table and snatched Obelís gavel. ìThe next one who laughs is getting this over his empty head.î There was sudden silence.
ìIím taking fifty assistants,î shouted the green-eyed Rigellian, ìand Joselin Am is taking me to Sol. I want five of you to come with me-Inar Tubal, Semper Gor and any three others -so that I can watch their stupid faces when Iíve done what I said I would.î He hefted the gavel, threateningly. ìWell?î
Frian Obel gazed at the ceiling placidly. ìAll right, Porus. Tubal. Gor. Helvin, Prat, and Winson can go with you. At the end of the specified time, weíll witness world-wide panic which will be very gratifying-or weíll watch you eat your words, and how much more gratifying that would be.î And with that, he chuckled very quietly to himself.
Tan Porus stared thoughtfully out the window. Terrapolis, capital city of Earth, sprawled beneath him to the very edge of the horizon. Its muted roar reached even to the half-mile height at which he stood.
There was something over that city, invisible and intangible but none the less real. Its presence was only too evident to the small psychologist. The choking, cloak of dank fear that spread over the metropolis beneath was one of his own weaving-a horrible cloak of dark uncertainty, that clutched with clammy fingers at the hearts of Mankind and stopped short -just short-of actual panic.
The roar of the city had voices in it, and the voices were tiny ones of fear.
The Rigellian turned away in disgust. ìHey, Haridin,î he roared.
The young Arcturian turned away from the televisor. ìCalling me, boss?î
ìWhat do you think Iím doing? Talking to myself? Whatís the latest from Asia?î
ìNothing new. The stimuli just arenít strong enough. The yellow men seem to be more stolid of disposition than the white dominants of America and Europe. Iíve sent out orders not to increase the stimuli, though.î
ìNo, they mustnít,î agreed Porus. ìWe canít risk active panic.î He ruminated in silence. ìListen, weíre about through. Tell them to hit a few of the big cities-theyíre more susceptible-and quit.î
He turned to the window again. ìSpace, what a world- what a world! An entirely new branch of psychology has opened up-one we never dreamed of. Mob psychology, Haridin, mob psychology.î He shook his head impressively.
ìThereís lots of suffering, though, boss,î muttered the younger man. ìThis passive panic has completely paralyzed trade and commerce. The business life of the entire planet is stagnant. The poor government is helpless-they donít know whatís wrong.î
ìTheyíll find out-when Iím ready. And, as for the suffering-well, I donít like it, either, but itís all a means to an end, a damned important end.î
There followed a short silence, and then Porusí lips twitched into a nasty smile. ìThose five nitwits returned from Europe yesterday, didnít they?î
Haridin smiled in turn and nodded vigorously, ìAnd hopping sore! Your predictions have checked to the fifth decimal place. Theyíre fit to be tied.î
ìGood! Iím only sorry I canít see Obelís face right now, after the last message I sent him. And, incidentallyî-his voice dropped lower-îwhatís the latest on them? î
Haridin raised two fingers. ìTwo weeks, and theyíll be here.î
ìTwo weeksÖ two weeks,î gurgled Porus jubilantly. He rose and made for the door. ìI think Iíll find my dear, dear colleagues and pass the time of day.î
The five scientists of the board looked up from their notes and fell into an embarrassed silence as Porus entered.
The latter smiled impishly. ìNotes satisfactory, gentlemen? Found some fifty or sixty fallacies in my fundamental assumptions, no doubt?î
Hybron Prat of Alpha Cepheus rumpled the gray fuzz he called hair. ìI donít trust the unholy tricks this crazy mathematical notation of yours plays.î
The Rigellian emitted a short bark of laughter. ìInvent a better, then. So far, itís done a good job of handling reactions, hasnít it?î
There was an unmusical chorus of throat-clearings but no definite answer.
ìHasnít it?î thundered Porus.
ìWell, what if it has,î returned Kim Winson, desperately. ìWhereís your panic? All this is well and good. These Humanoids are cosmic freaks, but whereís the big show you were going to put on? Until you break Krautís Law, this entire exhibition of yours isnít worth a pinhead meteor.î
ìYouíre beaten, gentlemen, youíre beaten,î crowed the small master psychologist. ìIíve proven my point-this passive panic is as impossible according to classic psychology as the active form. Youíre trying to deny facts and save face now, by harping on a technicality. Go home; go home, gentlemen, and hide under the bed.î
Psychologists are only human. They can analyze the motives that drive them, but they are the slave of those motives just as much as the commonest mortal of all. These galaxy-famous psychologists writhed under the lash of wounded pride and shattered vanity, and their blind stubbornness was the mechanical reaction due therefrom. They knew it was and they knew Porus knew it was-and that made it all the harder.
Inar Tubal stared angrily from red-rimmed eyes. ìActive panic or nothing. Tan Porus. Thatís what you promised, and thatís what weíll have. We want the letter of the bond or, by space and time, weíll balk at any technicality. Active panic or we report failure!î
Porus swelled ominously and, with a tremendous effort, spoke quietly. ìBe reasonable, gentlemen. We havenít the equipment to handle active panic. Weíve never come up against this superform they have here on Earth. What if it gets beyond control?î He shook his head violently.
ìIsolate it, then,î snarled Semper Gor. ìStart it up and put it out. Make all the preparations you want, but do it!î
ìIf you can,î grunted Hybron Prat.
But Tan Porus had his weak point. His brittle temper lay in splintered shards about him. His agile tongue blistered the atmosphere and inundated the sullen psychologist with wave after wave of concentrated profanity.
ìHave your way, vacuumheads! Have your way and to outer space with you!î He was breathless with passion. ìWeíll set it off right here in Terrapolis as soon as all the men are back home. Only youíd all better get from under!î
And with one last parting snarl, he stalked from the room.
Tan Porus parted the curtains with a sweep of his hand, and the five psychologists facing him averted their eyes. The streets of Earthís capital were deserted of civilian population. The ordered tramp of the military patrolling the highways of the city sounded like a dirge. The wintry sky hung low over a scene of strewn bodies-and silence; the silence that follows an orgy of wild destruction.
ìIt was touch and go for a few hours there, colleagues.î Porusí voice was tired. ìIf it had passed the city limits, we could never have stopped it.î
ìHorrible, horrible!î muttered Hybron Prat. ìIt was a scene a psychologist would have given his right arm to witness- and his life to forget.î
ìAnd these are Humanoids!î groaned Kim Winson.
Semper Gor rose to his feet in sudden decision. ìDo you see the significance of this, Porus? These Earthmen are sheer uncontrolled atomite. They canít be handled. Were they twice the technological geniuses they are, they would be useless. With their mob psychology, their mass panics, their superemotionalism, they simply wonít fit into the Humanoid picture.î
Porus raised an eyebrow. ìComet gas! Individually, we are as emotional as they are. They carry it into mass action and we donít; thatís the only difference.î
ìAnd thatís enough!î exclaimed Tubal. ìWeíve made our decision, Porus. We made it last night, at the height of theÖ theÖ of it. The Solar System is to be left to itself. It is a plague spot and we want none of it. As far as the Galaxy is concerned. Homo Sol will be placed in strict quarantine. That is final!î
The Rigellian laughed softly. ìFor the Galaxy, it may be final. But for Homo Sol?î
Tubal shrugged. ìThey donít concern us.î
Porus laughed again. ìSay, Tubal. Just between the two of us, have you tried a time integration of Equation 128 followed by expansion with Karolean tensors?î
ìNo-o. I canít say I have.î
ìWell, then, just glance up and down these calculations and enjoy yourself.î
The five scientists of the board grouped themselves about the sheets of paper Porus had handed them. Expressions changed from interest to bewilderment and then to something approaching panic.
Nam Helvin tore the sheets across with a spasmodic movement. ìItís a lie,î he screeched.
ìWeíre a thousand years ahead of them now, and by that time weíll be advanced another two hundred years!î Tubal snapped. ìThey wonít be able to do anything against the mass of the Galaxyís people.î
Tan Porus laughed in a monotone, which is hard to do, but very unpleasant to hear. ìYou still donít believe mathematics. Thatís in your behavior pattern, of course. All right, letís see if experts convince you-as they should, unless contact with these off-normal Humanoids has twisted you. Joselin-Joselin Am-come in here!î
The Centaurian commander came in, saluted automatically, and looked expectant.
ìCan one of your ships defeat one of the Sol ships in battle, if necessary?î 214
Arn grinned sourly. ìNot a chance, sir. These Humanoids break Krautís Law in panic-and also in fighting. We have a corps of experts manning our ships; these people have a single crew that functions as a unit, without individuality. They manifest a form of fighting-panic, I imagine, is the best word. Every individual on a ship becomes an organ of the ship. With us, as you know, thatís impossible.
ìFurthermore, this worldís a mass of mad geniuses. They have, to my certain knowledge, taken no less than twenty-two interesting but useless gadgets they saw in the Thalsoon Museum when they visited us, turned ëem inside out, and produced from them some of the most unpleasant military devices Iíve seen. You know of Julmun Thillís gravitational line tracer? Used-rather ineffectively-for spotting ore deposits before the modem electric potential method came in?
ìTheyíve turned it-somehow-into one of the deadliest automatic fire directors itís been my displeasure to see. It will automatically lay a gun or projector on a completely invisible target in space, air, water or rock, for that matter.î
ìWe,î said Tan Porus, gleefully, ìhave far greater fleets than they. We could overwhelm them, could we not?î
Joselin Am shook his head. ìDefeat them now-probably. It wouldnít be overwhelming, though, and I wouldnít bet on it too heavily. Certainly wouldnít invite it. The trouble is, in a military way, this collection of gadget maniacs invent things at a horrible rate. Technologically, theyíre as unstable as a wave in water; our civilization is more like a sanddune. Iíve seen their ground-car plants install a complete plant of machine tools for production of a new model of automobile-and rip it out in six months because itís completely obsolete!
ìNow weíve come in contact with their civilization briefly. Weíve learned the methods of one new civilization to add to our previous two hundred and eighty-odd-a small percentage advantage. Theyíve added one new civilization to their previous one-a one-hundred-percent advance!î
ìHow about,î Porus asked gently, ìour military position if we simply ignore them completely for two hundred years?î
Joselin Am gave an explosive little laugh. ì If we could- which means if theyíd let us-Iíd answer offhand and with assurance. Theyíre all Iíd care to tackle right now. Two hundred years of exploring the new tracks suggested by their brief contact with us and theyíd be doing things I canít imagine. Wait two hundred years and there wonít be a battle; thereíll be an annexation.î
Tan Porus bowed formally. ìThank you, Joselin Arn. That was the result of my mathematical work.î
Joselin Arn saluted and left the room.
Turning to the five thoroughly paralyzed scientists, Porus went on: ìAnd I hope these learned gentlemen still react in a vaguely Humanoid way. Are you convinced that it is not up to us to decide to end all intercourse with this race? Weí may -but they wonít!
ìFoolsî-he spat out the word-îdo you think Iím going to waste time arguing with you? Iím laying down the law, do you understand? Homo Sol shall enter the Federation. They are going to be trained into maturity in two hundred years. And Iím not asking you; Iím telling you! î The Rigellian stared up at them truculently.
ìCome with me!î he growled brusquely.
They followed in tame submission and entered Tan Porusí sleeping quarters. The little psychologist drew aside a curtain and revealed a life-size painting.
ìMake anything of that?î
It was the portrait of an Earthman, but of such an Earthman as none of the psychologists had yet seen. Dignified and sternly handsome, with one hand stroking a regal beard, and the other holding the single flowing garment that clothed him, he seemed personified majesty.
ìThatís Zeus,î said Porus. ìThe primitive Earthmen created him as the personification of storm and lightning.î He whirled upon the bewildered five. ìDoes it remind you of anybody?î
ìHomo Canopus?î ventured Helvin uncertainly.
For a moment, Porusí face relaxed in momentary gratification and then it hardened again. ìOf course,î he snapped. ìWhy do you hesitate about it? Thatís Canopus to the life, down to the full yellow beard.î
Then: ìHereís something else.î He drew another curtain.
The portrait was of a female, this time. Full-bosomed and wide-hipped she was. An ineffable smile graced her face and her hands seemed to caress the stalks of grain that sprang thickly about her feet.
ìDemeter!î said Porus. ìThe personification of agricultural fertility. The idealized mother. Whom does that remind you of?î
There was no hesitation this time. Five voices rang out as one: ìHomo Betelgeuse!î
Tan Porus smiled in delight. ìThere you have it Well?î
ìWell?î said Tubal.
ìDonít you see?î The smile faded. ìIsnít it clear? Nitwit! If a hundred Zeuses and a hundred Demeters were to land on Earth as part of a ëtrade mission,í and turned out to be trained psychologists-Now do you see?î
Semper Gor laughed suddenly. ìSpace, time, and little meteors. Of course! The Earthmen would be putty in the hands of their own personifications of storm and motherhood come to life. In two hundred years-why, in two hundred years, we could do anything.î
ìBut this so-called trade mission of yours, Porus,î interposed Prat. ìHow would you get Homo Sol to accept it in the first place?î
Porus cocked his head to one side. ìDear Colleague Prat,î he murmured, ìdo you suppose that I created the passive panic just for the show-or just to gratify five woodenheads? This passive panic paralyzed industry, and the Terrestrial government is faced with revolution-another form of mob action that could use investigation. Offer them Galactic trade and eternal prosperity and do you think theyíd jump at it? Has matter mass?î
The Rigellian cut short the excited babble that followed with an impatient gesture. ìIf youíve nothing more to ask, gentlemen, letís begin our preparations to leave. Frankly, Iím tired of Earth, and, more than that, Iím blasted anxious to get back to that squid of mine.î
He opened the door and shouted down the corridor: ìHey, Haridini Tell Arn to have the ship ready in six hours. Weíre leaving.î
ìButÖ but-î The chorus of puzzled objections crystallized into sudden action as Semper Gor dashed at Porus and snatched him back as he was on the point of leaving. The little Rigellian struggled vainly in the otherís powerful grasp.
ìLet go!î
ìWeíve endured enough, Porus,î said Gor, ìand now youíll just calm down and behave like a Humanoid. Whatever you say, weíre not leaving until weíre finished. Weíve got to arrange with the Terrestrial government concerning the trade mission. Weíve got to secure approval of the board. Weíve got to pick our psychologist. Weíve got to-î
Here Porus, with a sudden jerk, freed himself. ìDo you suppose for one moment that I would wait for your precious board to start to begin to commence to consider doing something about the situation in two or three decades?
ìEarth agreed to my terms unconditionally a month ago. The squad of Canopans and Betelgeusans set sail five months ago, and landed day before yesterday. It was only with their help that we managed to stop yesterdayís panic-though you never suspected it. You probably thought you did it yourself. Today, gentlemen, they have the situation in full control and your services are no longer needed. Weíre going home.î



***



ìHomo Solî has a plot of a sort that particularly appealed to Campbell. Although the human beings in the story are far behind the other intelligences of the Galaxy, it is clear that there is something special about them, that they have an unusual ability to move ahead very quickly, and that everyone else had better watch out for them.
Campbell liked stories in which human beings proved themselves superior to other intelligences, even when those others were further advanced technologically. It pleased him to have human beings shown to possess a unique spirit of daring, or a sense of humor, or a ruthless ability to kill when necessary, that always brought them victory over other intelligences, even against odds.
I sometimes got the uncomfortable notionª however, that this attitude reflected Campbellís feelings on the smaller, Earth scale. He seemed to me to accept the natural superiority of Americans over non-Americans, and he seemed automatically to assume the picture of an American as one who was of northwest European origin.
I cannot say that Campbell was racist in any evil sense of the term. I cannot recall any act of his that could be construed as unkind, and certainly he never, not once , made me feel uncomfortable over the fact that I was Jewish. Nevertheless, he did seem to take for granted, somehow, the stereotype of the Nordic white as the true representative of Man the Explorer, Man the Darer, Man the Victor,
I argued with him strenuously on the subject, or as violently as I dared, and in years to come our relationship was to be as nearly strained as it could be (considering our mutual affection, and all that I owed him) over the civil rights issue. I was on the liberal side of the issue, he on the conservative, and our minds never met on that subject.
All this had an important bearing on my science fiction work. I did not like Campbellís attitude concerning humanity vis-a-vis other intelligences and it took two revisions of ìHomo Solî before Campbell could move me close enough to what he wanted. Even then, he inserted several paragraphs, here and there, without consulting me, in the final version.
I tried to avoid such a situation in future. One way out was to depart from the traditions of those writers who wove plots against the gigantic web of entire galaxies containing many intelligences-notably those of E. E. Smith and of Campbell himself. Instead, I began to think of stories involving a galaxy populated by human intelligences only.
This came to fruit, soon enough, in. the ìFoundationî series. Undoubtedly the Smith-Campbell view makes more sense. It is almost certain that among the hundreds of billions of worlds in a large galaxy there ought to be hundreds or even thousands of different intelligent species. That there should be only one, ourselves, as I postulated, is most unlikely.
Some science fiction critics (notably Sam Moskowitz) have given me credit for inventing the human-only galaxy, as though it were some kind of literary advance. Others may have thought privately (I have never heard it stated openly) that I had only human intelligences in my galaxy because I lacked the imagination to think up extraterrestrials.
But the fact is that I was only trying to avoid a collision with Campbellís views; I did not want to set up a situation in which I would be forced to face the alternatives of adopting Campbellís views when I found them repugnant and failing to sell a story (which I also found repugnant).
On March 25, 1940, the day I put through my final submission of ìHomo Sol,î I went on to visit Fred Pohl at his office. He told me that the response to ìHalf-Breedî had been such that he felt justified in asking for a sequel. It was the first time I had ever been requested to write a specific story with acceptance virtually guaranteed in advance.
I spent April and May working on the sequel, ìHalf-Breeds on Venus,î and submitted it to Pohl on June 3. On June 14, he accepted it. The story was ten thousand words long, the longest I had ever sold up to that time. Whatís more, Pohlís magazines were doing so well that his budget had been increased and he was able to pay me five eighths of a cent a word for it-$62.50.
It appeared in the issue of Astonishing that reached the stands on October 24, 1940, two years almost to a day since my first sale. This was a red-letter day for me, too, since it was the first time that the cover painting on a magazine was ever taken from one of my stories. I had ìmade the cover.î
The title of the story and my name were on the cover in bold letters. It was a flattering indication that my name could be counted on to sell magazines by this time.








Half-Breeds on Venus


The damp, somnolent atmosphere stirred violently and shrieked aside. The bare plateau shook three times as the heavy egg-shaped projectiles shot down from outer space. The sound of the landing reverberated from the mountains on one side to the lush forest on the other, and then all was silent again.
One by one, three doors clanged open, and human figures stepped out in hesitant single file. First slowly, and then with impatient turbulence, they set first foot upon the new world, until the space surrounding the ships was crowded.
A thousand pairs of eyes gazed upon the prospect and a thousand mouths chattered excitedly. And in the other-world wind, a thousand crests of foot-high white hair swayed gracefully.
The Tweenies had landed on Venus!
Max Scanlon sighed wearily, ìHere we are!î
He turned from the porthole and slumped into his own special arm-chair. ìTheyíre as happy as children-and I donít blame them. Weíve got a new world-one all for ourselves- and thatís a great thing. But just the same, there are hard days ahead.of us. I am almost afraid! It is a project so lightly embarked upon, but one so hard to carry out to completion.î
A gentle arm stole about his shoulder and he grasped it tightly, smiling into the soft, blue eyes that met his. ìBut youíre not afraid, are you, Madeline?î
ìCertainly not!î And then her expression grew sadder, ìIf only father had come with us. You-you know that he meant more to us than to the others. We were the-the first he took under his wing, werenít we?î
There was a long silence after that as each fell into deep thought.
Max sighed, ìI remember him that day forty years ago- old suit, pipe, everything. He took me in. Me, a despised half-breed! And-and he found you for me, Madeline!î
ìI know,î there were tears in her eyes. ìBut heís still with us, Max, and always will be-here, and there.î Her hand crept first to her own heart and then to Maxís.
ìHey, there, Dad, catch her, catch her!î
Max whirled at the sound of his elder sonís voice, just in time to catch up the little bundle of flying arms and legs that catapulted into him.
He held her gravely up before him, ìShall I give you to your papa, Elsie? He wants you.î
The little girl kicked her legs ecstatically. ìNo, no. I want you, grand-daddy. I want you to give me a piggy-back and come out with grandmamma to see how nice everything is.î
Max turned to his son, and motioned him sternly away, ìDepart, despised father, and let old grand-dad have a chance.î
Arthur laughed and mopped a red face, ìKeep her, for Heavenís sake. Sheís been leading me and the wife a merry chase outside. We had to drag her back by the dress to keep her from running off into the forest. Didnít we, Elsie?î
Elsie, thus appealed to, suddenly recalled a past grievance. ìGrand-daddy, tell him to let me see the pretty trees. He doesnít want me to.î She wriggled from Maxís grasp and ran to the porthole. ìSee them, grand-daddy, see them. Itís all trees outside. Itís not black anymore. I hated it when it was black, didnít you?î
Max leaned over and ruffled the childís soft, white hair gravely, ìYes, Elsie, I hated it when it was black. But it isnít black anymore, and it wonít ever be black again. Now go run to grandmamma. Sheíll get some cake specially for you. Go ahead, run!î
He followed the departing forms of his wife and granddaughter with smiling eyes, and then, as they turned to his son, they became serious once more.
ìWell, Arthur?î
ìWell, dad, what now?î
ìThereís no time to waste, son. Weíve got to start building immediately-underground!î
Arthur snapped into an attentive attitude, ìUnderground!î He frowned his dismay.
ìI know, I know. I said nothing of this previously, but itís got to be done. At all costs we must vanish from the face of the System. There are Earthmen on Venus-purebloods. There arenít many, itís true, but there are some. They mustnít find us-at least, not until we are prepared for whatever may follow. That will take years.î
ìBut father, underground! To live like moles, hidden from light and air. I donít like that.î
ìOh, nonsense. Donít overdramatize. Well live on the surface-but the city; the power-stations, the food and water reserves, the laboratories-all that must be below and impregnable.î
The old Tweenie gestured the subject away with impatience, ìForget that, anyway. I want to talk about something else- something weíve discussed already.î
Arthurís eyes hardened and he shifted his glance to the ceiling. Max rose and placed his bands upon his sonís brawny shoulders.
ìIím past sixty, Arthur. How long I have yet to live, I donít know. In any case, the best of me belongs to the past and it is better that I yield the leadership to a younger, more vigorous person.î
ìDad, thatís sentimental bosh and you know it. There isnít one of us thatís fit to wipe your shoes and no one is going to listen for a second to any plan of appointing a successor while youíre still alive.î
ìIím not going to ask them to listen. Itís done-and youíre the new leader.î
The younger man shook his head firmly, ìYou canít make me serve against my will.î
Max smiled whimsically, ìIím afraid youíre dodging responsibility, son. Youíre leaving your poor old father to the strains and hardships of a job beyond his aged strength.î
ìDad!î came the shocked retort. ìThatís not so. You know it isnít. You-î
ìThen prove it. Look at it this way. Our race needs active leadership, and I canít supply it. Iíll always be here-while I live-to advise you and help you as best I can, but from now on, you must take the initiative.î
Arthur frowned and the words came from him reluctantly, ìAll right, then. I take the job of field commander. But remember, youíre commander-in-chief.î
ìGood! And now letís celebrate the occasion.î Max opened a cupboard and withdrew a box, from which he abstracted a pair of cigars. He sighed, ìThe supply of tobacco is down to the vanishing point and we wonít have any more until we grow our own, but- weíll smoke to the new leader.î
Blue smoke curled upwards and Max frowned through it at his son, ìWhereís Henry?î
Arthur grinned, ìDunno! I havenít seen him since we landed. I can tell you with whom he is, though.î
Max grunted, ìI know that, too.î
ìThe kidís making hay while the sun shines. It wonít be many years now. Dad, before youíll be spoiling a second set of grandchildren.î
ìIf theyíre as good as the three of my first set, I only hope I live to see the day.î
And father and son smiled affectionately at each other and listened in silence to the muted sound of happy laughter from the hundreds of Tweenies outside.
Henry Scanlon cocked his head to one side, and raised his hand for silence, ìDo you hear running water, Irene?î
The girl at his side nodded, ìOver in that direction.î
ìLetís go there, then. A river flashed by just before we landed and maybe thatís it.î
ìAll right, if you say so, but I think we ought to be getting back to the ships.î
ìWhat for?î Henry stopped and stared. ìI should think youíd be glad to stretch your legs after weeks on a crowded ship.î
ìWell, it might be dangerous.î
ìNot here in the highlands, Irene. Venusian highlands are practically a second Earth. You can see this is forest and not jungle. Now if we were in the coastal regions-î He broke off short, as if he had just remembered something. ìBesides, whatís there to be afraid of? Iím with you, arenít I?î And he patted the Tonite gun at his hip.
Irene repressed a sudden smile and shot an arch glance at her strutting companion, ìIím quite aware that youíre with me. Thatís the danger.î
Henryís chest deflated with an audible gasp. He frowned. ì Very funny-And I on my best behavior, too.î He drifted away, brooded sulkily awhile, and then addressed the trees in a distant manner, ìWhich reminds me that tomorrow is Daphneís birthday. Iíve promised her a present.î
ìGet her a reducing belt,î came the quick retort. ìFat thing!î
ìWhoís fat? Daphne? Oh-I wouldnít say so.î He considered matters carefully, one thoughtful eye upon the young girl at his side. ìNow my description of her would be-shall we say-ípleasingly plump,í or, maybe, ëcomfortably upholstered.í ì
ìSheís fat ,î Ireneís voice was suddenly a hiss, and something very like a frown wrinkled her lovely face, ìand her eyes are green.î She swung on ahead, chin high, and superbly conscious of her own little figure.
Henry hastened his steps and caught up, ìOf course, I prefer skinny girls any day.
Irene whirled on him and her little fists clenched, ìIím not skinny, you incredibly stupid ape.î
ìBut Irene, who said I meant you?î His voice was solemn, but his eyes were laughing,
The girl reddened to the ears and turned away, lower lip trembling. The smile faded from Henryís eyes and was replaced by a look of concern. His arm shot out hesitantly and slipped about her shoulder.
ìAngry, Irene?î
The smile that lit her face of a sudden was as brilliant as the sparkling sheen of her silvery hair in the bright sun.
ìNo,î she said.
Their eyes met and, for a moment, Henry hesitated-and found that he who hesitates is lost; for with a sudden twist and a smothered laugh, Irene was free once more.
Pointing through a break in the trees, she cried, ìLook, a lake!î and was off at a run.
Henry scowled, muttered something under his breath, and ran after.
The scene was truly Earthly. A rapids-broken stream wound its way through banks of slender-trunked trees and then spread into a placid lake some miles in width. The brooding quiet was unbroken save by the muffled beat that issued from the throat-bags of the frilled lizards that nested in the upper reaches of the trees.
The two Tweenies-boy and girl-stood hand in hand upon the bank and drank in the beauty of the scene.
Then there was a muffled splash near by and Irene shrank into the encircling arms of her companion.
ìWhatís the matter?î
ìN-nothing. Something moved in the water, I think.î
ìOh, imagination, Irene.î
ìNo. I did see something. It came up and-oh, goodness, Henry, donít squeeze so tightly-î
She almost lost her balance as Henry suddenly dropped her altogether and jerked at his Tonite gun.
Immediately before them, a dripping green head lifted out of the water and regarded them out of wide-set, staring goggle-eyes. Its broad lipless mouth opened and closed rapidly, but not a sound issued forth.
Max Scanlon stared thoughtfully at the rugged foot-hills ahead and clasped his hands behind his back.
ìYou think so, do you?î
ìCertainly, Dad,î insisted Arthur, enthusiastically. ìIf we burrow under these piles of granite, all Earth couldnít get at us. It wouldnít take two months to form the entire cavern, with our unlimited power.î
ìHmph! It will require care!î
ìIt will get it!î
ìMountainous regions are quake regions.î
ìWe can rig up enough stat-rays to hold up all Venus, quakes or no quakes.î
ìStat-rays eat up energy wholesale, and a breakdown that will leave us energyless would mean the end.î
ìWe can hook up five separate power-houses,-as foolproof as we can make them. All five wonít break down at once.î
The old Tweenie smiled, ìAll right, son. I see youíve got it planned thoroughly. Go ahead! Start whenever you want-and remember, itís all up to you.î
ìGood! Letís get back to the ships.î They picked their way gingerly down the rocky, slope.
ìYou know, Arthur,î said Max, stopping suddenly, ìIíve been thinking about those stat-beams.î
ìYes?î Arthur offered his arm, and the two resumed their walk.
ìItís occurred to me that if we could make them two-dimensional in extent and curve them, weíd have the perfect defense, as long as our energy lasted-a stat-field.î
ìYou need four-dimensional radiation for that. Dad-nice to think about but canít be done.î
ìOh, is that so? Well, listen to this-î
What Arthur was to listen to remained hidden, however- for that day at least. A piercing shout ahead jerked both their heads upward. Up towards them came the bounding form of Henry Scanlon, and following him, at a goodly distance and a much more leisurely pace, came Irene.
ìSay, Dad, I had a devil of a time finding you. Where were you?î
ìRight here, son. Where were you?î
ìOh, just around. Listen, Dad. You know those amphibians the explorers talk about as inhabiting the highland lakes of Venus, donít you? Well, weíve located them, lots of them, a regular convoy of them. Havenít we, Irene?î
Irene paused to catch her breath and nodded her head, ìTheyíre the cutest things, Mr. Scanlon. All green.î She wrinkled her nose laughingly.
Arthur and his father exchanged glances of doubt. The former shrugged. ìAre you sure you havenít been seeing things? I remember once. Henry, when you sighted a meteor in space, scared us all to death, and then had it turn out to be your own reflection in the port glass.î
Henry, painfully aware of Ireneís snicker, thrust out a belligerent lower lip, ìSay, Art, I guess youíre looking for a shove in the face. And Iím old enough to give it to you, too.î
ìWhoa there, quiet down,î came the peremptory voice of the elder Scanlon, ìand you, Arthur, had better leam to respect your younger brotherís dignity. Now here. Henry, all Arthur meant was that these amphibians are as shy as rabbits. No oneís ever caught more than a glimpse of them.î
ìWell, we have. Dad. Lots of them. I guess they were attracted by Irene. No one can resist her.î
ìI know you canít,î and Arthur laughed loudly.
Henry stiffened once more, but his father stepped between. ìGrow up, you two. Letís go and see these amphibians.î
ìThis is amazing,î exclaimed Max Scanlon. ìWhy, theyíre as friendly as children. I canít understand it.î
Arthur-shook his head, ìNeither can I, Dad. In fifty years, no explorer has ever gotten a good look at one, and here they are-thick as flies.î
Henry was throwing pebbles into the lake. ìWatch this, all of you.î
A pebble curved its way into the water, and as it splashed six green forms turned a back somersault and slid smoothly below the surface. With no time for a breath between, one was up again and the pebble arced back to fall at Henryís feet.
The amphibians were crowding closer in ever increasing numbers now, approaching the very edge of the lake, where they grasped at the coarse reeds on the bank and stared goggle-eyed at the Tweenies. Their muscular webbed, legs could be seen below the surface of the water, moving back and forth with lazy grace. Without cessation, the lipless mouths opened and closed in a queer, uneven rhythm.
ìI think theyíre talking, Mr. Scanlon,î said Irene, suddenly.
ìItís quite possible,î agreed the old Tweenie, thoughtfully. ìTheir brain-cases are fairly large, and they may possess considerable intelligence. If their voice boxes and ears are tuned to sound waves of higher or lower range than our own, we would be unable to hear them-and that might very well explain their soundlessness.î
ìTheyíre probably discussing us as busily as we are them,î said Arthur.
ìYes, and wondering what sort of freaks we are,î added Irene.
Henry said nothing. He was approaching the edge of the lake with cautious steps. The ground grew muddy beneath his feet, and the reeds thick. The group of amphibians nearest turned anxious eyes toward him, and one or two loosened their hold and slipped silently away.
But the nearest held his ground. His wide mouth was clamped tight; his eyes were wary-but he did not move.
Henry, paused, hesitated, and then held out his hand, ìHiya, Phib!î
The ìPhibî stared at the outstretched hand. Very cautiously, his own webbed forelimb stretched out and touched the Tweenieís fingers. With a jerk, they were drawn back, and the Phibís mouth worked in soundless excitement.
ìBe careful,î came Maxís voice from behind. ìYouíll scare him that way. His skin is terribly sensitive and dry objects must irritate him. Dip your hand in the water.î
Slowly, Henry obeyed. The Phibís muscles tensed to escape at the slightest sudden motion, but none came. Again the Tweenieís hand was held out, dripping wet this time.
For a long minute, nothing happened, as the Phib seemed to debate within itself the future course of action. And then, after two false starts and hasty withdrawals, fingers touched again.
ìAtaphib,î said Henry, and clasped the green hand in his own.
A single, startled jerk followed and then a lusty return of pressure to an extent that numbed the Tweenieís fingers. Evidently encouraged by the first Phibís example, his fellows were crowding close now, offering hosts of hands.
The other three Tweenies slushed up through the mud now, and offered wetted hands in their turn.
ìThatís funny,î said Irene. ìEverytime I shake hands I seem to keep thinking of hair.î
Max turned to her, ìHair?î
ìYes, ours. I get a picture of long, white hair, standing straight up and shining in the sun.î Her hand rose unconsciously to her own smooth tresses.
ìSay!î interrupted Henry suddenly, ìIíve been noticing that, too, now that you mention it. Only when I shake hands, though.î
ìHow about you, Arthur?î asked Max.
Arthur nodded once, his eyebrows climbing.
Max smiled and pounded fist into palm. ìWhy, itís a primitive sort of telepathy-too weak to work without physical contact and even then capable of delivering only a few simple ideas.î
ìBut why hair, dad?î asked Arthur.
ìMaybe itís our hair that attracted them in the first place. Theyíve never seen anything like it and-and-well, who can explain their psychology?î
He was down on his knees suddenly, splashing water over his high crest of hair. There was a frothing of water and a surging of green bodies as the Phibs pressed closer. One green paw passed gently through the stiff white crest, followed by excited, if noiseless, chattering. Struggling amongst themselves for favored vantage-points, they competed for the privilege of touching the hair until Max, for sheer weariness, was forced to rise again.
ìTheyíre probably our friends for life now,î he said. ìA pretty queer set of animals.î
It was Irene, then, who noticed the group of Phib? a hundred yards from shore. They paddled quietly, making no effort to approach closer, ìWhy donít they come?î she asked.
She turned to one of the foremost Phibs and pointed, making frantic gestures of dubious meaning. She received only solemn stares in return.
ìThatís not the way, Irene,î admonished Max, gently. He 229 held out his hand, grasped that of a willing Phib and stood motionless for a moment. When he loosed his grip, the Phib slid into the water and disappeared. In a moment, the laggard Phibs were approaching shore slowly.
ìHow did you do it?î gasped Irene.
ìTelepathy! I held on tightly and pictured an isolated group of Phibs and a long hand stretching out over the water to shake theirs.î He smiled gently, ìThey are quite intelligent, or they would not have understood so readily.î
ìWhy, theyíre females,î cried Arthur, in sudden breathless astonishment ìBy all thatís holy,-they suckle their young!î
The newcomers were slenderer and lighter in color than the others. They advanced shyly, urged on by the bolder males and held out timid hands in greeting.
ìOh-h,î Irene cried in sudden delight. ìLook at this!î
She was down on her knees in the mud, arms outstretched to the nearest female. The other three watched in fascinated silence as the nervous she-Phib clasped its tiny armful closer to its breast.
But Ireneís arms made little inviting gestures, ìPlease, please. Itís so cute. I wonít hurt him.î
Whether the Phib mother understood is doubtful, but with a sudden motion, she held out a little green bundle of squirming life and deposited it in the waiting arms.
Irene rose, squealing with delight. Little webbed feet kicked aimlessly and round frightened eyes stared at her. The other three crowded close and watched it curiously.
ìIts the dearest little thing, it is. Look at its funny little mouth. Do you want to hold it. Henry?î
Henry jumped backwards as if stung, ìNot on your life! Iíd probably drop it.î
ìDo you get any thought images, Irene?í asked Max, thoughtfully.
Irene considered and frowned her concentration, ìNo-o. Itís too young, mayb-oh, yes! Itís-itís-î She stopped, and tried to laugh. ìItís hungry! î
She returned the little baby Phib to its mother, whose muscular arms clasped the little mite close. The tiny Phib swiveled its little green head to bend one last goggling look at the creature that had held it for an instant.
ìFriendly creatures,î said Max, ìand intelligent. They can keep their lakes and rivers. Weíll take the land and wonít interfere with them.î
A lone Tweenie stood on Scanlon Ridge and his field-glass pointed at the Divide ten miles up the hills. For five minutes, the glass did not waver and the Tweenie stood like some watchful statue made of the same rock as formed the mountains all about.
And then the field-glass lowered, and the Tweenieís face was a pale thin-lipped picture of gloom. He hastened down the slope to the guarded, hidden entrance to Venustown.
He shot past the guards without a word and descended into the lower levels where solid rock was still being puffed into nothingness and shaped at will by controlled blasts of super-energy.
Arthur Scanlon looked up and with a sudden premonition of disaster, gestured the Disintegrators to a halt.
ìWhatís wrong, Sorrell?î
The Tweenie leant over and whispered a single word into Arthurís ear.
ìWhere?î Arthurís voice jerked out hoarsely.
ìOn the other side of the ridge. Theyíre coming through the Divide now in our direction. I spotted the blaze of sun on metal and-î he held up his field-glass significantly.
ìGood Lord!î Arthur rubbed his forehead distractedly and then turned to the anxiously-watching Tweenie at the controls of the Disinto. ìContinue as planned! No change!î
He hurried up the levels to the entrance, and snapped out hurried orders, ìTriple the guard immediately. No one but me or those with me, are to be permitted to leave. Send out men to round up any stragglers outside immediately and order them to keep within shelter and make no unnecessary sound.î
Then, back again through the central avenue to his fatherís quarters.
Max Scanlon looked up from his calculations and his grave forehead smoothed out slowly.
ìHello, son. Is anything wrong? Another resistant stratum?î
ìNo, nothing like that.î Arthur closed the door carefully and lowered his voice. ìEarthmen!î
For a moment. Max made no movement. The expression on his face froze for an instant, and then, with a sudden exhalation, he slumped in his chair and the lines in his forehead deepened wearily.
ìSettlers?î
ìLooks so. Sorrell said women and children were among them. There were several hundred in all, equipped for a stay-and headed in this direction.î
Max groaned, ìOh, the luck, the luck! All the vast empty spaces of Venus to choose and they come here. Come, letís get a firsthand look at this.î
