They came through the Divide in a long, snaky line. Hard-bitten pioneers with their pinched work-worn women and their carefree, half-barbarous, wilderness-bred children. The low, broad ìVenus Vansî joggled clumsily over the untrodden ways, loaded down with amorphous masses of household necessities.
The leaders surveyed the prospect and one spoke in clipped, jerky syllables, ìAlmost through, Jem. Weíre out among the foothills now.î
And the other replied slowly, ìAnd thereís good new growing-land ahead. We can stake out farms and settle down.î He sighed, ìItís been tough going this last month. Iím glad itís over!î
And from a ridge ahead-the last ridge before the valley-the Scanlons, father and son, unseen dots in the distance, watched the newcomers with heavy hearts.
ìThe one thing we could not prepare for-and itís happened.î
Arthur spoke slowly and reluctantly, ìThey are few and unarmed. We can drive them out in an hour.î With sudden fierceness, ìVenus is ours!î
ìYes, we can drive them out in an hour-in ten minutes. But they would return, in thousands, and armed. Weíre not ready to fight all Earth, Arthur.î
The younger man bit his lip and words were muttered forth half in shame, ìFor the sake of the race. Father-we could kill them all.î
ìNever!î exclaimed Max, his old eyes flashing. ìWe will not be the first to strike. If we kill, we can expect no mercy from Earth; and we will deserve none,î
ìBut, father, what else? We can expect no mercy from Earth as it is. If weíre spotted,-if they ever suspect our existence, our whole hegira becomes pointless and we lose out at the very beginning.î
ìI know. I know.î
ìWe canít change now,î continued Arthur, passionately. ìWeíve spent months preparing Venustown. How could we start over?î
ìWe canít,î agreed Max, tonelessly. ìTo even attempt to move would mean sure discovery. We can only-î
ìLive like moles after all. Hunted fugitives! Frightened refugees! Is that it?î
ìPut it any way you like-but we must hide, Arthur, and bury ourselves.î
ìUntil-?î
ìUntil I-or we-perfect a curved two-dimensional statbeam. Surrounded by an impermeable defense, we can come out into the open. It may take years; it may take one week. I donít know.î
ìAnd every day we run the risk of detection. Any day the swarms of purebloods can come down upon us and wipe us out. Weíve got to hang by a hair day after day, week after week, month after month-î
ìWeíve got to.î Maxís mouth was clamped shut, and his eyes were a frosty blue.
Slowly, they went back to Venustown.
Things were quiet in Venustown, and eyes were turned to the top-most level and the hidden exits. Out there was air and the sun and space-and Earthmen.
They had settled several miles up the river-bed. Their rude houses were springing up. Surrounding land was being cleared. Farms were being staked out. Planting was taking place.
And in the bowels of Venus, eleven hundred Tweenies shaped their home and waited for an old man to track down the elusive equations that would enable a stat-ray to spread in two dimensions and curve.
Irene brooded somberly as she sat upon the rocky ledge and stared ahead to where the dim gray light indicated the existence of an exit to the open. Her shapely legs swung gently back and forth and Henry Scanlon, at her side, fought desperately to keep his gaze focussed harmlessly upon air.
ìYou know what. Henry?î
ìWhat?î
ìIíll bet the Phibs could help us.î
ìHelp us do what, Irene?î
ìHelp us get rid of the Earthmen.î
Henry thought it over carefully, ìWhat makes you think that?î
ìWell, theyíre pretty clever-cleverer than we think. Their minds are altogether different, though, and maybe they could fix it. Besides-Iíve just got a feeling.î She withdrew her hand suddenly, ìYou donít have to hold it. Henry.î
Henry swallowed, ìI-I thought you had a sort of unsteady seat there-might fall, you know.î
ìOh!î Irene looked down the terrific three-foot drop. ëThereís something in what you say. It does look pretty high here.î
Henry decided he was in the presence of a hint, and acted accordingly. There was a momentís silence while he seriously considered the possibility of her feeling a bit chilly-but before he had quite decided that she probably was, she spoke again,
ìWhat I was going to say, Henry, was this. Why donít we go out and see the Phibs?î
ìDad would take my head off if I tried anything like that.î
ìIt would be a lot of fun.î
ìSure, but itís dangerous. We canít risk anyone seeing us.î
Irene shrugged resignedly, ìWell, if youíre afraid, weíll say no more about it.î
Henry gasped and reddened. He was off the ledge in a bound, ìWhoís afraid? When do you want to go?î
ìRight now, Henry. Right this very minute.î Her cheeks flushed with enthusiasm.
ìAll right then. Come on.î He started off at a half-run, dragging her along.-And then a thought occurred to him and he stopped short.
He turned to her fiercely, ì Iíll show you if Iím afraid.î His arms were suddenly about her and her little cry of surprise was muffled effectively.
ìGoodness,î said Irene, when in a position to speak once more. ìHow thoroughly brutal! î
ìCertainly. Iím a very well-known brute,î gasped Henry, as he uncrossed his eyes and got rid of the swimming sensation in his head. ìNow letís get to those Phibs; and remind me, when Iím president, to put up a memorial to the fellow who invented kissing.î
Up through the rock-lined corridor, past the backs of outward-gazing sentries, out through the carefully camouflaged opening, and they were upon the surface.
The smudge of smoke on the southern horizon was grim evidence of the presence of man, and with that in mind, the two young Tweenies slithered through the underbrush into the forest and through the forest to the lake of the Phibs.
Whether in some strange way of their own the Phibs sensed the presence of friends, the two could not tell, but they had scarcely reached the banks when approaching dull-green smudges beneath water told of the creaturesí coming.
A wide, goggle-eyed head broke the surface, and, in a second, bobbing frogheads dotted the lake.
Henry wet his hand and seized the friendly forelimb outstretched to him.
ìHi there, Phib.î
The grinning mouth worked and made its soundless answer.
ìAsk him about the Earthmen, Henry,î urged Irene. Henry motioned impatiently.
ìWait a while. It takes time. Iím doing the best I can.î
For two slow minutes, the two, Tweenie and Phib, remained motionless and stared into each otherís eyes. And then the Phib broke away and, at some silent order, every lake-creature vanished, leaving the Tweenies alone.
Irene stared for a moment, nonplussed, ìWhat happened?î
Henry shrugged, ìI donít know. I pictured the Earthmen and he seemed to know who I meant. Then I pictured Earthmen fighting us and killing us-and he pictured a lot of us and only a few of them and another fight in which we killed them. But then I pictured us killing them and then a lot more of them coming-hordes and hordes-and killing us and then-î
But the girl was holding her hands to her tortured ears, ìOh, my goodness. No wonder the poor creature didnít understand. I wonder he didnít go crazy.î
ìWell, I did the best I could,î was the gloomy response. ìThis was all your nutty idea, anyway.î
Irene got no further with her retort than the opening syllable, for in a moment the lake was crowded with Phibs once more. ìTheyíve come back,î she said instead.
A Phib pushed forward and seized Henryís hand while the others crowded around in great excitement. There were several moments of silence and Irene fidgeted.
ìWell?î she said.
ìQuiet, please. I donít get it. Something about big animals, or monsters, or-î His voice trailed away, and the furrow between his eyes deepened into painful concentration.
He nodded, first abstractedly, then vigorously.
He broke away and seized Ireneís hands. ìIíve got it-and itís the perfect solution. We can save Venustown all by ourselves, Irene, with the help of the Phibs-if you want to come to the Lowlands with me tomorrow. We can take along a pair of Tonite pistols and food supplies and if we follow the river, it oughtnít to take us more than two or three days there and the same time back. What do you say, Irene?î
Youth is not noted for forethought. Ireneís hesitation was for effect only, ìWell-maybe we shouldnít go ourselves, but -but Iíll go-with you.î There was the lightest accent on the last word.
Ten seconds later, the two were on their way back to Venustown, and Henry was wondering, if on the whole, it werenít better to put up two memorials to the fellow who invented kissing.
The flickering red-yellow of the fire sent back ruddy highlights from Henryís lordly crest of hair and cast shifting shadows upon his brooding face.
It was hot in the Lowlands, and the fire made it worse, yet Henry huddled close and kept an anxious eye upon the sleeping form of Irene on the other side. The teeming life of the Venusian jungle respected fire, and the flames spelt safety.
They were three days from the plateau now. The stream had become a lukewarm, slowly-moving river, the shores of which were covered with the green scum of algae. The pleasant forests had given way to the tangled, vine-looped growths of the jungle. The mingled sounds of life had grown in volume and increased to a noisy crescendo. The air became warmer and damper; the ground swampier; the surroundings more fantastically unfamiliar.
And yet there was no real danger-of that, Henry was convinced. Poisonous life was unknown on Venus, and as for the tough-skinned monsters that lorded the jungles, the fire at night and the Phibs during day would keep them away.
Twice the ear-splitting shriek of a Centosaur had sounded in the distance and twice the sound of crashing trees had caused the two Tweenies to draw together in fear. Both times, ëI the monsters had moved away again. ï
This was the third night out, and Henry stirred uneasily. The Phibs seemed confident that before morning they could start their return trip, and somehow the thought of Venustown was rather attractive. Adventure and excitement are fine and with every passing hour the glory of his scintillating bravery grew in Ireneís eyes-which was wonderful-but still Venustown and the friendly Highlands were nice to think about.
He threw himself on his stomach and gazed morosely into the fire, thinking of his twenty years of age-almost twenty years.
ìWhy, heck,î he tore at the rank grass beneath. ìItís about time I was thinking of getting married .î And his eye strayed involuntarily to the sleeping form beyond the fire.
As if in response, there was a flickering of eyelids and a vague stare out of deep blue eyes.
Irene sat up and stretched.
ìI canít sleep at all,î she complained, brushing futilely at her white hair. ìItís so hotî She stared at the fire distastefully.
Henryís good humor persisted. ìYou slept for hours-and snored like a trombone.î
Ireneís eyes snapped wide open. ìI did not!î Then, with a voice vibrant with tragedy, ìDid I?î
ìNo, of course not!î Henry howled his laughter, stopping only at the sudden, sharp contact between the toe of Ireneís shoe and the pit of his own stomach. ìOuch,î he said.
ìDonít speak to me anymore. Mister Scanlon!î was the girlís frigid remark.
It was Henryís turn to look tragic. He rose in panicky dismay and took a single step towards the girl. And then he froze in his tracks at the ear-piercing shriek of a Centosaur. When he came to himself, he found his arms full of Irene.
Reddening, she disentangled herself, and then the Centosaurian shriek sounded again, from another direction,-and there she was, right back again.
Henryís face was pale, in spite of his fair armful. ìI think the Phibs have snared the Centosaurs. Come with me and Iíll ask them.î
The Phibs were dim blotches in the grey dawn that was breaking. Rows and rows of strained, abstracted individuals were all that met the eye. Only one seemed to be unoccupied and when Henry rose from the handclasp, he said, ìTheyíve got three Centosaurs and thatís all they can handle. Weíre starting back to the Highlands right now.î
The rising sun found the party two miles up the river. The Tweenies, hugging the shore, cast wary eyes towards the bordering jungle. Through an occasional clearing, vast grey bulks could be made out The noise of the reptilian shrieks was almost continuous.
ìIím sorry I brought you, Irene,î said Henry. ìIím not so sure now that the Phibs can take care of the monsters.î
Irene shook her head. ìThatís all right, Henry. I wanted to come. Only-I wish we had thought of letting the Phibs bring the beasts themselves. They donít need us.î
ìYes, they do! If a Centosaur gets out of control, it will make straight for the Tweenies and theyíd never get away. Weíve got the Tonite guns to kill the ësaurs with if the worst comes to the worst-î His voice trailed away and he glanced at the lethal weapon in his hand and derived but cold comfort therefrom.
The first night was sleepless for both Tweenies. Somewhere, unseen in the blackness of the river, Phibs took shifts and their telepathic control over the tiny brains of the gigantic, twenty-legged Centosaurs maintained its tenuous hold. Off in the jungle, three hundred-ton monsters howled impatiently against the force that drove them up the river side against their will and raved impotently against the unseen barrier that prevented them from approaching the stream.
By the side of the fire, a pair of Tweenies, lost between mountainous flesh on one side and the fragile protection of a telepathic web on the other, gazed longingly towards the Highlands some forty miles off.
Progress was slow. As the Phibs tired, the Centosaurs grew balkier. But gradually, the air grew cooler. The rank jungle growth thinned out and the distance to Venustown shortened.
Henry greeted the first signs of familiar temperate-zone forest with a tremulous sigh of relief. Only Ireneís presence prevented him from discarding his role of heroism.
He felt pitifully eager for their quixotic journey to be over, but he only said, ìItís practically all over but the shouting. And you can bet thereíll be shouting, Irene. Weíll be heroes, you and I.î
Ireneís attempt at enthusiasm was feeble. ìIím tired. Henry. Letís rest.î She sank slowly to the ground, and Henry, after signalling the Phibs, joined her.
ìHow much longer, Henry?î Almost without volition, she found her head nestling wearily against his shoulder.
ìOne more day, Irene. Tomorrow this time, weíll be back.î He looked wretched, ìYou think we shouldnít have tried to do this ourselves, donít you?î
ìWell, it seemed a good idea at the time.î
ìYes, I know,î said Henry. ìIíve noticed that I get lots of ideas that seem good at the time, but sometimes they turn sour.î He shook his head philosophically, ìI donít know why, but thatís the way it is.î
ìAll I know,î said Irene, ìis that I donít care if I never move another step in my life. I wouldnít get up now-î
Her voice died away as her beautiful blue eyes stared off towards the right. One of the Centosaurs stumbled into the waters of a small, tributary to the stream they were following. Wallowing in the water, his huge serpentine body mounted on the ten stocky pairs of legs, glistened horribly. His ugly head weaved towards the sky and his terrifying call pierced the air. A second joined him.
Irene was on her feet. ìWhat are you waiting for. Henry. Letís go! Hurry!î
Henry gripped his Tonite gun tightly and followed.
Arthur Scanlon gulped savagely at his fifth cup of black coffee and, with an effort, brought the Audiomitter into optical focus. His eyes, he decided, were becoming entirely too balky. He rubbed them into red-rimmed irritation and cast a glance over his shoulder at the restlessly sleeping figure on the couch.
He crept over to her, and adjusted the coverlet.
ìPoor Mom,î he whispered, and bent to kiss the pale lips.
He turned to the Audiomitter and clenched a fist at it, ìWait till I get you, you crazy nutî
Madeline stirred, ìIs it dark yet?î
ìNo,î lied Arthur with feeble cheerfulness. ìHell call before sundown. Mom. You just sleep and let me take care of things. Dadís upstairs working on the stat-field and he says heís making progress. In a few days everything will be all right.î He sat silently beside her and grasped her band tightly. Her tired eyes closed once more.
The signal light blinked on and, with a last look at his mother, he stepped out into the corridor, ìWell!î
The waiting Tweenie saluted smartly, ìJohn Barno wants to say that it looks as if we are in for a storm.î He handed over an official report.
Arthur glanced at it peevishly, ìWhat of that? Weíve had plenty so far, havenít we? What do you expect of Venus?î
ìThis will be a particularly bad one, from all indications. The barometer has fallen unprecedentedly. The ionic concentration of the upper atmosphere is at an unequalled maximum. The Beulah River has overflowed its banks and is rising rapidly.î
The other frowned, ìThereís not an entrance to Venustown that isnít at least fifty yards above river level. As for rain- our drainage system is to be relied upon.î He grimaced suddenly. ìGo back and tell Barno that it can storm for my part -for forty days and forty nights if it wants to. Maybe it will drive the Earthmen away.î
He turned away, but the Tweenie held his ground, ìBeg pardon sir, but thatís not the worst. A scouting party today-î
Arthur whirled. ìA scouting party? Who ordered one to be sent out?î
ìYour father, sir. They were to make contact with the Phibs,-I donít know why.î
ìWell, go on.î
ìSir, the Phibs could not be located.î
And now, for the first time, Arthur was startled out of his savage ill-humor, ëThey were gone?î
The Tweenie nodded, ìIt is thought that they have sought shelter from the coming storm. It is that which causes Barno to fear the worst.î
ìThey say rats desert a sinking ship,î murmured Arthur. He buried his head in trembling hands. ìGodi Everything at once! Everything at once!î
The darkening twilight hid the pall of blackness that lowered over the mountains ahead and emphasized the darting flashes of lightning that flickered on and off continuously.
Irene shivered, ìItís getting sort of windy and chilly, isnít it?î
ìThe cold wind from the mountains. Weíre in for a storm, I guess,î Henry assented absently. ìI think the river is getting wider.î
A short silence, and then, with sudden vivacity, ìBut look, Irene, only a few more miles to the lake and then weíre practically at the Earth village. Itís almost over.î
Irene nodded, ìIím glad for all of us-and the Phibs, too.î
She had reason for the last statement. The Phibs were swimming slowly now. An additional detachment had arrived the day before from upstream, but even with those reinforcements, progress had slowed to a walk. Unaccustomed cold was nipping the multi-legged reptiles and they yielded to superior mental force more and more reluctantly.
The first drops fell just after they had passed the lake. Darkness had fallen, and in the blue glare of the lightning the trees about them were ghostly specters reaching swaying fingers towards the sky. A sudden flare in the distance marked the funeral pyre of a lightning-hit tree.
Henry paled. ìMake for the clearing just ahead. At a time like this, trees are dangerous.î
The clearing he spoke of composed the outskirts of the Earth village. The rough-hewn houses, crude and small against the fury of the elements, showed lights here and there that spoke of human occupancy. And as the first Centosaur stumbled out from between splintered trees, the storm suddenly burst in all its fury.
The two Tweenies huddled close. ìItís up to the Phibs,î screamed Henry, dimly heard above the wind and rain. ìI hope they can do it.î
The three monsters converged upon the houses ahead. They moved more rapidly as the Phibs called up every last bit of mental power.
Irene buried her wet head in Henryís equally wet shoulder, ìI canít look! Those houses will go like matchsticks. Oh, the poor people!î
ìNo, Irene, no. Theyíve stopped!î
The Centosaurs pawed vicious gouges out of the ground beneath and their screams rang shrill and clear above the noise of the storm. Startled Earthmen rushed from their cabins.
Caught unprepared-most having been roused from sleep -and faced with a Venusian storm and nightmarish Venusian monsters, there was no question of organized action. As they stood, carrying nothing but their clothes, they broke and ran.
There was the utmost confusion. One or two, with dim attempts at presence of mind, took wild, ineffectual pot-shots at the mountains of flesh before them-and then ran.
And when it seemed that all were gone, the giant reptiles surged forward once more and where once had been houses, there were left only mashed splinters.
ìTheyíll never come back, Irene, theyíll never come back.î Henry was breathless at the success of his plan. ìWeíre heroes now, and-î His voice rose to a hoarse shriek, ìIrene, get back! Make for the trees!î
The Centosaurian howls had taken on a deeper note. The nearest one reared onto his two hindmost pairs of legs and his great head, two hundred feet above ground, was silhouetted horribly against the lightning. With a rumbling thud, he came down on all feet again and made for the river-which under the lash of the storm was now a raging flood.
The Phibs had lost control!
Henryís Tonite gun flashed into quick action as he shoved Irene away. She, however, backed away slowly and brought her own gun into line.
The ball of purple light that meant a hit blazed into being and the nearest Centosaur screamed in agony as its mighty tail threshed aside the surrounding trees. Blindly, the hole where once a leg had been gushing blood, it charged.
A second glare of purple and it was down with an earthshaking thud, its last shriek reaching a crescendo of shrill frightfulness.
But the other two monsters were crashing towards them. They blundered blindly towards the source of the power that, had held them captive almost a week; driving violently with all the force of their mindless hate to the river. And in the path of the Juggernauts were the two Tweenies.
The boiling torrent was at their backs. The forest was a groaning wilderness of splintered trees and ear-splitting sound.
Then, suddenly, the reports of Tonite guns sounded from the distance. Purple glares-a flurry of threshing-spasmodic shrieking-and then a silence in which even the wind, as if overawed by recent events, held its peace momentarily.
Henry yelled his glee and performed an impromptu war-dance. ìTheyíve come from Venustown, Irene,î he shouted. ëTheyíve got the Centosaurs and everythingís finished! Weíve saved the Tweenies!î
It happened in a breathís time. Irene had dropped her gun and sobbed her relief. She was running to Henry and then she tripped-and the river had her.
ìHenry!î The wind whipped the sound away.
For one dreadful moment. Henry found himself incapable of motion. He could only stare stupidly, unbelievingly, at the spot where Irene had been, and then he was in the water. He plunged into the surrounding blackness desperately.
ìIrene!î He caught his breath with difficulty. The current drove him on.
ì Irene! î No sound but the wind. His efforts at swimming were futile. He couldnít even break surface for more than a second at a time, his lungs were bursting.
ì Irene! î There was no answer. -Nothing but rushing water and darkness.
And then something touched him. He lashed out at it instinctively, but the grip tightened. He felt himself borne up into the air. His tortured lungs breathed in gasps. A grinning Phib face stared into his and after that there were nothing but confused impressions of cold, dark wetness.
He became aware of his surroundings by stages. First, that he was sitting on a blanket under the trees, with other blankets wrapped tightly about him. Then, he felt the warm radiation of the heatlamps upon him and the illumination of Atomo bulbs. People were crowding close and he noticed that it was no longer raining.
He stared about him hazily and then, ìIrene!î
She was beside him, as wrapped up as he, and smiling feebly, ìIím all right, Henry. The Phibs dragged me back, too.î
Madeline was bending over him and he swallowed the hot coffee placed to his lips. ìThe Phibs have told us of what you two have helped them do. Weíre all proud of you, son-you and Irene.î
Maxís smile transfigured his face into the picture of paternal pride, ìThe psychology you used was perfect. Venus is too vast and has too many friendly areas to expect Earthmen to return to places that have shown themselves to be infested with Centosaurs-not for a good long while. And when they do come back, we shall have our stat-field.î
Arthur Scanlon hurried up out of the gloom. He thwacked Henry on the shoulder and then wrung Ireneís hand. ìYour guardian and I,î he told her, ìare fixing up a celebration for day after tomorrow, so get good and rested. Itís going to be the greatest thing you ever saw.î
Henry spoke lip, ìCelebration, huh? Well, Iíll tell you what you can do. After itís over, you can announce an engagementî
ìAn engagement?î Madeline sat up and looked interested. ìWhat do you mean?î
ìAn engagement-to be married,î came the impatient answer. ìIím old enough, I suppose. Today proves it!î
Ireneís eyes bent in furious concentration upon the grass, ìWith whom. Henry?î
ìHuh? With you , of course. Gosh, who else could it be?î
ìBut you havenít asked me.î The words were uttered slowly and with great firmness.
For a moment Henry flushed, and then his jaws grew grim, ìWell, Iím not going to. Iím telling you! And what are you going to do about it?î
He leaned close to her and Max Scanlon chuckled and motioned the others away. On tip-toes, they left.
A dim shape hobbled into view and the two Tweenies separated in confusion. They had forgotten the others.
But it wasnít another Tweenie. ìWhy-why, itís a Phib!î cried Irene.
He limped his ungainly way across the wet grass, with the inexpert aid of his muscular arms. Approaching, he flopped wearily on his stomach and extended his forearms.
His purpose was plain. Irene and Henry grasped a hand apiece. There was silence a moment or two and the Phibís great eyes glinted solemnly in the light of the Atomo lamps. Then there was a sudden squeal of embarrassment from Irene and shy laugh from Henry. Contact was broken.
ìDid you get the same thing I did?î asked Henry.
Irene was red, ìYes, a long row of little baby Phibs, maybe fifteen-î
ìOr twenty,î said Henry.
ì- with long white hear! î

The story, not surprisingly, reflects my personal situation at the time. I had gone to a boysí high school and to a boysí college. Now that I was in graduate school, however, the surroundings were, for the first time, coeducational.
In the fall of 1939, I discovered that a beautiful blond girl had the desk next to mine in the laboratory of my course in synthetic organic chemistry. Naturally I was attracted.
I persuaded her to go out with me on simple dates, the very first being on my twentieth birthday, when I took her to Radio City Music Hall. For five months, I mooned after her with feckless, romanticism.
At the end of the school year, though, she had earned her master of arts degree and, having decided not to go on for her doctorate, left school and took a job in Wilmington, Delaware, leaving me behind, woebegone and stricken.
I got over it, of course, but while she was still at school I wrote ìHalf-Breeds on Venus.î Of all the stories I had yet written, it was the most heavily boy-and-girl. The heroineís name was Irene, which was the name of my pretty blond lab neighbor.
Merely having a few dates on the hand-holding level did not, however, perform the magic required to make me capable of handling passion in literature, and I continued to use girls sparingly in later stories-and a good thing, too, I think.
The success of ìHalf-Breeds on Venusî made the notion of writing sequels generally seem a good idea. A sequel to a successful story must, after all, be a reasonably sure sale. So even while I was working on ìHalf-Breeds on Venus,î I suggested to Campbell that I write a sequel to ìHomo Sol.î
Campbellís enthusiasm was moderate, but he was willing to look at such a sequel if I were to write it. I did write it as soon as ìHalf-Breeds on Venusî was done and called it ìThe Imaginary.î Although it used one of the chief characters of ìHomo Sol,î the human-nonhuman confrontation was absent, which probably didnít help it as far as Campbell was concerned. I submitted it to him on June 11, and received it back-a rejection, sequel or no sequel-on June 19.
Pohl rejected it, too. Tremaine read it with more sympathy and was thinking of taking it for Comet , I heard, but that magazine ceased publication and the story was back on the market. Actually, I retired it, but two years later I sold it to Pohlís magazine after all-but at a time when Pohl was no longer editor.
But though I had my troubles and didnít click every time, or even right away, I did manage to make $272 during my first year as a graduate student, and that was an enormous help.








The Imaginary


The telecaster flashed its fitful signal, while Tan Porus sat by complacently. His sharp, green eyes glittered their triumph, and his tiny body was vibrant with excitement. Nothing could have better indicated the greatness of the occasion than his extraordinary position-Tan Porus had his feet on the desk!
The ëcaster glowed into life and a broad Arcturian countenance frowned fretfully out at the Rigellian psychologist.
ìDo you have to drag me here straight from bed, Porus? Itís the middle of the night!î
ìItís broad daylight in this part of the world. Final. But Iíve got something to tell you thatíll make you forget all about sleep.î
Gar Final, editor of the J.G.P.- Journal of Galactic Psychology -allowed a look of alertness to cross his face. Whatever Tan Porusís faults-and Arcturus knew they were many -he had never issued a false alarm. If he said something great was in the air, it was not merely great-it was colossal!
It was quite evident that Porus was enjoying himself. ìFinal,î he said, ìthe next article I send to your rag is going to be the greatest thing youíve ever printed.î
Final was impressed. ìDo you really mean what you say?î he asked idiotically.
ìWhat kind of a stupid question is that? Of course I do. Listen-î There followed a dramatic silence, while the tenseness on Finalís face reached painful proportions. Then came Porusís husky whisper-îIíve solved the problem of the squid!î
Of course the reaction was exactly what Porus had expected. There was a blow-up at the other end, and for thirty interesting seconds the Rigellian was surprised to learn that the staid and respectable Final had a blistering vocabulary.
Porusís squid was a by-word throughout the galaxy. For two years now, he had been fussing over an obscure Draconian animal that persisted in going to sleep when it wasnít supposed to. He had set up equations and torn them down with a regularity that had become a standing joke with every psychologist in the Federation-and none had explained the unusual reaction. Now Final had been dragged from bed to be told that the solution had been reached-and that was all.
Final ripped out a concluding phrase that all but put the ëcaster out of commission.
Porus waited for the storm to pass and then said calmly, ìBut do you know how I solved it?î
The otherís answer was an indistinct mumble.
The Rigellian began speaking rapidly. All traces of amusement had left his face and, after a few sentences, all traces of anger left Finalís.
The Arcturianís expression became one of wide-eyed interest. ìNo?î he gasped.
ìYes!î
When Porus had finished. Final raced madly to put in rush calls to the printers to delay publication of the coming issue of the J.G.P. for two weeks.
Furo Santins, head of the math department of the University of Arcturus, gazed long and steady at his Sirian colleague.
ìNo, no, youíre wrong! His equations were legitimate. I checked them myself.î
ìMathematically, yes,î retorted the round-faced Sirian. ìBut psychologically they had no meaning.î
Santins slapped his high forehead. ìMeaning! Listen to the mathematician talk. Great space, man, what have mathematics to do with meaning? Mathematics is a tool and as long as it can be manipulated to give proper answers and to make correct predictions, actual meaning has no significance. Iíll say this for Tan Porus-most psychologists donít know enough mathematics to handle a slide-rule efficiently, but he knows his stuff.î
The other nodded doubtfully, ìI guess so. I guess so. But using imaginary quantities in psychological equations stretches my faith in science just a little bit. Square root of minus one!î
He shudderedÖ
The seniorsí lounge in Psychology Hall was crowded and a-buzz with activity. The rumor of Porusís solution to the now-classic problem of the squid had spread fast, and conversation touched on nothing else.
At the center of the thickest group was Lor Haridin. He was young, with but newly acquired Senior status. But as Porusís assistant he was, under present conditions, master of the situation.
ìLook, fellows-just exactly what itís all about I donít know. Thatís the old manís secret. All I can tell you is that Iíve got the general idea as to how he solved it.î
The others squeezed closer. ìI hear he had to make up a new mathematical notation for the squid,î said one, ìlike that time we had trouble with the humanoids of Sol.î
Lor Haridin shook his head. ìWorse! What made him think of it, I canít imagine. It was either a brainstorm or a nightmare, but anyway he introduced imaginary quantities-the square root of minus one.î
There was an awful silence and then someone said, ìI donít believe it!î
ìFact!î was the complacent reply.
ìBut it doesnít make sense. What can the square root of minus one represent, psychologically speaking? Why, that would mean-î he was doing rapid calculation in his head, as were most of the others-îthat the neural synapses were hooked up in neither more nor less than four dimensions!î
ìSure,î broke in another. ìI suppose that if you stimulate the squid today, it will react yesterday. Thatís what an imaginary would mean. Comet gas! Thatís what I say.î
ìThatís why youíre not the man Tan Porus is,î said Haridin. ìDo you suppose he cares how many imaginaries there are in the intermediate steps if they all square out into minus one in the final solution. All heís interested in is that they give him the proper sign in the answer-an answer which will explain that sleep business. As for its physical significance, what matter? Mathematics is only a tool, anyway.î
The others considered silently and marveled.
Tan Porus sat in his stateroom aboard the newest and most luxurious interstellar liner and gazed at the young man before him happily. He was in amazing good humor and, for perhaps the first time in his life, did not mind being interviewed by the keen, efficient employees of the Ether Press.
The Ethereporter on his side wondered in silence at the affability of the scientist. From bitter experience, he had found out that scientists, as a whole, detested reporters-and that psychologists, in particular, thought it fun to practice a bit of applied psych on them and to induce killingly amusing -to others-reactions.
He remembered the time that the old fellow from Canopus had convinced him that arboreal life was the greatest good. It had taken twenty men to drag him down from the tree-tops and an expert psychologist to bring him back to normal.
But here was the greatest of them all. Tan Porus, actually answering questions like a normal human being.
ìWhat I would like to know now, Professor,î said the reporter, ìis just what this imaginary quantity is all about. That is,î he interposed hastily, ìnot the mathematics of it-weíll take your word on that-but just a general idea that the ordinary humanoid can picture. For instance, Iíve heard that the squid has a four-dimensional mind.î
Porus groaned, ìOh, Rigel! Four-dimensional poppycock! To tell the honest truth, that imaginary I used-which seems to have caught the popular fancy-probably indicates nothing more than some abnormality in the squidís nervous system, but just what, I donít know. Certainly, to the gross methods of ecology and micro-physiology, nothing unusual has been found. No doubt, the answer would lie in the atomic physics of the creatureís brain, but there I have no hope.î There was a trace of disdain in his voice. ìThe atomic physicists are too far behind the psychologists to expect them to catch up at this late date.î
The reporter bore down furiously on his stylus. The next dayís headline was clear in his mind: Noted Psychologist Blasts Atomic Physicists!
Also, the headline of the day after: Indignant Physicists Denounce Noted Psychologist!
Scientific feuds were great stuff for the Ether Press, particularly that between psychologists and physicists, who, it was well known, hated each otherís guts.
The reporter glanced up brightly. ìSay, Professor, the humanoids of the galaxy are very interested, you know, in the private lives of you scientists. I hope you donít mind if I ask you a few questions about your trip home to Rigel IV.î
ìGo ahead,î said Porus, genially. ìTell them itís the first time Iím getting home in two years. Iím sort of looking forward to it. Arcturus is just a bit too yellow for my eyes and the furniture you have here is too big.î
ìItís true, isnít it, that you have a wife at home?î
Porus coughed. ìHmm, yes. Sweetest little woman in the galaxy. Iím looking forward to seeing her, too. Put that down.î
The reporter put it down. ìHow is it you didnít bring her to Arcturus with you?î
Some of the geniality left the Rigellianís face. ìI like to be alone when I work. Women are all right-in their place. Besides, my idea of a vacation is one by myself. Donít put that down.î
The reporter didnít put it down. He gazed at the otherís little form with open admiration. ìSay, Prof, how did you ever get her to stay home, though? I wish youíd tell me the secretî Then, with a wealth of feeling he added, ìI could use it!î
Porus laughed. ìI tell you, son. When youíre an ace psychologist, youíre master in your own home!î
He motioned the interview to an end and then suddenly grasped the other by the arm. His green eyes were piercingly sharp. ìAnd listen, son, that last remark doesnít go into the story, you know.î
The reporter paled and backed away. ìNo, sir; no sir! Weíve got a little saying in our profession that goes: ëNever monkey around with a psychologist, or heíll make a monkey of you .íì
ìGood! I can do it literally, you know, if I have to.î
The young press employee ducked out hastily after that, wiped the cold perspiration from his brow and left with his story. For a moment, towards the last, he had felt himself hanging on the ragged edge. He made a mental note to refuse all future interviews with psychologists-unless they raised his pay.
Tens of billions of miles out, the pure white orb of Rigel had reached Porusís eyes, and something in his heart uplifted him.
Type B reaction-nostalgia; conditioned reflex through association of Rigel with happy scenes of youth-
Words, phrases, equations spun through his keen brain, but he was happy in spite of them. And in a little while, the human triumphed over the psychologist and Porus abandoned analysis for the superior joy of uncritical happiness.
He sat up past the middle of the sleep period two nights before the landing to catch first glimpse of Hanlon, fourth planet of Rigel, his home world. Some place on that world, on the shores of a quiet sea, was a little two-story house. A little house-not those giant structures fit only for Arcturians and other hulking humanoids.
It was the summer season now and the houses would be bathed in the pearly light of Rigel, and after the harsh yellow-red of Arcturus, how restful that would be.
And-he almost shouted in his joy-the very first night he was going to insist on gorging himself with broiled tryptex . He hadnít tasted it for two years, and his wife was the best hand at tryptex in the system.
He winced a little at the thought of his wife. It had been a dirty trick, getting her to stay home the last two years, but it had had to be done. He glanced over the papers before him once more. There was just a little nervousness in his fingers as they shuffled the sheets. He had spent a full day in calculating her reactions at first seeing him after two yearsí absence and they were not pleasant
Nina Porus was a woman of untamed emotions, and he would have to work quickly and efficiently.
He spotted her quickly in the crowd. He smiled. It was nice to see her, even if his equations did predict long and serious storms. He ran over his initial speech once more and made a last-minute change.
And then she saw him. She waved frantically and broke from the forefront of the crowd. She was on Tan Porus before he was aware of it and, in the grip of her affectionate embrace, he went limp with surprise.
That wasnít the reaction to be expected at all! Something was wrong!
She was leading him dexterously through the crowd of reporters to the waiting stratocar, talking rapidly along the way.
ìTan Porus, I thought Iíd never live to see you again. Itís so good to have you with me again; you have absolutely no idea. Everything here at home is just fine, of course, but it isnít quite the same without you.î
Porusís green eyes were glazed. This speech was entirely uncharacteristic of Nina. To the sensitive ears of a psychologist, it sounded little short of the ravings of a maniac. He had not even the presence of mind to grunt at proper intervals. Frozen mutely in his seat, he watched the ground rush downwards and heard the air shriek backwards as they headed for their little house by the sea.
Nina Porus prattled on gaily-the one normal aspect of her conversation being her ability to uphold both ends of a dialogue with smooth efficiency.
ìAnd, of course, dear, Iíve fixed up an entire tryptex , broiled to a turn, garnished with sarnees . And, oh yes, about that affair last year with that new planet-Earth, do you call it? I was so proud of you when I heard about it. I said-î
And so on and on, until her voice degenerated into a meaningless conglomeration of sounds.
Where were her tears? Where were the reproaches, the threats, the impassioned self-pity?
Tan Porus roused himself to one great effort at dinner. He stared at the steaming dish of tryptex before him with an odd lack of appetite and said, ìThis reminds me of the time at Arcturus when I dined with the President Delegate-î
He went into details, dilating on the gayety and abandon of the affair, waxing lyrical over his own enjoyment of it, stressing, almost unsubtly, the fact that he had not missed his wife, and finally, in one last wild burst of desperation, mentioning casually the presence of a surprising number of Rigellian females in the Arcturian system.
And through it all, his wife sat smiling. ìWonderful, darling,î sheíd say. ìIím so glad you enjoyed yourself. Eat your tryptex .î
But Porus did not eat his tryptex . The mere thought of food nauseated him. With one lingering stare of dismay at his wife, he arose with what dignity he could muster and left for the privacy of his room.
He tore up the equations furiously and hurled himself into a chair. He seethed with anger, for evidently something had gone wrong with Nina. Terribly wrong! Even interest in another man-and for just a moment that had occurred to him as a possible explanation-would not cause such a revolution in character.
He tore at his hair. There was some hidden factor more startling than that-but what it was he had no idea. At that moment Tan Porus would have given the sum total of his worldly possessions to have his wife enter and make one-just one-attempt to snatch his scalp off, as of old.
And below, in the dining room, Nina Porus allowed a crafty gleam to enter her eye.
Lor Haridin put down his pen and said, ìCome in!î
The door opened, and his friend, Eblo Ranin, entered, brushed off a corner of the desk and sat down.
ìHaridin, Iíve got an idea.î His voice was uncommonly like a guilty whisper.
Haridin gazed at him suspiciously.
ìLike the time,î he said, ìyou set up the booby trap for old man Obel?î
Ranin shuddered. He had spent two days hiding in the ventilator shaft after that brilliant piece of work. ìNo, this is legitimate. Listen, Porus left you in charge of the squid, didnít he?î
ìOh, I see what youíre getting at. Itís no go. I can feed the squid, but thatís all. If I as much as clapped my hands at it to induce a color-change tropism, the boss would throw a fit.î
ìTo space with him! Heís parsecs away, anyway.î Ranin drew forth a two-month old copy of the J.G.P. and folded the cover back. ìHave you been following Livellís experiments at Procyon U.? You know-magnetic fields applied with and without ultra-violet radiation.î
ìOut of my field,î grunted Haridin. ìIíve beard of it, but thatís all. What about it?î
ìWell, itís a type E reaction which gives, believe it or not, a strong Fimbal Effect in practically every case, especially in the higher invertebrates.î
ìHmm!î
ìNow, if we could try it on this squid, we could-î
ìNo, no, no, no!î Haridin shook his head violently. ìPorus would break me. Great stars and little meteors, how he would break me!î
ìListen, you nut-Porus canít tell you what to do with the squid. Itís Frian Obel that has final say. Heís head of the Psychological Board, not Porus. All you have to do is to apply for his permission and youíll get it. Just between us, since that Homo Sol affair last year, he canít stand the sight of Porus anyway.î
Haridin weakened. ìYou ask him.î
Ranin coughed. ìNo. On the whole, perhaps Iíd better not. Heís sort of got a suspicion that I set that booby trap, and Iíd rather keep out of his way.î
ìHmm. Well-all right!î
Lor Haridin looked as if he had not slept well for a week -which shows that sometimes appearances are not deceiving. Eblo Ranin regarded him with patient kindliness and sighed.
ìLook! Will you please sit down? Santin said he would have the final results in today, didnít he?î
ìI know, I know, but itís humiliating. I spent seven years on higher math. And now I make a stupid mistake and canít even find it!î
ìMaybe itís not there to find.î
ìDonít be silly. The answer is just impossible. It must be impossible. It must be.î His high forehead creased. ìOh, I donít know what to think.î
He continued his concentrated attempt to wear out the nap of the rug beneath and mused bitterly. Suddenly he sat down.
ìItís those time integrals. You canít work with them, I tell you. You look ëem up in a table, taking half an hour to find the proper entry, and they give you seventeen possible answers. You have to pick the one that makes sense, and- Arcturus help me!-either they all do, or none do! Run up against eight of them, as we do in this problem, and weíve got enough permutations to last us the rest of our life. Wrong answer! Itís a wonder I lived through it at all.î
The look he gave the fat volume of Heloís Tables of Time Integrals did not sear the binding, to Raninís great surprise.
The signal light flashed, and Haridin leaped to the door.
He snatched the package from the messengerís hand and ripped open the wrappings frantically.
He turned to the last page and stared at Santinís final note:
Your calculations are correct. Congratulations- and wonít this knock Porusís head right off his shoulders! Better get in touch with him at once.
Ranin read it over the otherís shoulder, and for one long minute the two gazed at each other.
ìI was right,î whispered Haridin, eyes bulging. ìWeíve found something in which the imaginary doesnít square out. Weíve got a predicted reaction which includes an imaginary quantity!î
The other swallowed and brushed aside his stupefaction with an effort. ìHow do you interpret it?î
ìGreat space! How in the galaxy should I know? Weíve got to get Porus, thatís all.î
Ranin snapped his fingers and grabbed the other by the shoulders. ìOh, no, we wonít. This is our big chance. If we can carry this through, weíre made for life.î He shuttered in his excitement. ìArcturus! Any psychologist would sell his life twice over to have our opportunity right now.î
The Draconian squid crawled placidly about, unawed by the huge solenoid that surrounded its tank. The mass of tangled wires, the current leads, the mercury-vapor lamp up above meant nothing to it. It nibbled contentedly at the fronds of the sea fern about it, and was at peace with the world.
Not so the two young psychologists. Eblo Ranin scurried through the complicated set-up in a last-minute effort at checking everything. Lor Haridin helped him in intervals between nail-biting.
ìEverythingís set,î said Ranin, and swabbed wearily at his damp brow. ìLet her shoot!î
The mercury-vapor lamp went on and Haridin pulled the window curtains together. In the cold red-less light, two green-tinted faces watched the squid closely. It stirred restlessly, its warm pink changing to a dull black in the mercury light
ìTurn on the juice,î said Haridin hoarsely.
There was a soft click, and that was all.
ìNo reaction?î questioned Ranin, half to himself. And then: he held his breath as the other bent closer.
ìSomethingís happening to the squid. It seems to glow a bit -or is it my eyes?î
The glow became perceptible and then seemed to detach itself from the body of the animal and take on a spherical shape of itself. Long minutes passed.
ìItís emitting some sort of radiation, field, force-whatever you want to call it-and there seems to be expansion with time.î
There was no answer, and none was expected. Again they waited and watched.
And then Ranin emitted a muffled cry and grasped Haridinís elbow tightly. ìCrackling comets, whatís it doing?î
The globular glowing sphere of whatever it was had thrust out a pseudopod. A gleaming little projection touched the swaying branch of the sea-fern, and where it touched the leaves turned brown and withered!
ìShut off the current!î
The current clicked off; the mercury-vapor lamp went out; the shades were parted and the two stared at each other nervously.
ìWhat was it?î
Haridin shook his head. ìI donít know. It was something definitely insane. I never saw anything like itî
ìYou never saw an imaginary in a reaction equation before, either, did you? As a matter of fact, I donít think that expanding field was any known form of energy at-î
His breath came out in one long whistling exhalation and he retreated slowly from the tank containing the squid. The mollusc was motionless, but around it half the fern. in the tank hung sere and withered.
Haridin gasped. He pulled the shades and in the gloom, the globe of glowing haze bulked through half the tank. Little curving tentacles of light reached toward the remaining fem and one pulsing thread extended through the glass and was creeping along the table.
That fright in Raninís voice rendered it a cracked, scarcely-understood sound.
ìItís a lag reaction. Didnít you test it by Wilbonís Theorem?î
ìHow could I?î The otherís heart pumped madly and his dry lips fought to form words. ìWilbonís Theorem didnít make sense with an imaginary in the equation. I let it go.î
Ranin sped into action with feverish energy. He left the room and was back in a moment with a tiny, squealing, squirrel-like animal from his own lab. He dropped it in the path of the thread of light stealing along the table, and held it there with a yard rule.
The glowing thread wavered, seemed to sense the presence of life in some horribly blind way, and lunged towards it The little rodent squealed once, a high-pitched shriek of infinite torture, and went limp. In two seconds it was a shriveled, shrunken travesty of its former self.
Ranin swore and dropped the rule with a sudden yell, for the thread, of light-a bit brighter, a bit thicker-began creeping up the wood toward him.
ìHere,î said Haridin, ìletís end this!î He yanked a drawer open and withdrew the chromium-plated Tonite gun within. Its sharp thin beam of purple light lunged forward towards the squid and exploded in blazing, soundless fury against the edge of the sphere of force. The psychologist shot again and again, and then compressed the trigger to form one continuous purple stream of destruction that ceased only when power failed.
And the glowing sphere remained unharmed. It engulfed the entire tank. The ferns were brown masses of death.
ìGet the Board,î yelled Ranin. ìItís beyond us entirely!î
There was no confusion-humanoids in the mass are simply not subject to panic, if you donít count the half-genius, half-humanoid inhabitants of the planets of Sol-and the evacuation of the University grounds was carried out smoothly.
ìOne fool,î said old Mir Deana, ace physicist of Arcturus U., ìcan ask more questions than a thousand wise men can answer.î He fingered his scraggly beard and his button nose sniffed loudly in disdain.
ìWhat do you mean by that?î questioned Frian Obel sharply. His green Vegan skin darkened angrily.
ìJust that, by analogy, one cosmic fool of a psychologist can make a bigger mess than a thousand physicists can clear up.î
Obel drew in his breath dangerously. He had his own opinion of Haridin and Ranin, but no lame-brain physicist could-
The plump figure of Qual Wynn, university president, came charging down upon them. He was out of breath and spoke between puffs.
ìIíve gotten in touch with the Galactic Congress and theyíre arranging for evacuation of all Eron, if necessary.î His voice became pleading. ìIsnít there anything that can be done?íí
Mir Deana sighed, ìNothing-yet! All we know is this: the squid is emitting some sort of pseudo-living radiatory field which is not electromagnetic in character. Its advance cannot be stopped by anything we have yet tried, material or vacuum. None of our weapons affect it, for within the field the ordinary attributes of space-time apparently donít hold.î
The president shook a worried head. ìBad, bad! Youíve sent for Porus, though?î He sounded as though we were clutching at a last straw.
ìYes,î scowled Frian Obel. ìHeís the only one that really knows that squid. If he canít help us, no one can.î He stared off toward the gleaming white of the university buildings, where the grass over half the campus was brown stubble and the trees blasted ruins.
ìDo you think,î said the president, turning to Deana once more, ìthat the field can span interplanetary space?î
ìSizzling novae, I donít know what to think!î Deana exploded, and he turned pettishly away.
There was a thick silence of utter gloom.
Tan Porus was sunk in deep apathy. He was unaware of the brilliant coruscations of color overhead. He didnít hear a sound of the melodious tones that filled the auditorium.
He knew only one thing-that he had been talked into attending a concert. Concerts above all were anathema to him, and in twenty years of married life he had steered clear of them with a skill and ease that only the greatest psychologist of them all could have shown. And now-
He was startled out of his stupor by the sudden discordant sounds that arose from the rear.
There was a rush of ushers to the exit where the disturbance originated, a waving of protesting uniformed arms and then a strident voice: ìI am here on urgent business direct from the Galactic Congress on Eron, Arcturus. Is Tan Porus in the audience?î
Tan Porus was out of his seat with a bound. Any excuse to leave the auditorium was nothing short of heaven-sent.
He ripped open the communication handed him by the messenger and devoured its contents. At the second sentence, his elation left him. When he was finished, he raised a face in which only his darting green eyes seemed alive.
ìHow soon can we leave?î
ìThe ship is waiting now.î
ìCome, then.î
He took one step forward and stopped. There was a hand on his elbow.
ìWhere are you going?î asked Nina Porus. There was hidden steel in her voice.
Tan Porus felt stifled for a moment. He foresaw what would happen. ìDarling, I must go to Eron immediately. The fate of a world, of the whole galaxy perhaps, is at stake. You donít know how important it is. I tell you-î
ìAll right, go! And Iíll go with you.î
The psychologist bowed his head.
ìYes, dear!î he said. He sighed.
The psychological board hemmed and hawed as one man and then stared dubiously at the large-scale graph before them.
ìFrankly, gentlemen,î said Tan Porus, ìI donít feel too certain about it myself, but-well, youíve all seen my results, and checked them too. And it is the only stimulus that will yield a canceling reaction.î
Frian Obel fingered his chin nervously. ìYes, the mathematics is clear. Increase in hydrogen-ion activity past pH3 would set up a Demaneís Integral and that- But listen, Porus, weíre not dealing with space-time. The math might not hold -perhaps nothing will hold.î
ìItís our only chance. If we were dealing with normal space-time, we could just dump in enough acid to kill the blasted squid or fry it with a Tonite. As it is, we have no choice but to take our chances with-î
Loud voices interrupted him. ìLet me through, I say! I donít care if there are ten conferences going on!î
The door swung open and Qual Wynnís portly figure made its entrance. He spied Porus and bore down upon him. ìPorus, I tell you Iím going crazy. Parliament is holding me, as university president, responsible for all this, and now Deana says that-î He sputtered into silence and Mir Deana, standing composedly behind him, took up the tale.
ìThe field now covers better than one thousand square miles and its rate of increase is growing steadily. There seems to do no doubt now that it can span interplanetary space if it wishes to do so-interstellar as well, if given the time.î
ìYou hear that? You hear that?î Wynn was fairly dancing in his anxiety. ìCanít you do something? The galaxy is doomed, I tell you, doomed!î
ìOh, keep your tunic on,î groaned Porus, ìand let us handle this.î He turned to Deana. ìDidnít your physicist stooges conduct some clumsy investigations as to the speed of penetration of the field through various substances?î
Deana nodded stiffly.
ìPenetration varies, in general, inversely with density. Osmium, iridium and platinum are the best. Lead and gold are fair.î
ìGood! That checks! What Iíll need then is an osmium-plated suit with a lead-glass helmet. And make both plating and helmet good and thick.î
Qual Wynn stared horrified. ìOsmium plating! Osmium! By the great nebula, think of the expense.î
ìIím thinking,î said Porus frostilyÖ
ìBut theyíll charge it to the university; theyíll-î He recovered with difficulty as the somber stares of the assembled psychologists fastened themselves upon him. ìWhen do you need it?î he muttered weakly.
ìYouíre really going, yourself?î
ìWhy not?î asked Porus, clambering out of the suit.
Mir Deana said, ìThe lead-glass headpiece will hold off the field not longer than an hour and youíll probably be getting partial penetration in much shorter time. I donít know if you can do it.î
ì Iíll worry about that.î He paused, and then continued uncertainly. ìIíll be ready in a few minutes. Iíd like to speak to my wife first-alone.î
The interview was a short one. It was one of the very few occasions that Tan Porus forgot that he was a psychologist, and spoke as his heart moved him, without stopping to consider the natural reaction of the one spoken to.
One thing he did know-by instinct rather than thought- and that was that his wife would not break down or go sentimental on him; and there he was right. It was only in the last few seconds that her eyes fell and her voice quavered. She tugged a handkerchief from her wide sleeve and hurried from the room.
The psychologist stared after her and then stooped to pick up the thin book that had fallen as she had removed the handkerchief. Without looking at it, he placed it in the inner pocket of his tunic.
He smiled crookedly. ìA talisman!î he said.
Tan Porusís gleaming one-man cruiser whistled into the ìdeath field.î The clammy sensation of desolation impressed itself upon him at once.
He shrugged. ìImagination! Mustnít get nervy now.î
There was the vaguest glitter-a sparkle that was felt rather than seen-in the air about him. And then it invaded the ship itself, and, looking up, the Rigellian saw the five Eronian ricebirds he had brought with him lying dead on the floor of their cage, huddled masses of bedraggled feathers.
ìThe ëdeath fieldí is in,î he whispered. It had penetrated the steel hull of the cruiser.
The cruiser bumped to a rather unskillful landing on the broad university athletic field, and Tan Porus, an incongruous figure in the bulky osmium suit, stepped out. He surveyed his depressing surroundings. From the brown stubble underfoot to the glimmering haze that hid the normal blue of the sky, all seemed-dead.
He entered Psychology Hall.
His lab was dark; the shades were still drawn. He parted them and studied the squidís tank. The water replenisher was still working, for the tank was full. However, that was the only normal thing about it. Only a few dark-brown, ragged strands of rot were left of what had once been sea-fern. The squid itself lay inertly upon the floor of the tank.
Tan Porus sighed. He felt tired and numbed. His mind was hazy and unclear. For long minutes he stared about him unseeingly.
Then, with an effort, he raised the bottle he held and glanced at the label-12 molar hydrochloric acid.
He mumbled vaguely to himself. ìTwo hundred cc. Just dump the whole thing in. Thatíll force the pH down-if only hydrogen ion activity means something here.î
He was fumbling with the glass stopper, and-suddenly- laughing. He had felt exactly like this the one and only time he had ever been drunk.
He shook the gathering cobwebs from his brain. ìOnly got a few minutes to do-to do what? I donít know-something anyway. Dump this thing in. Dump it in. Dump! Dump! Dumpety-dump!î He was mumbling a silly popular song to himself as the acid gurgled its way into the open tank.
Tan Porus felt pleased with himself and he laughed. He stirred the water with his mailed fist and laughed some more. He was still singing that song.
And then he became aware of a subtle change in environment He fumbled for it and stopped singing. And then it hit him with the suddenness of a downpour of cold water. The glitter in the atmosphere had gone!
With a sudden motion, he unclasped the helmet and cast it off. He drew in long breaths of air, a bit musty, but unkilling.
He had acidified the water of the tank, and destroyed the field at its source. Chalk up another victory for the pure mathematics of psychology!
He stepped out of his osmium suit and stretched. The pressure on his chest reminded him of something. Withdrawing the booklet his wife had dropped, he said, ìThe talisman came through!î and smiled indulgently at his own whimsy.
The smile froze as he saw for the first time the title upon the book.
The title was Intermediate Course in Applied Psychology- Volume 5 .
It was as if something large and heavy had suddenly fallen onto Porusís head and driven understanding into it Nina had been boning up on applied psych for two whole years .
This was the missing factor. He could allow for it. He would have to use triple time integrals, but-
He threw the communicator switch and waited for contact
ìHello! This is Porus! Come on in, all of you! The death field is gone! Iíve beaten the squid.î He broke contact and added triumphantly, ì-and my wife!î
Strangely enough-or, perhaps, not so strangely-it was the latter feat that pleased him more.



***



The chief interest to me in ìThe Imaginaryî is that it foreshadows the ìpsychohistoryî that was to play such a big role in the ìFoundationî series. It was in this story and in its predecessor, ìHomo Sol,î that for the first time I treated psychology as a mathematically refined science.
It was about time that I made another stab at Unknown , and I did so with a story called ìThe Oak,î which, as I recall, was something about an oak tree that served as an oracle and delivered ambiguous statements. I submitted it to Campbell on July 16, 1940, and it was promptly rejected.
One of the bad things about writing for Unknown was that the magazine was one of a kind. If Unknown rejected a story, there was no place else to submit it. It was possible to try Weird Tales , a magazine that was older than any science fiction magazine, but it dealt with old-fashioned, creaky horror tales and paid very little to boot. I wasnít really interested in trying to get into it. (And besides, they rejected both ìLife Before Birthî and ìThe Oakî when I submitted them.)
Still, July 29, 1940, was a turning point in my career, although, of course, I had no way of telling it. I had up to that point written twenty-two stories in twenty-five months. Of these I had sold (or was to sell) thirteen, while nine never sold at all and no longer exist. The record wasnít abysmal but neither was it great-letís call it mediocre.
However, as it happened, except for two short-short stories that were special cases, I never again wrote a science fiction story I could not sell. I had found the range.
But not Campbellís range particularly. In August I wrote ìHeredity,î which I submitted to Campbell on August 15, and which he rejected two weeks later. Fortunately, Pohl snapped it up at once.








Heredity


Dr. Stefansson fondled the thick sheaf of typewritten papers that lay before him, ìItís all here, Harvey-twenty-five years of work.î
Mild-mannered Professor Harvey puffed idly at his pipe, ìWell, your part is over-and Markeyís, too, on Ganymede. Itís up to the twins, themselves, now.î
A short ruminative silence, and then Dr. Stefansson stirred uneasily, ìAre you going to break the news to Allen soon?î
The other nodded quietly, ìIt will have to be done before we get to Mars, and the sooner the better.î He paused, then added in a tightened voice, ìI wonder how it feels to find out after twenty-five years that one has a twin brother whom one has never seen. It must be a damned shock.î
ìHow did George take it?î
ìDidnít believe it at first, and I donít blame him. Markey had to work like a horse to convince him it wasnít a hoax. I suppose Iíll have as hard a job with Allen.î He knocked the dottle from his pipe and shook his head.
ìI have half a mind to go to Mars just to see those two get together,î remarked Dr. Stefansson wistfully. ìYouíll do no such thing, Stef. This experimentís taken too long and means too much to have you rum it by any such fool move.î
ìI know, I know! Heredity versus environment! Perhaps at last the definite answer.î He spoke half to himself, as if repeating an old, familiar formula, ìTwo identical twins, separated at birth; one brought up on old, civilized Earth, the other on pioneer Ganymede. Then, on their twenty-fifth birthday brought together for the first time on Mars-God! I wish Carter had lived to see the end of it Theyíre his children.î
ìToo bad!-But weíre alive, and the twins. To carry the experiment to its end will be our tribute to him.î
There is no way of telling, at first seeing the Martian branch of Medicinal Products, Inc., that it is surrounded by anything but desert. You canít see the vast underground caverns where the native fungi of Mars are artificially nurtured into huge blooming fields. The intricate transportation system that connects all parts of the square miles of fields to the central building is invisible. The irrigation system; the air-purifiers; the drainage pipes, are all hidden.
And what one sees is the broad squat red-brick building and Martian desert, rusty and dry, all about
That had been all George Carter had seen upon arriving via rocket-taxi, but him, at least, appearances had not deceived. It would have been strange had it done so, for his life on Ganymede had been oriented in its every phase towards eventual general managership of that very concern. He knew every square inch of the caverns below as well as if he had been born and raised in them himself.
And now he sat in Professor Lemuel Harveyís small office and allowed just the slightest trace of uneasiness to cross his impassive countenance. His ice-blue eyes sought those of Professor Harvey.
ìThis-this twin brother oí mine. Heíll be here soon?î
Professor Harvey nodded, ìHeís on his way over right now.î
George Carter uncrossed his knees. His expression was almost wistful, ìHe looks a lot like me, díya rackon?î
ìQuite a lot. Youíre identical twins, you know.î
ìHmm! Rackon so! Wish Iíd known him all the time-on Ganny!î He frowned. ìHeís lived on Airth allís life, huh?î
An expression of interest crossed Professor Harveyís face. He said briskly, ìYou dislike Earthmen?î
ìNo, not exactly,î came the immediate answer. ìItís just the Airthmen are tanderfeet All of ëm I know are.î
Harvey stifled a grin, and conversation languished.
The door-signal snapped Harvey out of his reverie and George Carter out of his chair at the same instant. The professor pressed the desk-button and the door opened.
The figure on the threshold crossed into the room and then stopped. The twin brothers faced each other.
It was a tense, breathless moment, and Professor Harvey sank into his soft chair, put his finger-tips together and watched keenly.
The two stood stiffly erect, ten feet apart, neither making a move to lessen the distance. They made a curious contrast-a contrast all the more marked because of the vast similarity between the two.
Eyes of frozen blue gazed deep into eyes of frozen blue. Each saw a long, straight nose over full, red lips pressed firmly together. The high cheekbones were as prominent in one as in the other, the jutting, angular chin as square. There was even the same, odd half-cock of one eyebrow in twin expressions of absorbed, part-quizzical interest.
But with the face, all resemblance ended. Allen Carterís clothes bore the New York stamp on every square inch. From his loose blouse, past his dark purple knee breeches, salmon-colored cellulite stockings, down to the glistening sandals on his feet, he stood a living embodiment of latest Terrestrial fashion.
For a fleeting moment, George Carter was conscious of a feeling of ungainliness as he stood there in his tight-sleeved, close-necked shirt of Ganymedan linen. His unbuttoned vest and his voluminous trousers with their ends tucked into high-laced, heavy-soled boots were clumsy and provincial. Even he felt it-for just a moment
From his sleeve-pocket Allen removed a cigarette case-it was the first move either of the brothers had made-opened it, withdrew a slender cylinder of paper-covered tobacco that spontaneously glowed into life at the first puff.
George hesitated a fraction of a second and his subsequent action was almost one of defiance. His hand plunged into his inner vest pocket and drew therefrom the green, shriveled form of a cigar made of Ganymedan greenleaf. A match flared into.flame upon his thumbnail and for a long moment, he matched, puff for puff, the cigarette of his brother.
And then Allen laughed-a queer, high-pitched laugh, ìYour eyes are a little closer together, I think.î
ìRackon ëtis, maybe. Yír hairís fixed sort oí different.î There was faint disapproval in his voice. Allenís hand went self-consciously to his long, light-brown hair, carefully curled at the ends, while his eyes flickered over the carelessly-bound queue into which the otherís equally long hair was drawn.
ìI suppose weíll have to get used to each other. -Iím willing to try.î The Earth twin was advancing now, hand outstretched.
George smiled, ìYí bet. ëAt goes here, too.î
The hands met and gripped.
ìYír nameís Allín, huh?î said George.
ìAnd yours is George, isnít it?î answered Allen.
And then for a long while they said nothing more. They just looked-and smiled as they strove to bridge the twenty-five year gap that separated them.
George Carterís impersonal gaze swept over the carpet of low-growing purple blooms that stretched in plot-path bordered squares into the misty distance of the caverns. The newspapers and feature writers might rhapsodize over the ìFungus Goldî of Mars-about the purified extracts, in yields of ounces to acres of blooms, that had become indispensable to the medical profession of the System. Opiates, purified vitamins, a new vegetable specific against pneumonia-the blooms were worth their weight in gold, almost.
But they were merely blooms to George Carter-blooms to be forced to full growth, harvested, baled, and shipped to the Aresopolis labs hundreds of miles away.
He cut his little ground car to half-speed and leant furiously out the window, ìHi yí mudcat there. Yí with the dairty face. Watch what yír doing-keep the domned water in the channel.î
He drew back and the ground car leapt ahead once more. The Ganymedan muttered viciously to himself, ìThese domned men about here are wairse than useless. So many machines tí do their wairk for ëm they give their brains a pairmenent vacation, I rackon.î
The ground car came to a halt and he clambered out. Picking his way between the fungus plots, he approached the clustered group of men about the spider-armed machine in the plotway ahead.
ìWell, here I am. What is ët, Allín?î
Allenís head bobbed up from behind the other side of the machine. He waved at the men about him, ìStop it for a second!î and leaped toward his twin.
ìGeorge, it works. Itís slow and clumsy, but it works. We can improve it now that weíve got the fundamentals down. And in no time at all, weíll be able to-î
ìNow wait a while, Allín. On Ganny, we go slow. Yí live long, that way. What yí got there?î
Allen paused and swabbed at his forehead. His face shone with grease, sweat, and excitement. ìIíve been working on this thing ever since I finished college. Itís a modification of something we have on Earth-but itís no end improved. Itís a mechanical bloom picker.î
He had fished a much-folded square of heavy paper from his pocket and talked steadily as he spread it on the plotway before them, ìUp to now, bloom-picking has been the bottleneck of production, to say nothing of the 15 to 20% loss due to picking under- and over-ripe blooms. After all, human eyes are only human eyes, and the blooms-Here, look!î
The paper was spread flat and Allen squatted before it George leaned over his shoulder, with frowning watchfulness.
ìYou see. Itís a combination of fluoroscope and photoelectric cell. The ripeness of the bloom can be told by the state of the spores within. This machine is adjusted so that the proper circuit is tripped upon the impingement of just that combination of light and dark formed by ripe spores within the bloom. On the other hand, this second circuit-but look, itís easier to show you.î
He was up again, brimming with enthusiasm. With a jump, he was in the low seat behind the picker and had pulled the lever.
Ponderously, the picker turned towards the blooms and its ìeyeî travelled sideways six inches above the ground. As it passed each fungus bloom, a long spidery arm shot out, lopping it cleanly half an inch from the ground and depositing it neatly in the downward sloping slide beneath. A pile of blooms formed behind the machine.
ìWe can hook on a binder, too, later on. Do you notice those blooms it doesnít touch? Those are unripe. Just wait till it comes to an over-ripe one and see what it does.î
He yelled in triumph a moment later when a bloom was torn out and dropped on the spot.
He stopped the machine, ìYou see? In a month, perhaps, we can actually start putting it to work in the fields.î
George Carter gazed sourly upon his twin, ìTake more ën a month, I rackon. Itíll take foraver, more likely.î
ìWhat do you mean, forever. It just has to be sped up-î
ìI donít care if ët just has tí be painted pairple. ëTisnít going tí appear on my fields.î
ì Your fields?î
ìYup, mine,î was the cool response. ìIíve got veto powír here same as you have. Yí canít do anything ëthout my say-so-and yí wonít get it fír this. In fact, I want yí tí clear that thing out oí here, altogether. Got no use fír ët.î
Allen dismounted and faced his brother, ìYou agreed to let me have this plot to experiment on, veto-free, and Iím holding you to that agreement.î
ìAll right, then. But keep yír domned machine out oí the rest oí the fields.î
The Earthman approached the other slowly. There was a dangerous look in his eyes. ìLook, George, I donít like your attitude-and I donít like the way youíre using your veto power. I donít know what youíre used to running on Ganymede, but youíre in the big time now, and there are a lot of provincial notions youíll have to get out of your head.î
ìNot unless I want to. And if yí want tí have ët out with me, weíd better go tí yír office. Spatting before the men ëd be bad for discipline.î
The trip back to Central was made in ominous silence. George whistled softly to himself while Allen folded his arms and stared with ostentatious indifference at the narrow, twisting plotway ahead. The silence persisted as they entered the Earthmanís office. Allen gestured shortly towards a chair and the Ganymedan took it without a word. He brought out his ever-present green-leaf cigar and waited for the other to speak.
Allen hunched forward upon the edge of his seat and leaned both elbows on his desk. He began with a rush.
ìThereís lots to this situation, George, thatís a mystery to me. I donít know why they brought up you on Ganymede and me on Earth, and I donít know why they never let us know of each other, or made us co-managers now with veto-power over one another-but I do know that the situation is rapidly growing intolerable.
ìThis corporation needs modernization, and you know that. Yet youíve been wielding that veto-power over every trifling advance Iíve tried to initiate. I donít know just what your viewpoint is, but Iíve a suspicion that you think youíre still living on Ganymede. If youíre still in the sticks,-Iím warning you-get out of them fast. Iím from Earth, and this corporation is going to be run with Earth efficiency and Earth organization. Do you understand?î
George puffed odorous tobacco at the ceiling before answering, but when he did, his eyes came down sharply, and there was a cutting edge to his voice.
ìAirth, is it? Airth efficiency, no less? Well, Allín, I like ye. I canít help it Yír so much like me, that disliking yí would be like disliking myself, I rackon. I hate tí say this, but yír upbringingís all wrong.î
His voice became sternly accusatory, ìYír an Airthman. Well, look at yí. Airthmanís but half a man at best, and naturally yí lean on machines. But dí yí suppose I want the corporation to be run by machines-just machines ? Whatíre the men tí do?î
ìThe men run the machines,î came the clipped, angry response.
The Ganymedan rose, and a fist slammed down on the desk, ìThe machines run the men, and yî know it. Fairst, yí use them; then yí depend on them; and finally yír slaves tí them. Over on yír pracious Airth, it was machines, machines, machines-and as a result, what are yí? Iíll tell yí. Half a man!î
He drew himself up, ìI still like yí. I like yí weU enough f wish yîd lived on Gannie with me. By Jupe ëní domn, ëtwould have made a man oí yí.î
ìFinished?î said Allen.
ìRackon so!î
ìThen Iíll tell you something. Thereís nothing wrong with you that a life time on a decent planet wouldnít have fixed. As it is, however, you belong on Ganymede. Iíd advise you to go back there.î
George spoke very softly, ìYír not thinking oí taking a punch at me, are yí?î
ìNo. I couldnít fight a mirror image of myself, but if your face were only a little different, I would enjoy splashing it about the premises a bit.î
ìThink yí could do it-an Airthman like you? Here, sit down. Weíre both getting a bit too excited, I rackon. Nothingí!! be settled this way.î
He sat down once more, puffed vainly at his dead cigar, and tossed it into the incinerator chute in disgust.
ìWhereís yír water?î he grunted.
Allen grinned with sudden delight, ìWould you object to having a machine supply it?î
