ìMachine? What dí yí mean?î The Ganymedan gazed about him suspiciously.
ìWatch! I had this installed a week ago.î He touched a button on his desk and a low click sounded below. There was the sound of pouring water for a second or so and then a circular metal disk beside the Earthmanís right hand slid aside and a cup of water lifted up from below.
ìTake it,î said Allen.
George lifted it gingerly and drank it down. He tossed the empty cup down the incinerator shaft, then stared long and thoughtfully at his brother, ìMay I see this water feeder o* yírs?î
ìSurely. Itís just under the desk. Here, Iíll make room for you.î
The Ganymedan crawled underneath while Allen watched uncertainly. A brawny hand was thrust out suddenly and a muffled voice said, ìHand me a screwdriver.î
ìHere! What are you going to do?î
ìNothing. Nothing ët all. Just want tí investigate this contraption.î
The screw-driver was handed down and for a few minutes there was no other sound than an occasional soft scraping of metal on metal. Finally, George withdrew a flushed face and adjusted his wrinkled collar with satisfaction.
ìWhich button do I press for the water?î
Allen gestured and the button was pressed. The gurgling of water sounded. The Earthman stared in mystification from his desk to his brother and back again. And then he became aware of a moistness about his feet.
He jumped, looked downwards, and squawked in dismay, ìWhy, damn you, what have you done?î A snaky stream of water wriggled blindly out from under the desk and the pouring sound of water still continued.
George made leisurely for the door, ìJust short-caircuited it. Hereís yír screw-driver; fix ët up again.î And just before he slammed the door, ìSo much fír yír pracious machines. They go wrong at the wrong times.î
The sounder was buzzily insistent and Allen Carter opened one eye peevishly. It was still dark.
With a sigh, he lifted one arm to the head of his bed and put the Audiomitter into commission.
The treble voice of Amos Wells of the night shift squawked excitedly at him. Allenís eyes snapped open and he sat up.
ìYouíre crazy!î But he was plunging into his breeches even as he spoke. In ten seconds, he was careening up the steps three at a time. He shot into the main office just behind the charging figure of his twin brother.
The place was crowded;-its occupants in a jitter.
Allen brushed his long hair out of his eyes, ìTurn on the turret searchlight!î
ìItís on,î said someone helplessly.
The Earthman rushed to the window and looked out. The yellow beam reached dimly out a few feet and ended in a muddy murkiness. He pulled at the window and it lifted upwards grittily a few inches. There was a whistle of wind and a tornado of coughing from within the room. Allen slammed it down again and his hands went at once to his tear-filled eyes.
George spoke between sneezes, ìWeíre not located in the sandstorm zone. This canít be one.î
ìIt is,î asserted Wells in a squeak. ìItís the worst Iíve ever seen. Started full blast from scratch just like that. It caught me flat-footed. By the time I closed off all exits to above, it was too late.î
ìToo late!î Allen withdrew his attention from his sand-filled eyes and snapped out the words, ìToo late for what?î
ìToo late for our rolling stock. Our rockets got it worst of all. There isnít one that hasnít its propulsives clogged with sand. And that goes for our irrigation pumps and the ventilating system. The generators below are safe but everything else will have to be taken apart and put together again. Weíre stalled for a week at least. Maybe more.î
There was a short, pregnant silence, and then Allen said, ìTake charge. Wells. Put the men on double shift and tackle the irrigation pumps first. Theyíve got to be in working order inside of twenty-four hours, or half the crop will dry up and die on us. Here-wait, Iíll go with you.î
He turned to leave, but his first footstep froze in midair at the sight of Michael Anders, communications officer, rushing up the stairs.
ìWhatís the matter?î
Anders spoke between gasps, ìThe damned planetís gone crazy. Thereís been the biggest quake in history with its center not ten miles from Aresopolis.î
There was a chorus of ìWhat?î and a ragged follow-up of blistering imprecations. Men crowded in anxiously;-many had relatives and wives in the Martian metropolis.
Anders went on breathlessly, ìIt came all of a sudden. Aresopolis is in ruins and fires have started. There arenít any details but the transmitter at our Aresopolis labs went dead five minutes ago.î
There was a babel of comment The news spread out into the furthest recesses of Central, and excitement waxed to dangerously panicky proportions. Allen raised his voice to a shout.
ìQuiet, everyone. Thereís nothing we can do about Aresopolis. Weíve got our own troubles. This freak storm is connected with the quake some way-and thatís what we have to take care of. Everyone back to his work now-and work fast. Theyíll be needing us at Aresopolis damned soon.î He turned to Anders, ìYou! Get back to that receiver and donít knock off until youíve gotten in touch with Aresopolis again. Coming with me, George?î
ìNo, rackon not,î was the response. ìYí tend tí yír machines. Iíll go down with Anders.î
Dawn was breaking, a dusky, lightless dawn, when Allen Carter returned to Central. He was weary-weary in mind and body-and looked it. He entered the radio room.
ìThings are a mess. If-î
There was a ìShhhî and George waved frantically. Allen fell silent. Anders bent over the receiver, turning tiny dials with nervous fingers.
Anders looked up, ìItís no use, Mr. Carter. Canít get them.î
ìAll right. Stay here and keep yír ears open. Let me know if anything turns up.î
He walked out, hooking an arm underneath his brotherís and dragging the latter out.
ìWhen cín we get out the next shipment, Allín?î
ìNot for at least a week. We havenít a thing thatíll either roll or fly for days, and it will be even longer before we can start harvesting again.î
ìHave we any supplies on hand now?î
ìA few tons of assorted blooms-mainly the red-purples. The Earth shipment last Tuesday took off almost everything.î
George fell into a reverie.
His brother waited a moment and said sharply, ìWell, whatís on yourí mind? Whatís the news from Aresopolis?î
ìDomned bad! The quakeís leveled three-fourths oí Aresopolis and the restís pretty much gutted with fire, I rackon. There ëre fifty thousand thatíll have tí camp out nights.-Thatís no fun in Martian autumn weather with the Airth gravity system broken down.î
Allen whistled, ìPneumonia!î
ìAnd common colds and influenza and any oí half dozín diseases tí say nothing oí people bairnt. -Old Vincent is raising cain.î
ìWants blooms?î
ìHeís only got a two-day supply on hand. Heís got tí have more.î
Both, were speaking quietly, almost with indifference, with the vast understatement that is all that makes great crises bearable.
There was a pause and then George spoke again, ìWhatís the best we cín do?î
ìNot under a week-not if we kill ourselves to do it. If they could send over a ship as soon as the storm dies down, we might be able to send what we have as a temporary supply until we can get over with the rest.î
ìSilly even tí think oí that. The Aresopolis port is just ruins. They havenít a ship tí their names.î
Again silence. Then Allen spoke in a low, tense voice. ìWhat are you waiting for? Whatís that look on your face for?î
ìIím waiting fr yí tí admit yír domned machines have failed yí in the fairest emairgency weíve had tí meet.î
ìAdmitted,î snarled the Earthman.
ìGood! And now its up tí me tí show yí what human ingenuity can do.î He handed a sheet of paper to his brother, ìThereís a copy of the message I sent Vincent.î
Allen looked long at his brother and slowly read the pencilled scribbling.
ìWill deliver all we have on hand in thirty-six hours. Hope it will keep you going the few days until we can get a real shipment out. Things are a little rough out here.î
ìHow are you going to do it?î demanded Allen, upon finishing.
ìIím trying to show yí,î answered George, and Allen realized for the first time that they had left Central and were out in the caverns.
George led the way for five minutes and stopped before an object bulking blackly in the dimness. He turned on the section lights and said, ìSand truck!î
The sand truck was not an imposing object. With the low driving car in front and the three squat, open-topped freightcars behind, it presented a picture of obsolete decrepitude. Fifteen years ago, it had been relegated to the dust-heap by the sand-sleds and rocket-freights.
The Ganymedan was speaking, ìChecked it an hour ago, míself, and ëtis still in wairking order. It has shielded bearings, air conditioning unit fír the driving car, and an intairnal combustion engine.î
The other looked up sharply. There was an expression of distaste on his face. ìYou mean it burns chemical fuel.î
ìYup! Gasíline. Thatís why I like it. Reminds me oí Ganymede. On Gannie, I had a gas engine that-î
ìBut wait a while. We havenít any of that gasoline.î
ìNo, rackon not. But we got lots oí liquid hydrocarbons round the place. How about Solvent D? Thatís mostly octane. Weíve got tanks oí it.î
Allen said, ìThatís so;-but the truck holds only two.î
ìI know it. Iím one.î
ìAnd Iím the other.î
George grunted, ìI rackond yíd say that-but this isnít going tí be a push-button machine job. Rackon yír up tí it,- Airthman?î
ìI reckon I am-Gannie.î
The sun had been up some two hours before the sandtruckís engine whirred into life, but outside, the murk had become, if anything, thicker.
The main driveway within the caverns was ahum with activity. Grotesque figures with eyes peering through the thick glass of improvised air-helmets stepped back as the truckís broad, sand-adapted wheels began their slow turn. The three cars behind had been piled high with purple blooms, canvas covers had been thrown over them and bound down tightly,- and now the signal was given to open the doors.
The lever was jerked downwards and the double doors separated with sand-clogged protests. Through a gray whirl of inblown sand, the truck made its way outwards, and behind it sand-coated figures brushed at their air-helmets and closed the doors again.
George Carter, inured by long Ganymedan custom, met the sudden gravity change as they left the protective Gravitor fields of the caverns, with a single long-drawn breath. His hands held steady upon the wheels. His Terrestrial brother, however, was in far different condition. The hard nauseating knot into which his stomach tied itself loosened only very gradually, and it was a long time before his irregular stertorous breathing approached anything like normality again.
And throughout, the Earthman was conscious of the otherís side-long glance and of just a trace of a smile about the otherís lips.
It was enough to keep the slightest moan from issuing forth, though his abdominal muscles cramped and icy perspiration bathed his face.
The miles clicked off slowly, but the illusion of motionlessness was almost as complete as that in space. The surroundings were gray-uniform, monotonous and unvarying. The noise of the engine was a harsh purr and the clicking of the air-purifier behind like a drowsy tick. Occasionally, there was an especially strong gust of wind, and a patter of sand dashed against the window with a million tiny, separate pings.
George kept his eye strictly upon the compass before him. The silence was almost oppressive.
And then the Ganymedan swivelled his head, and growled, ìWhatís wrong with the domned ventílator?î
Allen squeezed upward, head against the low top, and then turned back, pale-faced, ìItís stopped.î
ìItíll be hours ëfore the stormís over. Yeíve got tí have air till then. Craw] in back there and start it again.î His voice was flat and final.
ìHere,î he said, as the other crawled over his shoulder into the back of the car. ìHereís the tool-kit. Yív got ëbout twenty minutes ëfore the air gets too foul tí breathe. ëTis pretty bad now.î
The clouds of sand hemmed in closer and the dim yellow light above Georgeís head dispelled only partially the darkness within.
There was the sound of scrambling from behind him and then Allenís voice, ìDamn this rope. Whatís it doing here?î There was a hammering and then a disgusted curse.
ìThis thing is choked with rust.î
ìAnything else wrong?î called out the Ganymedan.
ìDonít know. Wait till I clear it out.î More hammering and an almost continuous harsh, scraping sound followed.
Allen backed into his seat once more. His face dripped rusty perspiration and a swab with the back of an equally damp, rust-covered hand did it no good.
ìThe pump is leaking like a punctured kettle, now that the rustís been knocked loose. Iíve got it going at top speed, but the only thing between it and a total breakdown is a prayer.î
ìStart praying,î said George, bruskly. ìPray for a button to push.î
The Earthman frowned, and stared ahead in sullen silence.
At four in the afternoon, the Ganymedan drawled, ìAirís beginning tí thin out, looks like.î
Allen snapped to alertness. The air was foul and humid within. The ventilator behind swished sibilantly between each click and the clicks were spacing themselves further apart. It wouldnít hold out much longer now.
ìHow much ground have we covered?î
ìëBout a thaird oí the distance,î was the reply. ìHow ër y* holding out?î
ìWell enough,î Allen snapped back. He retired once more into his shelL
Night came and the first brilliant stars of a Martian night peeped out when with a last futile and long-sustained swi-i-i-s-s-sh, the ventilator died.
ìDomn!î said George. ìI canít breathe this soup any longer, anyway. Open the windows.î
The keenly cold Martian wind swept in and with it the last traces of sand. George coughed as he pulled his woolen cap over his ears and turned on the heaters.
ìYí can still taste the grit.î
Allen looked wistfully up into the skies, ìThereís Earth- with the moon hanging right onto her tail.î
ìAirth?î repeated George with fine contempt. His finger pointed horizonwards, ìThereís good old Jupe for yí.î
And throwing back his head, he sang in a full throated baritone:
ìWhen the golden orb oí Jove
Shines down from the skies above,
Then my spirit longs to go
To that happy land I know, Back tí good, old Ganyme-e-e-e-ede .î
The last note quavered and broke, and quavered and broke again and still again in an ever increasing rapidity of tempo until its vibrating ululation pierced the air about ear-shatteringly.
Allen stared at his brother wide-eyed, ìHow did you do that?î
George grinned, ìThatís the Gannie quaver. Didnít yí ever hear it before?î
The Earthman shook his head, ìIíve head of it, but thatís all.î
The other became a bit more cordial, ìWell, oí course yí can only do it in a thin atmosphere. Yí should hear me on Gannie. I cíd shake yí right off yír chair when Iím going good. Here! Wait till I gulp down some coffee, and then Iíll sing yí vairse twenty-four oí the ëBallad oí Ganymede.í ì
He took a deep breath:
ìThereís a fair-haired maid I love
Standing in the light oí Jove
And sheís waiting there for me-e-e-e-e.
Then-î
Allen grasped him by the arm and shook him. The Ganymedan choked into silence.
ìWhatís the matter?î he asked sharply.
ìThere was a thumping sound on the roof just a second ago. Thereís something up there.î
George stared upwards, ìGrab the wheel. Iíll go up.î
Allen shook his head, ìIím going myself. I wouldnít trust myself running this primitive contraption.î
He was out on the running board the next instant.
ìKeep her going,î he shouted, and threw one foot up onto the roof.
He froze in that position when he became aware of two yellow slits of eyes staring hard into his. It took not more than a second for him to realize that he was face to face with a keazel , a situation which for discomfort is about on a par with the discovery of a rattlesnake in oneís bed back on Earth.
There was little time for mental comparisons of his position with Earth predicaments, however, for the keazel lunged forward, its poisonous fangs agleam in the starlight.
Allen ducked desperately and lost his grip. He hit the sand with a slow-motion thud and the cold, scaly body of the Martian reptile was upon him.
The Earthmanís reaction was almost instinctive. His hand shot out and clamped down hard upon the creatureís narrow muzzle.
In that position, beast and man stiffened into breathless statuary. The man was trembling and within him his heart pounded away with hard rapidity. He scarcely dared move. In the unaccustomed Martian gravity, he found he could not judge movements of his limbs. Muscles knotted almost of their own accord and legs swung when they ought not to.
He tried to lie still-and think.
The keazel squirmed, and from its lips, clamped shut by Earth muscles, issued a tremulous whine. Allenís hand grew slick with perspiration and he could feel the beastís muzzle turn a bit within his palm. He clamped harder, panic-stricken. Physically, the keazel was no match for an Earthman, even a tired, frightened, gravity-unaccustomed Earthman-but one bite, anywhere, was all that was needed.
The keazel jerked suddenly; its back humped and its legs threshed. Allen held on with both hands and could not let go. He had neither gun nor knife. There was no rock on the level desert sands to crack its skull against. The sand-truck had long since disappeared into the Martian night, and he was alone-alone with a keazel .
In desperation, he twisted. The keazelís head bent. He could hear its breath whistling forth harshly-and again there was that low whine.
Allen writhed above it and clamped knees down upon its cold, scaly abdomen. He twisted the head, further and further. The keazel fought desperately, but Allenís Earthly biceps maintained their hold. He could almost sense the beastís agony in the last stages, when he called up all his strength,-something snapped.
And the beast lay still.
He rose to his feet, half-sobbing. The Martian night wind knifed into him and the perspiration froze on his body. He was alone in the desert.
Reaction set in. There was an intense buzzing in his ears. He found it difficult to stand. The wind was biting-but somehow he didnít feel it any more.
The buzzing in his ears resolved itself into a voice-a voice calling weirdly through the Martian wind.
ìAllín, where are yí? Domn yí, yí tanderfoot, where are yí? Allín! A llín!î
New life swept into the Earthman. He tossed the keazelís carcass onto his shoulders and staggered on towards the voice.
ìHere I am, G-Gannie. Right here.î
He stumbled blindly into his brotherís arms.
George began harshly, ìYí blasted Airthman, canít yí even keep yír footing on a sandtruck moving at ten miles per? Yí mightíve-î
His voice died away in a semi-gurgle.
Allen said tiredly, ìThere was a keazel on the roof. He knocked me off. Here, put it somewhere. Thereís a hundred dollar bonus for every keazel skin brought in to Aresopolis.î
He had no clear recollection of anything for the next half hour. When things straightened out, he was in the truck again with the taste of warm coffee in his mouth. The engine was rumbling once more and the pleasant warmth of the heaters surrounded him.
George sat next to him silently, eyes fixed on the desert ahead. But once in a while, he cleared his throat and shot a lightning glance at his brother. There was a queer look in his eyes.
Allen said, ìListen, Iíve got to keep awake,-and you look half dead yourself-so how about teaching me that ëGannie quaverí of yours. Thatís bound to wake the dead.î
The Ganymedan stared even harder and then said gruffly, ìSure, watch mí Adamís apple while I do ët again.î
The sun was half-way to zenith when they reached the canal.
An hour before dawn there had come the crackling sound of hoarfrost beneath the heavy wheels and that signified the end of the desert area and the approach of the canal oasis. With the rising of the sun, the crackling disappeared and the softening mud underneath slowed the sand-adapted truck. The pathetic clumps of gray-green scrub that dotted the flat landscape were the first variant to eternal red sand since the two had started on their journey.
And then Allen had leaned forward and grasped his brother by the arm, ìLook, thereís the canal itself right ahead.î
The ìcanalî-a small tributary of the mighty Jefferson Canal-contained a mere trickle of water at this season of the year. A dirty winding line of dampness, it was, and little more. Surrounding it on both sides were the boggy areas of black mud that were to fill up into a rushing ice-cold current an Earth-year hence.
The sand-truck nosed gingerly down the gentle slope, weaving a tortuous path among the sparsely-strewn boulders brought down by the springís torrents and left there as the sinking waters receded.
It slopped through the mud and splashed clumsily through the puddles. It jounced noisily over rocks, muddied itself past the hubs as it made its way through the murky mid-stream channel and then settled itself for the upward pull out.
And then, with a suddenness that tossed the two drivers out of their seats, it side-slipped, made one futile effort to proceed onwards, and thereafter refused to budge.
The brothers scrambled out and surveyed the situation. George swore lustily, voice more thickly accented than ever.
ìBí Jupe ëní domn, weíre in a pickled situation fír fair. Tis wallowing in the mud there like a blasted pig.î
Allen shoved his hair back wearily, ìWell, donít stand there looking at it. Weíre still a hundred miles or better from Aresopolis. Weíve got to get it out of there.î
ìSure, but how?î His imprecations dropped to sibilant breathings as he reached into the truck for the coil of rope in the back. He looked at it doubtfully.
ìYí get in here, Allín, and when I pull, press down with yír foot on that pedal.î
He was tying the rope to the front axle even as he spoke. He played it out behind him as he slogged out through ankle-deep mud, and stretched it taut.
ìAll right, now, give! î he yelled. His face turned purple with effort as his back muscles ridged. Allen, within the car, pressed the indicated pedal to the floor, heard a loud roar from the engine and a spinning whir from the back wheels. The truck heaved once, and then sank back.
ìëTis no use,î George called. ìI canít get a footing. If the ground were dry, I cíd do it.î
ìIf the ground were dry, we wouldnít be stuck,î retorted Allen. ìHere, give me that rope.í
ìDí yí think yí can do it, if I canít?î came the enraged cry, but the other had already left the car.
Allen had spied the large, deep-bedded boulder from the truck, and it was with relief that he found it to be within reaching distance of the rope. He pulled it taut and tossed its free end about the boulder. Knotting it clumsily, he pulled, and it held.
His brother leaned out of the car window, as he made his way, back, with one lumped Ganymedan fist agitating the air.
ìHi, yí nitwit. Whatíre yí doing? Dí yí expect that overgrown rock tí pull us out?î
ìShut up,î yelled back Allen, ìand feed her the gas when I pull.î
He paused midway between boulder and truck and seized the rope.
ì Give! î he shouted in his turn, and with a sudden jerk pulled the rope towards him with both hands.
The truck moved; its wheels caught hold. For a moment it hesitated with the engine blasting ahead full speed, and Georgeís hands trembling upon the wheel. And then it went over. And almost simultaneously, the boulder at the other end of the taut rope lifted out of the mud with a liquid smacking sound and went over on its side.
Allen slipped the noose off it and ran for the truck.
ìKeep her going,î he shouted, and hopped onto the running board, rope trailing.
ìHow did yí do that?î asked George, eyes round with awe.
ìI havenít got the energy to explain it now. When we get to Aresopolis and after weíve had a good sleep, Iíll draw the triangle of forces for you, and show you what happened. No muscles were involved. Donít look at me as if I were Hercules.î
George withdrew his gaze with an effort, ìTriangle oí forces, is it? I never heard oí it, but if thatís what it cín do, educationís a great thing.î
ìComet-gas! Is any coffee left?î He stared at the last thermos-bottle, shook it near his ear dolefully, and said, ìOh, well, letís practice the quaver. Itís almost as good and Iíve practically got it perfected.î
He yawned prodigiously, ìWill we make it by nightfall?î
ìMaybe!î
The canal was behind them now.
The reddening sun was lowering itself slowly behind the Southern Range. The Southern Range is one of the two ìmountain chainsî left on Mars. It is a region of hills; ancient, time-worn, eroded hills behind which lies Aresopolis.
It possesses the only scenery worth mentioning on all Mars and also the golden attribute of being able, through the updrafts along its sides, to suck an occasional ram out of the desiccated Martian atmosphere.
Ordinarily, perhaps, a pair from Earth and Ganymede might have idled through this picturesque area, but this was definitely not the case with the Carter twins.
Eyes, puffed for lack of sleep, glistened once more at the sight of hills on the horizons. Bodies, almost broken for sheer weariness, tensed once more when they rose against the sky.
And the truck leaped ahead,-for just behind the hills lay Aresopolis. The road they travelled was no longer a rule-edge straight one, guided by the compass, over table-top-flat land. It followed narrow, twisting trails over rocky ground.
They had reached Twin Peaks, then, when there was a sudden sputter from the motor, a few halting coughs and then silence.
Allen sat up and there was weariness and utter disgust in his voice, ìWhatís wrong with this everlastingly-to-be-damned machine now?î
His brother shrugged, ìNothing that I havenít been expecting for the last hour. Weíre out oí gas. Doesnít matter at all. Weíre at Twin Peaks-only ten miles frím the city. We cín get there in an hour, and then they cín send men out here for the blooms.î
ìTen miles in an hour!î protested Allen. ìYouíre crazy.î His face suddenly twisted at an agonizing thought, ìMy God! We canít do it under three hours and itís almost night. No one can last that long in a Martian night. George, weíre-î
George was pulling him out of the car by main force, ìBy Jupe ëní domn, Allín, donít let the tenderfoot show through now. We cín do it in an hour, I tell yí. Didnít yí ever try running under sub-normal gravity? Itís like flying. Look at me.î
He was off, skimming the ground closely, and proceeding in ground-covering leaps that shrank him to a speck up the mountain side in a moment.
He waved, and his voice came thinly, ìCome on!î
Allen started,-and sprawled at the third wide stride, arms nailing and legs straddled wide. The Ganymedanís laughter drifted down in heartless gusts.
Allen rose angrily and dusted himself. At an ordinary walk, he made his way upwards.
ìDonít get sore, Allín,î said George. ìItís just a knack, and Iíve had practice on Gannie. Just pretend yír running along a feather bed. Run rhythmically-a sort oí very slow rhythm- and run close tí the ground; donít leap high. Like this. Watch me!î
The Earthman tried it, eyes on his brother. His first few uncertain strides became surer and longer. His legs stretched and his arms swung as he matched his brother, step for step.
George shouted encouragement and speeded his pace, ìKeep lower tí the ground, Allín. Donít leap ëfore yír toes hit the ground.î
Allenís eyes shone and, for the moment, weariness was forgotten, ìThis is great; It is like flying-or like springs on your shoes.î
ìYí ought tí have lived on Gannie with me. Weíve got special fields fír subgravity races. An expairt racer cín do forty miles an hour at times-and I cín do thirty-five myself. -0í course, the gravity thereís a bit lower than here on Mars.î
Long hair streamed backwards in the wind and skin reddened at the bitter-cold air that blew past. The ruddy patches of sunlight travelled higher and higher up the slopes, lingered briefly upon the very summits and went out altogether. The short Martian twilight started upon its rapidly darkening career. The Evening Star-Earth-was already glimmering brightly, its attendant moon somewhat closer than the night previous.
The passing minutes went unheeded by Allen. He was too absorbed by the wonderful new sensation of sub-gravity running, to do anything more than follow his brother. Even the increasing chilliness scarcely registered upon his consciousness.
It was George, then, upon whose countenance a tiny, puckered uneasiness grew into a vast, panicky frown.
ìHi, Allín, hold up!î he called. Leaning backward, he brought himself to a short, hopping halt full of grace and ease. Allen tried to do likewise, broke his rhythm, and went forward upon his face. He rose with loud reproaches.
The Ganymedan turned a deaf ear to them. His gaze was sombre in the dusk, ìDí yí know where we are, Allín?î
Allen felt a cold constriction about his windpipe as he stared about him quickly. Things looked different in semidarkness, but they looked more different than they ought. It was impossible for things to be so different.
ìWe shouldíve sighted Old Baldy by now, shouldnít we have?î he quavered.
ìWe shídíve sighted him long ago,î came the hard answer. ìëTis that domned quake. Landslides mustíve changed the trails. The peaks themselves mustíve been screwed up-î His voice was thin-edged, ìAllen, ëtisnít any use making believe. Weíre dead lost.î
For a moment, they stood silently-uncertainly. The sky was purple and the hills retreated into the night. Allen licked bluechilled Ups with a dry tongue.
ìWe canít be but a few miles away. Weíre bound to stumble on the city if we look.î
ìConsider the situation, Airthman,î came. the savage, shouted answer, ì ëTis night, Martian night. The temperatureís down past zero and plummeting every minute. We havenít any time tí look;-weíve got tí go straight there. If weíre not there in half an hour, weíre not going tí get there at all.î
Allen knew that well, and mention of the cold increased his consciousness of it. He spoke through chattering teeth as he drew his heavy, fur-lined coat closer about him.
ìWe might build a fire!î The suggestion was a half-hearted one, muttered indistinctly, and fallen upon immediately by the other.
ìWith what?î George was beside himself with sheer disappointment and frustration. ìWeíve pulled through this far, and now weíll probíly freeze tí death within a mile oí the city. Címon keep running. Itís a hundred-tí-one chance.î
But Allen pulled him back. There was a feverish glint in the Earthmanís eye, ìBonfires!î he said irrelevantly. ìItís a possibility. Want to take a chance that might do the trick?î
ìNothin else tí do,î growled the other. ìBut hurry. Every minute I-î
ìThen run with the wind-and keep going.î
ìWhy?î
ìNever mind why. Do what I say-run with the wind!î
There was no false optimism in Allen as he bounded through the dark, stumbling over loose stones, sliding down declivities,-always with the wind at his back. George ran at his side, a vague, formless blotch in the night.
The cold was growing more bitter, but it was not quite as bitter as the freezing pang of apprehension gnawing at the Earthmanís vitals.
Death is unpleasant!
And then they topped the rise, and from Georgeís throat came a loud ìBí Jupe ëní domn!î of triumph.
The ground before them, as far as the eye could see, was dotted by bonfires. Shattered Aresopolis lay ahead, its homeless inhabitants making the night bearable by the simple agency of burning wood.
And on the hilly slopes, two weary figures slapped each other on the backs, laughed wildly, and pressed half-frozen, stubbly cheeks together for sheer, unadulterated joy.
They were there at last!
The Aresopolis lab, on the very outskirts of the city, was one of the few structures still standing. Within, by makeshift light, haggard chemists were distilling the last drops of extract. Without, the cityís police-force remnants were clearing desperate way for the precious flasks and vials as they were distributed to the various emergency medical centers set up in various regions of the bonfire-pocked ruins that were once the Martian metropolis.
Old Hal Vincent supervised the process and his faded eyes ever and again peered anxiously into the hills beyond, watching hopefully but doubtfully for the promised cargo of blooms.
And then two figures reeled out of the darkness and collapsed to halt before him.
Chill anxiety clamped down upon him, ìThe blooms! Where are they? Have you got them?î
ìAt Twin Peaks,î gasped Allen. ìA ton of them and better in a sand-truck. Send for them.î
A group of police ground-cars set off before he had finished, and Vincent exclaimed bewilderedly, ìA sand-truck? Why didnít you send it in a ship? Whatís wrong with you out there, anyway? Earthquake-î
He received no direct answer. George had stumbled towards the nearest bonfire with a beatific expression on his worn face.
ìAhhh, ëtis warm!î Slowly, he folded and dropped, asleep before he hit the ground.
Allen coughed gaspingly, ìHuh! The Gannie tenderfoot! Couldnít-ulp-take it!î
And the ground came up and hit him in the face.
Allen woke with the evening sun in his eyes and the odor of frying bacon in his nostrils. George shoved the frying pan towards him and said between gigantic, wolfing mouthfuls, ìHelp yourself.î
He pointed to the empty sand-truck outside the labs, ìThey got the stuff all right.î
Allen fell to, quietly. George wiped his lips with the back of his hand and said, ìSay, Allín, how ëd yí find the city? Iíve been sitting here trying tí figure it all outî
ìIt was the bonfires,î came the muffled answer. ìIt was the only way they could get heat, and fires over square miles of land create a whole section of heated air, which rises, causing the cold surrounding air of the hills to sweep in.î He suited his words with appropriate gestures. ìThe wind in the hills was heading for the city to replace warm air and we followed the wind. -Sort of a natural compass, pointing to where we wanted to go.î
George was silent, kicking with embarrassed vigor at the ashes of the bonfire of the night before.
ìLisín, Allín, Iíve had yí aíwrong. Yí were an Airthman tanderfoot tí me till-í He paused, drew a deep breath and exploded with, ìWell, by Jupe ní domn, yír my twin brother and Iím proud oí it All Airth cídnít drown out the Carter blood in yí.î
The Earthman opened his mouth to reply but his brother clamped one palm over it, ìYí keep quiet, till Iím finished. After we get back, yí can fix up that mechanical picker or anything else yí want. I drop my veto. If Airth and machines cín tairn out yír kind oí man, theyíre all right. But just the same,î there was a trace of wistfulness in his voice, ìyí got tî admit that everytime the machines broke down-from irrigation-trucks and rocket-ships to ventilators and sand-trucks- tíwas men who had tí pull through in spite oí all that Mars could do.î
Allen wrenched his face from out behind the restraining palm.
ìThe machines do their best,î he said, but not too vehemently.
ìSure, but thatís all they can do. When the emairgency comes, a manís got tí do a damn lot better than his.best or heís a goner.î
The other paused, nodded, and gripped the otherís hand with sudden fierceness, ìOh, weíre not so different. Earth and Ganymede are plastered thinly over the outside of us, but inside-î
He caught himself.
ìCome on, letís give out with that old Gannie quaver.î
And from the two fraternal throats tore forth a shrieking eldritch yell such as the thin, cold Martian air had seldom before carried.



***



I got the cover again with ìHeredity.î
In connection with that story, I remember best a comment I received from a young fellow named Scott Feldman (who was then still in his teens but who was later, as Scott Meredith, to become one of the most important literary agents in the business). He disapproved of the story because I introduced two characters at the start who disappeared from the story and were never heard of again.
Once that was pointed out to me, it seemed to me that this was indeed a major flaw, and I wondered why neither Campbell nor Pohl had specifically pointed it out. I never quite had the courage to ask, however.
But it did cause me to look at my stories more closely thereafter, and to realize again that writing isnít all inspiration and free flow. You do have to ask yourself pretty mechanical questions, such as, ìWhat do I do with this character now that Iíve taken the trouble to make use of him?î
By the time Campbell was rejecting, and Pohl accepting ìHeredity,î I was writing ìHistory.î The same thing happened. I submitted it to Campbell on September 13. It was rejected, and, eventually, Pohl took it.








History


Ullenís lank arm pushed the stylus carefully and painstakingly across the paper; his near-sighted eyes blinked through thick lenses. The signal light flashed twice before he answered.
He turned a page, and called out, ìIs dat you, Johnnie? Come in, please.î
He smiled gently, his thin, Martian face alight with pleasure.
ìSit down, Johnnie-but first lower de window-shade. De glare of your great Eard sun is annoying. Ah, datís good, and sid down and be very, very quiet for just a little while, because I am busy.î
John Brewster shifted a pile of ill-stacked papers and seated himself. He blew the dust from the edges of an open book in the next chair and looked reproachfully on the Martian historian.
ìAre you still poking around these musty old things? Donít you get tired?î
ìPlease, Johnnie,î Ullen did not look up, ìyou will lose de page. Dat book dere is William Stewartís ëHitlerian Eraí and it is very hard to read. So many words he uses which he doesnít explain.î
His expression as it focussed upon Johnnie was one of frowning petulance, ì Never do dey explain deir terms. It is so unscientific. On Mars, before we even start, we say, ëDis is a list of all definitions of terms to be used.í How oderwise can people talk sensibly? Hmp! You crazy Eardmen.î
ìOh, nuts, Ullen-forget it. Why donít you look at me. Donít you even notice anything?î
The Martian sighed, removed his glasses, cleaned them thoughtfully, and carefully replaced them. He stared impersonally at Johnnie, ìWell, I think it is new clothes you are wearing. Is it not so?î
ìNew clothes! Is that all you can say, Ullen? This is a uniform. Iím a member of the Home Defense.î He rose to his feet, a picture of boyish exuberance.
ìWhat is dis ëHome Defenseí?î asked Ullen languidly.
Johnnie gulped and sat down helplessly, ìYou know, I really think you havenít heard that Earth and Venus have been at war for the last week. Iíll bet money you havenít.î
ìIíve been busy.î He frowned and pursed his thin, bloodless lips, ìOn Mars, dere is no war-at least, dere isnít any more. Once, we used to fight, but dat was long ago. Once we were scientists, too, and dat was long ago. Now, dere are only a few of us-and we do not fight Dere is no happiness dat way.î He seemed to shake himself, and spoke more briskly, ìTell me, Johnnie, do you know where it is I can find what it means, dis ënational honor?í It holds me back. I canít go furder unless I can understand it.î
Johnnie rose to his full height and glittered in the spotless green of the Terrestrial Service. He laughed with fond indulgence, ìYouíre hopeless, Ullen,-you old coot. Arenít you going to wish me luck? Iím hitting space tomorrow.î
ìOh, is dere danger?î
There was a squawk of laughter, ìDanger? What do you think?î
ìWell, den, to seek danger-it is foolish. Why do you do it?î
ìYou wouldnít understand, Ullen. Just wish me luck and say you hope I come through whole.î
ìCer-tain-ly!.1 donít want anyone to die.î He slipped his hand into the strong fist held out to him. ìTake care of yourself, Johnnie-and wait, before you go, bring me Stewartís book. Everything is so heavy here on Eard. Heavy, heavy,- and de words have no definitions.î
He sighed, and was back at his books as Johnnie slipped quietly out of the room.
ìDese barbarous people,î he muttered sleepily to himself. ìWar! Dey dink dat by killing-î His voice died away and merged into a slurred mumble as his eyes followed creeping finger across the page.
ìëFrom the very moment of the union of the Anglo-Saxon world into a single governmental entity and even as far back as the spring of 1941, it was evident that the doom of-í ì
ìDese crazy Eardmeniî
Ullen leaned heavily upon his crutches on the steps of the University library and one thin hand shielded his watering eyes from the terrible Earthly sun.
The sky was blue, cloudless,-undisturbed. Yet somewhere up above, beyond the planetís airy blanket, steel-sided ships were veering and sparkling in vicious combat. And down upon the city were falling the tiny ìDrops of Death,î the highly radioactive bombs that noiselessly and inexorably ate out a fifteen foot crater wherever they fell.
The cityís population was herding into the shelters and burying themselves inside the deep-set leaden cells. Upstaring, silent, anxious, they streamed past Ullen. Uniformed guards invested some sort of order into the gigantic flight, steering the stragglers and speeding the laggards.
The air was filled with barked orders.
ìHit the shelter, Pop, Better get going. You canít stand there, you know.î
Ullen turned to the guard who addressed him and slowly brought his wandering thoughts to bear upon the situation.
ìI am sorry, Eardman-but I cannot move very fast on your huge world.î He tapped one crutch upon the marble flags beneath. îDings are so heavy. If I were to crowd in wid de rest, I would be crushed.î
He smiled gently down from his lank height, and the guard rubbed a stubbly chin, ìAll right, pop, I can fix that. It is tough on you Marsies at that-Here, hold those crutches up out of the way.î
With a heave, he cradled the Martian, ìHold your legsî close to my body, because weíre going to travel fast.î
His bulky figure pressed through the line of Earthmen. Ullen shut his eyes as the rapid motion under supernormal gravity stirred his stomach into rebellion. He opened them once again in the dim recesses of the low-ceilinged shelter.
The guard set him down carefully and adjusted the crutches beneath Ullenís armpits, ìO.K. Pop. Take care of yourself.î
Ullen took in his surroundings and hobbled to one of the low benches at the near end of the shelter. From behind him came the sombre clang of the thick, leaden door.
The Martian historian fished a worn tablet from his pocket and scribbled slow notes. He disregarded the excited babble that arose about him and the scraps of heated talk that filled the air thickly.
And then he scratched at his furrowed forehead with the stub end of his pencil, meeting the staring eyes of the man sitting next to him. He smiled abstractedly and returned to his notes.
ìYouíre a Martian, arenít you?î His neighbor spoke in quick, squeaky tones. ìI donít like foreigners much, but Iíve got nothing special against Marsies. These Veenies, now, they-î
Ullenís soft tones interrupted him. ìHate is all wrong, I dink. Dis war is a great annoyance-a great one. It interferes wid my work and you Eardmen ought to stop it. Is it not so?î
ìYou can bet your hide weíre going to stop it,î came the emphatic reply. ìWeíre going to bash their planet inside out- and the dirty Veenies with it.î
ìYou mean attack deir cities like dis?î The Martian blinked owlishly in thought, ìYou dink dat would be best?î
ìDamn it, yes. It-î
ìBut look.î Ullen placed a skeleton finger in one palm and continued in gentle argument. ìWould it not be easier to get de ships demselves by de fall-apart weapon?-Donít you dink so? Or is it dat de Venus people, dey have de screens?î
ìWhat weapon, did you say?î
Ullen ruminated carefully, ìI suppose dat isnít de name you call it by-but I donít know about weapons, anyway. We call it on Mars de ë skellingbeg í and dat means in English ëfallapart weapon.í Now you know?î
There was no direct answer unless a vague under-breath mutter could be called one. The Earthman pushed away from his companion and stared at the opposite wall in a fidget.
Ullen sensed the rebuff and shrugged one shoulder wearily, ìIt is not dat I care much about de whole ding. It is only dat de war is a big bodder. It should be ended.î He sighed, ìBut I donít care!î
His fingers had just begun manipulating the pencil once more in its travels across the open tablet on his lap, when he looked up again.
ìTell me, please, what is de name of dat country where Hitler died. Your Eard names, dey are so complicated sometimes. I dink it begins wid an M.î
His neighbor ripped him open with a stare and walked away. Ullenís eyes followed him with a puzzled frown.
And then the all-clear signal sounded.
ìOh, yes,î said Ullen. ìMadagascar I Such a silly name!î
Johnnie Brewsterís uniform was war-worn now; a bit more wrinkled about the neck and shoulders, a trace more worn at knees and elbows.
Ullen ran his finger along the angry scar that ran the length of Johnnieís right fore-arm, ìIt hurts no more, Johnnie?î
ìNuts! A scratch! I got the Veenie that did that. Heís chasing dreams in the moon now.î
ìYou were in de hospital long, Johnnie?î
ìA week!î He lit a cigarette, pushed some of the mess off the Martianís desk and seated himself. ìIíve spent the rest of the time with my family, though I did get around to visiting you, you see.î
He leaned over and poked an affectionate hand at the Martianís leathery cheek, ìArenít you going to say youíre glad to see me?î
Ullen removed his glasses and peered at the Earthman, ìWhy, Johnnie, are you so uncertain dat I am glad to see you, dat you require I should say it in words?î He paused, ìIíll make a note of dat. You silly Eardmen must always be telling each oder dese simple dings-and den you donít believe it anyway. On Mars-î
He was rubbing his glasses methodically, as he spoke, and now he replaced them, ìJohnnie, donít you Eardmen have de ëfall-apartí weapon? I met a person once in de raid shelter and he didnít know what I was talking about.î
Johnnie frowned, ìI donít either, for that matter. Why do you ask?î
ìBecause it seems strange dat you should have to fight so hard dese Venus men, when dey donít seem to have de screens to stop it wid. Johnnie, I want de war should be over. It makes me all de time stop my work to go to a shelter.î
ìHold on, now, Ullen. Donít sputter. What is this ëfall-apartí weapon? A disintegrator? What do you know about it?î
ìI? I know nodding about it at all. I dought you knew- datís why I asked. Back on Mars, in our histories, dey talk about using dat kind of weapon in our old wars. But we donít know nodding about weapons any more. Anyway, deyíre so silly, because de oder side always dinks of someding which protects against it, and den everyding is de same as always.- Johnnie, do you suppose you could go down to de desk and ask for a copy of Higginboddamís ëBeginnings of Space Travel?íì
The Earthman clenched his fists and shook them impotently, ìUllen, you damned Martian pedant-donít you understand that this is important? Earth is at war! War! War! War! î
ìWell, den, stop de war.î There was irritation in Ullenís voice. ìDere is no peace and quiet anywheres on Eard. I wish I had dis library-Johnnie, be careful. Please, what are you doing? Youíre hurting me.î
ìIím sorry, Ullen, but youíve got to come with me. Weíre going to see about this.î Johnny had the feebly protesting Martian wedged into the wheel-chair and was off with a rush, before he had finished the sentence.
A rocket-taxi was at the bottom of the Library steps, and together chauffeur and Spaceman lifted the chair inside. With a comet-tail of smoke, they were off.
Ullen moaned softly at the acceleration, but Johnnie ignored him. ìWashington in twenty minutes, fellow,î he said to the driver, ìand ignore the signal beams.î
The starched secretary spoke in a frozen monotone, ìAdmiral Korsakoff will see you now.î
Johnnie wheeled and stamped out the last cigarette butt. He shot a hasty glance at his watch and grunted.
At the motion of the wheel-chair, Ullen roused himself out of a troubled sleep. He adjusted his glasses, ìDid dey let us in finally, Johnnie?î
ìShhh!î
Ullenís impersonal stare swept over the rich furnishings of the room, the huge maps of Earth and Venus on the wall, the imposing desk in the center. It lingered upon the pudgy, bearded figure behind this desk and then came to rest upon the lanky, sandy-haired man at his side.
The Martian attempted to rise from the chair in sudden eagerness, ìArenít you Dr. Doming? I saw you last year at Princeton. You remember me, donít you? Dey gave me at dat time, my honorary degree.î
Dr. Thorning had advanced and shook hands vigorously, ìCertainly. You spoke then on Martian historical methods, didnít you?î
ìOh, you remember. Iím glad! But dis is a great opportunity for me, meeting you. Tell me, as a scientist, what would be your opinion of my deory dat de social insecurity of de Hitlerian Era was de direct cause for de lag-î
Dr. Thorning smiled, ìIíll discuss it with you later, Dr. Ullen. Right now, Admiral Korsakoff wants information from you, with which we hope to end the war.î
ìExactly,î Korsakoff spoke in clipped tones as he met Ullenís mild gaze. ìAlthough a Martian, I presume you favor the victory of the principles of freedom and justice over the foul practices of Venusian tyranny.î
Ullen stared uncertainly, ìDat sounds familiar-but I donít dink about it much. You mean, maybe, de war should end?î
ìWith victory, yes.î
ìOh, ëvictory,í dat is just a silly word. History proves dat a war decided on military superiority only lays de groundwork for future wars of retaliation and revenge. I refer you to a very good essay on de subject by a James Calkins. It was published all de way back in 2050.î
ìMy dear sir!î
Ullen raised his voice in bland indifference to Johnnieís urgent whisperings. ìNow to end de war-really end it-you should say to de plain people of Venus, ëIt is unnecessary to fight. Let us just talkí-î
There was the slam of fist on desk and a muttered oath of frightful import. ìFor Godís sakes, Thorning, get what you want out of him. I give you five minutes.î
Thorning stifled his chuckle, ìDr. Ullen, we want you to tell us what you know about the disintegrator.î
ìDisintegrator?î Ullen put a puzzled finger to his cheek.
ìThe one you told Lieutenant Brewster of.î
ìUmmmm- Oh! You mean de ëfall-apartí weapon. I donít know nodding about it De Martian historians mention it some times, but none of dem know about it-de technical side, dat is.î
The sandy-haired physicist nodded patiently, ìI know, I know. But what do they say? What kind of a weapon is it?î
ìWell, de way dey talk about it, it makes de metals to fall to pieces. What is it you call de ding dat holds metals togedder/now?î
ìIntra-molecular forces?î
Ullen frowned and then spoke thoughtfully, ìMaybe. I forgot what de Martian word is-except dat itís long. Anyway, dis weapon, it makes dis force dat holds de metals to gedder not to exist anymore and it all falls apart in a powder. But it only works on de dree metals, Iron, cobalt, and-uh-de odder one!î
ìNickel,î prompted Johnnie, softly.
ìYes, yes, nickel!î
Thorningís eyes glittered, ìAha, the ferromagnetic elements. Thereís an oscillating magnetic field mixed up in this, or Iím a Veenie. How about it, Ullen?î
The Martian sighed, ìSuch crazy Eard words.-Letís see now, most of what I know about de weapon is from de work of Hogel Beg. It was-Iím pretty sure-in his ìCultural and Social History of de Dird Empire.î It was a huge work in twenty-four volumes, but I always dought it was radder mediocre. His technique in de presentation of-î
ìPlease,î said Thorning, ìthe weapon-î
ìOh, yes, dat! î He hitched himself higher in his chair and grimaced with the effort. ìHe talks about electricity and it goes back and ford very fast- very fast, and its pressure-î He paused hopelessly, and regarded the scowling visage of the bearded Admiral naively, ìI dink de word is pressure, but I donít know, because it is hard to translate. De Martian word is ë cranstard .í Does dat help?î
ìI think you mean ëpotential,í Dr. Ullen!î Thorning sighed audibly.
ìWell, if you say so. Anyway, dis ëpotentialí changes also very fast and de two changes are synchronized somehow along wid magnetism dat-uh-shifts and datís all I know about it.î He smiled uncertainly, ìI would like to go back now. It would be all right now, wouldnít it?î
The Admiral vouchsafed no answer, ìDo you make anything out of that mess. Doctor?î
ìDamned little,î admitted the physicist, ìbut it gives me a lead or two. We might try getting hold of this Begís book, but thereís not much hope. It will simply repeat what weíve just heard. Dr. Ullen, are there any scientific works on your planet?î
The Martian saddened, ìNo, Dr. Doming, dey were all destroyed during de Kalynian reaction. On Mars, we doroughly disbelieve in science. History has shown dat it comes from science no happiness.î He turned to the young Earthman at his side, ìJohnnie, let us go now, please.î
Korsakoff dismissed the two with a wave of the hand.
Ullen bent carefully over the closely-typed manuscript and inserted a word. He glanced up brightly at Johnnie Brewster, who shook his head and placed a hand on the Martianís arm. His brow furrowed more deeply.
Ullen,î he said harshly, ìyouíre in trouble.î
ìEh? I? In trouble? Why, Johnnie, dat is not so. My book is coming along famously. De whole first volume, it is completed and, but for a bit of polishing, is ready for de printers.î
ìUllen, if you canít give the government definite information on the disintegrator, I wonít answer for the consequences.î
ìBut I told all I knew-î
ìIt wonít do. Ifs not enough. Youíve got to remember more, Ullen, youíve got to.î
ìBut knowledge where dere is none is impossible to have- dat is an axiom.î Ullen sat upright in his seat, propping himself on a crutch.
ìI know it,î Johnnieís mouth twisted in misery, ìbut youíve got to understand.
ìThe Venusians have control of space; our Asteroid garrisons have been wiped out, and last week Phobos and Deimos fell. Communications between Earth and Luna are broken and God knows how long the Lunar squadron can hold out. Earth itself is scarcely secure and their bombings are becoming more serious-.Oh, Ullen, donít you understand?î
The Martianís look of confusion deepened, ìEard is losing?î
ìGod, yes!î
ìDen give up. Dat is de logical ding to do. Why did you start at all-you stupid Eardmen.î
Johnnie ground his teeth, ìBut if we have the disintegrator, we wonít lose.î
Ullen shrugged, ìOh, Johnnie, it gets wearisome to listen to de same old story. You Eardmen have one-track minds. Look, wouldnít it make you feel better to have me read you some of my manuscript? It would do your intellect good.î
ìAll right, Ullen, youíve asked for it, and hereís everything right out If you donít tell Thorning what he wants to know, youíre going to be arrested and tried for treason.î
There was a short silence, and then a confused stutter, ìT- treason. You mean dat I betray-î The historian removed his glasses and wiped them with shaking hand, ìItís not true. Youíre trying to frighten me.î
ìOh, no, Iím not Korsakoff thinks you know more than youíre telling. Heís sure that youíre either holding out for a price or, more likely, that youíve sold out to the Veenies.î
ìBut Doming-î
ìThorning isnít any too secure himself. He has his own skin to think of. Earth governments in moments of stress are not famous for being reasonable.î There were sudden tears in his -eyes, ìUllen, there must be something you can do. Itís not only you-itís for Earth.î
Ullenís breathing whistled harshly, ìDey tink I would sell my scientific knowledge. Is dat de kind of insult dey pay my sense of eddies; my scientific integrity?î His voice was thick with fury and for the first time since Johnnie knew him, he lapsed into guttural Martian. ìFor dat, I say not a word,î he finished. ìLet dem put me in prison or shoot me, but dis insult I cannot forget.î
There was no mistaking the firmness in his eyes, and Johnnieís shoulders sagged. The Earthman didnít move at the glare of the signal light.
ìAnswer de light, Johnnie,î said the Martian, softly. ìDey are coming for me.î
In a moment, the room was crowded with green uniforms. Dr. Thorning and the two with him were the only ones present in civilian clothes.
Ullen struggled to his feet, ìGentlemen, say nodding. I have heard dat it is dought dat I am selling what I know- selling for money .î He spat the words. ìIt is a ding never before said of me-a ding-F-bave not deserved. If you wish you can imprison me immediately, but I shall say nodding more- nor have anyding furder to do wid de Eard government.î
A green-garbed official stepped forward immediately, but Dr. Thorning waved him back.
ìWhoa, there. Dr. Ullen,î he said jovially, ìdonít jump too soon. Iíve just come to ask if there isnít a single additional fact that you remember. Anything, no matter how insignificant-î
There was stony silence. Ullen leant heavily on his crutches but remained stolidly erect.
Dr. Thorning seated himself imperturably upon the historianís desk, picked up the high stack of type-written pages, ìAh, is this the manuscript young Brewster was telling me about.î He gazed at it curiously, ìWell, of course, you realize that your attitude will force the government to confiscate all this.î
ìEh?î Ullenís stern expression melted into dismay. His crutch slipped and he dropped heavily into his seat.
The physicist warded off the otherís feeble clutch, ìKeep your hands off. Dr. Ullen, Iím taking care of this.î He leafed through the pages with a rustling noise. ìYou see, if you are arrested for treason, your writings become subversive.î
ìSubversive!î Ullenís voice was hoarse, ìDr. Doming, you donít know what you are saying. It is my-my great labor.î His voice caught huskily, ìPlease, Dr. Doming, give me my manuscript.î
The other held it just beyond the Martianís shaking fingers.
ì If -î he said.
ìBut I donít know!î
The sweat stood out on the historianís pale face. His voice came thickly. ìTime! Give me time! But let me dink-and donít, please donít harm dis manuscriptî
The otherís fingers sank painfully into Ullenís shoulder, ìSo help me, I burn your manuscript in five minutes, if-î
ìWait, Iíll tell you. Somewhere-I donít know where-it was said dat in de weapon dey used a special metal for some of de wiring. I donít know what metal, but water spoiled it and had to be kept away-also air. It-î
ìHoly jumping Jupiter ,î came the sudden shout from one of Thorningís companions. ìChief, donít you remember Aspartierís work on sodium wiring in argon atmosphere five years ago-î
Dr. Thorningís eyes were deep with thought, ìWait-wait- wait- Damn! It was staring us in the face-î
ìI know,î shrieked Ullen suddenly. ìIt was in Karlsto. He was discussing de fall of Gallonie and dat was one of de minor causes-de lack of dat metal-and den he mentioned-î
He was talking to an empty room, and for a while he was silent in puzzled astonishment.
And then, ìMy manuscript!î He salvaged it from where it lay scattered over the floor, hobbling painfully about, smoothing each wrinkled sheet with care.
ìDe barbarians-to treat a great scientific work so!î
Ullen opened still another drawer and scrabbled through its contents. He closed it and looked about peevishly, ìJohnnie, where did I put dat bibliography? Did you see it?î
He looked toward the window, ìJohnnielî
Johnnie Brewster said, ìWait a while, Ullen. Here they come now.î
The streets below were a burst of color. In a long, stiffly-moving line the Green of the Navy paraded down the avenue, the air above them snow-thick with confetti, hail-thick with ticker-tape. The roar of the crowd was dull, muted.
ìAh, de foolish people,î mused Ullen. ìDey were happy just like dis when de war started and dere was a parade just like dis-and now anodder one. Silly!î He stumped back to his chair.
Johnnie followed, ìThe government is naming a new museum after you, isnít it?î
ìYes,î was the dry reply. He peered helplessly about under the desk, ìDe Ullen War Museum-and it will be filled wid ancient weapons, from stone knife to anti-aircraft gun. Dat is your queer Eard sense of de fitness of dings. Where in dunderation is dat bibliography?î
ìHere,î said Johnnie, withdrawing the document from Ullenís vest pocket. ìOur victory was due to your weapon, ancient to you, so it is fit in a way.î
ìVictory! Sure! Until Venus rearms and reprepares and refights for revenge. All history shows-but never mind. It is useless, dis talk.î He settled himself deeply in his chair, ìHere, let me show you a real victory. Let me read you some of de first volume of my work. Itís already in print, you know.î
Johnnie laughed, ìGo ahead, Ullen. Right now Iím even willing to listen to you read your entire twelve volumes- word for word.î
And Ullen smiled gently. ìIt would be good for your intellect,î he said.



***



ìHistory,î you will notice, mentions Hitlerís end. It was written in the first days of September 1940, when Hitler seemed at the very peak of his success. France was defeated and occupied and Britain was at bay and seemed unlikely to survive. -Still, I had no doubt as to his ultimate defeat. I did not visualize his ending in suicide, however. I thought that like Napoleon and the Kaiser, he would end his life in exile. Madagascar was the place I picked.
Also mentioned in the story are ìthe tiny ëDrops of Death,í the highly-publicized radioactive bombs that noiselessly and inexorably ate out a fifteen-foot crater wherever they fell.î
By the time I wrote the story, uranium fission had been discovered and announced. I had not yet heard of it, however, and I was unaware that reality was about to outstrip my prized science fictional imagination.
On October 23, 1940, I visited Campbell and outlined to him another robot story I wanted to write, a story I planned to call ìReason.î Campbell was completely enthusiastic. I had trouble writing it and had to start over several times, but eventually it was done, and on November 18 I submitted it to John. He accepted it on the twenty-second, and it appeared in the April 1941 issue of Astounding .
It was the third story of mine that he had accepted and the first in which he did not ask for a revision. (He told me, in fact, that he had liked it So well, he had almost decided to pay me a bonus.)
With ìReason,î the ìpositronic robotî series was fairly launched, and my two most successful characters yet, Gregory Powell and Mike Donovan (improvements on Turner and Snead of ìRing Around the Sunî) made their appearance. Eventually, ìReasonî and others of the series that were to follow, together with ìRobbie,î which Campbell had rejected, were to appear in I, Robot .
The success of ìReasonî didnít mean that I was to have no further rejections from Campbell.
On December 6, 1940, influenced by the season and never stopping to think that a Christmas story must sell no later than July in order to make the Christmas issue, I began ìChristmas on Ganymede.î I submitted it to him on the twenty-third, but the holiday season did not affect his critical judgment. He rejected it.
I tried Pohl next, and, as was happening so often that year, he took it. In this case, for reasons I will describe later, the acceptance fell through. I eventually sold it the next summer (June 27, 1941, the proper time of year) to Startling Stories, the younger, sister magazine of Thrilling Wonder Stories.








Christmas On Ganymede


Olaf Johnson hummed nasally to himself and his china-blue eyes were dreamy as he surveyed the stately fir tree in the corner of the library. Though the library was the largest single room in the Dome, Olaf felt it none too spacious for the occasion. Enthusiastically he dipped into the huge crate at his side and took out the first roll of red-and-green crepe paper.
What sudden burst of sentiment had inspired the Ganymedan Products Corporation, Inc. to ship a complete collection of Christmas decorations to the Dome, he did not pause to inquire. Olafís was a placid disposition, and in his self-imposed job as chief Christmas decorator, he was content with his lot.
He frowned suddenly and muttered a curse. The General Assembly signal light was Hashing on and off hysterically. With a hurt air Olaf laid down the tack-hammer he had just lifted, then the roll of crepe paper, picked some tinsel out of his hair and left for officers quarters.
Commander Scott Pelham was in his deep armchair at the head of the table when Olaf entered. His stubby fingers were drumming unrhythmically upon the glass-topped table. Olaf met the commanderís hotly furious eyes without fear, for nothing had gone wrong in his department in twenty Ganymedan revolutions.
The room filled rapidly with men, and Pelhamís eyes hardened as he counted noses in one sweeping glance.
ìWeíre all here. Men, we face a crisis!î
There was a vague stir. Olafís eyes sought the ceiling and he relaxed. Crises hit the Dome once a revolution, on the average. Usually they turned out to be a sudden rise in the quota of oxite to be gathered, or the inferior quality of the last batch of karen leaves. He stiffened, however, at the next words.
ìIn connection with the crisis, I have one question to ask.î Pelhamís voice was a deep baritone, and it rasped unpleasantly when he was angry. ìWhat dirty imbecilic troublemaker has been telling those blasted Ossies fairy tales?î
Olaf cleared his throat nervously and thus immediately became the center of attention. His Adamís apple wobbled in sudden alarm and his forehead wrinkled into a washboard. He shivered.
ìI-I-î he stuttered, quickly fell silent. His long fingers made a bewildered gesture of appeal. ìI mean I was out there yesterday, after the last-uh-supplies of karen leaves, on account the Ossies were slow and-î
A deceptive sweetness entered Pelhamís voice. He smiled.
ìDid you tell those natives about Santa Claus, Olaf?î
The smile looked uncommonly like a wolfish leer and Olaf broke down. He nodded convulsively.
ìOh, you did? Well, well, you told them about Santa Claus! He comes down in a sleigh that Hies through the air with eight reindeer pulling it, huh?î
ìWell-er-doesnít he?î Olaf asked unhappily.
ìAnd you drew pictures of the reindeer, just to make sure there was no mistake. Also, he has a long white beard and red clothes with white trimmings.î
ìYeah, thatís right,î said Olaf, his face puzzled
ìAnd he has a big bag, chock full of presents for good little boys and girls, and he brings it down the chimney and puts presents inside stockings.î
ìSure.î
ìYou also told them heís about due, didnít you? One more revolution and heís going to visit us.î
Olaf smiled weakly. ìYeah, Commander, I meant to ten you. Iím fixing up the tree and-î
ìShut up!î The commander was breathing hard in a whistling sort of way. ìDo you know what those Ossies have thought of?î
ìNo, Commander.î
Pelham leaned across the table toward Olaf and shouted:
ìThey want Santa Claus to visit them!î
Someone laughed and changed it quickly into a strangling cough at the commanderís raging stare.
ìAnd if Santa Claus doesnít visit them, the Ossies are going to quit work!î He repeated, ìQuit cold-strike!î
There was no laughter, strangled or otherwise, after that. If there were more than one thought among the entire group, it didnít show itself. Olaf expressed that thought:
ìBut what about the quota?î
ìWell, what about it?î snarled Pelham. ìDo I have to draw pictures for you? Ganymedan Products has to get one hundred tons of wolframite, eighty tons of karen leaves and fifty tons of oxite every year, or it loses its franchise. I suppose there isnít anyone here who doesnít know that. It so happens that the current year ends in two Ganymedan revolutions, and weíre five per cent behind schedule as it is.î
There was pure, horrified silence.
ìAnd now the Ossies worit work unless they get Santa Claus. No work, no quota, no franchise-no jobs! Get that, you low-grade morons. When the company loses its franchise, we lose the best-paying jobs in the System. Kiss them good-by, men, unless-î
He paused, glared steadily at Olaf, and added:
ìUnless, by next revolution, we have a flying sleigh, eight reindeer and a Santa Claus. And by every cosmic speck in the rings of Saturn, weíre going to have just that, especially a Santa!î
Ten faces turned ghastly pale.
ìGot someone in mind, Commander?î asked someone in a voice that was three-quarters croak.
ìYes, as a matter of fact, I have.î
He sprawled back in his chair. Olaf Johnson broke into a sudden sweat as he found himself staring at the end of a pointing forefinger.
ìAw, Commander!î he quavered.
The pointing finger never moved.
Pelham tramped into the foreroom, removed his oxygen nosepiece and the cold cylinders attached to it One by one he cast off thick woolen outer garments and, with a final, weary sigh, jerked off a pair of heavy knee-high space boots.
Sim Pierce paused in his careful inspection of the latest batch of karen leaves and cast a hopeful glance over his spectacles.
ìWell?î he asked.
Pelham shrugged. ìI promised them Santa. What else could I do? I also doubled sugar rations, so theyíre back on the job-for the moment.î
ìYou mean till the Santa we promised doesnít show up.î Pierce straightened and waved a long karen leaf at the commanderís face for emphasis. ìThis is the silliest thing I ever heard of. It canít be done. There ainít no Santa Claus!î
ìTry telling that to the Ossies:í Pelham slumped into a chair and his expression became stonily bleak. ìWhatís Benson doing?î
ìYou mean that flying sleigh he says he can rig up?î Pierce held a leaf up to the light and peered at it critically. ìHeís a crackpot, if you ask me. The old buzzard went down to the sub-level this morning and heís been there ever since. All I know is that heís taken the spare lectro-dissociator apart. If anything happens to the regular, it just means that weíre without oxygen.î
ìWell,î Pelham rose heavily, ìfor my part I hope we do choke. It would be an easy way out of this whole mess. Iím going down below.î
He stumped out and slammed the door behind him.
In the sub-level he gazed about in bewilderment, for the room was littered with gleaming chrome-steel machine parts. It took him some time to recognize the mess as the remains of what had been a compact, snugly built lectro-dissociator the day before. In the center, in anachronistic contrast, stood a dusty wooden sleigh atop rust-red runners. From beneath it came the sound of hammering.
ìHey, Benson!î called Pelham.
A grimy, sweat-streaked face pushed out from underneath the sleigh, and a stream of tobacco juice shot toward Bensonís ever-present cuspidor.
ìWhat are you shouting like that for?î he complained. ìThis is delicate work. ì
ìWhat the devil is that weird contraption?î demanded Pelham.
ìFlying sleigh. My own idea, too.î The light of enthusiasm shone in Bensonís watery eyes, and the quid in his mouth shifted from cheek to cheek as he spoke. ìThe sleigh was brought here in the old days, when they thought Ganymede was covered with snow like the other Jovian moons. All I have to do is fix a few gravo-repulsors from the dissociator to the bottom and thatíll make it weightless when the currentís on. Compressed air-jets will do the rest. ì
The commander chewed his lower lip dubiously.
ìWill it work?î
ìSure it will. Lots of people have thought of using repulsors in air travel, but theyíre inefficient, especially in heavy gravity fields. Here on Ganymede, with a field of one-third gravity and a thin atmosphere, a child could run it. Even Johnson could run it, though I wouldnít mourn if he fell off and broke his blasted neck.î
ìAll right, then, look here. Weíve got lots of this native purplewood. Get Charlie Finn and tell him to put that sleigh on a platform of it. Heís to have it extend about twenty feet or more frontward, with a railing around the part that projects.î
Benson spat and scowled through the stringy hair over his eyes.
ìWhatís the idea, Commander?î
Pelhamís laughter came in short, harsh barks.
ìThose Ossies are expecting reindeer, and reindeer theyíre going to have. Those animals will have to stand on something, wonít they?î
ìSureÖBut wait, hold on! There arenít any reindeer on Ganymede.î
Commander Pelham paused on his way out. His eyes narrowed unpleasantly as they always did when he thought of Olaf Johnson.
ìOlaf is out rounding up eight spinybacks for us. Theyíve got four feet, a head on one end and a tail on the other. Thatís close enough for the Ossies.î
The old engineer chewed this information and chuckled nastily.
ìGood! I wish the fool joy of his job.î
ìSo do I,î gritted Pelham.
He stalked out as Benson, still leering, slid underneath the sleigh.
The commanderís description of a spinyback was concise and accurate, but it left out several interesting details. For one thing, a spinyback has a long, mobile snout, two large ears that wave back and forth gently, and two emotional purple eyes. The males have pliable spines of a deep crimson color along the backbone that seem to delight the female of the species. Combine these with a scaly, muscular tail and a brain by no means mediocre, and you have a spinyback-or at least you have one if you can catch one.
It was just such a thought that occurred to Olaf Johnson as he sneaked down from the rocky eminence toward the herd of twenty-five spinybacks grazing on the sparse, gritty undergrowth. The nearest spinies looked up as Olaf, bundled in fur and grotesque with attached oxygen nosepiece, approached. However, spinies have no natural enemies, so they merely gazed at the figure with lanquidly disapproving eyes and returned to their crunchy but nourishing fare.
Olafís notions on bagging big game were sketchy. He fumbled in his pocket for a lump of sugar, held it out and said:
ìHere, pussy, pussy, pussy, pussy, pussy!î
The ears of the nearest spinie twitched in annoyance. Olaf came closer and held out the sugar again.
ìCome, bossy! Come. Bossy!î
The spinie caught sight of the sugar and rolled his eyes at it. His snout twitched as he spat out his last mouthful of vegetation and ambled over. With neck stretched out, he sniffed. Then, using a rapid, expert motion, he struck at the outheld palm and Hipped the lump into his mouth. Olafís other hand whistled down upon nothingness.
With a hurt expression, Olaf held out another piece. ìHere. Prince! Here, Fido!î
The spinie made a low, tremulous sound deep in his throat. It was a sound of pleasure. Evidently this strange monstrosity before him. having gone insane, intended to feed him these bits of concentrated succulence forever. He snatched and was back as quickly as the first time. But. since Olaf had held on firmly this time, the spinie almost bagged half a finger as well.
Olafís yell lacked a bit of the nonchalance necessary at such times. Nevertheless. a bite that can be felt through thick gloves is a bite!
He advanced boldly upon the spinie. There are some things that stir the Johnson blood and bring up the ancient spirit of the Vikings. Having oneís finger bitten, especially by an unearthly animal, is one of these.
There was an uncertain look in the spinieís eyes as he backed slowly away. There werenít any white cubes being offered any more and he wasnít quite sure what was going to happen now. The uncertainty vanished with a suddenness he did not expect, when two glove-muffled hands came down upon his ears and jerked. He let out a high-pitched yelp and charged forward.
A spinie has a certain sense of dignity. He doesnít like to have his ears pulled. particularly when other spinies. including several unattached females, have formed a ring and are looking on.
The Earthman went over backward and remained in that position for awhile. Meantime, the spinie backed away a few feet in a gentlemanly manner and allowed Johnson to get to his feet.
The old Viking blood frothed still higher in Olaf. After rubbing the hurt spot where he had landed on his oxygen cylinder, he jumped, forgetting to allow for Ganymedean gravity. He sailed five feet over the spinieís back.
There was awe in the animalís eye as he watched Olaf, for it was a stately jump. But there was a certain amount of bewilderment as well. There seemed to be no purpose to the maneuver.
Olaf landed on his back again and got the cylinder in the same place. He was beginning to feel a little embarrassed. The sounds that came from the circle of onlookers were remarkably like snickers.
ìLaugh!î he muttered bitterly. ìI havenít even begun to fight yet.î
He approached the spinie slowly, cautiously. He circled, watching for his opening. So did the spinie. Olaf feinted and the spinie ducked. Then the spinie reared and Olaf ducked.
Olaf kept remembering new profanity all the time. The husky ìUr-r-r-r-rî that came out the spinieís throat seemed to lack the brotherly spirit that is usually associated with Christmas.
There was a sudden, swishing sound. Olaf felt something collide with his skull, just behind his left ear. This time he turned a back somersault and landed on the nape of his neck. There was a chorused whinny from the onlookers, and the spinie waved his tail triumphantly.
Olaf got rid of the impression that he was floating through a star-studded unlimited space and wavered to his feet.
ìListen,î he objected, ìusing your tail is a foul!î
He leaped back as the tail shot forward again, then flung himself forward in a diving tackle. He grabbed at the spinieís feet and felt the animal come down on his back with an indignant yelp.
Now it was a case of Earth muscles against Ganymedan muscles, and Olaf became a man of brute strength. He struggled up, and the spinie found himself slung over the strangerís shoulders.
The spinie objected vociferously and tried to prove his objections by a judicious whip of the tail. But he was in an inconvenient position and the stroke whistled harmlessly over Olafís head.
The other spinies made way for the Earthman with saddened expressions. Evidently they were all good friends of the captured animal and hated to see him lose a fight. They returned to their meal in philosophic resignation, plainly convinced that it was kismet.
On the other side of the rocky ledge, Olaf reached his prepared cave. There was the briefest of scrambling shíuggles before he managed to sit down hard on the spinieís head and put enough knots into rope to hold him there.
A few hours later, when he had corralled his eighth spinyback, he possessed the technique that comes of long practice. He could have given a Terrestrial cowboy valuable pointers on throwing a maverick. Also, he could have given a Terrestrial stevedore lessons in simple and compound swearing.
ìTwas the night before Christmas-and all through the Ganymedan Dome there was deafening noise and bewildering excitement, like an exploding nova equipped for sound. Around the rusty sleigh, mounted on its huge platform of purplewood, five Earthmen were staging a battle royal with a spinie.
The spinie had definite views about most things, and one of his stubbornest and most definite views was that he would never go where he didnít want to go. He made that clear by flailing one head, one tail, three spines and four legs in every possible direction, with all possible force.
But the Earthmen insisted, and not gently. Despite loud, agonized squeaks, the spinie was lifted onto the platform, hauled into place and harnessed into hopeless helplessness.
ìOkay!î Peter Benson yelled. ìPass the bottle.î
Holding the spinieís snout with one hand, Benson waved the bottle under it with the other. The spinie quivered eagerly and whined tremulously. Benson poured some of the liquid down the animalís throat. There was a gurgling swallow and an appreciative whinny. The spinieís neck stretched out for more.
Benson sighed. ìOur best brandy, too.î
