He up-ended the bottle and withdrew it half empty. The spinie, eyes whirling in their sockets rapidly, did what seemed an attempt at a gay jig. It didnít last long, however, for Ganymedan metabolism is almost immediately affected by alcohol. His muscles locked in a drunken rigor and, with a loud hiccup, he went out on his feet.
ìDrag out the next!î yelled Benson.
In an hour the eight spinybacks were so many cataleptic statues. Forked sticks were tied around their heads as antlers. The effect was crude and sketchy, but it would do.
As Benson opened his mouth to ask where Olaf Johnson was, that worthy showed up in the arms of three comrades, and he was putting up as stiff a fight as any spinie. His objections, however, were highly articulate.
ìIím not going anywhere in this costume!î he roared, gouging at the nearest eye. ìYou hear me?î
There certainly was cause for objection. Even at his best, Olaf had never been a heart-throb. But in his present condition, he resembled a hybrid between a spinieís nightmare and a Picassian conception of a patriarch.
He wore the conventional costume of Santa. His clothes were as red as red tissue paper sewed onto his space coat could make it. The ìermineî was as white as cotton wool, which it was. His beard, more cotton wool glued into a linen foundation, hung loosely from his ears. With that below and his oxygen nosepiece above, even the strongest were forced to avert their eyes.
Olaf had not been shown a mirror. But, between what he could see of himself and what his instinct told him, he would have greeted a good, bright lightning bolt like a brother.
By fits and starts, he was hauled to the sleigh. Others pitched in to help, until Olaf was nothing but a smothered squirm and muffled voice.
ìLeggo,î he mumbled. ìLeggo and come at me one by one. Come on!î
He tried to spar a bit, to point his dare. But the multiple grips upon him left him unable to wriggle a finger.
ìGet in!î ordered Benson.
ìYou go to hell!î gasped Olaf. ìIím not getting into any patented short-cut to suicide, and you can take your bloody flying sleigh and-ì
ìListen,î interrupted Benson, ìCommander Pelham is waiting for you at the other end. Heíll skin you alive if you donít show up in half an hour.î
ìCommander Pelham can take the sleigh sideways and-î
ìThen think of your job! Think of a hundred and fifty a week. Think of every other year off with pay. Think of Hilda, back on Earth, who isnít going to marry you without a job. Think of all that!î
Johnson thought, snarled. He thought some more, got into the sleigh, strapped down his bag and turned on the gravo-repulsors. With a horrible curse, he opened the rear jet.
The sleigh dashed forward and he caught himself from going backward, over and out of the sleigh, by two-thirds of a whisker. He held onto the sides thereafter, watching the surrounding hills as they rose and fell with each lurch of the unsteady sleigh.
As the wind rose, the undulations grew more marked. And when Jupiter came up, its yellow light brought out every jag and crag of the rocky ground, toward everyone of which, in turn, the sleigh seemed headed. And by the time the giant planet had shoved completely over the horizon, the curse of drink-which departs from the Ganymedan organism just as quickly as it descends-began removing itself from the spinies.
The hindmost spinie came out of it first, tasted the inside of his mouth, winced and swore off drink. Having made that resolution, he took in his immediate surroundings languidly. They made no immediate impression on him. Only gradually was the fact forced upon him that his footing, whatever it was, was not the usual stable one of solid Ganymede. It swayed and shifted, which seemed very unusual.
Yet he might have attributed this unsteadiness to his recent orgy, had he not been so careless as to drop his glance over the railing to which he was anchored. No spinie ever died of heart-failure, as far as is recorded, but, looking downward, this one almost did.
His agonized screech of horror and despair brought the other spinies into full, if headachy, consciousness. For a while there was a confused blur of squawking conversation as the animals tried to get the pain out of their heads and the facts in. Both aims were achieved and a stampede was organized. It wasnít much of a stampede, because the spinies were anchored tightly. But, except for the fact that they got nowhere, they went through all the motions of a full gallop. And the sleigh went crazy.
Olaf grabbed his beard a second before it let go of his ears.
ìHey!î he shouted.
It was something like saying ìTut, tutî to a hurricane.
The sleigh kicked, bucked and did a hysterical tango. It made sudden spurts, as if inspired to dash its wooden brains out against Ganymedeís crust. Meanwhile Olaf prayed, swore, wept and jiggled all the compressed air jets at once.
Ganymede whirled and Jupiter was a wild blur. Perhaps it was the spectacle of Jupiter doing the shimmy that steadied the spinies. More likely it was the fact that they just didnít give a hang any more. Whatever it was, they halted, made lofty farewell speeches to one another, confessed their sins and waited for death.
The sleigh steadied and Olaf resumed his breathing once more. Only to stop again as he viewed the curious spectacle of hills and solid ground up above, and black sky and swollen Jupiter down below.
It was at this point that he, too, made his peace with the eternal and awaited the end.
ìOssieî is short for ostrich, and thatís what native Ganymedans look like, except that their necks are shorter, their heads are larger, and their feathers look as if they were about to fall out by the roots. To this, add a pair of scrawny, feathered arms with three stubby fingers apiece. They can speak English, but when you hear them, you wish they couldnít
There were fifty of them in the low purplewood structure that was their ìmeeting hall.î On the mound of raised dirt in the front of the room-dark with the smoky dimness of burning purplewood torches fetid to boot-sat Commander Scott Pelham and five of his men. Before them strutted the frowziest Ossie of them all, inflating his huge chest with rhythmic, booming sounds.
He stopped for a moment and pointed to a ragged hole in the ceiling.
ìLook!î he squawked. ìChimney. We make. Sannycaws come in.î
Pelham grunted approval. The Ossie clucked happily. He pointed to the little sacks of woven grass that hung from the walls.
ìLook! Stockies. Sannycaws put presets!î
ìYeah,î said Pelham unenthusiastically. ìChimney and stockings. Very nice.î He spoke out of the corner of his mouth to Sim Pierce, who sat next to him: ìAnother half-hour in this dump will kill me. When is that fool coming?î
Pierce stirred uneasily.
ìListen,î he said, ìIíve been doing some figuring. Weíre safe on everything but the karen leaves, and weíre still four tons short on that If we can get this fool business over with in the next hour, so we can start the next shift and work the Ossies at double, we can make itî He leaned back ìYes, I think we can make itî
ìJust about,î replied Pelham gloomily. ìThatís if Johnson gets here without pulling another bloomer.î
The Ossie was talking again, for Ossies like to talk He said:
ìEvery year Kissmess comes. Kissmess nice, evvybody friendly. Ossie like Kissmess. You like Kissmess?î
ìYeah, fine,î Pelham snarled politely. ìPeace on Ganymede, good will toward men-especially Johnson. Where the devil is that idiot, anyhow?î
He fell into an annoyed fidget, while the Ossie jumped up and down a few times in a thoughtful sort of manner, evidently for the exercise of it. He continued the jumping, varying it with little hopping dance steps, till Pelhamís fists began making strangling gestures. Only an excited squawk from the hole in the wall dignified by the term ìwindowî kept Pelham from committing Ossie-slaughter.
Ossies swarmed about and the Earthmen fought for a view.
Against Jupiterís great yellowness was outlined a flying sleigh, complete with reindeers. It was only a tiny thing, but there was no doubt about it. Santa Claus was coming.
There was only one thing wrong with the picture. The sleigh, ìreindeerî and all, while plunging ahead at a terrific speed, was flying upside down.
The Ossies dissolved into squawking cacophony. ìSannycaws! Sannycaws! Sannycaws!î
They scrambled out the window like so many animated dust-mops gone mad. Pelham and his men used the low door.
The sleigh was approaching, growing larger, lurching from side to side and vibrating like an off-center flywheel. Olaf Johnson was a tiny figure holding on desperately to the side of the sleigh with both hands.
Pelham was shouting wildly, incoherently, choking on the thin atmosphere every time he forgot to breathe through his nose. Then he stopped and stared in horror. The sleigh, almost life-size now, was dipping down. If it had been an arrow shot by William Tell, it could not have aimed between Pelhamís eyes more accurately.
ìEverybody down!î he shrieked, and dropped.
The wind of the sleighís passage whistled keenly and brushed his face. Olafís voice could be heard for an instant, high-pitched and indistinct. Compressed air spurted, leaving tracks of condensing water vapor.
Pelham lay quivering, hugging Ganymedeís frozen crust. Then, knees shaking like a Hawaiian hula-girl, he rose slowly. The Ossies who had scattered before the plunging vehicle had assembled again. Off in the distance, the sleigh was veering back.
Pelham watched as it swayed and hovered, still rotating. It lurched toward the dome, curved off to one side, turned back, and gathered speed.
Inside that sleigh, Olaf worked like a demon. Straddling his legs wide, he shifted his weight desperately. Sweating and cursing, trying hard not to look ìdownwardî at Jupiter, he urged the sleigh into wilder and wilder swings. It was wobbling through an angle of 180 degrees now, and Olaf felt his stomach raise strenuous objections.
Holding his breath, he leaned hard with his right foot and felt the sleigh swing far over. At the extremity of that swing, he released the gravo-repulsor and, in Ganymedeís weak gravity, the sleigh jerked downward. Naturally, since the vehicle was bottom-heavy due to the metal gravo-repulsor beneath, it righted itself as it fell.
But this was little comfort to Commander Pelham, who found himself once more in the direct path of the sleigh.
ìDown!î he yelled, and dropped again.
The sleigh whi-i-ished overhead, came up against a huge boulder with a crack, bounced twenty-five feet into the air, came down with a rush and a bang, and Olaf fell over the railing and out.
Santa Claus had arrived.
With a deep, shuddering breath, Olaf swung his bag over his shoulders, adjusted his beard and patted one of the silently suffering spinies on the head. Death might be coming-in fact, Olaf could hardly wait-but he was going to die on his feet nobly, like a Johnson.
Inside the shack, into which the Ossies had once more swarmed, a thump announced the arrival of Santaís bag on the roof, and a second thud the arrival of Santa himself. A ghastly face appeared through the makeshift hole in the ceiling.
ìMerry Christmas!î it croaked, and tumbled through. Olaf landed on his oxygen cylinders, as usual, and got them in the usual place.
The Ossies jumped up and down like rubber balls with the itch.
Olaf limped heavily toward the first stocking and deposited the garishly colored sphere he withdrew from his bag, one of the many that had originally been intended as a Christmas tree ornament One by one he deposited the rest in every available stocking.
Having completed his job, he dropped into an exhausted squat, from which position he watched subsequent proceedings with a glazed and fishy eye. The jolliness and belly-shaking good humor, traditionally characteristic of Santa Claus, were absent from this one with remarkable thoroughness.
The Ossies made up for it by their wild ecstasy. Until Olaf had deposited the last globe, they had kept their silence and their seats. But when he had finished, the air heaved and writhed under the stresses of the discordant screeches that arose. In half a second the hand of each Ossie contained a globe.
They chattered among themselves furiously, handling the globes carefully and hugging them close to their chests. Then they compared one with another) flocking about to gaze at particularly good ones.
The frowziest Ossie approached Pelham and plucked at the commanderís sleeve. ìSannycaws good)î he cackled. ìLook, he leave eggs Iî He stared reverently at his sphere and said: ìPittierín Ossie eggs. Must be Sannycaws eggs, huh?î
His skinny finger punched Pelham in the stomach.
ìNo!î yowled Pelham vehemently. ìHell, no!î
But the Ossie wasnít listening. He plunged the globe deep into the warmth of his feathers and said:
ìPitty colors. How long take for little Sannycaws come out? And what little Sannycaws eat?î He looked up. ìWe take good care. We teach little Sannycaws) make him smart and full of brain like Ossie.î
Pierce grabbed Commander Pelhamís arm.
ìDonít argue with them)Ö he whispered frantically. ìWhat do you care if they think those are Santa Claus eggs? Come on! If we work like maniacs) we can still make the quota. Lets get started.î
ìThatís right,î Pelham admitted. He turned to the Ossie. ìTell everyone to get going.î He spoke clearly and loudly. ìWork now. Do you understand? Hurry) hurry) hurry! Come on!î
He motioned with his arms. But the frowzy Ossie had come to a sudden halt. He said slowly:
ìWe work, but Johnson say Kissmess come evvy yearÖ
ìIsnít one Christmas enough for you?î Pelham rasped.
ìNo!î squawked the Ossie. ìWe want Sannycaws next year. Get more eggs. And next year more eggs. And next year. And next year) And next year. More eggs. More little Sannycaws eggs. If Sannycaws not come) we not work.î
ìThatís a long time off,Ö said Pelham. ìWeíll talk about it then. By that time Iíll either have gone completely crazy) or youíll have forgotten all about itÖ
Pierce opened his mouth, closed it, opened his mouth, closed it, opened it, and finally managed to speak.
ìCommander, they want him to come every yearÖ
ìI know. They wonít remember by next year, thoughÖ
ìBut you donít get it. A year to them is one Ganymedan revolution around Jupiter. In Earth time, thatís seven days and three hours. They want Santa Claus to come every weekÖ
ìEvery week!î Pelham gulped. ìJohnson told them-î
For a moment everything turned sparkling somersaults before his eyes. He choked, and automatically his eye sought Olaf.
Olaf turned cold to the marrow of his bones and rose to his feet apprehensively, sidling toward the door. There he stopped as a sudden recollection of tradition hit him. Beard a-dangle, he croaked:
ìMerry Christmas to all, and to all a good night!î
He made for the sleigh as if all the imps of Hades were after him. The imps werenít, but Commander Scott Pelham was.



***



In January of 1941 (the month in which I attained my majority), I undertook something new-a collaboration.
Fred Pohl, after all, was not merely an editor. He was also a budding writer. He has since come to be a giant in the field, but in those early days he was struggling along with only the sort of meager success I was having. Alone, and in collaboration with other Futurians, he turned out stories under a variety of pseudonyms. The one he used most frequently was ìJames MacCreigh.î
As it happened, he had written, under that pseudonym, a small fantasy called ìThe Little Man on the Subway,î which he apparently had hopes for but couldnít get right. He asked me if I would rewrite it, and the request flattered me. Besides, I was still trying to get into Unknown, and if I couldnít do it on my own, maybe I could do it by way of a collaboration. I wasnít proud-at least as far as fantasy was concerned.
I took on the task and did it virtually at a sitting. Doing it easily didnít help, however. I submitted it to Campbell for Unknown on January 27, 1941, and he rejected it. I had to hand it back to Pohl.
Pohl, however, with the true agentís soul, never gave up, and in 1950, long after I had utterly forgotten it, he managed to place it with a small magazine called Fantasy Book.








The Little Man on the Subway






(with James MacCreigh)



Subway stations are places where people usually get out, so when no one left the first car at Atlantic Avenue station, Conductor Cullen of the I.R. T. began to get worried. In fact, no one had left the first car from the time the run to Flatbush had begun-though dozens were getting on all the time.
Odd! Very odd! It was the kind of proposition that made well-bred conductors remove their caps and scratch their heads. Conductor Cullen did so. It didnít help, but he repeated the process at Bergen Street, the next station, where again the first car lost not one of its population. And at Grand Army Plaza, he added to the head-scratching process a few rare old Gaelic words that had passed down from father to son for hundreds of years. They ionized the surrounding atmosphere, but otherwise did not affect the situation.
At Eastern Parkway, Cullen tried an experiment. He carefully refrained from opening the first carís doors at all. He leaned forward eagerly, twisted his head and watched-and was treated to nothing short of a miracle. The New York subway rider is neither shy, meek, nor modest, and doors that do not open immediately or sooner are helped on their way by sundry kicks. But this time there was not a kick, not a shriek, not even a modified yell. Cullenís eyes popped.
He was getting angry. At Franklin Avenue, where he again contacted the Express, he flung open the doors and swore at the crowd. Every door spouted commuters of both sexes and all ages, except that terrible first car. At those doors, three men and a very young girl got on, though Cullen could plainly see the slight bulging of the walls that the already super-crowded condition of the car had caused.
For the rest of the trip to Flatbush Avenue, Cullen ignored the first car completely, concentrating on that last stop where everyone would have to get off. Everyone! President, Church, and Beverly Road were visited and passed, and Cullen found himself counting the stations to the Flatbush terminus.
They seemed like such a nice bunch of passengers, too. They read their newspapers, stared into the whirling blackness out the window, or at the girlís legs across the way, or at nothing at all, quite like ordinary people. Only, they didnít want to get out. They didnít even want to get into the next car, where empty seats filled the place. Imagine New Yorkers resisting the impulse to pass from one car to the other, and missing the chance to leave the doors open for the benefit of the draft.
But it was Flatbush Avenue! Cullen rubbed his hands, slammed the doors open and yelled in his best unintelligible manner, ìLasstop!î He repeated it two or three times hoarsely and several in that damned first car looked up at him. There was reproach in their eyes. Have you never heard of the Mayorís anti-noise campaign, they seemed to say.
The last other passenger had come out of the train, and the scattered new ones were coming in. There were a few curious looks at the jammed car, but not too many. The New Yorker considers everything he cannot understand a publicity stunt.
Cullen fell back on his Gaelic once more and dashed up the platform toward the motormanís booth. He needed moral assistance. The motorman should have been out of his cab, preparing for his next trip, but he wasnít. Cullen could see him through the glass of the door, leaning on the controls and staring vacantly at the bumper-stop ahead.
ìGus!î cried Cullen. ìCome out! Thereís a hell of-î
At that point, his tongue skidded to a halt, because it wasnít Gus. It was a little old man, who smiled politely and twiddled his fingers in greeting.
Patrick Cullenís Irish soul rebelled. With a yelp, he grabbed the edge of the door and tried to shove it open. He should have known that wouldnít work. So, taking a deep breath and commending said Irish soul to God, he made for the open door and ploughed into the mass of haunted humans in that first car. Momentum carried him six feet, and then there he stuck. Behind him, those he had knocked down picked themselves up from the laps of their fellow-travelers, apologized with true New York courtesy (consisting of a growl, a grunt, and a grimace) and returned to their papers.
Then, caught helplessly, he heard the Dispatcherís bell. It was time for his own train to be on its way. Duty called! With a superhuman effort, he inched towards the door, but it closed before he could get there, and the train commenced to move.
It occurred to Cullen that he had missed a report for the first time, and he said, ìDamn!î After the train had travelled some fifty feet, it came to him that they were going the wrong way, and this time he said nothing.
After all, what was there to say-even in the purest of Gaelic.
How could a train go the wrong way at Flatbush Ave. There were no further tracks. There was no further tunnel. There was a bumper-stop to prevent eccentric motormen from trying to bore one. It was absurd. Even the Big Deal couldnít do it.
But there they were!
There were stations in this new tunnel, too,-cute little small ones just large enough for one car. But that was all right, because only one car was travelling. The rest had somehow become detached, presumably to make the routine trip to Bronx Park.
There were maybe a dozen stations on the line-with curious names. Cullen noticed only a few, because he found it difficult to keep his eyes from going out of focus. One was Archangel Boulevard; another Seraph Road; still another Cherub Plaza.
And then, the train slid into a monster station, that looked uncommonly like a cave, and stopped. It was huge, about three hundred feet deep, and almost spherical. The tracks ran to the exact center, without trusses, and the platform at its side likewise rested comfortably upon air.
The conductor was the only person left in the car, the rest having mostly gotten off at Hosannah Square. He hung limply from the porcelain hand-grip, staring fixedly at a lip-stick advertisement. The door of the motonnanís cabin opened and the little man came out. He glanced at Cullen, turned away, then whirled back.
ìHey,î he said, ìwho are you?î
Cullen rotated slowly, still clutching the hand-grip. ìOnly the conductor. Donít mind me. Iím quitting anyway. I donít like the work.î
ìOh, dear, dear, this is unexpected.î The little man waggled his head and tch-tched. ìIím Mr. Crumley,î he explained. ìI steal things. People mostly. Sometimes subway cars,-but theyíre such big, clumsy things, donít you think?î
ìMister,î groaned Cullen. ìI quit thinking two hours ago. It didnít get me anywhere. Who are you, anyway?î
ìI told you-Iím Mr. Crumley. Iím practicing to be a god.î
ìA gob?î said Cullen. ìYou mean a sailor?î
ìDear, no,î frowned Mr. Crumley. ìI said, ëgod,í as in Jehovah. Look!î He pointed out the window to the wall of the cave. Where his finger pointed, the rock billowed and rose. He moved his finger and there was a neat ridge of rock describing a reversed, lower case ìh.î
ìThatís my symbol,î said Crumley modestly. ìMystic, isnít it? But thatís nothing. Wait till I really get things organized. Dear, dear, will I give them miracles!î
Cullenís head swivelled between the raised-rock symbol and the simpering Mr. Crumley, until he began to get dizzy, and then he stopped.
ìListen,î he demanded hoarsely. ìHow did you get that car out of Flatbush Avenue? Where did that tunnel come from? Are some of them foreigners-î
ìOh, my, no!î answered Mr. Crumley. ìI made that myself and willed it so that no one would notice. It was quite difficult. It just wears the ectoplasm right out of me. Miracles with people mixed up in it are much harder than the other kind, because you have to fight their wills. Unless you have lots of Believers, you canít do it. Now that Iíve got over a hundred thousand, I can do it, but there was a time,î he shook his head reminiscently, ìwhen I couldnít even have levitated a baby-or healed a leper. Oh, well, weíre wasting time. We ought to be at the nearest factory.î
Cullen brightened. ëFactoryí was more prosaic. ìI once had a brother,î he said, ìwho worked in a sweater factory, but-î
ìOh, goodness, Mr. Cullen. Iím referring to my Believersí Factories. I have to educate people to believe in me, donít I, and preaching is such slow work. I believe in mass production. Some day I intend to be called the Henry Ford of Utopia. Why, Iíve got twelve Factories in Brooklyn alone and when I manufacture enough Believers, Iíll just cover the world with them.î
He sighed, ìGracious me, if I only had enough Believers. Iíve got to have a million before I can let things progress by themselves and until then I have to attend to every little detail myself. It is so boring! I even have to keep reminding my Believers who I am-even the Disciples. Incidentally, Cullen,-I read your mind, by the way, so thatís how I know your name-you want to be a Believer, of course.î
ìWell, now,î said Cullen nervously.
ìOh, come now. Some gods would have been angry at your intrusion and done away with you,î he snapped his fingers, ìlike that. Not I, though, because I think killing people is messy and inconsiderate. Just the same, youíll have to be a Believer.î
Now Patrick Cullen was an intelligent Irishman. That is to say, he admitted the existence of banshees, leprechauns, and the Little Folk, and kept an open mind on poltergeists, werewolves, vampires and such-like foreign trash. At mere supernaturalities, he was too well educated to sneer. Still, Cullen did not intend to compromise his religion. His theology was weak, but for a mortal to claim godship smacked of heresy, not to say sacrilege and blasphemy, even to him.
ìYouíre a faker,î he cried boldly, ìand youíre headed straight for Hell the way youíre going.î
Mr. Crumley clicked his tongue, ìWhat terrible language you use. And so unnecessary! Of course you Believe in me.î
ìOh, yeah?î
ìWell, then, if you are stubborn, Iíll pass a minor miracle. Its inconvenient, but now,î he made vague motions with his left hand, ìyou Believe in me.î
ìCertainly,î said Cullen, hurt. ìI always did. How do I go about worshipping you? I want to do this properly.î
ìJust Believe in me, and thatís enough. Now you must go to the factories and then weíll send you back home-theyíll never know you were gone-and you can live your life like a Believer.î
The conductor smiled ecstatically, ìOh, happy life! I want to go to the factories.î
ìOf course you would,î replied Mr. Crumley. ìYouíd be a fine Crumleyite otherwise, wouldnít you? Come!î He pointed at the door of the car, and the door slid open. They walked out and Crumley kept on pointing. Rock faded away in front, and bit down again behind. Through the wall Cullen walked, following that little figure who was his god.
That was a god, thought Cullen. Any god that could do that was one hell of a damn good god to believe in.
And then he was at the factory-in another cave, only smaller. Mr. Crumley seemed to like caves.
Cullen didnít pay much attention to his surroundings. He couldnít see much anyway on account of the faint violet mist that blurred his vision. He got the impression of a slowly-moving conveyor belt, with men stationed at intervals along it. Disciples, he thought. And the parts being machined on that belt were probably non-Believers, or such low trash.
There was a man watching him, smiling. A Disciple, Cullen thought, and quite naturally made the sign to him. He had never made it before, but it was easy. The Disciple replied in kind.
ìHe told me you were coming,î said the Disciple. ìHe made a special miracle for you, he said. Thatís quite a distinction. Do you want me to show you around the belt?î
ìYou bet.î
ìWell, this is Factory One. Itís the nerve center of all the factories of the country. The others give preliminary treatment only; and make only Believers. We make Disciples.î
Oh, boy, Disciples! ìAm I going to be a Discipler asked Cullen eagerly.
ìAfter being miraculated by him. Of course! Youíre a somebody, you know. There are only five other people he ever took personal charge of.î
This was a glorious way to do things. Everything Mr. Crumley did was glorious. What a god! What a god!
ìYou started that way, too.î
ìCertainly,î said the Disciple, placidly, ìIím an important fellow, too. Only I wish I were more important, even.î
ìWhat for?î said Cullen, in a shocked tone of voice. ì Are you murmuring against the dictates of Mr. Crumley? (may he prosper).This is sacrilege.î
The Disciple shifted uncomfortably, ìWell, Iíve got ideas, and Iíd like to try them out.î
ìYouíve got ideas, huh?î muttered Cullen balefully. ìDoes Mr. Crumley (may he live forever) know?î
ìWell-frankly, no! But just the same,î the Disciple looked over each shoulder carefully and drew closer, ìIím not the only one. There are lots of us that think Mr. Crumley (on whom be blessings) is just a trifle old-fashioned. For instance, take the lights in this place.î
Cullen stared upwards. The lights were the same type as those in the terminal-cave. They might have been stolen from any line of the IRT subway. Perfect copies of the stop-and-go signals and the exit markers.
ìWhatís wrong?î he asked.
The Disciple sneered, ìThey lack originality. Youíd think a grade A god would do something new. When he takes people, he does it through the subway, and he obeys subway rules. He waits for the Dispatcher to tell him to go; he stops at every station; he uses crude electricity and so on. What we need,î the Disciple was waving his hands wildly and shouting, ìis more enterprise, more git-and-go. Weíve got to speed up things and run them with efficiency and vim.î
Cullen stared hotly, ìYou are a heretic,î he accused. ìyou are doomed to damnation.î He looked angrily about for a bell, whistle, gong, or drum wherewith to summon the great Crumley, but found nothing.
The other blinked in quick thought. ìSay,î he said, bluffly, ìlook at what time it is. Iím behind schedule. You better get on the belt for your first treatment.î
Cullen was hot about the slovenly assistance Mr. Crumley was getting from this inferior Disciple, but a treatment is a treatment, so making the sign devoutly, he got on. He found it fairly comfortable despite its jerky motion. The Disciple motioned to Cullenís first preceptor-another Disciple-standing beside a sort of blackboard. Cullen had watched others while discussing Crumley and he had noticed the question and answer procedure that had taken place. He had noticed it particularly.
Consequently, he was surprised, when the second Disciple, instead of using his heavy pointer to indicate a question on the board, reversed it and brought it down upon his head.
The lights went out!
When he came to, he was under the belt, at the very bottom of the cave. He was tied up, and the Rebellious Disciple and three others were talking about him.
ìHe couldnít be persuaded,î the Disciple was saying. ìCrumley must have given him a double treatment or something.î
ìItís the last double treatment Crumleyíll ever give,î said the fat little man.
ìLetís hope so. Howís it coming?î
ìVery well. Very well, indeed. We teleported ourselves to Section Four about two hours ago. It was a perfect miracle.î
The Disciple was pleased. ìFine! Howíre they doing at Four?î
The fat little man clucked his lips. COW ell, now, not so hot. For some reason, theyíre getting odd effects over there. Miracles are just happening. Even ordinary Crumleyites can pass them, and sometimes they-just happen. Itís extremely annoying.î
ìHmm, thatís bad. If there are too many hitches, Crumleyíll get suspicious. ti he investigates there first, he can reconvert all of them in a jiffy, before he comes here and then without their support we might not be strong enough to stand up against him.î
ìSay, now,î said the fat man apprehensively, ìweíre not strong enough now, you mow. None of this going off half-cocked.î
ìWeíre strong enough,î pointed out the Disciple stiffly, ìto weaken him long enough to get us a new god started, and after that-
ìA new god, eh?î said another. He nodded wisely.
ìSure,î said the Disciple. ì A new god, created by us, can be destroyed by us. Heíd be completely under our thumb and then instead of this one-man tyranny, we can have a sort of-er-council.î
There were general grins and everyone looked pleased.
ìBut weíll discuss that further some other time,î continued the Disciple briskly. ìLetís Believe just a bit. Crumley isnít stupid, you mow, and we donít want him to observe any slackening. Come on, now. All together.î
They closed their eyes, concentrated a bit, and then opened them with a sigh.
ìWell,î said the little, fat man, ì thatís over. Iíd better be getting back now.î
From under the belt, Cullen watched him. He looked singularly like a chicken about to take off for a tree as he flexed his knees and stared upwards. Then he added to the resemblance not a little when he spread his arms, gave a little hop and fluttered away.
Cullen could follow his flight only by watching the eyes of the three remaining. Those eyes turned up and up, following the fat man to the very top of the cave, it seemed. There was an air of self-satisfaction about those eyes. They were very happy over their miracles.
Then they all went away and left Cullen to his holy indignation. He was shocked to the very core of his being at this sinful rebellion, this apostasy-this-this-There werenít any words for it, even when he tried Gaelic.
Imagine trying to create a god that would be under the thumbs of the creators. It was anthropomorphic heresy (where had he heard that word, now?) and struck at the roots of all religion. Was he going to lie there and watch anything strike at the roots of all religion? Was he going to submit to having MI. Crumley (may he swim through seas of ecstasy) deposed?
Never!
But the ropes thought otherwise, so there he stayed.
And then there was an interruption in his thoughts. There came a low, booming sound-a sound which would have been a voice if it had not been pitched so incredibly low. There was a menace to it that got immediate attention. It got attention from Cullen, who quivered in his bonds; from the others in the cave, who quivered even harder, not being restrained by ropes; from the belt itself, which stopped dead with a jerk, and quivered mightily.
The Rebellious Disciple dropped to his knees and quivered more than any of them.
The voice came again, this time in a recognizable language, ìWHERE IS THAT BUM, CRUMLEY?î it roared.
There was no wait for an answer. A cloud of shadow gathered in the center of the hall and spat a black bolt at the belt. A spot of fire leaped out from where the bolt had touched and spread slowly outward. Where it passed, the belt ceased to exit. It was far from Cullen, but there were humans nearer, and among those scurrying pandemonium existed.
Cullen wanted very much to join the flight, but unfortunately the Disciple who had trussed him up had evidently been a Boy Scout. Jerking, twisting, and writhing had no effect upon the stubborn ropes, so he fell back upon Gaelic and wishing. He wished he were flee. He wished he werenít tied. He wished he were far away from that devouring flame. He wished lots of things, some unprintable, but mainly those.
And with that he felt a gentle slipping pressure and down at his feet was an untidy pile of hempen fibre. Evidently the forces liberated by the rebellion were getting out of control here as well as in Section Four. What had the little fat man said? ìMiracles are just happening. Even ordinary Crumleyites can pass them, and sometimes they-just happen.î
But why waste time? He ran to the rock wall and howled a wish at it to dissolve into nothing. He howled several times with Gaelic modifications, but the wall didnít even slightly soften. He stared wildly and then saw the hole. It was on the side of the cave, diametrically across from Cullenís position at the bottom of the hall, and about three loops of the belt up. The upward spiral passed just below it.
Somehow he made the leap that grabbed the lower lip of the spiral, wriggled his way onto it and jumped into a run. The fire of disintegration was behind him and plenty far away, but it was making time. Up the belt to the third loop he ran, not taking time to be dizzy from the circular trip. But when he got there, the hole, large, black and inviting, was just the tiniest bit higher than he could jump.
He leaned against the wall panting. The spot of fire was now two spots, crawling both ways from a twenty foot break in the belt. Everyone in the cavern, some two hundred people, was in motion, and everyone made some sort of noise.
Somehow, the sight stimulated him. It nerved him to further efforts to get into the hole. Wildly, he tried walking up the sheer wall, but this didnít work.
And then Mr. Crumley stuck his head out of the hole and said, ìOh, mercy me, what a perfectly terrible mess. Dear, dear! Come up here, Cullen! Why do you stay down there!î
A great peace descended upon Cullen. ìHail, Mr. Crumley,î he cried. ìMay you sniff the essence of roses forever.î
Mr. Crumley looked pleased, ìThank you, Cullen.î He waved his hand, and the conductor was beside him-a simple matter of levitation. Once again, Cullen decided in his inmost soul that here was a god.
ìAnd now,î said Mr. Crumley, ìwe must hurry, hurry, hurry. Iíve lost most of my power when the Disciples rebelled, and my subway car is stuck half-way. Iíll need your help. Hurry!î
Cullen had no time to admire the tiny subway at the end of the tunnel. He jumped off the platform on Crumleyís heels and dashed about a hundred feet down the tube to where the car was standing idle. He wafted into the open front door with the grace of a chorusboy. Mr. Crumley took care of that.
ìCullen,î said Mr. Crumley, ìstart this thing and take it back to the regular line. And be careful; he is waiting for me.î
ìWho?î
ìHe, the new god. Imagine those fools-no, idiots-thinking they could create a controllable god, when the very essence of godship is uncontrollability. of course, when they made a god to destroy me, they made a Destroyer, and heíll just destroy everything in sight that I created, including my Disciples.î
Cullen worked quickly. He knew how to start car 30990; any conductor would. He raced to the other end of the car for the control lever, snatched it off, and returned at top speed. That was all he needed. There was power in the rail; the lights were on; and there were no stop signals between him and Godís Country.
Mr. Crumley lay himself down on a seat, ìBe very quiet. He may let you get past him. Iím going to blank myself out, and maybe he wonít notice me. At any rate, he wonít harm you-I hope. Dear, dear, since this all started in section four, things are such a mess.î
Eight stations passed before anything happened and then came Utopia Circle station and-well, nothing really happened. It was just an impression-an impression of people all around him for a few seconds watching him closely with a virulent hostility. It wasnít exactly people, but a person. It wasnít exactly a person either, but just a huge eye, watching-watching-watching.
But it passed, and almost immediately Cullen saw a black and white ìFlatbush Avenueî sign at the side of the tunnel. He jammed on his brakes in a hurry, for there was a train waiting there. But the controls didnít work the way they should have, and the car edged up until it was in contact with the cars before. With a soft click, it coupled and 30900 was just the last car of the train.
It was Mr. Crumleyís work, of course. Mr. Crumley stood behind him, watching. ìHe didnít get you, did he? No-I see he didnít.î
ìIs there any more danger?î asked Cullen, anxiously.
ìI donít think so,î responded Mr. Crumley sadly. ìAfter he has destroyed all my creation, there will be nothing left for him to destroy, and, deprived of a function, he will simply cease to exist. Thatís the result of this nasty, slipshod work. Iím disgusted with human beings.î
ìDonít say that, ì said Cullen.
ìI will,î reported Mr. Crumley savagely, ìHuman beings arenít fit to be god of. Theyíre too much trouble and worry. It would give any self-respecting god grey hairs and I suppose you think a god looks very dignified all grey. Darn all humans! They can get along without me. From now on, Iím going to go to Africa and try the chimpanzees. Iíll bet they make much better material.î
ìBut wait, ì wailed Cullen. ìWhat about me? I believe in you.î
ìOh, dear, that would never do. Here! Return to normal.î
Mr. Crumleyís hand caressed the air, and Cullen, once more a God-fearing Irishman, let loose a roar in the purest Gaelic and made for him.
ìWhy, you blaspheming spalpeen-î
But there was no Mr. Crumley. There was only the Dispatcher, asking very impolitely-in English-what the blankety-blank hell was the matter with him.



***



I am sorry to say that I have no clear memory, at this time, what parts of the story are mine and what parts are Pohlís. Going over it, I can say, ìThis part sounds like me, this part doesnít,î but whether Iíd be right or not I couldnít swear.
 Fantasy Book was a very borderline publication that lasted only eight issues. ìThe Little Man on the Subwayî was in the sixth.
An amusing fact about this issue of a small magazine that had to make do with what it could find among the rejects of the field was that it included ìScanners Live in Vain,Ö by Cordwainer Smith. This was Smithís first published story and he was not to publish another for eight years or so. In the 1960s, Smith (a pseudonym for a man whose real identity was not made clear until after his death) became a writer of considerable importance, and this first story of his became a classic.
While working on ìThe Little Man on the Subwayî I was also doing another ìpositronic robotî story, called ìLiar!î In this one, my character Susan Calvin first appeared (she has been a character in ten of my stories up to the present time and I donít eliminate the possibility that she will appear yet again).
It was while Campbell and I were discussing this story, by the way, on December 16, 1940, that the ìThree Laws of Roboticsî were worked out in full. (I say it was Campbell who worked them out and he says it was I-but I know Iím right. It was he.)
ìLiar!î was accepted at once by Campbell, at the end of January, without revision, and appeared in the May 1941 issue of Astounding. It was my fourth appearance in that magazine. The fact that it appeared the month after ìReasonî helped fix the ìpositronic robotî stories in the readersí minds as a ìseriesÖ ìLiar!î eventually appeared in I, Robot.
The sale of two ìpositronic robotî stories, ìReasonî and ìLiar!î virtually back to back put me all on fire to do more of the same. When I suggested still another story of the sort to Campbell on February 3, 1941, he approved, but he said he didnít want me, this early in the game, tying myself down too completely into a rigid formula. He suggested I do other kinds of stories first. I was a good boy; I obeyed.
On that very day, in fact, I decided to try fantasy again. I wrote a short one (1,500 words) called ìMasks,î and heaven only knows what it was about, for I donít. I submitted it to Campbell for Unknown on February 10, and he rejected it. It is gone; it no longer exists.
Later that month I also wrote a short story called ìThe Hazing,î intended for Pohl. I submitted it to him on February 24, and he rejected it at once. Eventually I submitted it to Thrilling Wonder Stories. They requested a revision, I obliged, and they accepted it on July 2 9, 1941.








The Hazing


The Campus of Arcturus University, on Arcturusís second planet, Eron, is a dull place during mid-year vacations and, moreover, a hot one, so that Myron Tubal, sophomore, found life boring and uncomfortable. For the fifth time that day, he looked in at the Undergraduate Lounge in a desperate attempt at locating an acquaintance, and was at last gratified to behold Bill Sefan, a green-skinned youngster from Vegaís fifth planet.
Sefan, like Tubal, had flunked Biosociology and was staying through vacation to study for a make-up exam. Things like that weave strong bonds between sophomore and sophomore.
Tubal grunted a greeting, dropped his huge hairless body-he was a native of the Arcturian System itself-into the largest chair and said:
ìHave you seen the new freshmen yet?î
ìAlready! Itís six weeks before the fall semester starts!î
Tubal yawned. ìThese are a special breed of frosh. Theyíre the very first batch from the Solarian System-ten of them.î
ìSolarian System? You mean that new system that joined the Galactic Federation three-four years ago?î
ìThatís the one. Their world capital is called Earth, I think.î
ìWell, what about them?î
ìNothing much. Theyíre just here, thatís all. Some of them have hair on the upper lip, and very silly it looks, too. Otherwise, they look like any of a dozen or so other breeds of Humanoids.î
Itwas at this point that the door flew open and little Wri Forase ran in. He was from Denebís single planet, and the short, gray fuzz that covered his head and face bristled with agitation, while his large purple eyes gleamed excitedly.
ìSay,î he twittered breathlessly, ìhave you seen the Earthmen?î
Sefan sighed. ìIsnít anyone ever going to change the subject? Tubal was just telling me about them.î
ìHe was?î Forase seemed disappointed. ìBut-but did he tell you these were that abnormal race they made such a fuss over when the Solarian System entered the Federation?î
ìThey looked all right to me,î said Tubal.
ìIím not talking about them from the physical standpoint,î said the Denebian disgustedly. ìItís the mental aspect of the case. Psychology! Thatís the stuff?î Forase was going to be a psychologist some day.
ìOh, that! Well, whatís wrong with them?î
ìTheir mob psychology as a race is all wrong,î babbled Forase. ìInstead of becoming less emotional with numbers, as is the case with every other type of Humanoid known, they become more emotional! In groups, these Earthmen riot, panic, go crazy. The more there are, the worse it is. So help me, we even invented a new mathematical notation to handle the problem. Look!î
He had his pocket-pad and stylus out in one rapid motion; but Tubalís hand clamped down upon them before the stylus so much as made a mark.
Tubal said, ìWhoa! Iíve got a walloping lulu of an idea.î
ìImagine!î murmured Sefan.
Tubal ignored him. He smiled again, and his hand rubbed thoughtfully over his bald dome.
ìListen,î he said, with sudden briskness. His voice dropped to a conspiratorial whisper.
Albert Williams, late of Earth, stirred in his sleep and became conscious of a prodding finger exploring the space between his second and third ribs. He opened his eyes, swiveled his head, stared stupidly; then gasped, shot upright, and reached for the light switch.
ìDonít move,î said the shadowy figure beside his bed. There was a muted click, and the Earthman found himself centered in the pearly beam of a pocket Hash.
He blinked and said, ìWho the blasted devil are you?î
ìYou are going to get out of bed,î replied the apparition stolidly. ìDress, and come with me.î
Williams grinned savagely. ìTry and make me.î
There was no answer, but the Hash beam shifted slightly and fell upon the shadowís other hand. It held a ìneuronic whip,î that pleasant little weapon that paralyzes the vocal cords and twists nerves into so many knots of agony. Williams swallowed hard, and got out of bed.
He dressed in silence, and then said:
ìAll right, what do I do now?î
The gleaming ìwhipî gestured, and the Earthman moved toward the door.
ìJust walk ahead,î said the unknown.
Williams moved out of the room, along the silent corridor, and down eight stories without daring to look back. Out upon the campus he stopped, and felt metal probe the small of his back.
ìDo you know where Obel Hall is?î
Williams, nodding, began walking. He walked past Obel Hall, turned right at University Avenue, and after half a mile stepped off the roads and past the trees. A spaceship hulked dimly in the darkness, with ports closely curtained and only a dim light showing where the airlock opened a crack.
ìGet in!î He was shoved up a flight of stairs and into a small room.
He blinked, looked about him and counted aloud.
ì-seven, eight, nine, and I make ten. Theyíve got us all, I guess.î
ìItís no guess,î growled Eric Chamberlain sourly. ìItís a certainty.î
He was rubbing his hand. ìIíve been here an hour.î
ìWhatís wrong with the mitt?î asked Williams.
ìI sprained it on the jaw of the rat that brought me here. Heís as tough as a spaceshipís hull.î
Williams seated himself cross-legged upon the floor and rested his head against the wall.
ìHas anyone any idea as to what this is all about?î
ìKidnaping!î said little Joey Sweeney. His teeth were chattering.
ìWhat the devil for?î snorted Chamberlain. ìIf any of us are millionaires, I hadnít heard of it. I know Iím not!î
Williams said, ìLook, letís not go off the deep end. Kidnaping or anything of that sort is. out. These people canít be criminals. It stands to reason that a civilization that has developed psychology to the extent this Galactic Federation has, would be able to wipe out crime without raising a sweat.î
ìPirates,î grunted Lawrence Marsh. ìI donít think so, but itís just a suggestion.î
ìNuts!î said Williams. ìPiracy is a frontier phenomenon. This region of space has been civilized for tens of millennia.î
ìJust the same, they had guns,î insisted Joe, ìand I donít like it.î He had left his glasses in his room and peered about in near-sighted anxiety.
ìThat doesnít mean much,î answered Williams. ìNow, Iíve been thinking. Here we are-ten newly arrived freshmen at Arcturus u. On our first night here, weíre bundled mysteriously out of our rooms and into a strange spaceship. That suggests something to me. How about it?î
Sidney Morton raised his head from his arms long enough to say sleepily:
ìIíve thought of it, too. It looks like weíre in for one hell of a hazing. Gents, I think the local sophs are just having good, clean fun.î
ìExactly,î agreed Williams. ìAnyone have any other ideas?î
Silence. ì All right, then, so there isnít anything to do but wait. Personally, Iíve going to catch up on my sleep. They can wake me up if they need me.î
There was a jar at that moment and he fell off balance. ìWell, weíre off-wherever weíre going.î
Moments later, Bill Sefan hesitated just an instant before entering the control room. When he finally did, it was to face a highly excited Wri Forase.
ìHow is it working?î demanded the Denebian.
ìRotten,î responded Sefan sourly. ìIf theyíre panicked, then Iíve damned. Theyíre going to sleep.î
ìAsleep! All of them? But what were they saying?î
ìHow do I know? They werenít speaking Galactic, and I canít make head or tail out of their infernal foreign gibberish.î
Forase threw his hands into the air in disgust.
Tubal spoke finally. ìListen, Forase, Iím cutting a class in Biosoc.-which I canít afford. You guaranteed the psychology of this stunt. If it turns out to be a flop, Iím not going to like it.î
ìWell, for the love of Deneb,î grated Forase desperately, ìyou two are a fine pair of yellow-bellies! Did you expect them to start screaming and kicking right off? Sizzling Arcturus I Wait till we get to the Spican System, will you? When we maroon them overnight-î
He tittered suddenly. ìThis is going to be the fanciest trick since they tied those stink-bats to the chromatic organ on Concert Night.î
Tubal cracked a grin, but Sefan leaned back in his chair and remarked thoughtfully.
ìWhat if someone-say, President Wynn-hears about this?î
The Arcturian at the controls shrugged. ìItís only a hazing. Theyíll ìgo easy.
ìDonít play dumb, M. T. This isnít kid stuff. Planet Four, Spica-the whole Spican System, in fact-is banned to Galactic ships, and you know that. Itís got a sub-Humanoid race on it. Theyíre supposed to develop entirely free of interference until they discover interstellar travel on their own. Thatís the law, and theyíre strict about it. Space! If they find out about this, weíll be in the soup for fair.î
Tubal turned in his seat. ìHow in Arcturus do you expect Prexy Wynn-damn his thick hide!-to find out about us? Now, mind you, Iím not saying the story wonít spread around the campus, because half the fun will be killed if we have to keep it to ourselves. But how will names come out? No one will squeal. You know that.î
ìOkay,î said Sefan, and shrugged.
And then Tubal said, ìReady for hyper-space!î
He compressed keys and there was the queer internal wrench that marked the shipís departure from normal space.
The ten Earthmen were rather the worse for wear, and looked it. Lawrence Marsh squinted at his watch again.
ìTwo-thirty,î he said. ìThatís thirty-six hours now. I wish theyíd get this over with.î
ìThis isnít a hazing,î moaned Sweeney. ìIt takes too long.î
Williams grew red. ìWhat do you all look half-dead about? Theyíve been feeding us regularly, havenít they? They havenít tied us up, have they? I should say it was pretty evident that they were taking good care of us.î
ìOr,î came Sidney Mortonís discontented drawl, ìfattening us up for the slaughter.î
He paused, and everyone stiffened. There was no mistaking the queer internal wrench they had felt.
ìGet that!î said Eric Chamberlain in sudden frenzy. ìWeíre back in normal space again, and that means weíre only an hour or two from wherever weíre going. Weíve got to do something!î
ìHear, hear,î Williams snorted. ìBut what?î
ìThere are ten of us, arenít there?î shouted Chamberlain, puffing out his chest. ìWell, Iíve only seen one of them so far. Next time he comes in, and weíve got another meal due us pretty soon, weíre going to mob him.î
Sweeney looked sick. ìWhat about the neuronic whip he always carries?î
ìIt wonít kill us. He canít get us all before we pin him down, anyway.î
ìEric,î said Williams bluntly, ìyouíre a fool.î
Chamberlain flushed and his stub-fingered fists closed slowly.
ìIím just in the mood for a little practice persuasion. Call me that again, will you?î
ìSit down!î Williams scarcely bothered to look up. ì And donít work so hard justifying my epithet. All of us are nervous and keyed-up, but that doesnít mean we ought to go altogether crazy. Not yet, anyway. First of all, even discounting the whip, mobbing our jailer wonít be particularly successful.
ìWeíve only seen one, but that one is from the Arcturian System. Heís better than seven feet tall, and comfortably past the three-hundred-pound mark. Heíd mop us up-all ten of us-with his bare fists. I thought you had one run-in with him already, Eric.î
There was a thickish silence.
Williams added, ì And even if we could knock him out and finish as many others as there may be in the ship, we still havenít the slightest idea where we are or how to get back or even how to run the ship.î A pause. Then, ìWell?î
ìNuts!î Chamberlain turned away, and glowered in silence.
The door kicked open and the giant Arcturian entered. With one hand, he emptied the bag he carried, and with the other kept his neuronic whip carefully leveled.
ìLast meal,î he grunted.
There was a general scramble for the rolling cans, still lukewarm from recent heating. Morton glared at his with disgust.
ìSay,î he spoke stumblingly in Galactic, ìcanít you give us a change? Iím tired of this rotten goulash of yours. This is the fourth can!î
ìSo what? Itís your last meal,î the Arcturian snapped, and left.
A horrified paralysis prevailed.
ìWhat did he mean by that?î gulped someone huskily.
ìTheyíre going to kill us!î Sweeney was round-eyed, the thin edge of panic in his voice.
Williamsí mouth was dry and he felt unreasoning anger grow against Sweeneyís contagious fright. He paused-the kid was only seventeen-and said huskily, ìStow it, will you? Letís eat.î
It was two hours later that he felt the shuddering jar that meant the landing and end of the journey. In that time, no one had spoken, but Williams could feel the pall of fear choke tighter with the minutes.
Spica had dipped crimsonly below the horizon and there was a chill wind blowing. The ten Earthmen, huddled together miserably upon the rock-strewn hilltop, watched their captors sullenly. It was the huge Arcturian, Myron Tubal, that did the talking, while the green-skinned Vegan, Bill Sefan, and the fuzzy little Denebian, Wri Forase, remained placidly in the background.
ìYouíve got your fire,î said the Arcturian gruffly, ìand thereís plenty of wood about to keep it going. That will keep the beasts away. Weíll leave you a pair of whips before we go, and those will do as protection, if any of the aborigines of the planet bother you. You will have to use your own wits as far as food, water and shelter are concerned.î
He turned away. Chamberlain let loose with a sudden roar, and leaped after the departing Arcturian. He was sent reeling back with an effortless heave of the otherís arm.
The lock closed after the three other-world men. Almost at once, the ship lifted off the ground and shot upward. Williams finally broke the chilled silence.
ìTheyíve left the whips. Iíll take one and you can have the other, Eric.î
One by one, the Earthmen dropped into a sitting position, back to the fire, frightened, half panicky.
Williams forced a grin. ìThereís plenty of game about-the region is well-wooded. Come on, now, there are ten of us and theyíve got to come back sometime. Letís show them we Earthmen can take it. How about it, fellows?î
He was talking aimlessly now. Morton said listlessly.
ìWhy donít you shut up? Youíre not making this any easier.î
Williams gave up. The pit of his own stomach was turning cold.
The twilight blackened into night, and the circle of light about the fire contracted into a little flickering area that ended in shadows. Marsh gasped suddenly, and his eyes went wide.
ìThereís some-something coming!î
The stir that followed froze itself into attitudes of breathless attention.
ìYouíre crazy,î began Williams huskily-and stopped dead at the unmistakable, slithering sound that reached his ears.
ìGrab your whip!î he screamed to Chamberlain.
Joey Sweeney laughed suddenly-a strained, high-pitched laugh.
And then-there was a sudden shrieking in the air, and the shades charged down upon them.
Things were happening elsewhere, too.
Tubalís ship lazed outward from Spicaís fourth planet, with Bin Sefan at the controls. Tubal himself was in his own cramped quarters, polishing off a huge flagon of Denebian liquor in two gulps.
Wri Forase watched the operation sadly.
ìIt cost twenty credits a bottle,î he said, ìand I only have a few left.î
ìWell, donít let me hog it,î said Tubal magnanimously, ìMatch me bottle for bottle. Itís all right with me.î
ìOne swig like that,î grumbled the Denebian, ìand r d be out till the Fall exams:í
Tubal paid scant attention. ìThis,î he began, ìis going to make campus history as the hazing stunt-î
And at this point, there was a sharp, singing pinging ping-g-g-g, scarcely muffled by intervening walls, and the lights went out.
Wri Forase felt himself pressed hard against the wall. He struggled for breath and stuttered out in gasps.
ìB-by Space, weíre at f-full acceleration! Whatís wr-rong with the equalizer?î
ìDamn the equalizer!î roared Tubal, heaving to his feet. ìWhatís wrong with the ship?î
He stumbled out the door, into the equally dark corridor, with Forase crawling after him. When they burst into the control room, they found Sefan surrounded by the dim emergency lights, his green skin shining with perspiration.
ìMeteor,î he croaked. ìIt played hob with our power distributors. Itís all going into acceleration. The lights, heating units and radio are all out of commission, while the ventilators are just barely limping.î He added, ìAnd Section Four is punctured:í
Tubal gazed about him wildly. ìIdiot! Why didnít you keep your eye on the mass indicator?î
ìI did, you overgrown lump of putty,î howled Sefan, ìbut it never registered! It-never-registered! Isnít that just what youíd expect from a second-hand jalopy, rented for two hundred credits? It went through the screen as if it were empty ether.î
ìShut up!î Tubal flung open the suit-compartments and groaned. ìTheyíre all Arcturian models. I should have checked up. Can you handle one of these, Sefan?î
ìMaybe.î The Vegan scratched a doubtful ear.
In five minutes, Tubal swung into the lock and Sefan, stumbling awkwardly, followed after. It was half an hour before they returned.
Tubal removed his head-piece. ìCurtains!î
Wri Forase gasped. ìyou mean-weíre through?î
The Arcturian shook his head. ìWe can fix it, but it will take time. The radio is ruined for good, so we canít get help.î
ìGet help!î Forase looked shocked. ìThatís all we need. How would we explain being inside the Spican system? We might as well commit suicide as send out radio calls. As long as we can get back without help, weíre safe. Missing a few more classes wonít hurt us too much.î
Sefanís voice broke in dully. ìBut what about those panicky Earthmen back on Spica Four?î
Foraseís mouth opened, but he didnít say a word. It closed again, and if ever a Humanoid looked sick, Forase was that Humanoid.
That was only the beginning.
It took a day and a half to unscramble the space jalopyís power lines. It took two more days to decelerate to safe turning point. It took four days to return to Spica IV. Total-eight days.
When the ship hovered once more over the place where they had marooned the Earthmen, it was midmorning, and the Tubalís face as he surveyed the area through the televisor was a study in length. Shortly he broke a silence that had long since become sticky.
ìI guess weíve made every boner we could possibly have made. We landed them right outside a native village. Thereís no sign of the Earthmen.î
Sefan shook his head dolefully. ìThis is a bad business.î
Tubal buried his head in his long arms clear down to the elbows.
ìThatís the finish. If they didnít scare themselves to death, the natives got them. Violating prohibited solar systems is bad enough-but itís just plain murder now, I guess.î
ìWhat weíve got to do,î said Sefan, ìis to get down there and find out if there are any still alive. We owe them that much. After that-î
He swallowed. Forase finished in a whisper.
ìAfter that, itís expulsion from the U., psycho-revision-and manual labor for life.î
ìForget it!î barked Tubal. ìWeíll face that when we have to.î
Slowly, very slowly, the ship circled downward and came to rest on the rocky clearing where, eight days previously, ten Earthmen had been left stranded.
ìHow do we handle these natives?î Tubal turned to Forase with raised eyebrow ridges (there was no hair on them, of course). ìCome on, son, give with some sub-Humanoid psychology. There are only three of us and I donít want any trouble.î
Forase shrugged and his fuzzy face wrinkled in perplexity. ìIíve just been thinking about that, Tubal. I donít know any.î
ìWhat!î exploded Sefan and Tubal in twin shouts.
ìNo one does,î added the Denebian hurriedly. ìItís a fact. After all, we donít let sub-Humanoids into the Federation till theyíre fully civilized, and we quarantine them until then. Do you suppose we have much opportunity to study their psychology?î
The Arcturian seated himself heavily. ìThis gets better and better. Think, Fuzzy-face, will you? Suggest something!î
Forase scratched his head. ìWell-uh-the best we can do is to treat them like normal Humanoids. If we approach slowly, palms spread out, make no sudden movements and keep calm, we ought toget along. Now, remember, Iím saying we ought to. I canít be certain about this.î
ìLetís go, and damnation with certainty,î urged Sefan impatiently. ìIt doesnít matter much, anyway. If I get knocked off here, I donít have to go back home.î His face took on a hunted look. ìWhen I think of what my family is going to say-î
They emerged from the ship and sniffed the atmosphere of Spicaís fourth planet. The sun was at meridian, and loomed overhead like a large orange basketball. Off in the woods, a bird called once in a creaky caw. Utter silence descended.
ìHmph!î said Tubal, arms akimbo.
ìItís enough to make you feel sleepy. No signs of life at all. Now, which way is the villager
There was a three-way dispute about this, but it didnít last long. The Arcturian first, the other two tagging along, they strode down the slope and toward the straggling forest.
A hundred feet inside, the trees came alive, as a wave of natives dropped noiselessly from the overhanging branches. Wri Forase went under at the very first of the avalanche. Bill Sefan stumbled, stood his ground momentarily, then went over backward with a grunt.
Only huge Myron Tubal was left standing. Legs straddled wide, and whooping hoarsely, he laid about right and left. The attacking natives hit him and bounced off like drops of water from a whirling flywheel. Modeling his defense on the principle of the windmill, he backed his way against a tree.
Here he made a mistake. On the lowest branch of that tree squatted a native at once more cautious and more brainy than his fellows. Tubal had already noticed that the natives were equipped with stout, muscular tails, and had made a mental note of the fact. Of all the races in the Galaxy, only one other, Homo Gamma Cepheus, possessed tails. What he didnít notice, however, was that these tails were prehensile.
This he found out almost immediately, for the native in the branch above his head looped his tail downward, Hashed it about Tubalís neck and contracted it.
The Arcturian threshed wildly in agony, and the tailed attacker was jerked from his tree. Suspended head-first and whirled about in huge sweeps, the native nevertheless maintained his hold and tightened that tail-grip steadily.
The world blacked out. Tubal was unconscious before he hit the ground.
Tubal came to slowly, unpleasantly aware of the stinging stiffness of his neck. He tried vainly to rub that stiffness, and it took a few seconds to realize that he was tied tightly. The fact startled him into alertness. He became aware, first, that he was lying on his stomach; second, of the horrible din about him; third, of Sefan and Forase bundled up next to him-and last, that he could not break his bonds.
ìHey, Sefan, Forase! Can you hear me?î
It was Sefan that answered joyfully. ìyou old Draconian goat! We thought you were out for good.î
ìI donít die so easy,î grunted the Arcturian. ìWhere are we?î
There was a short pause.
ìIn the native village, I imagine,î Wri Forase said dully. ìDid you ever hear such a noise? The drum hasnít stopped a minute since they dumped us here.î
ìHave you seen anything of-î
Hands were upon Tubal, and he felt himself whirled about. He was in a sitting posture now and his neck hurt worse than ever. Ramshackle huts of thatch and green logs gleamed in the early afternoon sun. In a circle about them, watching in silence, were dark-skinned, long-tailed natives. There must have been hundreds, all wearing feathered head-dresses and carrying short, wickedly barbed spears.
Their eyes were upon the row of figures that squatted mysteriously in the foreground, and upon these Tubal turned his angry glare. It was plain that they were the leaders of the tribe. Dressed in gaudy, fringed robes of ill-tanned skins, they added further to their barbaric impressiveness by wearing tall wooden masks painted into caricatures of the human face.
With measured steps, the masked horror nearest the Humanoids approached.
ìHello,î it said, and the mask lifted up and off. ìBack so soon?î
For quite a long while, Tubal and Sefan said absolutely nothing, while Wri Forase went into a protracted fit of coughing.
Finally, Tubal drew a long breath. ìYouíre one of the Earthmen, arenít you?î
ìThatís right. Iím Al Williams. Just call me Al.î
ìThey havenít killed you yet?î
Williams smiled happily. ìThey havenít killed any of us. Quite the contrary. Gentlemen,î he bowed extravagantly, ìmeet the new tribal-er-gods.î
ìThe new tribal what?î gasped Forase. He was still coughing. ì-er-gods. Sorry, but I donít know the Galactic word for a god.î
ìWhat do you ëgodsí represent?î
ìWeíre sort of supernatural entities-objects to be worshipped. Donít you get it?î
The Humanoids stared unhappily.
ìYes, indeed,î Williams grinned, ìweíre persons of great power.î
ìWhat are you talking about?î exclaimed Tubal indignantly. ìWhy should they think you were of great power? You Earth people are below average physically-well below!î
ìIts the psychology of the thing,î explained Williams. ìIf they see us landing in a large, gleaming vehicle that travels mysteriously through the air, and then takes off in a burst of rocket-flame-theyíre bound to consider us supernatural. Thatís elementary barbaric psychology.î
Foraseís eyes seemed on the point of dropping out as Williams continued.
ìIncidentally, what detained you? We figure it was all a hazing of some sort, and it was, wasnít it?î
ìSay,î broke in Sefan, ìI think youíre feeding us a lot of bull! If they thought you people were gods, why didnít they think we were? We had the ship, too, and-î
ìThat,î said Williams, ìis where we started to interfere. We explained-via pictures and sign language-that you people were devils. When you finally came back-and say, were we glad to see that ship coming down-they knew what to do.î
ìWhat, ì asked Forase, with a liberal dash of awe in his voice, ìare ëdevilsí?î
Williams sighed. ìDonít you Galaxy people know anything? Tubal moved his aching neck slowly. ìHow about letting us up now?î he rumbled. ìIíve got a crick in my neck.î
ìWhatís your hurry? After all, you were brought here to be sacrificed in our honor.î
ìSacrificed!î
ìSure. Youíre to be carved up with knives.î
There was a horror-laden silence. ìDonít give us any of that cometgas!î Tubal managed to grind out at last. ìWeíre not Earthmen who get panicky or scared, you know.î
ìOh, we know that! I wouldnít fool you for the world. But simple ordinary savage psychology always goes for a little human sacrifice, and-î
Sefan writhed against his bonds and tried to throw himself in a rage at Forase.
ìI thought you said no one knew any sub-Humanoid psychology! Trying to alibi your ignorance, werenít you, you shriveled; fuzz-covered, pop-eyed son of a half-breed Vegan lizard! A fine mess weíre in now!î
Forase shrank away. ìNow, wait! Just-î
Williams decided the joke had gone far enough.
ìTake it easy,î he soothed. ìYour clever hazing blew up right in your faces-it blew up beautifully-but weíre not going to carry it too far. I guess weíve had enough fun out of you fellows. Sweeney is with the native chief now, explaining that weíre leaving and taking you three with us. Frankly, Iíll be glad to get going-Wait a while, Sweeneyís calling me.î
When Williams returned two seconds later, his expression was peculiar, having turned a bit greenish. In fact, he got greener by the second.
ìIt looks,î he gulped throatily, ëëas if our counter-haze has blown up in our faces. The native chief insists on the sacrifice!î
Silence brooded, while the three Humanoids thought over the state of affairs. For moments, none of them could say a word
ìIíve told Sweeney,î Williams added, glumly, ìto go back and tell the chief that if he doesnít do as we say, something terrible is going to happen to his tribe. But itís pure bluff and he may not fall for it. Uh,-Iím sorry, fellows. I guess we went too far. If it looks really bad, weíll cut you loose and join in the fight.î
ìCut us loose now,î growled Tubal, his blood running cold. ìLetís get this over with!î
ìWait!î cried Forase frantically. ìLet the Earthman try some of his psychology. Go ahead, Earthman. Think hard!î
Williams thought until his brain began to hurt.
ìYou see,î he said weakly, ìweíve lost some of our godlike prestige, ever since we were unable to cure the chiefís wife. She died yesterday.î He nodded abstractedly to himself. ìWhat we need is an impressive miracle. Er-have you fellows anything in your pockets?î
He knelt beside them and began searching. Wri Forase had a stylus, a pocket-pad, a thin-toothed comb, some anti-itch powder, a sheaf of credits and a few odds and ends. Sefan had a collection of similar nondescript material.
It was from Tubalís hip pocket that Williams withdrew a small black gunlike object with a huge hand-grip and a short barrel.
ìWhatís this?î
Tubal scowled. ìIs that what Iíve been sitting on all this while? Itís a weld-gun that I used to fix up a meteor puncture in our ship. Itís no good; powerís almost gone.î
Williamsí eyes kindled. His whole body galvanized with excitement.
ìThatís what you think! You Galaxy men never could see farther than your noses. Why donít you come down to Earth for a spell-and get a new point of view?î
Williams was running toward his fellow conspirators now.
ìSweeney,î he howled, ìyou tell that damned monkey-tailed chief that in just about one second, Iím going to get sore and pull the whole sky down over his head. Get tough!î
But the chief did not wait for the message. He gestured defiance and the natives made a united rush. Tubal roared, and his muscles cracked against the bonds. The weld-gun in Williamsí hand flared into life, its feeble power beaming outward.
The nearest native hut went up in sudden flames. Another followed-and another-and the fourth-and then the weld-gun went dead.
But it was enough. Not a native remained standing. All were groveling on their faces, wailing and shrieking for pardon. The chief wailed and shrieked loudest of all.
ìTell the chief,î said Williams to Sweeney, ìthat thatís just a little, insignificant sample of what weíre thinking of doing to him!î
To the Humanoids, as he cut the rawhide holding them, he added complacently,
ìJust some simple, ordinary savage psychology.î
It was only after they were back in their ship and off in space again that Forase locked up his pride.
ìBut I thought Earthmen had never developed mathematical psychology! How did You know all that sub-Humanoid stuff? No one in the Galaxy has got that far yet!î
ìWell,î Williams grinned, ìwe have a certain amount of rule-of-thumb knowledge about the workings of the uncivilized mind. You see-we come from a world where most people, in a manner of speaking, are still uncivilized. So we have to know!î
Forase nodded slowly. ìYou screwball Earthmen! At least, this little episode has taught us all one thing.î
ìWhatís that?î
ìNever,î said Forase, dipping a second time into Earth slang, ìget tough with a bunch of nuts. They may be nuttier than you think!î



***



In going through my stories while preparing this book, I found ìThe Hazingî to be the only published story concerning which I could remember nothing from the title alone. Even as I reread it, nothing clicked. If I had been given the story without my name on it and had been asked to read it and guess the author, I would probably have been stumped. Maybe that means something.
It does seem to me, though, that the story is set against a ìHomo Solî background.
I had better luck with Fred Pohl with another story, ìSuper-Neutron,î which I wrote at the end of the same February in which I did ìMasksî and ìThe Hazing.î I submitted it to him on March 3, 1941, and he accepted it on March 5.
By that time, less than three years after my first submission, I was clearly becoming rather impatient with rejections. At least, the news of the acceptance of ìSuper-Neutronî is greeted in my diary with an ìItís about time I made a sale-five and a half weeks since the last one.î








Super-Neutron


It was at the seventeenth meeting of the Honorable Society of Ananias that we got the greatest scare of our collective lives and consequently elected Gilbert Hayes to the office of Perpetual President.
The Society is not a large one. Before the election of Hayes there were only four of us: John Sebastian, Simon Murfree, Morris Levin and myself. On the first Sunday of every month we met at luncheon, and on these monthly occasions justified our Societyís title by gambling the dinner check on our ability to lie.
It was quite a complicated process, with strict Parliamentary rules. One member spun a yarn each meeting as his turn came up, and two conditions had to be adhered to. His story had to be an outrageous, complicated, fantastic lie; and, it had to sound like the truth. Members were allowed to-and did-attack any and every point of the story by asking questions or demanding explanations.
Woe to the narrator who did not answer all questions immediately, or who, in answering, involved himself in a contradiction. The dinner-check was his! Financial loss was slight; but the disgrace was great.
And then came that seventeenth meeting-and Gilbert Hayes. Hayes was one of several non-members who attended occasionally to listen to the after-dinner whopper, paying his own check, and, of course, being forbidden to participate; but on this occasion he was the only one present aside from the regular members.
Dinner was over, I had been voted into the chair (it was my regular turn to preside), and the minutes had been read, when Hayes leaned forward and said quietly, ìIíd like a chance today, gentlemen.î
I frowned, ìIn the eyes of the Society you are non-existent, Mr. Hayes. It is impossible for you to take part.î
ìThen just let me make a statement, ì he rejoined. ìThe Solar System is coming to an end at exactly seventeen and a half minutes after two this afternoon.î
There was a devil of a stir, and I looked at the electric clock over the television receiver. It was 1:14 P.M.
I said hesitantly, ìIf you have anything to substantiate that extraordinary statement, it should be most interesting. It is Mr. Levinís turn today, but if he is willing to waive it, and if the rest of the Society agrees-î
Levin smiled and nodded, and the others joined in.
I banged the gavel, ìMr. Hayes has the floor.î
Hayes lit his cigar and gazed at it pensively. ìI have little more than an hour, gentlemen, but Iíll start at the beginning-which is about fifteen years ago. At that time, though Iíve resigned since, I was an astrophysicist at Yerkes Observatory-young, but promising. I was hot on the trail of the solution to one of the perennial puzzles of astrophysics-the source of the cosmic rays-and full of ambition.î
He paused, and continued in a different tone, ìYou know, it is strange that with all our scientific advance in the last two centuries we have never found either that mysterious source or the equally mysterious reason for the explosion of a star. They are the two eternal puzzles and we know as little about them today as we did in the days of Einstein, Eddington, and Millikan.
ìStill, as I say, I thought I had the cosmic ray by the tail, so I set out to check my ideas by observation, and for that I had to go out in space. It wasnít, however, as easy as all that. It was in 2129, you see, just after the last war, and the Observatory was about broke-as werenít we all?
ìI made the best of it. I hired an old second-hand ë07 model, piled my apparatus in, and set out alone. Whatís more, I had to sneak out of port without clearance papers, not wishing to go through the red tape the occupation army would have put me through. It was illegal, but I wanted my data-so I headed out at a right angle to the ecliptic, in the direction of the South Celestial Pole, approximately, and left Sol a billion miles behind me.
ìThe voyage I made, and the data I collected are unimportant. I never reported one or the other. It was the planet I found that makes the story.î
At this point, Murfree raised those bushy eyebrows of his and grunted, ìI would like to warn the gentleman, Mr. Chairman. No member has yet escaped with his skin with a phony planet.î
Hayes smiled grimly, ìIíll take my chance. -To continue; it was on the eighteenth day of my trip that I first detected the planet, as a little orange disc the size of a pea.
