Naturally, a planet in that region of space is something of a sensation. I headed for it; and immediately discovered that I had not even scratched the surface of that planetís queerness. To exist there at all was phenomenal-but it likewise possessed absolutely no gravitational field.î
Levinís wine-glass crashed to the floor. ìMr. Chairman,î he gasped, ìI demand the gentlemanís immediate disqualification. No mass can exist without distorting the space in its neighborhood and thus creating a gravitational field He has made an impossible statement, and should therefore be disqualified.î His face was an angry red.
But Hayes held his hand up, ìI demand time, Mr. Chairman. The explanation will be forthcoming in due course. To make it now would only complicate things. Please, may I continue?î
I considered, ìIn view of the nature of your story, I am disposed to be lenient. Delay is granted, but please remember that an explanation will be required eventually. You will lose without it.î
ìAll right, ì said Hayes. ìFor the present, you will have to accept my statement that the planet had no gravity at all. That is definite, for I had complete astronomical equipment upon my ship, and though my instruments were very sensitive, they registered a dead zero.
ìIt worked the other way around as well, for the planet was not affected by the gravity of other masses. Again, I stress the point that it was not affected at all. This I was not able to determine at the time, but subsequent observation over a period of years, showed that the planet was traveling in a straight-line orbit and at a constant speed. As it was well within the sunís influence, the fact that its orbit was neither elliptical nor hyperbolic, and that, though approaching the sun, it was not accelerating, showed definitely that it was independent of solar gravity.î
ìWait a while, Hayes.î Sebastian scowled till his gold premolar gleamed. ìWhat held this wonderful planet together? Without gravity, why didnít it break up and drift apart?î
ìSheer inertia, for one thing!î was the immediate retort. ìThere was nothing to pull it apart. A collision with another body of comparable size might have done it-leaving out of consideration the possibility of the existence of some other binding force peculiar to the planet ì
He sighed and continued, ìThat doesnít finish the properties of the body. Its red-orange color and its low reflective power, or albedo, set me on another track, and I made the astonishing discovery that the planet was entirely transparent to the whole electro-magnetic spectrum from radio waves to cosmic rays. It was only in the region of the red and yellow portion of the visible-light octave that it was reasonably opaque. Hence, its color.î
ìWhy was this?î demanded Murfree.
Hayes looked at me, ìThat is an unreasonable question, Mr. chairman. I maintain that I might as well be asked to explain why glass is entirely transparent to anything above or below the ultra-violet region, so that heat, light, and X-rays pass through, while it remains opaque to ultra-violet light itself. This sort of thing is a property of the substance itself and must be accepted as such without explanation.î
I whacked my gavel, ìQuestion declared improper!î
ìI object,î declared Murfree. ìHayes missed the point Nothing is perfectly transparent Glass of sufficient thickness will stop even cosmic rays. Do you mean to say that blue light would pass through an entire planet, or heat, for instance?î
ìWhy not?î replied Hayes. ìThat perfect transparency does not exist in your experience does not mean it does not exist altogether. There is certainly no scientific law to that effect This planet was perfectly transparent except for one small region of the spectrum. Thatís a definite fact of observation.î
My gavel thumped again, ìExplanation declared sufficient Continue, Hayes.î
His cigar had gone out and he paused to relight Then, ìIn other respects, the planet was normal. It was not quite the size of Saturn-perhaps half way in diameter between it and Neptune. Subsequent experiments showed it to possess mass, though it was hard to find out how much-certainly more than twice Earthís. With mass, it possessed the usual properties of inertia and momentum-but no gravity.î
It was 1:35 now.
Hayes followed my eyes and said, ìYes, only three-quarters of an hour is left. Iíll hurry!ÖNaturally, this queer planet set me to thinking, and that, together with the fact that I had already been evolving certain theories concerning cosmic rays and novae, led to an interesting solution.î
He drew a deep breath, ìImagine-if you can-our cosmos as a cloud of-well, super-atoms which-î
ìI beg your pardon,î exclaimed Sebastian, rising to his feet, ìare you intending to base any of your explanation on drawing analogies between stars and atoms, or between solar systems and electronic orbits?î
ìWhy do you ask?î questioned Hayes, quietly. ìBecause if you do, I demand immediate disqualification. The belief that atoms are miniature solar systems is in a class with the Ptolemaic scheme of the universe. The idea has never been accepted by responsible scientists even at the very dawn of the atomic theory.î
I nodded, ìThe gentleman is correct. No such analogy will be permitted as part of the explanation.î
ì I object,î said Hayes. ìIn your school course in elementary physics or chemistry, you will remember that in the study of the properties of gases, it was often pretended, for the sake of illustrating a point, that the gas molecules were tiny billiard balls. Does that mean that gas molecules are billiard balls?î
ìNo,î admitted Sebastian.
ìIt only means,î drove on Hayes, ìthat gas molecules act similarly to billiard balls in some ways. Therefore the actions of one are better visualized by studying the actions of the other. -Well, then, I am only trying to point out a phenomenon in our universe of stars, and for the sake of ease of visualization, I compare it to a similar, and better-known, phenomenon in the world of atoms. That does not mean that stars are magnified atoms.î
I was won over. ìThe point is well-taken,î I said. ìYou may continue with your explanation, but if it is the judgment of the chair that the analogy becomes a false one, you will be disqualified.î
ìGood,î agreed Hayes, ìbut weíll pass on to another point for a moment. Do any of you remember the first atomic power plants of a hundred and seventy years ago and how they operated?î
ìI believe,î muttered Levin, ìthat they used the classical uranium fission method for power. They bombarded uranium with slow neutrons and split it up into masurium, barium, gamma rays and more neutrons, thus establishing a cyclic process.î
ìThatís right! Well, imagine that the stellar universe acted in ways-mind you, this is a metaphor, and not to be taken literally-like a body composed of uranium atoms, and imagine this stellar universe to be bombarded from without by objects which might act in some ways similar to the way neutrons act on an atomic scale.
ìSuch a super-neutron, hitting a sun, would cause that sun to explode into radiation and more super-neutrons. In other words, you would have a nova.î He looked around for disagreement.
ìWhat justification have you for that idea?î demanded Levin.
ìTwo; one logical, and one observational. Logic first. Stars are essentially in matter-energy equilibrium, yet suddenly, with no observable change, either spectral or otherwise, they occasionally explode. An explosion indicates instability, but where? Not within the star, for it had been in equilibrium for millions of years. Not from a point within the universe, for novae occur in even concentration throughout the universe. Hence, by elimination, only from a point outside the universe.
ìSecondly, observation. I came across one of these super-neutrons!î
Said Murfree indignantly: ìI suppose you mean that gravitationless planet you came across?î
ìThatís right.î
ìThen what makes you think itís a super-neutron? You canít use your theory as proof, because youíre using the super-neutron itself to bolster the theory. Weíre not allowed to argue in circles here.î
ìI know that,î declared Hayes, stiffly. ìIíll resort to logic again. The world of atoms possesses a cohesive force in the electro-magnetic charge on electrons and protons. The world of stars possesses a cohesive force in gravity. The two forces are only alike in a very general manner. For instance, there are two kinds of electrical charges, positive and negative, but only one kind of gravity-and innumerable minor differences. Still, an analogy this far seems to me to be permissible. A neutron on an atomic scale is a mass without the atomic cohesive force-electric charge. A super-neutron on a stellar scale ought to be a mass without the stellar cohesive force-gravity. Therefore, if I find a body without gravity, it seems reasonable to assume it to be a super-neutron.î
ìDo you consider that a rigorously scientific proof?î asked Sebastian sarcastically.
ìNo,î admitted Hayes, ìbut it is logical, conflicts with no scientific fact I know of, and works out to form a consistent explanation of novae. That should be enough for our purpose at present.î
Murfree was gazing hard at his fingernails, ìAnd just where is this superneutron of yours heading?î
ìI see you anticipate,î said Hayes, sombrely. ìIt was what I asked myself at the time. At 2:09Y2 today it hits the sun square, and eight minutes later, the radiation resulting from the explosion will sweep Earth to oblivion.î
ìWhy didnít you report all this?î barked Sebastian.
ìWhere was the use? There was nothing to be done about it. We canít handle astronomical masses. All the power available on Earth would not have sufficed to swerve that great body from its path. There was no escape within the Solar System itself, for Neptune and Pluto will turn gaseous along with the other planets, and interstellar travel is as yet impossible. Since man cannot exist independently in space, he is doomed.
ìWhy tell of all this? What would result after I had convinced them that the death warrant was signed? Suicides, crime waves, orgies, messiahs, evangelists, and everything bad and futile you could think of. And after all, is death by nova so bad? It is instantaneous and clean. At 2:17 youíre here. At 2:18 you are a mass of attenuated gas. It is so quick and easy a death, it is almost not death.î
There was a long silence after this. I felt uneasy. There are lies and lies, but this sounded like the real thing. Hayes didnít have that little quirk of the lip or that little gleam in the eye which marks the triumph of putting over a good one. He was deadly, deadly serious. I could see the others felt the same. Levin was gulping at his wine, hand shaking.
Finally, Sebastian coughed loudly, ìHow long ago did you discover this super-neutron and where?î
ìFifteen years ago, a billion miles or better from the sun.î
ìAnd all that time it has been approaching the sun?î
ìYes; at a constant speed of two miles per second.î
ìGood, Iíve got you!î Sebastian almost laughed his relief. ìWhy havenít the astronomers spotted it in all this while?î
ìMy God,î responded Hayes, impatiently, ìitís clear you arenít an astronomer. Now, what fool would look to the Southern Celestial Pole for a planet, when theyíre only found in the ecliptic?î
ìBut,ì pointed out Sebastian, ìthe region is studied just the same. It is photographed.î
ìSurely! For all I know, the super-neutron has been photographed a hundred times-a thousand times if you like-though the Southern Pole is the most poorly watched region of the sky. But whatís to differentiate it from a star? With its low albedo, it never passed eleventh magnitude in brightness. After all, itís hard enough to detect any planets in any case. Uranus was spotted many times before Herschel realized it was a planet. Pluto took years to find even when they were looking for it. Remember also that without gravity, it causes no planetary perturbations, and that the absence of these removes the most obvious indication of its presence.î
ìBut, ì insisted Sebastian, desperately, ìas it approached the sun, its apparent size would increase and it would begin to show a perceptible disc through a telescope. Even if its reflected light were very faint, it would certainly obscure the stars behind it.î
ìTrue,î admitted Hayes. ìI will not say that a really thorough mapping of the Polar Region would not have uncovered it, but such mapping has been done long ago, and the present cursory searches for novae, special spectral types, and so on are by no means thorough. Then, as the super-neutron approaches the sun, it begins to appear only in the dawn and twilight-in evening and morning star fashion-so that observation becomes much more difficult. And so, as a matter of fact, it just has not been observed-and it is what should have been expected.î
Again a silence, and I became aware that my heart was pounding. Itwas two oíclock even, and we hadnít been able to shake Hayesí story. We had to prove it a lie fast, or r d die of sheer suspense. We were all of us watching the clock.
Levin took up the fight. ìItís an awfully queer coincidence that the super-neutron should be heading straight for the sun. What are the chances against it? Remember, that would be the same thing as reciting the chances against the truth of the story.î
I interposed, ìThat is an illegitimate objection, Mr. Levin. To cite improbability, however great, is not sufficient. Only outright impossibility or citation of inconsistency can serve to disqualify.î
But Hayes waved his hand, ìItís all right. Let me answer. Taking an individual super-neutron and an individual star, the chances of collision, head on, are all but infinitely small. However, statistically, if you shoot enough super-neutrons into the universe, then, given enough time, every star ought to be hit sooner or later. Space must be swarming with super-neutrons-say one every thousand cubic parsecs-so that in spite of the vast distances between the stars and the relative minuteness of the targets, twenty novae occur in our single Galaxy every year-that is, there are twenty collisions between superneutrons and stars annually.
ìThe situation is no different really from uranium being bombarded with ordinary neutrons. Only one neutron out of a hundred million may score a hit, but, given time, every nucleus is exploded eventually. If there is an outer-universe intelligence directing this bombardment-pure hypothesis, and not part of my argument, please-a year to us is probably an infinitesimal fraction of a second to them. The hits, to them, may be occurring at the rate of billions to their seconds. Energy is being developed, perhaps, to the point where the material this universe composes has become heated to the gaseous state-or whatever passes for the gaseous state there. The universe is expanding, you know-like a gas.î
ìStill, for the very first super-neutron entering our system to head straight for the sun seems-î Levin ended in a weak stammer.
ìGood Lord,î snapped Hayes, ìwho told you this was the first? Hundreds may have passed through the system in geologic times. One or two may have passed through in the last thousand years or so. How would we know? Even when one is headed straight for the sun, astronomers donít find it. Perhaps this is the only one thatís passed through since the telescope was invented, and before then, of course. And never forget that, having no gravity, they can go right through the middle of the system, without affecting the planets. Only a hit on the sun registers, and then itís too late.î
He looked at the clock, ì2:o51 We ought to see it now against the sun.î He stood up and raised the window shade. The yellow sunlight streamed in and I moved away from the dusty shaft of light. My mouth was dry as desert sand. Murfree was mopping his brow, but beads of sweat stood out all along his cheeks and neck.
Hayes took out several slips of exposed film-negative and handed them out, ìI came prepared, you see.î He held one up and squinted at the sun. ìThere it is,î he remarked placidly. ìMy calculations showed it would be in transit with respect to Earth at the time of collision. Rather convenient!î
I was looking at the sun, too, and felt my heart skip a beat. There, quite clear against the brightness of the sun, was a little, perfectly round, black spot.
ìWhy doesnít it vaporize?î stammered Murfree. ìIt must be almost in the sunís atmosphere.î I donít think he was trying to disprove Hayesí story. He had gone past that. He was honestly seeking information.
ìI told you,î explained Hayes, ìthat it is transparent to almost all solar radiation. Only the radiation it absorbs can go into heat and thatís a very small percentage of all it receives. Besides, it isnít ordinary matter. Itís probably much more refractory than anything on Earth, and the Solar surface is only at 6,000 degrees Centrigrade.î
He pointed a thumb over his shoulder, ìItís 2:09?, gentlemen. The super-neutron has struck and death is on its way. We have eight minutes.î
We were dumb with something that was just simply unbearable terror. I remember Hayesí voice, quite matter-of-fact, saying, ìMercury just went?î then a few minutes later, ìVenus has gone!î and lastly, ìThirty seconds left, gentlemen!î
The seconds crawled, but passed at last, and another thirty seconds, and still anotherÖ
And on Hayesí face, a look of astonishment grew and spread. He lifted the clock and stared at it, then peered through his film at the sun once more.
ìItís gone?î He turned and faced us, ìItís unbelievable. I had thought of it, but I dared not draw the atomic analogy too far. You know that not all atomic nuclei explode on being hit by a neutron. Some, cadmium, for instance, absorb them one after the other like sponges do water. I-î
He paused again, drew a deep breath, and continued musingly, ìEven the purest block of uranium contains traces of all other elements. And in a universe of trillions of stars acting like uranium, what does a paltry million of cadmium-like stars amount to-nothing! Yet the sun is one of them! Mankind never deserved that!î
He kept on talking, but relief had finally penetrated and we listened no longer. In half-hysterical fashion, we elected Gilbert Hayes to the office of Perpetual President by enthusiastic acclamation, and voted the story the whoppingest lie ever told.
But thereís one thing that bothers me. Hayes fills his post well; the Society is more successful than ever-but I think he should have been disqualified after all. His story fulfilled the second condition; it sounded like the truth. But I donít think it fulfilled the first condition.
I think it was the truth!



***



I had series on my mind by now. ìSuper-Neutronî was certainly intended to be but the first in a long chain of very clever and very ingenious tales to be told at the meetings of the ìHonorable Society of Ananias.î It didnít work out that way. There was never a second story, not even the beginnings of one, not even the idea for one.
By the time I was writing ìSuper-Neutron,î in February of 1941, I had heard of uranium fission and had even discussed it in some detail with Campbell. I managed to refer to it in the course of the story as ìthe classical uranium fission method for power.î I also spoke of the metal cadmium as a neutron absorber. It wasnít bad for a story that appeared in 1941, and I sometimes quote it in public to create an impression.
Notice, though, that in the same paragraph in which I mention fission, I also talk of ìmasurium.î Actually, masurium was the name given to element ~43 in 1926, but that discovery had proven a false alarm. The element was really discovered in 1937 and was given the now-accepted name of ìtechnetium.î It seems, then, that I could look years into the future and see uranium fission as a practical power source, but I couldnít look a few years into the past and see the correct name for element #43.
This brings us to March 17, 1941, and one of the key turning points of my literary career.
By that day, I had written thirty-one stories. Of these I had already sold seventeen and was yet to sell four more. Of all these stories, three perhaps, and no more, were to turn out to be of more than ephemeral value, and those were the three ìpositronic robotsî stories I had so far written: ìRobbie,î
ìReason,î and ìLiar!î
Looking back on my first three years as a writer, then, I can judge myself to be nothing more than a steady and (perhaps) hopeful third-rater. Whatís more, thatís all I considered myself then, too. Nor did anyone else, at that time, seriously consider me as a potential first-magnitude star in the science fiction heavens-except, maybe, Campbell.
What are the odds, then, that on March 17, 1941, I would sit down and write something that for thirty years now has been considered by a surprising number of people to be the outstanding short classic of magazine science fiction? It was one of those things that couldnít possibly happen-yet it did.
It began when I walked into Campbellís office that day and, as usual, suggested an idea. What it was I donít remember, but whatever it was he turned it down instantly, not because it was such a bad idea but because he had something he wanted to show me that crowded everything else out of his mind. He had come across a quotation from Ralph Waldo Emerson that went: ìIf the stars should appear one night in a thousand years, how would men believe and adore, and preserve for many generations the remembrance of the city of God!î [Does anyone know in what essay, and in what connection, Emerson says this? Every once in a while I make a desultory search through quotation books or through a collection of Emerson but havenít found it yet. I hope it exists and that the quote is given correctly.]
Campbell asked me what I thought would happen if the stars would appear at only very long intervals. I had nothing intelligent to suggest.
ìI think men would go mad,î he said thoughtfully.
We talked about that notion for quite a while, and I went home to write a story on the subject, one that Campbell and I decided from the start was to be called ìNightfallî
I began it that night. I can remember the details exactly: my parentsí apartment on Windsor Place in Brooklyn, across the street from the candy store; my own room, just next to the living room, is clear in my mind, with the position of my bed, my desk, my typewriter-and myself getting started.
In years to come, fans would occasionally vote in polls designed to decide the best science fiction short stories of all time. Quite frequently, ìNightfallî would finish in first place. Just a couple of years ago, the Science Fiction Writers of America polled their membership to decide the best science fiction short stories ever published, for inclusion in a Hall of Fame anthology. ìNightfallî finished in first place by a sizable margin. And, of course, it has been anthologized a dozen times so far.
With all this, one might argue that ìNightfallî is the best (or at least the most popular) short science fiction story ever to appear in the magazines. Well, I often wonder, with a shudder, what might have happened on the evening of March 17, 1941, if some angelic spirit had whispered in my ear, ìIsaac, you are about to start writing the best short science fiction story of our time.î
I would undoubtedly have frozen solid. I wouldnít have been able to type a word.
But we donít know the future, and I tapped away blissfully, writing the story and completing it by April 9, 1941. That day, I submitted it to Campbell. He asked for a small revision. I took care of that, and on April 24, 1941, he bought the story.
It set several records for me. It was the longest story I had yet sold, a little over thirteen thousand words. Since Campbell paid me a bonus (my first one), the word rate was one and a quarter cents a word, and the total check was for $166, more than twice as large as any single payment I had ever before received. [ìBlack Friar of the Flameî was three thousand words longer than ìNightfall,î but the former was not to be sold for another half year, and since it earned merely one cent a word, it brought in only $161. Of course, first-time earnings are not the whole story, either. ìNightfallî has earned me some thousands of dollars since 1941 and will yet earn me more; ìBlack Friar of the Flameî has not yet earned me one cent over the original check-till its appearance in this book.]
Then, too, ìNightfallî appeared in the September 1941 issue of Astounding as the lead novelette. For the first time, I made the cover of that magazine, with ìNightfall, by Isaac Asimovî in large, bold letters.
Most important of all, the appearance of ìNightfallî graduated me by common consent (three years after I had begun my career) into the list of first-rank science fiction writers.
Alas, the story is not included here. It appears (of course) in Nightfall and Other Stories. [In telling the story, in that collection, of how ìNightfallî came to be written, I mentioned that I had received $150 for it, quoting from memory. Once again, I must confess fallibility. The records say $166. It is a small point, and perhaps not worth noting, but I know my readers. By explaining this now, I fend off dozens of letters that will mention the discrepancy and demand an explanation.]
The excitement of writing ìNightfallî and Campbellís hearty and unqualified praise of it ought, one might think, to have set me furiously to work at the typewriter, but it didnít. Spring 1941 was a bad time for me.
I could at any time that half year have left Columbia with a masterís degree, but that would have done me no good. I had no job to go to, so I could only mark time and try to raise my value to some prospective employer by going on to the big one, the doctorate.
But that meant I had to take a series of elaborate, interminable ìqualifying examinations,î which I had to pass in order to be allowed to begin the research without which I could not get the Ph.D. Passing was difficult and I didnít feel prepared at all, but I had to try it sometime, and besides, if I didnít fall short by too far, I would be allowed to continue taking courses and to repeat the qualifying examinations at some future date.
So in May I absented myself from the typewriter, studied earnestly for my qualifyings, took them-and didnít pass. I did well enough to earn the option of a future repeat, and I also received my M.A. as a kind of consolation prize, but I was badly disheartened all the same.
(And in the larger world outside, though Great Britain had survived air bombardment, Hitler still seemed unstoppable. He invaded the Balkans and was again winning spectacular victories, and that was disheartening, too.)
It was not till May 24. 1941, that I could bring myself to go back to my writing. I turned out ìNot Final!î which I submitted to Campbell on June z. It was accepted on the sixth, but without a bonus.








Not Final!


Nicholas Orloff inserted a monocle in his left eye with all the incorruptible Briticism of a Russian educated at Oxford and said reproachfully, ìBut, my dear Mr. Secretary! Half a billion dollars!î
Leo Birnam shrugged his shoulders wearily and allowed his lank body to cramp up still farther in the chair, ìThe appropriation must go through, commissioner. The Dominion government here at Ganymede is becoming desperate. So far, Iíve been holding them off, but as secretary of scientific affairs, my powers are small.î
ìI know, but-î and Orloff spread his hands helplessly. ìI suppose so,î agreed Birnam. ìThe Empire government finds it easier to look the other way. Theyíve done it consistently up to now. Iíve tried for a year now to have them understand the nature of the danger that hangs over the entire System, but it seems that it canít be done. But Iím appealing to you, Mr. Commissioner. Youíre new in your post and can approach this Jovian affair with an unjaundiced eye.î
Orloff coughed and eyed the tips of his boots. In the three months since he had succeeded Gridley as colonial commissioner he had tabled unread everything relating to ìthose damned Jovian D.T.ís.î That had been according to the established cabinet policy which had labeled the Jovian affair as ìdeadwoodî long before he had entered office.
But now that Ganymede was becoming nasty, he found himself sent out to Jovopolis with instructions to hold the ìblasted provincialsî down. It was a nasty spot.
Birnam was speaking, ìThe Dominion government has reached the point where it needs the money so badly, in fact, that if they donít get it, theyíre going to publicize everything.î
Orloffís phlegm broke completely, and he snatched at the monocle as it dropped, ìMy dear fellow!î
ìI know what it would mean. Iíve advised against it, but theyíre justified. Once the inside of the Jovian affair is out; once the people know about it; the Empire government wonít stay in power a week. And when the Technocrats come in, theyíll give us whatever we ask. Public opinion will see to that.î
ìBut youíll also create a panic and hysteria-î
ìSurely! That is why we hesitate. But you might call this an ultimatum. We want secrecy, we need secrecy; but we need money more.î
ìI see.î Orloff was thinking rapidly, and the conclusions he came to were not pleasant. ìIn that case, it would be advisable to investigate the case further. If you have the papers concerning the communications with the planet Jupiter-î
ìI have them,î replied Birnam, dryly, ìand so has the Empire government at Washington. That wonít do, commissioner. Itís the same cud thatís been chewed by Earth officials for the last year, and itís gotten us nowhere. I want you to come to Ether Station with me.î
The Ganymedan had risen from his chair, and he glowered down upon Orloff from his six and a half feet of height.
Orloff flushed, ì Are you ordering me?î
ìIn a way, yes. I tell you there is no time. If you intend acting, you must act quickly or not at all.î Birnam paused, then added, ìYou donít mind walking, I hope. Power vehicles arenít allowed to approach Ether Station, ordinarily, and I can use the walk to explain a few of the facts. Itís only two miles off.î
ìIíll walk,î was the brusque reply.
The trip upward to subground level was made in silence, which was broken by Orloff when they stepped into the dimly lit anteroom.
ìItís chilly here.î
ìI know. Itís difficult to keep the temperature up to norm this near the surface. But it will be colder outside. Here!î
Birnam had kicked open a closet door and was indicating the garments suspended from the ceiling. ìPut them on. Youíll need them.î
Orloff fingered them doubtfully, ìAre they heavy enough?î
Birnam was pouring into his own costume as he spoke. ìTheyíre electrically heated. Youíll find them plenty warm. Thatís it! Tuck the trouser legs inside the boots and lace them tight.î
He turned then and, with a grunt, brought out a double compressed-gas cylinder from its rack in one corner of the closet. He glanced at the dial reading; and then turned the stopcock. There was a thin wheeze of escaping gas, at which Birnam sniffed with satisfaction.
ìDo you know how to work one of these?î he asked, as he screwed onto the jet a flexible tube of metal mesh, at the other end of which was a curiously curved object of thick, clear glass.
ìWhat is it?î
ìOxygen nosepiece! What there is of Ganymedeís atmosphere is argon and nitrogen, just about half and half. It isnít particularly breathable.î He heaved the double cylinder into position, and tightened it in its harness on Orloffís back.
Orloff staggered, ìItís heavy. I canít walk two miles with this.î
ìIt wonít be heavy out there,î Birnam nodded carelessly upward and lowered the glass nosepiece over Orloffís head. ìJust remember to breathe in through the nose and out through the mouth, and you wonít have any trouble. By the way, did you eat recently?î
ìI lunched before I came to your place.î
Birnam sniffed dubiously, ìWell, thatís a little awkward.î He drew a small metal container from one of his pockets and tossed it to the commissioner. ìput one of those pills in your mouth and keep sucking on it.î
Orloff worked clumsily with gloved fingers and finally managed to get a brown spheriod out of the tin and into his mouth. He followed Birnam up a gently sloped ramp. The blind-alley ending of the corridor slid aside smoothly when they reached it and there was a faint soughing as air slipped out into the thinner atmosphere of Ganymede.
Birnam caught the otherís elbow, and fairly dragged him out.
ìIíve turned your air tank on full,î he shouted. ìBreathe deeply and keep sucking at that pill.î
Gravity had flicked to Ganymedan normality as they crossed the threshold and Orloff after one horrible moment of apparent levitation, felt his stomach turn a somersault and explode.
He gagged, and fumbled the pill with his tongue in a desperate attempt at self-control. The oxygen-rich mixture from the air cylinders burned his throat, and gradually Ganymede steadied. His stomach shuddered back into place. He tried walking.
ìTake it easy, now,î came Birnamís soothing voice. ìIt gets you that way the first few times you change gravity fields quickly. Walk slowly and get the rhythm, or youíll take a tumble. Thatís right, youíre getting it ì
The ground seemed resilient Orloff could feel the pressure of the otherís arm holding him down at each step to keep him from springing too high. Steps were longer now-and flatter, as he got the rhythm. Birnam continued speaking, a voice a little muffled from behind the leather flap drawn loosely across mouth and chin.
ìEach to his own world,î he grinned. ìI visited Earth a few years back, with my wife, and had a hell of a time. I couldnít get myself to learn to walk on a planetís surface without a nosepiece. I kept choking-I really did. The sunlight was too bright and the sky was too blue and the grass was too green. And the buildings were right out on the surface. Iíll never forget the time they tried to get me to sleep in a room twenty stories up in the air, with the window wide open and the moon shining in.
ìI went back on the first spaceship going my way and donít ever intend returning. How are you feeling now?î
ìFine! Splendid!î Now that the first discomfort had gone. Orloff found the low gravity exhilarating. He looked about him. The broken, hilly ground, bathed in a drenching yellow light, was covered with ground-hugging broad-leaved shrubs that showed the orderly arrangement of careful cultivation.
Birnam answered the unspoken question, ìThereís enough carbon dioxide in the air to keep the plants alive, and they all have the power to fix atmospheric nitrogen. Thatís what makes agriculture Ganymedeís greatest industry. Those plants are worth their weight in gold as fertilizers back on Earth and worth double or triple that as sources for half a hundred alkaloids that canít be gotten anywhere else in the System. And, of course, everyone knows that Ganymedan green-leaf has Terrestrial tobacco beat hollow.î
There was the drone of a strato-rocket overhead, shrill in the thin atmosphere, and Orloff looked up.
He stopped-stopped dead-and forgot to breathe!
It was his first glimpse of Jupiter in the sky.
It is one thing to see Jupiter, coldly harsh, against the ebon backdrop of space. At six hundred thousand miles, it is majestic enough. But on Ganymede, barely topping the hills, its outlines softened and ever so faintly hazed by the thin atmosphere; shining mellowly from a purple sky in which only a few fugitive stars dare compete with the Jovian giant-it can be described by no conceivable combination of words.
At first, Orloff absorbed the gibbous disk in silence. It was gigantic, thirty-two times the apparent diameter of the Sun as seen from Earth. Its stripes stood out in faint washes of color against the yellowness beneath and the Great Red Spot was an oval splotch of orange near the western rim.
And finally Orloff murmured weakly, ìItís beautiful!î
Leo Birnam stared, too, but there was no awe in his eyes. There was the mechanical weariness of viewing a sight often seen, and besides that an expression of sick revulsion. The chin flap hid his twitching smile, but his grasp upon Orloffís arm left bruises through the tough fabric of the surface suit.
He said slowly, ìItís the most horrible sight in the System.î
Orloff turned reluctant attention to his companion, ìEh?î Then, disagreeably, ìOh, yes, those mysterious Jovians.î
At that, the Ganymedan turned away angrily and broke into swinging, fifteen-foot strides. Orloff followed clumsily after, keeping his balance with difficulty.
ìHere, now,î he gasped.
But Birnam wasnít listening. He was speaking coldly, bitterly, ìYou on Earth can afford to ignore Jupiter. You know nothing of it. Itís a little pin prick in your sky, a little flyspeck. You donít live here on Ganymede, watching that damned colossus gloating over you. Up and over fifteen hours-hiding God knows what on its surface. Hiding something thatís waiting and waiting and trying to get out. Like a giant bomb just waiting to explode!î
ìNonsense!î Orloff managed to jerk out. ìWill you slow down. I canít keep up.î
Birnam cut his strides in half and said tensely, ìEveryone knows that Jupiter is inhabited, but practically no one ever stops to realize what that means. I tell you that those Jovians, whatever they are, are born to the purple. They are the natural rulers of the Solar System.î
ìPure hysteria,î muttered Orloff. ìThe Empire government has been hearing nothing else from your Dominion for a year.î
ìAnd youíve shrugged it oil. Well, listen! Jupiter, discounting the thickness of its colossal atmosphere, is eighty thousand miles in diameter. That means it possesses a surface one hundred times that of Earth, and more than fifty times that of the entire Terrestrial Empire. Its population, its resources. its war potential are in proportion.î
ìMere numbers-ì
ìI know what you mean,î Birnam drove on, passionately. ìWars are not fought with numbers, but with science and with organization. The Jovians have both. In the quarter of a century during which we have communicated with them, weíve learned a bit. They have atomic power and they have radio. And in a world of ammonia under great pressure-a world in other words in which almost none of the metals can exist as metals for any length of time because of the tendency to form soluble ammonia complexes-they have managed to build up a complicated civilization. That means they have had to work through plastics, glasses, silicates and synthetic building materials of one sort or another. That means a chemistry developed just as far as ours is, and r d put odds on its having developed further.î
Orloff waited long before answering. And then, ìBut how certain are you people about the Joviansí last message. We on Earth are inclined to doubt that the Jovians can possibly be as unreasonably belligerent as they have been described.î
The Ganymedan laughed shortly. ìThey broke oil all communication after that last message, didnít they? That doesnít sound friendly on their part, does it? I assure you that weíve all but stood on our ears trying to contact them.
ìHere now. donít talk. Let me explain something to you. For twenty-five years here on Ganymede a little group of men have worked their hearts out trying to make sense out of a static-ridden, gravity-distorted set of variable clicks in our radio apparatus. for those clicks were our only connection with living intelligence upon Jupiter. It was a job for a world of scientists, but we never had more than two dozen at the Station at anyone time. I was one of them from the very beginning and, as a philologist, did my part in helping construct and interpret the code that developed between ourselves and the Jovians, so that you can see I am speaking from the real inside.
ìIt was a devil of a heartbreaking job. It was five years before we got past the elementary clicks of arithmetic: three and four are seven; the square root of twenty-five is five; factorial six is seven hundred and twenty. After that, months sometimes passed before we could work out and check by further communication a single new fragment of thought.
ìBut- andthis is the point-by the time the Jovians broke off relations, we understood them thoroughly. There was no more chance of a mistake in comprehension, than there was of Ganymede suddenly cutting loose from Jupiter. And their last message was a threat, and a promise of destruction. Oh, thereís no doubt-thereís no doubt!î
They were walking through a shallow pass in which the yellow Jupiter light gave way to a clammy darkness.
Orloff was disturbed. He had never had the case presented to him in this fashion before. He said, ìBut the reason, man. What reason did we give them-î
ìNo reason! It was simply this: the Jovians had finally discovered from our messages-just where and how I donít know-that we were not Jovians.î
ìWell, of course.î
ìIt wasnít ëof courseí to them. In their experiences they had never come across intelligences that were not Jovian. Why should they make an exception in favor of those from outer space?î
ìYou say they were scientists.î Orloffís voice had assumed a wary frigidity. ëWouldnít they realize that alien environments would breed alien life? We knew it. We never thought the Jovians were Earthmen though we had never met intelligences other than those of Earth.î
They were back in the drenching wash of Jupiter light again, and a spreading region of ice glimmered amberly in a depression to the right.
Birnam answered, ìI said they were chemists and physicists-but I never said they were astronomers. Jupiter, my dear commissioner, has an atmosphere three thousand miles or more thick, and those miles of gas block off everything but the Sun and the four largest of Jupiterís moons. The Jovians know nothing of alien environments.î
Orloff considered. ìAnd so they decided we were aliens. What next?î
ìIf we werenít Jovians, then, in their eyes, we werenít people. It turned out that a non-Jovian was ëverminí by definition.î
Orloffís automatic protest was cut off short by Birnam, ëIn their eyes, I said, vermin we were; and vermin we are. Moreover, we were vermin with the peculiar audacity of having dared to attempt to treat with Jovians-with human beings. Their last message was this, word for word-íJovians are the masters. There is no room for vermin. We will destroy you immediately.í I doubt if there was any animosity in that message-simply a cold statement of fact. But they meant it. ì
ìBut why?î
ìWhy did man exterminate the housefly?î
ìCome, sir. Youíre not seriously presenting an analogy of that nature.î
ìWhy not, since it is certain that the Jovian considers us a sort of housefly-an insufferable type of housefly that dares aspire to intelligence.î
Orloff made a last attempt. ìBut truly, Mr. Secretary, it seems impossible for intelligent life to adopt such an attitude.î
ìDo you possess much of an acquaintance with any other type of intelligent life than our own?î came with immediate sarcasm. ìDo you feel competent to pass on Jovian psychology? Do you know just how alien Jovians must be physically? Just think of their world with its gravity at two and one half Earth normal; with its ammonia oceans-oceans that you might throw all Earth into without raising a respectable splash; with its three-thousand-mile atmosphere, dragged down by the colossal gravity into densities and pressures in its surface layers that make the sea bottoms of Earth resemble a medium-thick vacuum. I tell you weíve tried to figure out what sort of life could exist under those conditions and weíve given up. Itís thoroughly incomprehensible. Do you expect their mentality, then, to be any more understandable? Never! Accept it as it is. They intend destroying us. Thatís all we know and all we need to know.î
He lifted a gloved hand as he finished and one finger pointed. ìThereís Ether Station just ahead.î
Orloffís head swiveled, ìUnderground?î
ìCertainly! All except the Observatory. Thatís that steel and quartz dome to the right-the small one.î
They had stopped before two large boulders that flanked an earthy embankment, and from behind either one a nosepieced, suited soldier in Ganymedan orange, with blasters ready, advanced upon the two.
Birnam lifted his face into Jupiterís light and the soldiers saluted and stepped aside. A short word was barked into the wrist mike of one of them and the camouflaged opening between the boulders fell into two and Orloff followed the secretary into the yawning air lock. The Earthman caught one last glimpse of sprawling Jupiter before the closing door cut off the surface altogether.
It was no longer beautiful!
Orloff did not quite feel normal again until he had seated himself in the overstuffed chair in Dr. Edward Prosserís private office. With a sigh of utter relaxation, he propped his monocle under his eyebrow.
ìWould Dr. Prosser mind if I smoked in here, while weíre waiting?î he asked.
ìGo ahead, ì replied Birnam, carelessly. ìMy own idea would be to drag Prosser away from whatever heís fooling with just now, but heís a queer chap. Weíll get more out of him if we wait until heís ready for us.î He withdrew a gnarled stick of greenish tobacco from its case, and bit off the edge viciously.
Orloff smiled through the smoke of his own cigarette, ìI donít mind waiting. I still have something to say. You see, for the moment, Mr. Secretary, you gave me the jitters, but, after all, granted that the Jovians intend mischief once they get at us, it remains a fact, ì and here he spaced his words emphatically, ìthat they canít get at us.î
ìA bomb without a fuse, hey?î
ìExactly! Itís simplicity itself, and not really worth discussing. You will admit, I suppose, that under no circumstances call the Jovians get away from Jupiter.î
ìUnder no circumstances?î There was a quizzical tinge in Birnamís slow reply. ìShall we analyze that?î
He stared hard at the purple flame of his cigar. ìItís an old trite saying that the Jovians canít leave Jupiter. The fact has been highly publicized by the sensation mongers of Earth and Ganymede and a great deal of sentiment has been driveled about the unfortunate intelligences who are irrevocably surface-bound, and must forever stare into the Universe without, watching, watching, wondering, and never attaining.
ìBut, after all, what holds the Jovians to their planet? Two factors! Thatís all! The first is the immense gravity field of the planet. Two and a half Earth normal.î
Orloff nodded. ìPretty bad!î he agreed.
ìAnd Jupiterís gravitational potential is even worse, for because of its greater diameter the intensity of its gravitational field decreases with distance only one tenth as rapidly as Earthís field does. Itís a terrible problem-but ití sbeen solved.î
ìHey?î Orloff straightened.
ìTheyíve got atomic power. Gravity-even Jupiterís-means nothing once youíve put unstable atomic nuclei to work for you.î
Orloff crushed his cigarette to extinction with a nervous gesture. ìBut their atmosphere-î
ìYes, thatís whatís stopping them. Theyíre living at the bottom of a three-thousand-mile-deep ocean of it, where the hydrogen of which it is composed is collapsed by sheer pressure to something approaching the density of solid hydrogen. It stays a gas because the temperature of Jupiter is above the critical point of hydrogen, but you just try to figure out the pressure that can make hydrogen gas half as heavy as water. Youíll be surprised at the number of zeros youíll have to put down.
ìNo spaceship of metal or of any kind of matter can stand that pressure. No Terrestrial spaceship can land on Jupiter without smashing like an eggshell, and no Jovian spaceship can leave Jupiter without exploding like a soap bubble. That problem has not yet been solved, but it will be some day. Maybe tomorrow, maybe not for a hundred years, or a thousand. We donít know, but when it is solved, the Jovians will be on top of us. And it can be solved in a specific way.î
ìI donít see how-ì
ìForce fields! Weíve got them now, you know.î
ìForce fields!î Orloff seemed genuinely astonished, and he chewed the word over and over to himself for a few moments. ìTheyíre used as meteor shields for ships in the asteroid zone-but I donít see the application to the Jovian problem.î
ìThe ordinary force field,î explained Birnam, ìis a feeble rarefied zone of energy extending over a hundred miles or more outside the ship. Itíll stop meteors but itís just so much empty ether to an object like a gas molecule. But what if you took that same zone of energy and compressed it to a thickness of a tenth of an inch. Molecules would bounce offit like this- ping-g-g-g! And if you used stronger generators, and compressed the field to a hundredth of an inch, molecules would bounce offeven when driven by the unthinkable pressure of Jupiterís atmosphere-and then if you build a ship inside-î He left the sentence dangling.
Orloff was pale. ìYouíre not saying it can be done?î
ìIíll bet you anything you like that the Jovians are trying to do it. And weíre trying to do it right here at Ether Station.î
The colonial commissioner jerked his chair closer to Birnam and grabbed the Ganymedanís wrist. ìWhy canít we bombard Jupiter with atomic bombs. Give it a thorough going-over, I mean! With her gravity, and her surface area, we canít miss.î
Birnam smiled faintly, ìWeíve thought of that. But atomic bombs would merely tear holes in the atmosphere. And even if you could penetrate, just divide the surface of Jupiter by the area of damage of a single bomb and find how many years we must bombard Jupiter at the rate of a bomb a minute before we begin to do significant damage. Jupiterís big! Donít ever forget that!î
His cigar had gone out, but he did not pause to relight. He continued in a low, tense voice. ìNo, we canít attack the Jovians as long as theyíre on Jupiter. We must wait for them to come out-and once they do, theyíre going to have the edge on us in numbers. A terrific, heart-breaking edge-so weíll just have to have the edge on them in scienceÖ
ìBut,î Orloff broke in, and there was a note of fascinated horror in his voice, ìhow can we tell in advance what theyíll have?î
ìWe canít. Weíve got to scrape up everything we can lay our hands on and hope for the best. But thereís one thing we do know theyíll have, and thatís force fields. They canít get out without them. And if they have them, we must, too, and thatís the problem weíre trying to solve here. They will not insure us victory, but without them, we will suffer certain defeat. And now you know why we need money-and more than that. We want Earth itself to get to work. Itís got to start a drive for scientific armaments and subordinate everything to that. You seer
Orloff was on his feet. ìBirnam, Iím with you-a hundred percent with you. You can count on me back in Washington.î
There was no mistaking his sincerity. Birnam gripped the hand outstretched toward him and wrung it-and at the moment, the door flew open and a little pixie of a man hurtled in.
The newcomer spoke in rapid jerks, and exclusively to Birnam. ìWhereíd you come from? Been trying to get in touch with you. Secretary said you werenít in. Then five minutes later you show up on your own. Canít understand it.î He busied himself furiously at his desk.
Birnam grinned. ìIf youíll take time out, doc, you might say hello to Colonial Commissioner OrloffÖ
Dr. Edward Prosser turned on his toe like a ballet dancer and looked the Earthman up and down twice. ìThe new un, hey? We getting any money? We ought to. Been working on a shoestring ever since. At that, we might not be needing any. It depends.î He was back at the desk.
Orloff seemed a trifle disconcerted, but Birnam winked impressively, and he contented himself with a glassy stare through the monocle.
Prosser pounced upon a black leather booklet in the recesses of a pigeonhole, threw himself into his swivel chair and wheeled about.
ìGlad you came, Birnam,î he said, leafing through the booklet. ìGot something to show you. Commissioner Orloff, too.î
ìWhat were you keeping us waiting for?î demanded Birnam. ìWhere were you?î
ìBusy! Busy as a pig! No sleep for three nights.î He looked up, and his small puckered face fairly Hushed with delight. ìEverything fell into place of a sudden. Like a jig-saw puzzle. Never saw anything like it. Kept us hopping, I tell you.î
ìYouíve gotten the dense force fields youíre after?î asked Orloff in sudden excitement.
Prosser seemed annoyed. ìNo, not that. Something else. Come on.î He glared at his watch and jumped out of his seat. ìWeíve got half an hour. Letís go.î
An electric-motored flivver waited outside and Prosser spoke excitedly as he sped the purring vehicle down the ramps into the depths of the Station.
ìTheory!î he said. ìTheory! Damned important, that. You set a technician on a problem. Heíll fool around. Waste lifetimes. Get nowhere. Just putter about at random. A true scientist works with theory. Lets math solve his problems.î He overflowed with self-satisfaction.
The flivver stopped on a dime before a huge double door and Prosser tumbled out, followed by the other two at a more leisurely pace.
ìThrough here! Through here!î he said. He shoved the door open and led them down the corridor and up a narrow flight of stairs onto a wall-hugging passageway that circled a huge three-level room. Orloff recognized the gleaming quartz-and-steel pipe-sprouting ellipsoid two levels below as an atomic generator.
He adjusted his monocle and watched the scurrying activity below. An earphoned man on a high stool before a control board studded with dials looked up and waved. Prosser waved back and grinned.
Orloff said, ìYou create your force fields here?î
ìThatís right! Ever see one?î
ìNo.î The commissioner smiled, ruefully. ìI donít even know what one is, except that it can be used as a meteor shield.î
Prosser said, ìItís very simple. Elementary matter. All matter is composed of atoms. Atoms are held together by interatomic forces. Take away atoms. Leave interatomic forces behind. Thatís a force field.î
Orloff looked blank, and Birnam chuckled deep in his throat and scratched the back of his ear.
ìThat explanation reminds me of our Ganymedan method of suspending an egg a mile high in the air. It goes like this. You find a mountain just a mile high and put the egg on top. Then, keeping the egg where it is, you take the mountain away. Thatís all.î
The colonial commissioner threw his head back to laugh, and the irascible Dr. Prosser puckered his lips in a pursed symbol of disapproval.
ìCome, come. No joke, you know. Force fields most important. Got to be ready for the Jovians when they come:í
A sudden rasping bur from below sent Prosser back from the railing.
ìGet behind screen here,î he babbled. ìThe twenty-millimeter field is going up. Bad radiation.î
The bur muted almost into silence, and the three walked out onto the passageway again. There was no apparent change, but Prosser shoved his hand out over the railing and said, ìFeel!î
Orloff extended a cautious finger, gasped, and slapped out with the palm of his hand. It was like pushing against very soft sponge rubber or superresilient steel springs.
Birnam tried, too. ìThatís better than anything weíve done yet, isnít it?î He explained to Orloff, ì A twenty-millimeter screen is one that can hold an atmosphere of a pressure of twenty millimeters of mercury against a vacuum without appreciable leakage.î
The commissioner nodded, ìI see! Youí d need a seven-hundred-sixty-millimeter screen to hold Earthís atmosphere then.î
ìYes! That would be a unit atmosphere screen. Well, Prosser, is this what got you excited?î
ìThis twenty-millimeter screen? Of course not. I can go up to two hundred fifty millimeters using the activated vanadium pentasulphide in the praseodymium breakdown. But itís not necessary. Technician would do it and blow up the place. Scientist checks on theory and goes slow.î He winked. ëWeíre hardening the field now. Watch!î
ìShall we get behind the screen?î
ìNot necessary now. Radiation bad only at beginningÖ
The burring waxed again, but not as loudly as before. Prosser shouted to the man at the control board, and a spreading wave of the hand was the only reply.
Then the control man waved a clenched fist and Prosser cried, ìWeíve passed fifty millimeters! Feel the field!î
Orloff extended his hand and poked it curiously. The sponge rubber had hardened! He tried to pinch it between finger and thumb so perfect was the illusion, but here the ìrubberÖ faded to unresisting air.
Prosser tch-tched impatiently. ìNo resistance at right angles to force. Elementary mechanics, that isÖ
The control man was gesturing again. ìPast seventy,î explained Prosser. ìWeíre slowing down now. Critical point is 83.42.î
He hung over the railing and kicked out with his feet at the other two. ìStay away! Dangerous!î
And then he yelled, ìCareful! The generatorís bucking!î
The bur had risen to a hoarse rnaximum and the control man worked frantically at his switches. From within the quartz heart of the central atomic generator, the sullen red glow of the bursting atoms had brightened dangerously.
There was a break in the bur, a reverberant roar, and a blast of air that threw Orloff hard against the wall.
Prosser dashed up. There was a cut over his eye. ìHurt? No? Good, good! I was expecting something of the sort. Should have warned you. Letís go down. Whereís Birnam?î
The tall Ganymedan picked herself up off the floor and brushed at his clothes. ìHere I am. What blew up?î
ìNothing blew up. Something buckled. Come on, down we go.î He debbed at his forehead with a handkerchief and led the way downward.
The control man removed his earphones as he approached and got off his stool. He looked tired, and his dirt-smeared face was greasy with perspiration.
ìThe damn thing started going at 82.8, boss. It almost caught me.î
ìIt did, did it?î growled Prosser. ìWithin limits of error, isnít it? Howís the generator? Hey, Stoddard!î
The technician addressed replied from his station at the generator, ìTube 5 died. Itíll take two days to replace.î
Prosser turned in satisfaction and said, ìIt worked. Went exactly as presumed. Problem solved, gentlemen. Trouble over. Letís get back to my office. I want to eat. And then I want to sleep.î
He did not refer to the subject again until once more behind the desk in his office, and then he spoke between huge bites of a liver-and-onion sandwich.
He addressed Birnam, ìRemember the work on space strain last June. It Hopped, but we kept at it. Finch got a lead last week and I developed it. Everything fell into place. Slick as goose grease. Never saw anything like it.î
ìGo ahead,î said Birnam, calmly. He knew Prosser sufficiently well to avoid showing impatience.
ìYou saw what happened. When a field tops 83.42 millimeters, it becomes unstable. Space wonít stand the strain. It buckles and the field blows. Boom/î
Birnamís mouth dropped open and the arms of Orloffís chair creaked under sudden pressure. Silence for a while, and then Birnam said unsteadily, ìYou mean force fields stronger than that are impossible?î
ìTheyíre possible. You can create them. But the denser they are, the more unstable they are. If I had turned on the two-hundred-and-fifty-millimeter field, it would have lasted one tenth of a second. Then, blooie! Would have blown up the Station! And myself! Technician would have done it. Scientist is warned by theory. Works carefully, the way I did. No harm done.î
Orloff tucked his monocle into his vest pocket and said tremulously, ìBut if a force field is the same thing as interatomic forces, why is it that steel has such a strong interatomic binding force without bucking space? Thereís a Haw there.î
Prosser eyed him in annoyance. ìNo Haw. Critical strength depends on number of generators. In steel, each atom is a force-field generator. That means about three hundred billion trillion generators for every ounce of matter. If we could use that many-As it is, one hundred generators would be the practical limit. That only raises the critical point to ninety-seven or thereabout.î
He got to his feet and continued with sudden fervor, ìNo. Problemís over, I tell you. Absolutely impossible to create a force field capable of holding Earthís atmosphere for more than a hundredth of a second. Jovian atmosphere entirely out of question. Cold figures say that; backed by experiment. Space wonít stand it!
ìLet the Jovians do their damnedest. They canít get out! Thatís final! Thatís final! Thatís final!î
Orloff said, ìMr. Secretary, can I send a spacegram anywhere in the Station? I want to tell Earth that Iím returning by the next ship and that the Jovian problem is liquidated-entirely and for good.î
Birnam said nothing, but the relief of his face as he shook hands with the colonial commissioner, transfigured the gaunt homeliness of it unbelievably.
And Dr. Prosser repeated, with a birdlike jerk of his head, ìThatís final!î
Hal Tuttle looked up as Captain Everett of the spaceship Transparent, newest ship of the Comet Space Lines, entered his private observation room in the nose of the ship.
The captain said, ì A spacegram has just reached me from the home offices at Tucson. Weíre to pick up Colonial Commissioner Orloff at Jovopolis, Ganymede, and take him back to Earth.î
ìGood. We havenít sighted any ships?î
ìNo, no! Weíre way off the regular space lanes. The first the System will know of us will be the landing of the Transparent on Ganymede. It will be the greatest thing in space travel since the first trip to the Moon.î His voice softened suddenly, ìWhatís wrong, Hal? This is your triumph, after all:í
Hal Tuttle looked up and out into the blackness of space. ìI suppose it is. Ten years of work, Sam. I lost an arm and an eye in that first explosion, but I donít regret them. Itís the reaction thatís got me. The problem is solved; my lifework is finished. ì
ìSo is every steel-hulled ship in the System.î
Tuttle smiled. ìYes. Itís hard to realize, isnít it?î He gestured outward. ìYou see the stars? Part of the time, thereís nothing between them and us. It gives me a queazy feeling.î His voice brooded, ìNine years I worked for nothing. I wasnít a theoretician, and never really knew where I was headed-just tried everything. I tried a little too hard and space wouldnít stand it. I paid an arm and an eye and started fresh.î
Captain Everett balled his fist and pounded the hull-the hull through which the stars shone unobstructed. There was the muffled thud of flesh striking an unyielding surface-but no response whatever from the invisible wall.
Tuttle nodded, ìItís solid enough, now-though it flicks on and off eight hundred thousand times a second. I got the idea from the stroboscopic lamp. You know them-they flash on and off so rapidly that it gives all the impression of steady illumination.
ìAnd so it is with the hull. Itís not on long enough to buckle space. Itís not off long enough to allow appreciable leakage of the atmosphere. And the net effect is a strength better than steel.î
He paused and added slowly, ìAnd thereís no telling how far we can go. Speed up the intermission effect. Have the field flick off and on millions of times per second-billions of times. You can get fields strong enough to hold an atomic explosion. My lifework!î
Captain Everett pounded the otherís shoulder. ìSnap out of it, man. Think of the landing on Ganymede. The devil! It will be great publicity. Think of Orloffís face, for instance, when he finds he is to be the first passenger in history ever to travel in a spaceship with a force-field hull. How do you suppose heíll feel?î
Hal Tuttle shrugged. ìI imagine heíll be rather pleased.î



***



With ìNot Final!î I completed my third year as a writer-three years since my initial trip to Campbellís office. In that time I had earned just a hair short of a thousand dollars (not as bad as it sounds in days when college tuition was only four hundred dollars a year) and I had about a quarter of that in my savings account.
Still, you can see that there was nothing in that financial record to lead me to think that writing was a possible way of making a living-especially since I had no dream of ever writing anything but magazine science fiction.
On June 10, 1941, in the course of a talk with Fred Pohl, I mentioned my frustration at not being able to make a sale to Unknown. Fred said he had a good idea for a fantasy, and from that it was a short step to an agreement to go halfies. Weí d talk the idea over, I would write it, and weíd split the sale, if any, fifty-fifty.
Fred must have been willing because (as I found out three days later) his magazines were doing poorly and he was being relieved of his editorial position.
It was too bad, of course, but not an irredeemable catastrophe. Pohl had had nearly two years of valuable editorial experience, and the time would come when this would stand him in good stead in a much more important and longer-enduring role as editor of Galaxy, which during the 1950s and 1960s was to compete with Astounding for leadership in the field.
As for myself, I could scarcely complain. Pohl had accepted eight of my stories (over a quarter of those I had written and nearly half of those I had sold up to then).of these, six had already been published and one (ìSuper-Neutronî) was safely slated for publication in the forthcoming issue of Astonishing. That left the ninth, ìChristmas on Ganymede.î It was not yet paid for, nor had it actually been set in type, and, regretfully, Pohl had to return it. However, I sold it within two weeks to Thrilling Wonder Stories for a little more than Pohl would have been able to pay me, so no harm was done even there.-and though I regretted the loss of a market, Pohl had safely seen me through the period during which I developed to the point where Campbell and Astounding itself could become my major market.
At first, when ìChristmas on Ganymedeî was returned, I thought it was because the Pohl magazines had been suspended altogether. If the publishers had intended that, they changed their minds. Astonishing continued a couple of years, until it was killed by the World War II paper shortage. Super Science Stories survived World War II and even a little past the 1940s, and was yet to publish one more story of mine.
But back to June 10-Taking Fredís fantasy idea, I wrote the story entirely on my own, calling it ìLegal Rights.î Once again, though, a collaboration didnít succeed. On July 8, Campbell rejected it, the first rejection I had received from him in half a year.
By that time, though, Fred was agenting again. I gave him the story, rather shamefacedly, and forgot about it. He changed the name to ìLegal Ritesî (much better) and rewrote it quite a bit. Seven years later, he actually sold it.








Legal Rites








(with James MacCreigh)







I


Already the stars were out, though the sun had just dipped under the horizon, and the sky of the west was a blood-stuck gold behind the Sierra Nevadas.
ìHey!î squawked Russell Harley. ìCome back!î
But the one-lunged motor of the old Ford was making too much noise; the driver didnít hear him. Harley cursed as he watched the old car careen along the sandy ruts on its half-flat tires. Its taillight was saying a red no to him. No, you canít get away tonight; no, youíll have to stay here and fight it out.
Harley grunted and climbed back up the porch stairs of the old wooden house. It was well made, anyhow. The stairs, though half a century old, neither creaked beneath him nor showed cracks.
Harley picked up the bags heíd dropped when he experienced his abrupt change of mind-fake leather and worn out, they were-and carted them into the house. He dumped them on a dust-jacketed sofa and looked around.
It was stifling hot, and the smell of the desert outside had permeated the room. Harley sneezed.
ìWater,î he said out loud. ìThatís what I need.î
Heíd prowled through every room on the ground floor before he stopped still and smote his head. Plumbing-naturally thereíd be no plumbing in this hole eight miles out on the desert! A well was the best he could hope for
If that.
It was getting dark. No electric lights either, of course. He blundered irritatedly through the dusky rooms to the back of the house. The screen door shrieked metallically as he opened it. A bucket hung by the door. He picked it up, tipped it, shook the loose sand out of it. He looked over the ìback yardî-about thirty thousand visible acres of hilly sand, rock and patches of sage and flame-tipped ocotillo.
No well.
The old fool got water from somewhere, he thought savagely. Obstinately he climbed down the back steps and wandered out into the desert. Overhead the stars were blinding, a million billion of them, but the sunset was over already and he could see only hazily. The silence was murderous. Only a faint whisper of breeze over the sand, and the slither of his shoes.
He caught a glimmer of starlight from the nearest clump of sage and walked to it. There was a pool of water, caught in the angle of two enormous boulders. He stared at it doubtfully, then shrugged. It was water. It was better than nothing. He dipped the bucket in the little pool. Knowing nothing of the procedure, he filled it with a quart of loose sand as he scooped it along the bottom. When he lifted it, brimful, to his lips, he spat out the first mouthful and swore violently.
Then he used his head. He set the bucket down, waited a second for the sand grains to settle, cupped water in his hands, lifted it to his lipsÖ
Pat. HISS. Pat. HISS. Pat. HISS-
îWhat the hell!î Harley stood up, looked around in abrupt puzzlement. It sounded like water dripping from somewhere, onto a redhot stove, Hashing into sizzling steam. He saw nothing, only the sand and the sage and the pool of tepid, sickly water.
Pat. HISS
Then he saw it, and his eyes bulged. Out of nowhere it was dripping, a drop a second, a sticky, dark drop that was thicker than water, that fell to the ground lazily, in slow defiance of gravity. And when it struck each drop sizzled and skittered about, and vanished. It was perhaps eight feet from him, just visible in the starlight.
And then, ìGet off my land!î said the voice from nowhere.
Harley got. By the time he got to Rebel Butte three hours later, he was barely managing to walk, wishing desperately that heíd delayed long enough for one more good drink of water, despite all the fiends of hell. But heíd run the first three miles. Heíd had plenty of encouragement. He remembered with a shudder how the clear desert air had taken milkly shape around the incredible trickle of dampness and had advanced on him threateningly.
And when he got to the first kerosene-lighted saloon of Rebel Butte, and staggered inside, the saloonkeeperís fascinated stare at the front of his shoddy coat showed him strong evidence that he hadnít been suddenly taken with insanity, or drunk on the unaccustomed sensation of fresh desert air. All down the front of him it was, and the harder he rubbed the harder it stayed, the stickier it got. Blood!
ìWhiskey!î he said in a strangled voice, tottering to the bar. He pulled a threadbare dollar bill from his pocket, flapped it onto the mahogany.
The blackjack game at the back of the room had stopped. Harley was acutely conscious of the eyes of the players, the bartender and the tall, lean man leaning on the bar. All were watching him.
The bartender broke the spell. He reached for a bottle behind him without looking at it, placed it on the counter before Harley. He poured a glass of water from a jug, set it down with a shot glass beside the bottle.
ìI could of told you that would happen, ì he said casually. ìOnly you wouldnít of believed me. You had to meet Hank for yourself before youíd believe he was there:í
Harley remembered his thirst and drained the glass of water, then poured himself a shot of the whiskey and swallowed it without waiting for the chaser to be refilled. The whiskey felt good going down, almost good enough to stop his internal shakes.
ìWhat are you talking about?î he said finally. He twisted his body and leaned forward across the bar to partly hide the stains on his coat. The saloonkeeper laughed.
ìOld Hank,î he said. ìI knowed who you was right away, even before Tom came back and told me where heíd took you. I knowed you was Zeb Harleyís no-good nephew, come to take Harley Hall aní sell it before he was cold in the grave.î
The blackjack players were still watching him, Russell Harley saw. Only the lean man farther along the bar seemed to have dismissed him. He was pouring himself another drink, quite occupied with his task.
Harley flushed. ìListen,î he said, ìI didnít come in here for advice. I wanted a drink. Iím paying for it. Keep your mouth out of this.î
The saloonkeeper shrugged. He turned his back and walked away to the blackjack table. After a couple of seconds one of the players turned, too, and threw a card down. The others followed suit.
Harley was just getting set to swallow his pride and talk to the saloonkeeper again-he seemed to know something about what Harleyíd been through, and might be helpful-when the lean man tapped his shoulder. Harley whirled and almost dropped his glass. Absorbed and jumpy, he hadnít seen him come up.
ìYoung man, ì said the lean one, ìMy nameís Nicholls. Come along with me, sir, and weíll talk this thing over. I think we may be of service to each other.î
Even the twelve-cylinder car Nicholls drove jounced like a haywagon over the sandy ruts leading to the place old Zeb had-laughingly-named ìHarley Hall.î
Russell Harley twisted his neck and stared at the heap of paraphernalia in the open rumble seat. ìI donít like it, ì he complained. ìI never had anything to do with ghosts. How do I know this stuffíll work?î
Nicholls smiled. ìYouíll have to take my word for it. Iíve had dealings with ghosts before. You could say that I might qualify as a ghost exterminator, if I chose.î
Harley growled. ìI still donít like it.î Nicholls turned a sharp look on him. ìYou like the prospect of owning Harley Hall, donít you? And looking for all the money your late uncle is supposed to have hidden around somewhere?î Harley shrugged. ìCertainly you do,î said Nicholls, returning his eyes to the road. ì And with good reason. The local reports put the figure pretty high, young man.î
ìThatís where you come in, I guess,î Harley said sullenly. ìI find the money-that I own anyhow-and give some of it to you. How much?î
ìWeíll discuss that later,î Nicholls said. He smiled absently as he looked ahead.
ìWeíll discuss it right now!î
The smile faded from Nichollsí face. ìNo,î he said. ìWe wonít. Iíve doing you a favor, young Harley. Remember that. In return-youíll do as I say, all the way!î
Harley digested that carefully, and it was not a pleasant meal. He waited a couple of seconds before he changed the subject.
ìI was out here once when the old man was alive,î he said. ìHe didnít say nothing about any ghost. ì
ìPerhaps he felt you might think him-well, peculiar,î Nicholls said. ìAnd perhaps you would have. When were you here?î
ìOh, a long time ago,î Harley said evasively. ìBut I was here a whole day, and part of the night. The old man was crazy as a coot, but he didnít keep any ghosts in the atticÖ
ìThis ghost was a friend of his.î Nicholls said. ìThe gentleman in charge of the bar told you that. surely. Your late uncle was something of a recluse. He lived in this house a dozen miles from nowhere. came into town hardly ever. Wouldnít let anyone get friendly with him. But he wasnít exactly a hermit. He had Hank for company.î
ìFine companyÖ
Nicholls inclined his head seriously. ìOh, I donít know.î he said. ìFrom all accounts, they got on well together. They played pinochle and chess-Hankís supposed to have been a great pinochle player. He was killed that way, according to the local reports. Caught somebody dealing from the bottom and shot it out with him. He lost. A bullet pierced his throat and he died quite bloodilyÖ He turned the wheel, putting his weight into the effort, and succeeded in twisting the car out of the ruts of the ìroad, ì sent it jouncing across unmarked sand to the old frame house to which they were going.
ìThat,î he finished as he pulled up before the porch. ìAccounts for the blood that accompanies his apparitionÖ
Harley opened the door slowly and got out, looking uneasily at the battered old house. Nicholls cut the motor, got out and walked at once to the back of the car.
ìCome on.î he said, dragging things out of the compartment. ìGive me a hand with this. Iíve not going to carry this stuff all by myselfÖ
Harley came around reluctantly, regarded the curious assortment of bundles of dried faggots, lengths of colored cord, chalk pencils, ugly little bunches of wilted weeds, bleached bones of small animals and a couple of less pleasant things without pleasure.
Pat. HISS. Pat. HISS-
îHeís here!î Harley yelped. ìListen! Heís someplace around here watching us.î
ìHa!î
The laugh was deep, unpleasant and-bodiless. Harley looked around desperately for the tell-tale trickle of blood. And he found it; from the air it issued, just beside the car, sinking gracefully to the ground and sizzling, vanishing, there.
ìIím watching you, all right,î the voice said grimly. ìRussell, you worthless piece of corruption, Iíve got no more use for you than you used to have for me. Dead or alive, this is my land! I shared it with your uncle, you young scalawag, but I wonít share it with you. Get out!î
Harleyís knees weakened and he tottered dizzily to the rear bumper, sat on it. ìNicholls-î he said confusedly.
ìOh, brace up,î Nicholls said with irritation. He tossed a ball of gaudy twine, red and green, with curious knots tied along it, to Harley. Then he confronted the trickle of blood and made a few brisk passes in the air before it. His lips were moving silently, Harley saw, but no words came out.
There was a gasp and a chopped-off squawk from the source of the blood drops. Nicholls clapped his hands sharply, then turned to young Harley.
ìTake that cord you have in your hands and stretch it around the house,î he said. ì All the way around, and make sure it goes right across the middle of the doors and windows. Itisnít much, but itíll hold him till we can get the good stuff set up.î
Harley nodded, then pointed a rigid finger at the drops of blood, now sizzling and fuming more angrily than before. ìWhat about that?î he managed to get out.
Nicholls grinned complacently. ìIíll hold him here till the cows come home,î he said. ìGet moving!î
Harley inadvertently inhaled a lungful of noxious white smoke and coughed till the tears rolled down his cheeks. When he recovered he looked at Nicholls, who was reading silently from a green leather book with dog-eared pages. He said, ìCan I stop stirring this now?î
Nicholls grimaced angrily and shook his head without looking at him. He went on reading, his lips contorting over syllables that were not in any language Harley had ever heard, then snapped the book shut and wiped his brow.
ìFine,î he said. ìSo far, so good.î He stepped over to windward of the boiling pot Harley was stirring on the hob over the fireplace, peered down into it cautiously.
ìThatís about done,î he said. ìTake it off the fire and let it cool a bit.î
Harley lifted it down, then squeezed his aching biceps with his left hand. The stuff was the consistency of sickly green fudge.
ìNow what?î he asked.
Nicholls didnít answer. He looked up in mild surprise at the sudden squawk of triumph from outside, followed by the howling of a chill wind.
ìHank must be loose,î he said casually. ìHe canít do us any harm, I think, but weíd better get a move on.î He rummaged in the dwindled pile of junk heíd brought from the car, extracted a paintbrush. ìSmear this stuff around all the windows and doors.
