All but the front door. For that I have something else.î He pointed to what seemed to be the front axle of an old Model-T. îLeave that on the doorsill. Cold iron. You can just step over it, but Hank wonít be able to pass it. Itís been properly treated already with the very best thaumaturgy.î
ìStep over it, ì Harley repeated. ìWhat would I want to step over it for? Heís out there.î
ìHe wonít hurt you,î said Nicholls. ìYou will carry an amulet with you-that one, there-that will keep him away. Probably he couldnít really hurt you anyhow, being a low-order ghost who canít materialize to any great density. But just to take no chances, carry the amulet and donít stay out too long. It wonít hold him off forever, not for more than half an hour. If you ever have to go out and stay for any length of time, tie that bundle of herbs around your neck.î Nicholls smiled. ìThatís only for emergencies, though. It works on the asafoetida principle. Ghosts canít come anywhere near it-but you wonít like it much yourself. It has-ah-a rather definite odor.î
He leaned gingerly over the pot again, sniffing. He sneezed.
ìWell, thatís cool enough,î he said. ìBefore it hardens, get moving. Start spreading the stuff upstairs-and make sure you donít miss any windows.î
ìWhat are you going to do?î
ìI,î said Nicholls sharply, ìwill be here. Start.î
But he wasnít. When Harley finished his disagreeable task and came down, he called Nichollsí name, but the man was gone. Hurley stepped to the door and looked out; the car was gone, too.
He shrugged. ìOh, well, ì he said, and began taking the dust-cloths off the furniture.








II


Somewhere within the cold, legal mind of Lawyer Turnbull, he weighed the comparative likeness of nightmare and insanity.
He stared at the plush chair facing him, noted with distinct uneasiness how the strangely weightless, strangely sourceless trickle of redness disappeared as it hit the floor, but left long, mud-ochre streaks matted on the upholstery. The sound was unpleasant, too; Pat. HISS. Pat. HISS-
The voice continued impatiently, ìDamn your human stupidity! I may be a ghost, but heaven knows Iím not trying to haunt you. Friend, youíre not that important to me. Get this-Iím here on business.î
Turnbull learned that you cannot wet dry lips with a dehydrated tongue. ìLegal business?î
ìSure. The fact that I was once killed by violence, and have to continue my existence on the astral plane, doesnít mean Iíve lost my legal rights. Does it?î
The lawyer shook his head in bafflement. He said, ìThis would be easier on me if you werenít invisible. Canít you do something about it?î
There was a short pause. ëWell, I could materialize for a minute,î the voice said. ìItís hard work-damn hard, for me. There are a lot of us astral entities that can do it easy as failing out of bed, but-Well, if I have to I shall try to do it once.î
There was a shimmering in the air above the armchair, and a milky, thin smoke condensed into an intangible seated figure. Turnbull took no delight in noting that, through the figure, the outlines of the chair were still hazily visible. The figure thickened. Just as the features took form-just as Turnbullís bulging eyes made out a prominent hooked nose and a crisp beard-it thinned and exploded with a soft pop.
The voice said weakly, ìI didnít think I was that bad. Iím way out of practice. I guess thatís the first daylight materialization Iíve made in seventy-five years.î
The lawyer adjusted his rimless glasses and coughed. Hellís binges, he thought, the worst thing about this is that Iím believing it!î
ìOh, well, ì he said aloud. Then he hurried on before the visitor could take offense: ìJust what did you want? Iím just a small-town lawyer, you know. My business is fairly routine-î
ìI know all about your business,î the voice said. ìYou can handle my case-itís a land affair. I want to sue Russell Harley.î
ìHarley?î Turnbull fingered his cheek. ì Any relation to Zeb Harley?î
ìHis nephew-and his heir, too.î
Turnbull nodded. ìYes, I remember now. My wifeís folks live in Rebel Butte, and Iíve been there. Quite a coincidence you should come to me-ì
The voice laughed. ìIt was no coincidence,î it said softly.
ìOh.î Turnbull was silent for a second. Then, ìI see,î he said. He cast a shrewd glance at the chair. ìLawsuits cost money, Mr.-I donít think you mentioned your name?î
ìHank Jenkins,î the voice prompted. ìI know that. Would-letís see. Would six hundred and fifty dollars be sufficient?î
Turnbull swallowed. ìI think so,î he said in a relatively unemotional tone-relative to what he was thinking.
ìThen suppose we call that your retainer. I happen to have cached a considerable sum in gold when I was-that is to say, before I became an astral entity. Iím quite certain it hasnít been disturbed. You will have to call it treasure trove, I guess, and give half of it to the state, but thereís thirteen hundred dollars altogether.î
Turnbull nodded judiciously. ìAssuming we can locate your trove,î he said, ìI think that would be quite satisfactory.î He leaned back in his chair and looked legal. His aplomb had returned.
And half an hour later he said slowly, ìIíll take your case.î
Judge Lawrence Gimbel had always liked his job before. But his thirteen honorable years on the bench lost their flavor for him as he grimaced wearily and reached for his gavel. This case was far too confusing for his taste.
The clerk made his speech, and the packed courtroom sat down en masse. Gimbel held a hand briefly to his eyes before he spoke.
ìIs the counsel for the plaintiff ready?î
ìI am, your honor.î Turnbull, alone at his table, rose and bowed.
ìThe counsel for the defendant?î
ìReady, your honor!î Fred Wilson snapped. He looked with a hard flicker of interest at Turnbull and his solitary table, then leaned over and whispered in Russell Harleyís ear. The youth nodded glumly, then shrugged.
Gimbel said, ìI understand the attorneys for both sides have waived jury trial in this case of Henry Jenkins versus Russell Joseph Harley.î
Both lawyers nodded. Gimbel continued, ìIn view of the unusual nature of this case, I imagine it will prove necessary to conduct it with a certain amount of informality. The sole purpose of this court is to arrive at the true facts at issue, and to deliver a verdict in accord with the laws pertaining to these facts. I will not stand on ceremony. Nevertheless, I will not tolerate any disturbances or unnecessary irregularities. The spectators will kindly remember that they are here on privilege. Any demonstration will result in the clearing of the court.î
He looked severely at the white faces that gleamed unintelligently up at him. He suppressed a sigh as he said, ìThe counsel for the plaintiff will begin.î
Turnbull rose quickly to his feet, faced the judge.
ìYour honor,î he said, ìwe propose to show that my client, Henry Jenkins, has been deprived of his just rights by the defendant. Mr. Jenkins, by virtue of a sustained residence of more than twenty years in the house located on Route 22, eight miles north of the town of Rebel Butte, with the full knowledge of its legal owner, has acquired certain rights. In legal terminology we define these as the rights of adverse possession. The layman would call them common-law rights-squattersí rights.î
Gimbel folded his hands and tried to relax. Squattersí rights-for a ghost! He sighed, but listened attentively as Turnbull went on.
ìUpon the death of Zebulon Harley, the owner of the house involved-it is better known, perhaps, as Harley Hall-the defendant inherited title to the property. We do not question his right to it. But my client has an equity in Harley Hall; the right to free and full existence. The defendant has forcefully evicted my client, by means which have caused my client great mental distress, and have even endangered his very existence.î
Gimbel nodded. If the case only had a precedent somewhereÖ But it hadnít; he remembered grimly the hours heíd spent thumbing through all sorts of unlikely law books, looking for anything that might bear on the case. It had been his better judgment that he throw the case out of court outright-a judge couldnít afford to have himself laughed at, not if he were ambitious. And public laughter was about the only certainty there was to this case. But Wilson had put up such a fight that the judgeís temper had taken over. He never did like Wilson, anyhow.
ìYou may proceed with your witnesses,î he said.
Turnbull nodded. To the clerk he said, ìCall Henry Jenkins to the stand.î
Wilson was on his feet before the clerk opened his mouth.
ìObjection!î he bellowed. ìThe so-called Henry Jenkins cannot qualify as a witness!î
ìWhy not?î demanded Turnbull.
ìBecause heís dead!î
The judge clutched his gavel with one hand, forehead with the other. He banged on the desk to quiet the courtroom.
Turnbull stood there, smiling. ìNaturally,î he said, ìyouíll have proof of that statement.î
Wilson snarled. ìCertainly.î He referred to his brief. ìThe so-called Henry Jenkins is the ghost, spirit or specter of one Hank Jenkins, who prospected for gold in this territory a century ago. He was killed by a bullet through the throat from the gun of one Long Tom Cooper, and was declared legally dead on September 14, 1850. Cooper was hanged for his murder. No matter what hocus-pocus you produce for evidence to the contrary now, that status of legal death remains completely valid.î
ìWhat evidence have you of the identity of my client with this Hank Jenkins?î Turnbull asked grimly.
ìDo you deny it?î
Turnbull shrugged. ìI deny nothing. Iím not being cross-examined. Furthermore, the sole prerequisite of a witness is that he understand the value of an oath. Henry Jenkins was tested by John Quincy Fitzjames, professor of psychology at the University of Southern California. The results-I have Dr. Fitzjamesí sworn statement of them here, which I will introduce as an exhibit-show clearly that my clientís intelligence quotient is well above normal, and that a psychiatric examination discloses no important aberrations which would injure his validity as a witness. I insist that my client be allowed to testify on his own behalf.î
ìBut heís dead!î squawked Wilson. ìHeís invisible right now!î
ìMy client.î said Turnbull stiffly, ìis not present just now. Undoubtedly that accounts for what you term his invisibility.î He paused for the appreciative murmur that swept through the court. Things were breaking perfectly, he thought, smiling. ìI have here another affidavit,î he said. ìIt is signed by Elihu James and Terence MacRae, who respectively head the departments of physics and biology at the same university. It states that my client exhibits all the vital phenomena of life. I am prepared to call all three of my expert witnesses to the stand, if necessary.î
Wilson scowled but said nothing. Judge Gimbel leaned forward. ìI donít see how it is possible for me to refuse the plaintiff the right to testify,î he said. ìIf the three experts who prepared these reports will testify on the stand to the facts contained in them, Henry Jenkins may then take the stand.î
Wilson sat down heavily. The three experts spoke briefly-and dryly. Wilson put them through only the most formal of cross-examinations.
The judge declared a brief recess. In the corridor outside, Wilson and his client lit cigarettes and looked unsympathetically at each other.
ìI feel like a fool,î said Russell Harley. ìBringing suit against a ghost.î
ìThe ghost brought the suit,î Wilson reminded him. ìIf only weíd been able to hold fire for a couple more weeks, till another judge came on the bench, I couldíve got this thing thrown right out of court.î
ìWell, why couldnít we wait?î
ìBecause you were in such a damn hurry!î Wilson said. ìyou and that idiot Nicholls-so confident that it would never come to trial.î
Harley shrugged, and thought unhappily of their failure in completely exorcising the ghost of Hank Jenkins. That had been a mess. Jenkins had somehow escaped from the charmed circle theyíd drawn around him, in which theyíd hoped to keep him till the trial was forfeited by non-appearance.
ìThatís another thing,î said Wilson. ìWhere is Nicholls?î
Harley shrugged again. ìI dunno. The last I saw of him was in your office. He came around to see me right after the deputy slapped the show-cause order on me at the house. He brought me down to you-said youíd been recommended to him. Then you and him and I talked about the case for a while. He went out, after he lent me a little money to help meet your retainer. Havenít seen him since.î
ìIíd like to know who recommended me to him,î Wilson said grimly. ìI donít think heíd ever recommend anybody else. I donít like this case-and I donít much like you.î
Harley growled but said nothing. He flung his cigarette away. It tasted of the garbage that hung around his neck-everything did. Nicholls had told no lies when he said Harley wouldnít much like the bundle of herbs that would ward off the ghost of old Jenkins. They smelled.
The court clerk was in the corridor, bawling something, and people were beginning to trickle back in. Harley and his attorney went with them.
When the trial had been resumed, the clerk said, ìHenry Jenkins!î
Wilson was on his feet at once. He opened the door of the judgeís chamber, said something in a low tone. Then he stepped back, as if to let someone through.
Pat. HISS. Pat. HISS-
There was a concerted gasp from the spectators as the weirdly appearing trickle of blood moved slowly across the open space to the witness chair. This was the ghost-the plaintiff in the most eminently absurd case in the history of jurisprudence.
ìAll right, Hank,î Turnbull whispered. ìYouíll have to materialize long enough to let the clerk swear you in.î
The clerk drew back nervously at the pillar of milky fog that appeared before him, vaguely humanoid in shape. A phantom hand, half transparent, reached out to touch the Bible. The clerkís voice shook as he administered the oath, and heard the response come from the heart of the cloudpillar.
The haze drifted into the witness chair, bent curiously at about hip-height, and popped into nothingness.
The judge banged his gavel wildly. The buzz of alarm that had arisen from the spectators died out.
ìIíll warn you again,î he declared, ìthat unruliness will not be tolerated. The counsel for the plaintiff may proceed.î
Turnbull walked to the witness chair and addressed its emptiness. ì
ìYour name?î
ìMy name is Henry Jenkins.î
ìYour occupation?î
There was a slight pause. ìI have none. I guess youíd say Iím retired.î
ìMr. Jenkins, just what connection have you with the building referred to as Harley Hall?î
ìI have occupied it for ninety years.î
ìDuring this time, did you come to know the late Zebulon Harley, owner of the Hall?î
ìI knew Zeb quite well.î
Turnbull nodded. ìWhen did you make his acquaintance?î he asked.
ìIn the spring of 1907. Zeb had just lost his wife. After that, you see, he made Harley Hall his year-round home. He became-well, more or less of a hermit. Before that we had never met, since he was only seldom at the Hall. But we became friendly then.î
ìHow long did this friendship last?î
ìUntil he died last fall. I was with him when he died. I still have a few keepsakes he left me then.î There was a distinct nostalgic sigh from the witness chair, which by now was liberally spattered with muddy red liquid. The falling drops seemed to hesitate for a second, and their sizzling noise was muted as with a strong emotion.
Turnbull went on, ìYour relations with him were good, then?î
ìIíd call them excellent,î the emptiness replied firmly. ìEvery night we sat up together. When we didnít play pinochle or chess or cribbage, we just sat and talked over the news of the day. I still have the book we used to keep records of the chess and pinochle games. Zeb made the entries himself, in his own handwriting.î
Turnbull abandoned the witness for a moment. He faced the judge with a smile. ìI offer in evidence,î he said, ìthe book mentioned. Also a ring given to the plaintiff by the late Mr. Harley, and a copy of the plays of Gilbert and Sullivan. On the flyleaf of this book is inscribed, ëTo Old Hankí, in Harleyís own hand.î
He turned again to the empty, blood-leaking witness chair.
He said, ìIn all your years of association, did Zebulon Harley ever ask you to leave, or to pay rent?î
ìOf course not. Not Zeb!î
Turnbull nodded. ìVery good,î he said. ìNow, just one or two more questions. Will you tell in your own words what occurred, after the death of Zebulon Harley, that caused you to bring this suit?î
ìWell, in January young Harley-î
ìYou mean Russell Joseph Harley, the defendant?î
ìYes. He arrived at Harley Hall on January fifth. I asked him to leave, which he did. On the next day he returned with another man. They placed a talisman upon the threshold of the main entrance, and soon after sealed every threshold and windowsill in the Hall with a substance which is noxious to me. These activities were accompanied by several of the most deadly spells in the Ars Magicorum. He further added an Exclusion Circle with a radius of a little over a mile, entirely surrounding the Hall.î
ìI see,î the lawyer said. ìWill you explain to the court the effects of these activities?î
ìWell,î the voice said thoughtfully, ìitís a little hard to put in words. I canít pass the Circle without a great expenditure of energy. Even if I did I couldnít enter the building because of the talisman and the seals.î
ìCould you enter by air? Through a chimney, perhaps?î
ìNo. The Exclusion Circle is really a sphere. Iím pretty sure the effort would destroy me.î
ìIn effect, then, you are entirely barred from the house you have occupied for ninety years, due to the wilful acts of Russell Joseph Harley, the defendant, and an unnamed accomplice of his.î
ìThat is correct.î
Turnbull beamed. ìThank you. Thatís all.î
He turned to Wilson, whose face had been a study in dourness throughout the entire examination. ìYour witness,î he said.
Wilson snapped to his feet and strode to the witness chair.
He said belligerently, ìYou say your name is Henry Jenkins?î
ìYes.î
ìThat is your name now, you mean to say. What was your name before?î
ìBefore?î There was surprise in the voice that emanated from above the trickling blood-drops. ìBefore when?î
Wilson scowled. ìDonít pretend ignorance,î he said sharply. ìBefore you died, of course.î
ìObjection!î Turnbull was on his feet, glaring at Wilson. ìThe counsel for the defense has no right to speak of some hypothetical death of my client!î
Gimbel raised a hand wearily and cut off the words that were forming on Wilsonís lips. ìObjection sustained,î he said. ìNo evidence has been presented to identify the plaintiff as the prospector who was killed in 1850-or anyone else.î
Wilsonís mouth twisted into a sour grimace. He continued on a lower key.
ìYou say, Mr. Jenkins, that you occupied Harley Hall for ninety years.î
ìNinety-two years next month. The Hall wasnít built-in its present form, anyhow-until 1876, but I occupied the house that stood on the site previously.î
ìWhat did you do before then?î
ìBefore then?î The voice paused, then said doubtfully, ìI donít remember.î
ìYouíre under oath!î Wilson flared.
The voice got firmer. ìNinety years is a long time,î it said. ìI donít remember.î
ìLetís see if I canít refresh your memory. Is it true that ninety-one years ago, in the very year in which you claim to have begun your occupancy of Harley Hall, Hank Jenkins was killed in a gun duel?î
ìThat may be true, if you say so. I donít remember.î
ìDo you remember that the shooting occurred not fifty feet from the present site of Harley Hall?î
ìIt may be.î
ìWell, then,î Wilson thundered, ìis it not a fact that when Hank Jenkins died by violence his ghost assumed existence? That it was then doomed to haunt the site of its slaying throughout eternity?î
The voice said evenly, ìI have no knowledge of that.î
ìDo you deny that it is well known throughout that section that the ghost of Hank Jenkins haunts Harley Hall?î
ìObjection!î shouted Turnbull. ìPopular opinion is not evidence.î
ìObjection sustained. Strike the question from the record.î
Wilson, badgered, lost his control. In a dangerously uneven voice, he said, ìPerjury is a criminal offense. Mr. Jenkins, do you deny that you are the ghost of Hank Jenkins?î
The tone was surprised. ìWhy, certainly.î
ìYou are a ghost, arenít you?î
Stiffly, ìIím an entity on the astral plane.î
ìThat, I believe, is what is called a ghost?î
ìI canít help what itís called. Iíve heard you called a lot of things. Is that proof?î
There was a surge of laughter from the audience. Gimbel slammed his gavel down on the bench.
ìThe witness,î he said, ìwill confine himself to answering questions.î
Wilson bellowed, ìIn spite of what you say, itís true, isnít it, that you are merely the spirit of a human being who had died through violence?î
The voice from above the blood drops retorted, ìI repeat that I am an entity of the astral plane. I am not aware that I was ever a human being.î
The lawyer turned an exasperated face to the bench.
ìYour honor,î he said, ìI ask that you instruct the witness to cease playing verbal hide-and-seek. It is quite evident that the witness is a ghost, and that he is therefore the relict of some human being, ipso facto. Circumstantial evidence is strong that he is the ghost of the Hank Jenkins who was killed in 1850. But this is a non-essential point. What is definite is that he is the ghost of someone who is dead, and hence is unqualified to act as witness! I demand his testimony be stricken from the record!î
Turnbull spoke up at once. ìWill the counsel for the defense quote his authority for branding my client a ghost-in the face of my clientís repeated declaration that he is an entity of the astral plane? What is the legal definition of a ghost?î
Judge Gimbel smiled. ìCounsel for the defense will proceed with the cross-examination,î he said.
Wilsonís face Hushed dark purple. He mopped his brow with a large bandanna, then glared at the dropping, sizzling trickle of blood.
ìWhatever you are,î he said, ìanswer me this question. Can you pass through a wall?î
ìWhy, yes. Certainly.î There was a definite note of surprise in the voice from nowhere. ìBut it isnít as easy as some people think. It definitely requires a lot of effort.î
ìNever mind that. You can do it?î
ìYes.î
ìCould you be bound by any physical means? Would handcuffs hold you? Or ropes, chains, prison walls, a hermetically sealed steel chest?î
Jenkins had no chance to answer. Turnbull, scenting danger, cut in hastily. ìI object to this line of questioning. It is entirely irrelevant. ì
ìOn the contrary,î Wilson cried loudly, ìit bears strongly on the qualifications of the so-called Henry Jenkins as a witness! I demand that he answer the question.î
Judge Gimbel said, ìObjection overruled. Witness will answer the question.î
The voice from the chair said superciliously, ìI donít mind answering. Physical barriers mean nothing to me, by and large.î
The counsel for the defense drew himself up triumphantly.
ìVery good,î he said with satisfaction. ìVery good.î Then to the judge, the words coming sharp and fast, ìI claim, your honor, that the so-called Henry Jenkins has no legal status as a witness in court. There is clearly no value in understanding the nature of an oath if a violation of the oath can bring no punishment in its wake. The statements of a man who can perjure himself freely have no worth. I demand they be stricken from the record!î
Turnbull was at the judgeís bench in two strides.
ìI had anticipated that, your honor,î he said quickly. ìFrom the very nature of the case, however, it is clear that my client can be very definitely restricted in his movements-spells, pentagrams, talismans, amulets, Exclusion Circles and what-not. I have here-which I am prepared to deliver to the bailiff of the court-a list of the various methods of confining an astral entity to a restricted area for periods ranging from a few moments to all eternity. Moreover, I have also signed a bond for five thousand dollars, prior to the beginning of the trial, which I stand ready to forfeit should my client be confined and make his escape, if found guilty of any misfeasance as a witness.î
Gimbelís face, which had looked startled for a second, slowly cleared. He nodded. ìThe court is satisfied with the statement of the counsel for the plaintiff,î he declared. ìThere seems no doubt that the plaintiff can be penalized for any misstatements, and the motion of the defense is denied.î
Wilson looked choleric, but shrugged. ì All right,î he said. ìThat will be all:í
ìYou may step down, Mr. Jenkins,î Gimbel directed, and watched in fascination as the blood-dripping column rose and floated over the floor, along the corridor, out the door.
Turnbull approached the judgeís bench again. He said, ìI would like to place in evidence these notes, the diary of the late Zebulon Harley. Itwas presented to my client by Harley himself last fall. I call particular attention to the entry for April sixth, nineteen seventeen, in which he mentions the entrance of the United States into the First World War, and records the results of a series of eleven pinochle games played with a personage identified as ëOld Hank.í With the courtís permission, I will read the entry for that day, and also various other entries for the next four years. Please note the references to someone known variously as ëJenkinsí, ëHank Jenkinsí and-in one extremely significant passage-íOld Invisible: ì
Wilson stewed silently during the slow reading of Harleyís diary. There was anger on his face, but he paid close attention, and when the reading was over he leaped to his feet.
ìI would like to know,î he asked, ìif the counsel for the plaintiff is in possession of any diaries after nineteen twenty?î
Turnbull shook his head. ìHarley apparently never kept a diary, except during the four years represented in this.î
ìThen I demand that the court refuse to admit this diary as evidence on two counts,î Wilson said. He raised two fingers to tick off the points. ìIn the first place, the evidence presented is frivolous. The few vague and unsatisfactory references to Jenkins nowhere specifically describe him as what he is-ghost, astral entity or what you will. Second, the evidence, even were the first point overlooked, concerns only the years up to nineteen twenty-one. The case concerns itself only with the supposed occupation of Harley Hall by the so-called Jenkins in the last twenty years- since ëtwenty-one. Clearly, the evidence is therefore irrelevant.î
Gimbel looked at Turnbull, who smiled calmly.
ìThe reference to ëOld Invisibleí is far from vague,î he said. ìIt is a definite indication of the astral character of my client. Furthermore, evidence as to the friendship of my client with the late Mr. Zebulon Harley before nineteen twenty-one is entirely relevant, as such a friendship, once established, would naturally be presumed to have continued indefinitely. Unless of course, the defense is able to present evidence to the contrary.î
Judge Gimbel said, ìThe diary is admitted as evidence.î
Turnbull said, ìI rest my case.î
There was a buzz of conversation in the courtroom while the judge looked over the diary, and then handed it to the clerk to be marked and entered.
Gimbel said, ìThe defense may open its case.î
Wilson rose. To the clerk he said, ìRussell Joseph Harley.î
But young Harley was recalcitrant. ìNix, ì he said, on his feet, pointing at the witness chair. ìThat thingís got blood all over it! You donít expect me to sit down in that large puddle of blood, do you?î
Judge Gimbel leaned over to look at the chair. The drip-drop trickle of blood from the apparition whoíd been testifying had left its mark. Muddy brown all down the front of the chair. Gimbel found himself wondering how the ghost managed to replenish its supply of the fluid, but gave it up.
ìI see your point,î he said. ëWell, itís getting a bit late anyhow. The clerk will take away the present witness chair and replace it. In the interim, I declare the court recessed till tomorrow morning at ten oíclock.î








III


Russell Harley noticed how the elevator boyís back registered repulsion and disapproval, and scowled. He was not a popular guest in the hotel, he knew well. Where he made his mistake, though, was in thinking that the noxious bundle of herbs about his neck was the cause of it. His odious personality had a lot to do with the chilly attitude of the management and his fellow guests.
He made his way to the bar, ignoring the heads that turned in surprise to follow the reeking comet-tail of his passage. He entered the red-leather-and-chromium drinking room, and stared about for Lawyer Wilson.
And blinked in surprise when he saw him. Wilson wasnít alone. In the booth with him was a tall, dark figure, with his back to Harley. The back alone was plenty for recognition. Nicholls!
Wilson had seen him. ìHello, Harley,î he said, all smiles and affability in the presence of the man with the money. ìCome on and sit down. Mr. Nicholls dropped in on me a little while ago, so I brought him over.î
ìHello,î Harley said glumly, and Nicholls nodded. The muscles of his cheeks pulsed, and he seemed under a strain, strangely uncomfortable in Harleyís presence. Still there was a twinkle in the look he gave young Harley, and his voice was friendly enough-though supercilious-as he said:
ìHello, Harley. How is the trial going?î
ìAsk him,î said Harley, pointing a thumb at Wilson as he slid his knees under the boothís table and sat down. ìHeís the lawyer. Heís supposed to know these things.î
ìDoesnít he?î
Harley shrugged and craned his neck for the waitress. ìOh, I guess soÖRye and water!î He watched the girl appreciatively as she nodded and went off to the bar, then turned his attention back to Nicholls. ìThe trouble is,î he said, ìWilson may think he knows, but I think heís all wet:í
Wilson frowned. ìDo you imply-î he began, but Nicholls put up a hand.
ìLetís not bicker,î said Nicholls. ìSuppose you answer my question. I have a stake in this, and I want to know. Howís the trial going?î
Wilson put on his most open-faced expression. ìFrankly,î he said, ìnot too well. Iím afraid the judge is on the other side. If youíd listened to me and stalled till another judge came along-î
ìI had no time to stall, ì said Nicholls. ìI have to be elsewhere within a few days. Even now, I should be on my way. Do you think we might lose the case?î
Harley laughed sharply. As Wilson glared at him he took his drink from the waitressí tray and swallowed it. The smile remained on his face as he listened to Wilson say smoothly:
ìThere is a good deal of danger, yes.î
ìHum.î Nicholls looked interestedly at his fingernails. ìPerhaps I chose the wrong lawyer.î
ìSure you did.î Harley waved at the waitress, ordered another drink. ìYou want to know what else I think? I think you picked the wrong client, spelled s-t-o-o-g-e. Iím getting sick of this. This damn thing around my neck smells bad. How do I know itís any good, anyhow? Far as I can see, it just smells bad, and thatís all.î
ìIt works,î Nicholls said succinctly. ìI wouldnít advise you to go without it. The late Hank Jenkins is not a very strong ghost-a strong one would tear you apart and chew up your herbs for dessert but without the protection of what you wear about your neck, you would become a very uncomfortable human as soon as Jenkins heard youíd stopped wearing it.î
He put down the glass of red wine heíd been inhaling without drinking, looked intently at Wilson. ìIíve put up the money in this,î he said. ìI had hoped youíd be able to handle the legal end. I see Iíll have to do more. Now listen intently, because I have no intention of repeating this. Thereís an angle to this case thatís got right by your blunted legal acumen. Jenkins claims to be an astral entity, which he undoubtedly is. Now, instead of trying to prove him a ghost, and legally dead, and therefore unfit to testify, which you have been doing, suppose you do thisÖî
He went on to speak rapidly and to the point.
And when he left them a bit later, and Wilson took Harley up to his room and poured him into bed, the lawyer felt happy for the first time in days.
Russell Joseph Harley, a little hung over and a lot nervous, was called to the stand as first witness in his own behalf.
Wilson said, ìYour name?î
ìRussell Joseph Harley.î
ìYou are the nephew of the late Zebulon Harley, who bequeathed the residence known as Harley Hall to you?î
ìYes.î
Wilson turned to the bench. ìI offer this copy of the late Mr. Zebulon Harleyís will in evidence. All his possessions are left to his nephew and only living kin, the defendant.î
Turnbull spoke from his desk. ìThe plaintiff in no way disputes the defendantís equity in Harley Hall.î
Wilson continued, ìYou passed part of your childhood in Harley Hall, did you not, and visited it as a grown man on occasion?î
ìYes.î
ìAt any time, has anything in the shape of a ghost, specter or astral entity manifested itself to you in Harley Hall?î
ìNo. Iíd remember it.î
ìDid your late uncle ever mention any such manifestation to you?î
ìHim? No.î
ìThatís all.î
Turnbull came up for the cross-examination.
ìWhen, Mr. Harley, did you last see your uncle before his death?î
ìIt was in nineteen thirty-eight. In September, some time-around the tenth or eleventh of the month.î
ìHow long a time did you spend with him?,í
Harley flushed unaccountably. ìAh-just one day,î he said.
ìWhen before that did you see him?,í
ìWell, not since I was quite young. My parents moved to Pennsylvania in nineteen twentyÖ
ìAnd since then-except for that one-day visit in nineteen thirty-eight-has any communication passed between your uncle and yourself?î
ìëNo, I guess not. He was a rather queer duck-solitary. A little bit balmy, I think.î
ìëWell, youíre a loving nephew. But in view of what youíve just said, does it sound surprising that your uncle never told you of Mr. Jenkins? He never had much chance to, did he?î
ìHe had a chance in nineteen thirty-eight, but he didnít,î Harley said defiantly.
Turnbull shrugged. ìIím finished, ì he said.
Gimbel began to look bored. He had anticipated something more in the way of fireworks. He said, ìHas the defense any further witnesses?î
Wilson smiled grimly. ìYes, your honor,Ö he said. This was his big moment, and he smiled again as he said gently, ìI would like to call Mr. Henry Jenkins to the stand.î
In the amazed silence that followed, Judge Gimbel leaned forward. ìëYou mean you wish to call the plaintiff as a witness for the defense?î
Serenely, ìYes, your honor.î
Gimbel grimaced. ìCall Henry Jenkins,î he said wearily to the clerk, and sank back in his chair.
Turnbull was looking alarmed. He bit his lip, trying to decide whether to object to this astonishing procedure, but finally shrugged as the clerk bawled out the ghostís name.
Turnbull sped do\VD the corridor, out the door. His voice was heard in the anteroom, then he returned more slowly. Behind him came the trickle of blood drops: Pat. HISS. Pat. HISS-
ìOne moment, ì said Gimbel, coming to life again. ìI have no objection to your testifying, Mr. Jenkins, but the State should not be subjected to the needless expense of reupholstering its witness chair every time you do. Bailiff, find some sort of a rug or something to throw over the chair before Mr. Jenkins is sworn in:í
A tarpaulin was hurriedly procured and adjusted to the chair; Jenkins materialized long enough to be sworn in, then sat.
ìTell me, Mr. Jenkins,î he said, ìjust how many ëastral entitiesí-I believe that is what you call yourself-are there?î
ìI have no way of knowing. Many billions.î
ìAs many, in other words, as there have been human beings to die by violence?î
Turnbull rose to his feet in sudden agitation, but the ghost neatly evaded the trap. ìI donít know. I only know there are billions.î
The lawyerís cat-who-ate-canary smile remained undimmed. ìAnd all these billions are constantly about us, everywhere, only remaining invisible. Is that it?î
ìOh, no. Very few remain on Earth. Of those, still fewer have anything to do with humans. Most humans are quite boring to us.î
ìWell, how many would you say are on Earth? A hundred thousand?î
ìEven more, maybe. But thatís a good guess.î
Turnbull interrupted suddenly. ìI would like to know the significance of these questions. I object to this whole line of questioning as being totally irrelevant.î
Wilson was a study in legal dignity. He retorted, ìI am trying to elicit some facts of major value, your honor. This may change the entire character of the case. I ask your patience for a moment or two.î
ìCounsel for the defense may continue,î Gimbel said curtly. Wilson showed his canines in a grin. He continued to the blood dripping before him. ìNow, the contention of your counsel is that the late Mr. Harley allowed an ëastral entityí to occupy his home for twenty years or more, with his full knowledge and consent. That strikes me as being entirely improbable, but shall we for the moment assume it to be the case?î
ìCertainly! Itís the truth.î
ìThen tell me, Mr. Jenkins, have you fingers?î
ìHave I-what?î
ìYou heard me!î Wilson snapped. ìHave you fingers, flesh-and-blood fingers, capable of making an imprint?î
ìWhy, no. I-î Wilson rushed on. ìOr have you a photograph of yourself-or specimens of your handwriting-or any sort of material identification? Have you any of these?î
The voice was definitely querulous. ìWhat do you mean?î
Wilsonís voice became harsh, menacing. ìI mean, can you prove that you are the astral entity alleged to have occupied Zebulon Harleyís home. Was it you-or was it another of the featureless, faceless, intangible unknowns-one of the hundreds of thousands of them that, by your own admission, are all over the face of the earth, rambling where they choose, not halted by any locks or bars? Can you prove that you are anyone in particular?î
ìYour honor!î Turnbullís voice was almost a shriek as he found his feet at last. ìMy clientís identity was never in question!î
ìIt is now!î roared Wilson. ìThe opposing counsel has presented a personage whom he styles ëHenry Jenkins: Who is this Jenkins? What is he? Is he even an individual-or a corporate aggregation of these mysterious ëastral entitiesí which we are to believe are everywhere, but which we never see? If he is an individual, is he the individual? And how can we know that, even if he says he is? Let him produce evidence-photographs, a birth certificate, fingerprints. Let him bring in identifying witnesses who have known both ghosts, and are prepared to swear that these ghosts are the same ghost. Failing this, there is no case! Your honor, I demand the court declare an immediate judgment in favor of the defendant!î
Judge Gimbel stared at Turnbull. ìHave you anything to say?î he asked. ìThe argument of the defense would seem to have every merit with it. Unless you can produce some sort of evidence as to the identity of your client, I have no alternative but to find for the defense.î
For a moment there was a silent tableau. Wilson triumphant, Turnbull furiously frustrated.
How could you identify a ghost?
And then came the quietly amused voice from the witness chair.
ìThis thing has gone far enough, ì it said above the sizzle and splatter of its own leaking blood. ìI believe I can present proof that will satisfy the court.î
Wilsonís face fell with express-elevator speed. Turnbull held his breath, afraid to hope.
Judge Gimbel said, ìYou are under oath. Proceed.î
There was no other sound in the courtroom as the voice said, ìMr. Harley, here, spoke of a visit to his uncle in nineteen thirty-eight. I can vouch for that. They spent a night and a day together. They werenít alone. I was there.î
No one was watching Russell Harley, or they might have seen the sudden sick pallor that passed over his face.
The voice, relentless, went on. ìPerhaps I shouldnít have eavesdropped as I did, but old Zeb never had any secrets from me anyhow. I listened to what they talked about. Young Harley was working for a bank in Philadelphia at the time. His first big job. He needed money, and needed it bad. There was a shortage in his department. A woman named Sally-î
ìHold on!î Wilson yelled. ìThis has nothing to do with your identification of yourself. Keep to the point!î
But Turnbull had begun to comprehend. He was shouting, too, almost too excited to be coherent. ìYour honor, my client must be allowed to speak. If he shows knowledge of an intimate conversation between the late Mr. Harley and the defendant, it would be certain proof that he enjoyed the late Mr. Harleyís confidence, and thus, Q.E.D., that he is no other than the astral entity who occupied Harley Hall for so long!î
Gimbel nodded sharply. ìLet me remind counsel for the defense that this is his own witness. Mr. Jenkins, continue.î
The voice began again, ìAs I was saying, the womanís name-î
ìShut up, damn you!î Harley yelled. He sprang upright. turned beseechingly toward the judge. ìHeís twisting it! Make him stop! Sure, I knew my uncle had a ghost. Heís it. all right, curse his black soul! He can have the house if he wants it-Iíll clear out. Iíll clear out of the whole damned state!î
He broke off into babbling and turned about wildly. Only the intervention of a marshal kept him from hurtling out of the courtroom.
Banging of the gavel and hard work by the court clerk and his staff restored order in the courtroom. When the room had returned almost to normalcy, Judge Gimbel, perspiring and annoyed, said, ì As far as I am concerned, identification of the witness is complete. Has the defense any further evidence to present?î
Wilson shrugged morosely. ìNo, your honor.î
ìCounsel for the plaintiff?î
ìNothing, your honor. I rest my case.î Gimbel plowed a hand through his sparse hair and blinked. ìIn that case,î he said, ìI find for the plaintiff. An order is entered hereby that the defendant. Russell Joseph Harley, shall remove from the premises of Harley Hall all spells, pentagrams, talismans and other means of exorcism employed; that he shall cease and desist from making any attempts, of whatever nature, to evict the tenant in the future; and that Henry Jenkins, the plaintiff, shall be permitted to full use and occupancy of the premises designated as Harley Hall for the full term of his natural-ah-existence.î
The gavel banged. ìThe case is closed.î
ìDonít take it so hard,î said a mild voice behind Russell Harley. He whirled surlily. Nicholls was coming up the street after him from the courthouse, Wilson in tow.
Nicholls said, ìYou lost the case, but youíve still got your life. Let me buy you a drink. In here, perhaps.î
He herded them into a cocktail lounge, sat them down before they had a chance to object. He glanced at his expensive wrist watch. ìI have a few minutes,î he said ìThen I really must be off. Itís urgent.î
He hailed a barman, ordered for all. Then he looked at young Harley and smiled broadly as he dropped a bill on the counter to pay for the drinks.
ìHarley,î he said, ìI have a motto that you would do well to remember at times like these. Iíll make you a present of it, if you like.î
ìWhat is it?î
ìëThe worst is yet to come.í ì
Harley snarled and swallowed his drink without replying. Wilson said, ìWhat gets me is, why didnít they come to us before the trial with that stuff about this charmingly illicit client you wished on me? Weíd have had to settle out of court.î
Nicholls shrugged. ìThey had their reasons,î he said ì After all, one case of exorcism, more or less, doesnít matter. But lawsuits set precedents. Youíre a lawyer, of sorts, Wilson; do you see what I mean?î
ìPrecedents?î Wilson looked at him slack-jawed for a moment; then his eyes widened
ìI see you understand me.î Nicholls nodded. ìFrom now on in this state-and by virtue of the full-faith-and-credence clause of the Constitution, in every state of the country-a ghost has a legal right to haunt a house!î
ìGood lord!î said Wilson. He began to laugh, not loud, but from the bottom of his chest.
Harley stared at Nicholls. ìOnce and for all,î he whispered, ìtell me -whatís your angle on all this?î
Nicholls smiled again.
ìThink about it a while,î he said lightly. ìYouíll begin to understand.î He sniffed his wine once more, then sat the glass down gently
And vanished.



***



As Iíve mentioned before, I was never a reader of Weird Tales, and its type of fiction did not captivate me. In 1950, though, when ìLegal Ritesî finally appeared, Weird Tales was nearing the end of its thirty-year road and Iím rather glad I made its pages at least once before its end, even if only as half of a collaboration. It was the longest story in the issue and it received the cover.
ìLegal Ritesî and ìThe Little Man on the Subwayî are the only pieces of fiction I ever wrote in collaboration, and I didnít really enjoy the process. Later on in my career, I had occasion to collaborate on four or five non-fiction books and never really enjoyed that either, nor were any of the collaborations successful Iím essentially a loner and like to take full responsibility for what I write.
In the case of ìLegal Ritesî it seems to me that the beginning is mostly Pohlís rewriting; the trial scene is mostly mine; the ending-I donít remember.
Fantasy was not the only type of story I kept bullheadedly trying, over and over, without much success. Another type was the broadly farcical. I never sold either type to Campbell, but I at least sold the latter elsewhere.
Even while I was writing ìLegal Rites,î I was working on another robot story, but a humorous one-or what I considered humor. I called it ìSource of Powerî and at least knew better than to waste time trying it on Campbell. I sent it directly to Thrilling Wonder, and when it was rejected there, I tried Amazing.
Amazingbought it on October 8, 1941-my first sale to that magazine since those exciting beginning days of the fall of 1938. When it appeared on the stands (two days after Pearl Harbor) in the February 1942. issue, I found that Amazing had retitled it ìRobot AL-76 Goes Astray.î
Although ìRobot AL-76 Goes Astrayî was a ìpositronic robotî story, it didnít really fit in with the other three I had thus far written. When I, Robot, my first collection of ìpositronic robotî stories, was put together, in 1950, I did not include ìRobot AL-76 Goes Astrayî in that volume. When, however, in 1964, The Rest of the Robots was put together, I felt honor-bound by the title, if nothing else, to include all the remaining robot stories published till then, and therefore ìRobot AL-76 Goes Astrayî was included.
August 1, 1941 (ìRobot AL-76 Goes Astrayî was then still working its slow way through the typewriter, because the Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union distracted me) was another important day in my writing career. I went to see John Campbell that day and, not liking to come to him without an idea, I thought hard on the subway ride there.
The fate of ìPilgrimageî (soon to become ìBlack Friar of the Flameî) was still rankling, and I wanted to write another future-historical. I therefore suggested to him that I do a short story against the background of the slow fall of the Galactic Empire (something I intended to model quite frankly on the fall of the Roman Empire).
Campbell caught fire. We spent two hours together, and by the time it was over it was not going to be a short story at all, but an indefinitely long series of stories dealing with the fall of the First Galactic Empire and the rise of the Second.
I submitted the first story of the series, ìFoundation,î to Campbell on September 8, 1941, and it was accepted on the fifteenth. It appeared in the May 1942 issue of Astounding.
Over the next eight years I was to write seven more stories of what came to be called the ìFoundationî series, and these were finally collected into three volumes, Foundation, Foundation and Empire, and Second Foundation, which collectively were called The Foundation Trilogy.
Of all my science fiction, these books were most successful. First published in 1951, 1952, and 1953, respectively, they have been in print constantly as hard-covers ever since, despite the appearance of numerous soft-cover editions. And in 1966, at the 24th World Science Fiction Convention, in Cleveland, the ìFoundationî series received a Hugo (science fictionís equivalent of the Oscar) as the ìBest All-Time Series.î
After ìFoundationî I was ready to try a serious positronic robot story for the first time in half a year. This one, ìRunaround, ì was submitted to Campbell on October 20, 1941, and he accepted it on the twenty-third. It appeared in the March 1942 issue of Astounding and was eventually included in I, Robot.
I then had to get to work at once on a sequel to ìFoundation.î ìFoundationî had been brought to an inconclusive ending on the assumption that a sequel would be forthcoming, and I had to come through. On November 17, the sequel, ìBridle and Saddle,î which was the second story of the ìFoundationî series, was submitted to Campbell, and he accepted it the same day-a record in speed. Whatís more, it was the longest story I had yet written-eighteen thousand words-and even though I received no bonus, the check, for $180, was the largest single check I had yet received. ìBridle and Saddleî was eventually included in Foundation.
Now, at last, I had a series of long stories going, together with my ìpositronic robotî series of short stories. I was feeling quite good.
On November 17, 1941, the day I submitted and sold ìBridle and Saddle,î Campbell told me his plan for starting a new department in Astounding, one to be called ìProbability Zero.î This was to be a department of short-shorts, five hundred to one thousand words, which were to be in the nature of plausible and entertaining Munchausen-like lies. Campbellís notion was that, aside from the entertainment value of these things, they would offer a place where beginners could penetrate the market without having to compete quite so hard with established writers. It would form a stairway to professional status.
This was a good idea in theory and even worked a little. Ray Bradbury, later to be one of the best-known and successful of all science fiction writers, broke into the field with a ìProbability Zeroî item in the July 1942 Astounding. Hal Clement and George 0. Smith also published in ìProbability Zeroî near the very start of their careers.
Unfortunately, it didnít work enough. Campbell had to start the department going with professionals, hoping to let the amateurs carry on once they saw what it was Campbell wanted. There were, however, never enough amateurs who could meet Campbellís standards even for short-shorts of an undemanding nature, and after twelve appearances of ìProbability Zeroî over a space of two and a half years, Campbell gave up.
On November 17, however, he was just beginning, and he wanted me to do a ìProbability Zeroî for him. I was delighted that he considered me to be at that stage of virtuosity where he could order me to do something for him according to measure. I promptly sat down and wrote a short-short called ìBig Game.î On November 24, 1941, I showed it to Campbell. He glanced over it and, rather to my astonishment, handed it back. It wasnít what he wanted.
I wish I could remember what ìBig Gameî was about, for I thought enough of it to try submitting it to Collierís magazine (an over-awing slick) in 1944-and it was, of course, rejected. The title, however, recalls nothing to my mind, and the story now no longer exists.
I tried a second time and did a humorous little positronic robot story called ìFirst Law.î I showed it to Campbell on December 1, and he didnít like that, either. This time, though, I kept the story. Thank goodness, I had finally learned that stories must be carefully saved for eternity, however many times they are rejected, and however firmly you imagine they are retired. ìBig Gameî was the eleventh of my stories to disappear, but it was also the last.
In the case of ìFirst Lawî there came a time when a magazine that did not exist in 1941 was to ask me for something. The magazine in question was Fantastic Universe, whose editor, Hans Stefan Santesson, asked me for a story at rates that would have been fine in 1941 but that by the mid-1950s I was reluctant to accept. I remembered ìFirst Law,î however, and sent it in. Santesson took it and ran it in the October 1956 issue of Fantastic Universe, and, eventually, I included it in The Rest of the Robots.
But back to ìProbability Zeroî-
I tried a third time with a short-story called ìTime Pussy,î which I wrote on the morning of Sunday, December 7, 1941, finishing it just before the radio went crazy with the news of Pearl Harbor. I brought it in to Campbell the next day (life goes on!), and this time he took it, but ìnot too enthusiastically,î according to my diary.










Time Pussy


This was told me long ago by old Mac, who lived in a shack just over the hill from my old house. He had been a mining prospector out in the Asteroids during the Rush of ë37, and spent most of his time now in feeding his seven cats.
ìWhat makes you like cats So much, Mr. Mac?î I asked him.
The old miner looked at me and scratched his chin. ìWell,î he said, ìthey reminds me oí my leetle pets on Pallas. They was something like cats-same kind of head, sort oí-and the cleverest leetle fellers yí ever saw. All dead!î
I felt sorry and said so. Mac heaved a sigh. ìCleverest leetle fellers,î he repeated. ìThey was four-dimensional pussies.î
ìFour-dimensional, Mr. Mac? But the fourth dimension is time.î I had learned that the year before, in the third grade.
ìSo youíve had a leetle schooling, hey?î He took out his pipe and filled it slowly. ìSure, the fourth dimension is time. These pussies was about a foot long and six inches high and four inches wide and stretched somewheres into middle oí next week. Thatís four dimensions, ainít it? Why, if you petted their heads, they wouldnít wag their tails till next day, mebbe. Some 0 the big ones wouldnít wag till day after. Fact!î
I looked dubious, but didnít say anything.
Mac went on: ìThey was the best leetle watchdogs in all creation, too. They had to be. Why, if they spotted a burglar or any suspicious character, theyíd shriek like a banshee. And when one saw a burglar today, heíd shriek yesterday, so we had twenty-four hoursí notice every time.î
My mouth opened. ìHonest?î
ìCross my heart! Yí want to know how we used to feed them? Weí d wait for them to go to sleep, see, and then weíd know they was busy digesting their meals. These leetle time pussies, they always digested their meals exactly three hours before they ate it, on account their stomachs stretched that far back in time. So when they went to sleep, we used to look at the time, get their dinner ready and feed it to them exactly three hours later.î
He had lit his pipe now and was puffing away. He shook his head sadly. ìOnce, though, I made a mistake. Poor leetle time pussy. His name was Joe, and he was just about my favorite, too. He went to sleep one morning at nine and somehow I got the idea it was eight. Naturally, I brought him his feed at eleven. I looked allover for him, but I couldnít find him.î
ìWhat had happened, Mr. Mac?î
ìWell, no time pussyís insides could be expected to handle his breakfast only two hours after digesting it. Its too much to expect. I found him finally under the tool kit in the outer shed. He had crawled there and died of indigestion an hour before. Poor leetle feller! After that, I always set an alarm, so I never made that mistake again.î
There was a short, mournful silence after that, and I resumed in a respectful whisper: ìYou said they all died, before. Were they all killed like that?î
Mac shook his head solemnly. ìNo! They used to catch colds from us fellers and just die anywhere from a week to ten days before they caught them. They wasnít too many to start with, and a year after the miners hit Pallas they wasnít but about ten left and them ten sort oí weak and sickly. The trouble was, leetle feller, that when they died, they went all to pieces; just rotted away fast. Especially the little four-dimensional jigger they had in their brains which made them act the way they did. It cost us all millions oí dollars.î
ìHow was that, Mr. Mac?î
ìYí see, some scientists back on Earth got wind of our leetle time pussies, and they knew theyíd all be dead before they could get out there next conjunction. So they offered us all a million dollars for each time pussy we preserved for them.î
ìAnd did you?î
ìWell, we tried, but they wouldnít keep. After they died, they were just no good any more, and we had to bury them. We tried packing them in ice, but that only kept the outside all right. The inside was a nasty mess, and it was the inside the scientists wanted.
ìNaturílly, with each dead time pussy costing us a million dollars, we didnít want that to happen. One of us figured out that if we put a time pussy into hot water when it was about to die, the water would soak all through it. Then, after it died, we could freeze the water so it would just be one solid chunk oí ice, and then it would keep.î
My lower jaw was sagging. ìDid it work?î
ìWe tried and we tried, son, but we just couldnít freeze the water fast enough. By the time we had it all iced, the four-dimensional jigger in the time pussyís brain had just corrupted away. We froze the water faster and faster but it was no go. Finally, we had only one time pussy left, and he was just fixing to die, too. We was desperate-and then one of the fellers thought oí something. He figured out a complicated contraption that would freeze all the water just like that -in a split second.
ìWe picked up the last leetle feller and put him into the hot water and hooked on the machine. The leetle feller gave us a last look and made a funny leetle sound and died. We pressed the button and iced the whole thing into a solid block in about a quarter of a second.î Here Mac heaved a sigh that must have weighed a ton. ìBut it was no use. The time pussy spoiled inside 0í fifteen minutes and we lost the last million dollars.î
I caught my breath. ìBut Mr. Mac, you just said you iced the time pussy in a quarter of a second. It didnít have time to spoil.î
ìThatís just it, leetle feller,î he said heavily. ìWe did it too doggoned fast. The time pussy didnít keep because we froze that hot water so derned fast that the ice was still warm!î



***



The most unusual thing about this small item is that it was not published under my own name. Campbell wanted one item in that first ìProbability Zeroî to appear to be by a non-professional, just to encourage the newcomers he hoped would try to break in. He had three entries in that first department and the other two were by L. Sprague de Camp and Malcolm Jameson. Both were longer-established and (despite ìNightfallî) more renowned than I. As low man, it was up to me to use a pseudonym and pretend to be a newcomer.
I saw Campbellís point and, just a little sullenly, agreed. I used the name George E. Dale. It is the only time I ever used a pseudonym in the magazines. In later years I used the pseudonym Paul French on a series of six teen-age science fiction novels for reasons that are another story altogether. That was a special case, and in 1971 and 1972 those six novels appeared as paperbacks under my own name. Now ìTime Pussyî appears here under my own name, and the record is at last absolutely clean.
There followed a two-month period during which I wrote nothing.
The reasons were twofold. In the first place, Pearl Harbor put the United States in the war the day I wrote ìTime Pussy,î and those first two months after the debacle were too disastrous and heartbreaking to allow much in the way of fiction composing.
If that in itself werenít enough, the time had come to try, once again, the qualifying examinations that would, or would not, grant me permission to do research. I very much felt myself to be dangling over the abyss. A second failure to pass would probably mean an end for me at Columbia. Consequently, during those hours when I wasnít working in my fatherís candy store or hanging over the radio, I had to be studying. There was time for nothing else at all.
Hedging my bets rather desperately, I registered for graduate work at New York University, just in case I did not pass once again. After I took my qualifying examinations, at the end of January 1942, I actually attended a few classes at N.Y.U. while waiting for the results to be announced. -but I wonít keep you in suspense. On Friday, the thirteenth of February, the results were announced. I had passed, this time.
During the interval between the taking of the qualifying examinations and the annunciation, I managed to do ìVictory Unintentional.î This was a positronic robot story that was a sequel to ìNot Final!î which had not been a positronic robot story. obviously I was trying to ride the series notion all I could, in the hope of surer sales.
I submitted it to Campbell on February 9, 1942, and if I thought Campbell would find himself unable to reject a series story, I was roundly disabused. Nor was he so impressed by ìNightfallî and by my ìFoundationî series as to find himself incapable of making the rejection a severe one.
On February 13. the very day of my passing into the sacred list of those permitted to do research toward their Ph.D., my spirits were somewhat dashed when I received ìVictory Unintentional?î back with a cryptic rejection, which consisted of the following, in toto, ìCH3C2CH2CH2SH.î Campbell very well knew that this was the formula for ìbutyl mercaptan, ì which gives the skunk its smell, and I very well knew it, too, and Campbell very well knew I knew.
Oh, well! I managed to sell it anyway, to Super Science Stories under its post-Pohl editor, on March 16, 1942, and it appeared in the August 1942 issue of that magazine. Though I did not include it in I, Robot, I did include it, of necessity, in The Rest of the Robots.
After that, though, there came another dry period, the longest I was ever to experience. Once ìVictory Unintentionalî was finished, fourteen months (I) were to pass before I turned back to the typewriter. It was not the conventional ìwriterís block,î of course, for that I have never experienced. Rather, it was the coming of a vast, triple change in my life.
The first change was the fact that I was now beginning chemical research in earnest under Professor Charles R. Dawson. Research is a full-time job and I still had to work it around, somehow, my duties in my fatherís candy store, so there was bound to be very little time for writing.
Then, as though that werenít enough, a second change took place simultaneously
In January 1942 I joined an organization called ëThe Brooklyn Writersí Club,î which had sent me a postcard of invitation. I took the invitation to be a recognition of my status as a ìwriterî and I couldnít possibly have refused.
The first meeting I attended was on January 19, 1942. It turned out to be rather pleasant. I welcomed the chance to get my mind off the qualifying examinations and the war disasters (though I remember spending part of that first meeting discussing the possibility that New York might be bombed).
Most of the members of the club were no further advanced in the profession than I was; nor were any of them, aside from myself, science fiction writers. The chief activity consisted of reading from our own manuscripts so that criticism from the others might be invited. Since it was quickly discovered that I read ìwith expression, ì I became chief reader, a role I enjoyed(It was to be eight years yet before I discovered that I had a natural Hair for the lecture platform.)
On February 9, 1942, the third meeting I attended, there was present a young man, Joseph Goldberger, whom I had not met before. He was a couple of years older than I was. I did most of the reading that day and Goldberger was sufficiently impressed to suggest, after the meeting had adjourned, that the two of us, with our girls, go out on a double date and get to know each other. Embarrassed, I had to explain that I had no girl. With an expansive gesture, he said he would get one for me.
And so he did. On February 14. 1942 (Valentineís Day and the day after I had passed my qualifying examinations) I met him at the Astor Hotel at 8:30 P.M. With him was his girl friend, and with her was her girl friend, Gertrude Blugerman, who was going to be my blind date. -I fell in love, and when I wasnít thinking of research I was thinking of her.
But there was also a third change, in a way the most drastic-
With war, the job situation suddenly changed: technically trained men of all sorts were in demand.
Robert Heinlein, for instance, was an engineer who had been trained at Annapolis. His health had retired him from active service in the Navy and had kept him retired, but his Annapolis connections made it possible for him to work as a civilian engineer at the Naval Air Experimental Station of the u. S. Navy Yard in Philadelphia. He cast about for other qualified people he might persuade to join him there, particularly among his fellow science fiction writers.
He got L. Sprague de Camp to come to the N.A.E.S., and on March 30, 1942, I received a letter from the navy yard asking if I would consider joining them.
I am rather single-minded and, having labored toward my Ph.D. for a year and a half, I would not ordinarily have considered letting go for anything short of a major force. -but the major force was there. I was in love and I wanted to get married even more than I wanted my degree. It occurred to me that I could suspend work toward my Ph.D. with the full approval of the school, thanks to the war emergency, and that I could also get full permission to resume after the war. And by taking a job and postponing-merely postponing- myresearch, I could get married.
I went down to Philadelphia for an interview on April 10 and apparently met their requirements. I took the job, and on May 14, having left my fatherís candy store at last and (at least as a worker) forever, I moved to Philadelphia. Fortunately, Philadelphia was only an hour and a half from New York by train (in those days, I couldnít drive a car and, even if I could, I wouldnít have been able to get the gasoline because of rationing). I was therefore back in New York every weekend.
By the twenty-fourth of the month I had persuaded Gertrude to agree to marry me, and on July 26 we were married.
During those months it did not bother me that I was doing no writing. I had too much to think of-first the war, then research, then the job, then the marriage.
Besides, in the years up to early 1942, I never thought of my writing as anything but a way to help out with my college tuition. It was fun; it was exciting; and such success as I managed to achieve was deeply satisfying-but it had been done to serve a purpose and that purpose had been served. I had no notion that writing could be my career; that it could ever possibly be my career.
My career was to be chemistry. All the time I was writing and selling stories, I was also slaving away at Columbia. Once I earned my Ph.D., I intended to make my living by doing chemical research for some large industry at some munificent salary such as a hundred dollars a week. (As the son of a candy-store keeper, brought up in the depression, I suffered dizzy spells if I tried to think of more than a hundred dollars a week, so I confined my ambitions to that.)
My Philadelphia job, to be sure, paid me only fifty dollars a week at the beginning, but a young couple could live on that, those days, with taxes very small, with an apartment costing $42.50 a month and dinner for two at a restaurant coming to two dollars (including tip).
It wasnít the height of my dreams, but it was only a temporary war job, after all. Once the war was over, I would go back to my research and get my Ph.D. and a better job. Meanwhile, even a salary of $2,600 a year seemed to make it unnecessary for me to write. By my marriage day, I had written forty-two stories, of which twenty-eight had been sold (and three more were yet to sell).My total bachelor earnings over a space of four years had been $1,788.50 for those twenty-eight stories. This amounted to an average earning of just under $8.60 per week or $64 per story.
I never dreamed at that time that I could ever do much better. I had no intention of ever writing anything but science fiction or fantasy for the pulp magazines, which paid one cent a word at most-a cent and a quarter with bonus.
To make even the feeble fifty dollars a week that my job paid me would make it necessary for me to write and sell some forty stories a year, and, at that time, that didnít seem conceivable to me.
It had been all right to labor at the typewriter to pay my way through school, when I had no other source of income, but for what purpose ought I to be writing now? And with a six-day, fifty-four hour week, and the excitement of a new marriage, who had time?
The very existence of science fiction seemed to fade. I had left my magazine collection in New York; I no longer saw Campbell regularly, or Pohl, or any of my science fiction cronies. I scarcely even read the current magazines as they came out.
I might have let science fiction die altogether, and my writing career with it, except that there were little reminders from the outside world, and little itchings inside me that meant (though I didnít know it at the time) that writing was a great deal more to me than just a handy device to make a little spare cash.
I had hardly begun to work at the N.A.E.S., for instance, when the June 1942 issue of Astounding came out with my story ìBridle and Saddle.î And it made the cover.
It was quite beyond my power to resist the temptation to take a copy to work and show it around. I couldnít help but feel the status I gained as a ìwriter.î Later that summer and fall, three other stories were published: ìVictory Unintentionalî and ìThe Imaginaryî in the post-Pohl Super Science Stories and ìThe Hazingî in Thrilling Wonder Stories. Each kept the science fiction world alive for me.
And although my New York coterie of science fiction editors, writers, and readers were gone, I was left not entirely bereft.
Working with me at the N.A.E.S. were Robert Heinlein and L. Sprague de Camp, and I kept up a close social relationship with both. To be sure, each had quit writing for the duration but they were far more successful writers than I was and I hero-worshipped them. In addition, John D. Clark, who was an ardent science fiction fan and who had written and published a couple of stories in 1937, was living in Philadelphia at the time and we frequently saw one another. All three kept the science fiction atmosphere about me.
It was on January 5, 1943, though, that the real trigger came. On that day I received a letter from Fred Pohl to the effect that he was planning to rewrite ìLegal Ritesî and was going to try to sell it again. That was exciting. He wasnít to succeed in selling the story for six more years, but of course I had no way of telling that. To me it seemed that another sale was in the offing and that I was an as-yet-active writer.
Besides, ìLegal Ritesî was a fantasy and I had never yet satisfied that long-standing desire to write and sell a fantasy to Unknown. Five times I had tried, and five times I had failed.
On January 13, quite suddenly, a week after the letter had come and fourteen months after my last-written story, the urge overwhelmed me. I sat down to write a fantasy called ì Author! Author!î
Quickly I found there was something lacking. It was the first time I had ever tried to write something for Campbell without conferences with him. I missed the inspiration that invariably came through talks with him; I missed his encouragement. In fact, I wasnít sure that I could write at all without him. So the story limped and there were dry spells. I didnít finish the first draft till March 5, and the final version wasnít ready for mailing till April 4. 1943.
It had taken me nearly three months to write the story. To be sure, it was twelve thousand words long, but ìBridle and Saddle,î which was half again as long, had taken me only three weeks.
Perhaps if ì Author! Author!î had been rejected, it might have been a long time before I would have had the courage to try again. Fortunately, that was never put to the test. I mailed the story to Campbell on April 6, 1943 (the first time I ever mailed him a story instead of handing it to him), and on the twelfth the check of acceptance arrived. There was not even a revision requested, and whatís more, Campbell paid me a bonus for the first time since ìNightfall.î I received one and a quarter cents a word, or $150 in all. My sixth try at Unknown had succeeded.
It was the equivalent of three weeksí pay at the N.A.E.S. for something that had taken me, off and on, three months. However, the three monthsí work onî Author! Author!î had been of a totally different kind than the three weeksí work at the N.A.E.S. would have been, and the receipt of the $150 check was infinitely more exciting than picking up a similar check, or even a larger one, earned in the course of a punch-the-time-clock job. (Yes, indeed, I punched a time clock at the N.A.E.S.)
As it happened, though, the happy excitement with which I greeted the sale was premature. I had scaled the heights of Unknown too late, and though I had the money, I didnít have the magazine. Robert Heinlein brought me the sad news on August 2, less than four months after the sale.
 Unknown had been having a difficult time of it. Sales werenít high enough, and after its first two years of operation it had had to switch from monthly to bimonthly issues. Now the war had introduced a paper shortage and Street amp; Smith Publications decided to save what paper it could receive for the more successful Astounding and let Unknown go.
At the time I made my sale, there were only three more issues of Unknown fated to be issued and there was no room in any of them forî Author! Author!î The story remained in the vaults of Street amp; Smith indefinitely; a story sold, but not published; and the $150 check was deprived of most of its fun as a result.
There is, however, a happy ending. Twenty years later, Don Bensen of Pyramid Publications was publishing a paperback anthology of stories from Unknown, he asked me for an introduction. With glad nostalgia I complied, writing it on January 15, 1963, almost twenty years to the day after I had started writing the only story I ever sold to the magazine. In the course of the introduction, I referred to the sad story of my attempts to write for Unknown.
The 1960s were not the 1940s. In 1963, the mere mention of an existing Asimov story that had never been published produced excitement, and Bensen wrote to me within three days, asking to see the story. I dug out the manuscript (I saved them now, you see, even for twenty years) and sent it to him.
He asked permission to include it in a second anthology of Unknown stories (pointing out that it had been accepted by the magazine). I explained he would also need permission from Campbell and the publisher. They very kindly granted the permission, and in January 1964. twenty-one years after it was written, ì Author! Author!î was finally published and I finally-after a fashion, and glancingly-made Unknown.








Author! Author!


It occurred to Graham Dorn, and not for the first time, either, that there was one serious disadvantage in swearing youíll go through fire and water for a girl, however beloved. Sometimes she takes you at your miserable word.
This is one way of saying that he had been waylaid, shanghaied and dragooned by his fiancee into speaking at her maiden auntís Literary Society. Donít laugh! Itís not funny from the speakerís rostrum. Some of the faces you have to look at!
To race through the details, Graham Dorn had been jerked onto a platform and forced upright. He had read a speech on ìThe Place of the Mystery Novel in American Literatureî in an appalled tone. Not even the fact that his own eternally precious June had written it (part of the bribe to get him to speak in the first place) could mask the fact that it was essentially tripe.
And then when he was weltering, figuratively speaking, in his own mental gore, the harpies closed in, for lo, it was time for the informal discussion and assorted feminine gush.
óOh, Mr. Dorn, do you work from inspiration? I mean, do you just sit down and then an idea strikes you-all at once? And you must sit up all night and drink black coffee to keep you awake till you get it down?
óOh, yes. Certainly. (His working hours were two to four in the afternoon every other day, and he drank milk.)
óOh, Mr. Dorn, you must do the most awful research to get all those bizarre murders. About how much must you do before you can write a story?
óAbout six months, usually. (The only reference books he ever used were a six-volume encyclopedia and year-before-lastís World Almanac.)
óOh, Mr. Dom, did you make up your Reginald de Meister from a real character? You must have. Heís oh, so convincing in his every detail.
óHeís modeled after a very dear boyhood chum of mine. (Dom had never known anyone like de Meister. He lived in continual fear of meeting someone like him. He had even a cunningly fashioned ring containing a subtle Oriental poison for use just in case he did. So much for de Meister.)
Somewhere past the knot of women, June Billings sat in her seat and smiled with sickening and proprietary pride.
Graham passed a finger over his throat and went through the pantomime of choking to death as unobtrusively as possible. June smiled, nodded, threw him a delicate kiss, and did nothing.
Graham decided to pass a stern, lonely, woman-less life and to have nothing but villainesses in his stories forever after.
He was answering in monosyllables, alternating yesses and noes. Yes, he did take cocaine on occasion. He found it helped the creative urge. No, he didnít think he could allow Hollywood to take over de Meister. He thought movies werenít true expressions of real Art. Besides, they were just a passing fad. Yes, he would read Miss Crumís manuscripts if she brought them. Only too glad to. Reading amateur manuscripts was such fun, and editors are really such brutes.
And then refreshments were announced, and there was a sudden vacuum. It took a split-second for Grahamís head to clear. The mass of femininity had coalesced into a single specimen. She was four feet ten and about eighty-five pounds in weight. Graham was six-two and two hundred ten worth of brawn. He could probably have handled her without difficulty, especially since both her arms were occupied with a pachyderm of a purse. Still, he felt a little delicate, to say nothing of queasy, about knocking her down. It didnít seem quite the thing to do.
She was advancing, with admiration and fervor disgustingly clear in her eyes, and Graham felt the wall behind him. There was no doorway within armreach on either side.
ìOh, Mr. de Meister-do, do please let me call you Mr. de Meister. Your creation is so real to me, that I canít think of you as simply Graham Dorn. You donít mind, do you?î
ìNo, no, of course not,î gargled Graham, as well as he could through thirty-two teeth simultaneously set on edge. ìI often think of myself as Reginald in my more frivolous moments.î
ìThank you. You can have no idea, dear Mr. de Meister, how I have looked forward to meeting you. I have read all your works, and I think they are wonderful.î
ìIím glad you think so.î He went automatically into the modesty routine. ìReally nothing, you know. Ha, ha, ha! Like to please the readers, but lots of room for improvement. Ha, ha, ha!î
