ìBut you really are, you know.î This was said with intense earnestness. ìI mean good, really good. I think it is wonderful to be an author like you. It must be almost like being God.î
Graham stared blankly. ìNot to editors, sister.î
Sister didnít get the whisper. She continued, ìTo be able to create living characters out of nothing; to unfold souls to all the world; to put thoughts into words; to build pictures and create worlds. I have often thought that an author was the most gloriously gifted person in creation. Better an inspired author starving in a garret than a king upon his throne. Donít you think so?î
ìDefinitely,î lied Graham.
ìWhat are the crass material goods of the world to the wonders of weaving emotions and deeds into a little world of its own?î
ìWhat, indeed?î
ìAnd posterity, think of posterity!î
ìYes, yes. I often do.î
She seized his hand. ìThereís only one little request. You might,î she blushed faintly, ìyou might give poor Reginald-if you will allow me to call him that just once-a chance to marry Letitia Reynolds. You make her just a little too cruel to him. Iím sure I weep over it for hours together sometimes. But then he is too, too real to me.î
And from somewhere, a lacy frill of handkerchief made its appearance, and went to her eyes. She removed it, smiled bravely, and scurried away. Graham Dorn inhaled, closed his eyes, and gently collapsed into Juneís arms.
His eyes opened with a jerk. ìYou may consider,î he said severely, ìour engagement frazzled to the breaking point. Only my consideration for your poor, aged parents prevents your being known henceforward as the ex-fiancee of Graham Dom.î
ìDarling, you are so noble.î She massaged his sleeve with her cheek. ìCome, Iíll take you home and bathe your poor wounds.î
ìAll right, but youíll have to carry me. Has your precious, loveable aunt got an axe?î
ìBut why?î
ìFor one thing, she had the gall to introduce me as the brain-father, God help me, of the famous Reginald de Meister.î
ìAnd arenít you?î
ìLetís get out of this creep-joint. And get this. Iím no relative by brain or otherwise, of that character. I disown him. I cast him into the darkness. I spit upon him. I declare him an illegitimate son, a foul degenerate, and the offspring of a hound, and Iíll be damned if he ever pokes his lousy patrician nose into my typewriter again.î
They were in the taxi, and June straightened his tie. ì All right, Sonny, letís see the letter.î
ìWhat letter?î
She held out her hand. ìThe one from the publishers.î
Graham snarled and flipped it out of his jacket pocket. ìIíve thought of inviting myself to his house for tea, the damned flintheart. Heís got a rendezvous with a pinch of strychnine.î
ìYou may rave later. What does he say? Hmm-uh-huh-ídoesnít quite come up to what is expected-feel that de Meister isnít in his usual form-a little revision perhaps towards-feel sure the novel can be adjusted-are returning under separate cover-í ì
She tossed it aside. ìI told you you shouldnít have killed off Sancha Rodriguez. She was what you needed. Youíre getting skimpy on the love interest.î
ìYou write it! Iím through with de Meister. Itís getting so clubwomen call me Mr. de Meister, and my picture is printed in newspapers with the caption Mr. de Meister. I have no individuality. No one ever heard of Graham Dom. Iím always: Dom, Dom, you know, the guy who writes the de Meister stuff, you know.î
June squealed, ìSilly! Youíre jealous of your own detective.î
ìI am not jealous of my own character. Listen! I hate detective stories. I never read them after I got into the two-syllable words. I wrote the first as a clever, trenchant, biting satire. It was to blast the entire false school of mystery writers. Thatís why I invented this de Meister. He was the detective to end all detectives. The Compleat Ass, by Graham Dom.
ìSo the public, along with snakes, vipers, and ungrateful children takes this filth to its bosom. I wrote mystery after mystery trying to convert the publicî
Graham Dom drooped a little at the futility of it all.
ìOh, well.î He smiled wanly, and the great soul rose above adversity. ìDonít you see? Iíve got to write other things. I canít waste my life. But whoís going to read a serious novel by Graham Dorn, now that Iím so thoroughly identified with de Meister?î
ìYou can use a pseudonym.î
ìI will not use a pseudonym. Iím proud of my name.î
ìBut you canít drop de Meister. Be sensible, dear.î
ìAnormal fiancee,î Graham said bitterly, ìwould want her future husband to write something really worthwhile and become a great name in literature.î
ìWell, I do want you to, Graham. But just a little de Meister once in a while to pay the bills that accumulate.î
ìHa!î Graham knocked his hat over his eyes to hide the sufferings of a strong spirit in agony. ìNow you say that I canít reach prominence unless I prostitute my art to that unmentionable. Hereís your place. Get out Iím going home and write a good scorching letter on asbestos to our senile Mr. MacDunlap.î
ìDo exactly as you want to, cookie,î soothed June. ìAnd tomorrow when you feel better, youíll come and cry on my shoulder, and weíll plan a revision of Death on the Third Deck together, shall we?î
ìThe engagement, ì said Graham, loftily, ìis broken. ì
ìYes, dear. Iíll be home tomorrow at eightî
ìThat is of no possible interest to me. Good-bye!î
Publishers and editors are untouchables, of course. Theirs is a heritage of the outstretched hand and the well-toothed smile; the nod of the head and the slap of the back.
But perhaps somewhere, in the privacy of the holes to which authors scurry when the night falls, a private revenge is taken. There, phrases may be uttered where no one can overhear, and letters may be written that need not be mailed, and perhaps a picture of an editor, smiling pensively, is enshrined above the typewriter to act the part of bulls-eye in an occasional game of darts.
Such a picture of MacDunlap, so used, enlightened Graham Domís room. And Graham Dom himself, in his usual writing costume (street-clothes and typewriter), scowled at the fifth sheet of paper in his typewriter. The other four were draped over the edge of the wastebasket, condemned for their milk-and-watery mildness.
He began:
ìDear Sir-î and added slowly and viciously, ìor Madam, as the case may be.î
He typed furiously as the inspiration caught him, disregarding the faint wisp of smoke curling upward from the overheated keys:
ìYou say you donít think much of de Meister in this story. Well, I donít think much of de Meister, period. You can handcuff your slimy carcass to his and jump off the Brooklyn Bridge. And I hope they drain the East River just before you jump.
ìFrom now on, my works will be aimed higher than your scurvy press. And the day will come when I can look back on this period of my career with the loathing that is its just-î
Someone had been tapping Graham on the shoulder during the last paragraph. Graham twitched it angrily and ineffectively at intervals.
Now he stopped, turned around, and addressed the stranger in his room courteously: ìWho the devilish damnation are you? And you can leave without bothering to answer. I wonít think you rude.î
The newcomer smiled graciously. His nod wafted the delicate aroma of some unobtrusive hair-oil toward Graham. His lean, hard-bitten jaw stood out keenly, and he said in a well-modulated voice:
ìDe Meister is the name. Reginald de Meister.î
Graham rocked to his mental foundations and heard them creak.
ìGlub,î he said.
ìPardon?î
Graham recovered. ìI said, ëglub,í a little code word meaning which de Meister.î
ìThe de Meister,î explained de Meister, kindly. ìMy character? My detective?î
De Meister helped himself to a seat, and his finely-chiseled features assumed that air of well-bred boredom so admired in the best circles. He lit a Turkish cigarette, which Graham at once recognized as his detectiveís favorite brand, tapping it slowly and carefully against the back of his hand first, a mannerism equally characteristic.
ìReally, old man,î said de Meister. ìThis is really excruciatiníly funny. I suppose I am your charcter, yíknow, but letís not work on that basis. It would be so devastatiníly awkward.î
ìGlub,î said Graham again, by way of rejoinder.
His mind was feverishly setting up alternatives. He didnít drink, more, at the moment, was the pity, so he wasnít drunk. He had a chrome-steel digestion and he wasnít overheated, so it wasnít a hallucination. He never dreamed, and his imagination-as befitted a paying commodity-was under strict control. And since, like all authors, he was widely considered more than half a screwball, insanity was out of the question.
Which left de Meister simply an impossibility, and Graham felt relieved. Itís a very poor author indeed who hasnít learned the fine art of ignoring impossibilities in writing a book.
He said smoothly, ìI have here a volume of my latest work. Do you mind naming your page and crawling back into it. Iím a busy man and God knows I have enough of you in the tripe I write.î
ìBut Iím here on business, old chap. Iíve got to come to a friendly arrangement with you first. Things are deucedly uncomfortable as they are.î
ìLook, do you know youíre bothering me? Iím not in the habit of talking to mythical characters. As a general thing, I donít pal around with them. Besides which, itís time your mother told you that you really donít exist.î
ìMy dear fellow, I always existed. Existence is such a subjective thing. What a mind thinks exists, does exist. I existed in your mind, for instance, ever since you first thought of me.î
Graham shuddered. ìBut the question is, what are you doing out of my mind? Getting a little narrow for you? Want elbow room?î
ìNot at all. Rather satisfactíry mind in its way, but I achieved a more concrete existence only this afternoon, and so I seize the opportunity to engage you face to face in the aforementioned business conversation. You see, that thin, sentimental lady of your society-î
ìWhat society?î questioned Graham hollowly. It was all awfully clear to him now.
ìThe one at which you made a speech-î de Meister shuddered in his turn-îon the detective novel. She believed in my existence, so naturally, I exist.î
He finished his cigarette and flicked it out with a negligent twist of the wrist.
ìThe logic,î declared Graham, ìis inescapable. Now, what do you want and the answer is no.î
ìDo you realize, old man, that if you stop writing de Meister stories, my existence will become that dull, wraithlike one of all superannuated fictional detectives. Iíd have to gibber through the gray mists of Limbo with Holmes, Lecocq, and Dupin.î
ìA very fascinating thought, I think. A very fitting fate.î
Reginald de Meisterís eyes turned icy, and Graham suddenly remembered the passage on page 123 of The Case of the Broken Ashtray:
His eyes, hitherto lazy and unattentive, hardened into twin pools of blue ice and transfixed the butler, who staggered back, a stifled cry on his lips.
Evidently, de Meister lost none of his characteristics out of the novels he adorned.
Graham staggered back, a stifled cry on his lip.
De Meister said menacingly, ìIt would be better for you if the de Meister mysteries continue. Do you understand?î
Graham recovered and summoned a feeble indignation. ìNow, wait a while. Youíre getting out of hand. Remember: in a way, Iím your father. Thatís right. Your mental father. You canít hand me ultimatums or make threats. It isnít filial. Itís lacking in the proper respect and love.î
ìAnd another thing,î said de Meister, unmoved. ìWeíve got to straighten out this business of Letitia Reynolds. Itís gettiní deucedly boriní, yíknow:í
ìNow youíre getting silly. My love scenes have been widely heralded as miracles of tenderness and sentiment not found in one murder mystery out of a thousand. -Wait, Iíll get you a few reviews. I donít mind your attempts to dictate my actions so much, but Iím damned if youíll criticize my writing.î
ìForget the reviews. Tenderness and all that rot is what I donít want. Iíve been driftiní after the fair lady for five volumes now, and behaviní the most insufferable ass. This has got to stop.î
ìIn what way?î
ìIíve got to marry her in your present story. Either that, or make her a good, respectable mistress. And youíll have to stop making me so damned Victorian and gentlemanly towards ladies. Iím only human, old man.î
ìImpossible!î said Graham, ìand that includes your last remark.î
De Meister grew severe. ìReally, old chap, for an author, you display the most appalliní lack of concern for the well-beiní of a character who has supported you for a good many years.î
Graham choked eloquently. ìSupported me? In other words, you think I couldnít sell real novels, hey? Well, Iíll show you. I wouldnít write another de Meister story for a million dollars. Not even for a fifty percent royalty and all television rights. Howís that?î
De Meister frowned and uttered those words that had been the sound of doom to so many criminals: ìWe shall see, but you are not yet done with me.î
With firmly jutting jaw, he vanished.
Grahamís twisted face straightened out, and slowly-very slowly -he brought his hands up to his cranium and felt carefully.
For the first time in a long and reasonably ribald mental life, he felt that his enemies were right and that a good dry cleaning would not hurt his mind at all.
The things that existed in it!
Graham Dorn shoved the doorbell with his elbow a second time. He distinctly remembered her saying she would be home at eight
The peep-hole shoved open. ìHello!î
ìHello!î
Silence!
Graham said plaintively, ìItís raining outside. Canít I come in to dry?î
ìI donít know. Are we engaged, Mr. Dorn?î
ìIf Iím not,î was the stiff reply, ìthen Iíve been turning down the frenzied advances of a hundred passion-stricken girls-beautiful ones, all of them-for no apparent reason.î
ìYesterday, you said-î
ìAh, but who listens to what I say? Iím just quaint that way. Look, I brought you posies.î He flourished roses before the peep-hole.
June opened the door. ìRoses! How plebeian. Come in, cookie, and sully the sofa. Whoa, whoa, before you move a step, what have you got under the other arm? Not the manuscript of Death on the Third Deck?î
ìCorrect. Not that excrescence of a manuscript This is something differentî
Juneís tone chilled. ìThat isnít your precious novel, is it?î
Graham flung his head up, ìHow did you know about it?î
ìYou slobbered the plot all over me at MacDunlapís silver anniversary party.î
ìI did not I couldnít unless I were drunk.î
ìOh, but you were. Stinking is the term. And on two cocktails too.î
ìWell, if I was drunk, I couldnít have told you the right plotî
ìIs the setting a coal-mine district?î
ì-Uh-yes.î
ìAnd are the people concerned real, earthy, unartificial, down-to-earth characters, speaking and thinking just like you and me? Is it a story of basic economic forces? Are the human characters lifted up and thrown down and whirled around, all at the mercy of the coal mine and mechanized industry of today?î
ì-Uh-yes.î
She nodded her head retrospectively. ìI remember distinctly. First, you got drunk and were sick. Then you got better, and told me the first few chapters. Then I got sick.î
She approached the glowering author. ìGraham.î She leant her golden head upon his shoulder and cooed softly. ìWhy donít you continue with the de Meister stories? You get such pretty checks out of them.î
Graham writhed out of her grasp. ìYou are a mercenary wretch, incapable of understanding an authorís soul. You may consider our engagement broken.î
He sat down hard on the sofa, and folded his arms. ìUnless you will consent to read the script of my novel and give me the usual story analysis.î
ìMay I give you my analysis of Death on the Third Deck first?î
ìNo.î
ìGood! In the first place, your love interest is becoming sickening.î
ìIt is not.î Graham pointed his finger indignantly. ìIt breathes a sweet and sentimental fragrance, as of an older day. Iíve got the review here that says it.î He fumbled in his wallet.
ìOh, bullfeathers. Are you going to start quoting that guy in the Pillsboro (Okla.) Clarion? Heís probably your second cousin. You know that your last two novels were completely below par in royalties. And Third Deck isnít even being sold.î
ìSo much the better-Ow!î He rubbed his head violently. ìWhat did you do that for?î
ìBecause the only place I could hit as hard as I wanted to, without disabling you, was your head. Listen! The public is tired of your corny Letitia Reynolds. Why donít you let her soak her ëgleaming golden crown of hairí in kerosene and get familiar with a match?î
ìBut June, that character is drawn from life. From you!î
ìGraham Dorn! I am not here to listen to insults. The mystery market today is swinging towards action and hot, honest love and youíre still in the sweet, sentimental stickiness of five years ago.î
ìBut thatís Reginald de Meisterís character.î
ìWell, change his character. Listen! You introduce Sancha Rodriguez. Thatís fine. I approve of her. Sheís Mexican, flaming, passionate, sultry, and in love with him. So what do you do? First he behaves the impeccable gentleman, and then you kill her off in the middle of the story.î
ìHmm, I see-You really think it would improve things to have de Meister forget himself. A kiss or so-î
June clenched her lovely teeth and her lovely fists. ìOh, darling, how glad I am love is blind! If it ever peeked one tiny little bit, I couldnít stand it. Look, you squirrelís blue plate special, youíre going to have de Meister and Rodriquez fall in love. Theyíre going to have an affair through the entire book and you can put your horrible Letitia into a nunnery. She probably be happier there from the way you make her sound.î
ìThatís all you know about it, my sweet. It so happens that Reginald de Meister is in love with Letitia Reynolds and wants her, not this Roderiguez person.î
ìAnd what makes you think that?î
ìHe told me so.î
ìWho told you so?î
ìReginald de Meister.î
ìWhat Reginald de Meister?î
ì My Reginald de Meister.î
ìWhat do you mean, your Reginald de Meister?î
ìMy character, Reginald de Meister.î
June got up, indulged in some deep-breathing and then said in a very calm voice, ìLetís start all over.î
She disappeared for a moment and returned with an aspirin. ìyour Reginald de Meister, from your books, told you, in person, he was in love with Letitia Reynolds?î
ìThatís right.î
June swallowed the aspirin.
ìWell, Iíll explain, June, the way he explained it to me. All characters really exist-at least, in the minds of the authors. But when people really begin to believe in them, they begin to exist in reality, because what people believe in, is, so far as theyíre concerned, and what is existence anyway?î
Juneís lips trembled. ìOh, Gramie, please donít. Mother will never let me marry you if they put you in an asylum.î
ìDonít call me Gramie, June, for Godís sake. I tell you he was there, trying to tell me what to write and how to write it. He was almost as bad as you. Aw, come on, Baby, donít cry.î
ìI canít help it. I always thought you were crazy, but I never thought you were crazy!î
ìAll right, whatís the difference? Letís not talk about it, any more. Iím never going to write another mystery novel. After all-î (he indulged in a bit of indignation)-îwhen it gets so that my own character-my own character-tries to tell me what to do, itís going too farÖ
June looked over her handkerchief. ìHow do you know it was really de Meister?î
ìOh, golly. As soon as he tapped his Turkish cigarette on the back of his hand and started dropping gís like snowflakes in a blizzard, I knew the worst had come.î
The telephone rang. June leaped up. ìDonít answer, Graham. Itís probably from the asylum. Iíll tell them youíre not here. Hello. Hello. Oh, Mr. MacDunlapÖ She heaved a sigh of relief, then covered the mouthpiece and whispered horasely, ìIt might be a trap.î

ìGraham, youíre to lunch with MacDunlap tomorrowÖ
ìAt his expense! Only at his expense!î
Her great blue eyes got greater and bluer, ìAnd Reginald de Meister is to dine with youÖ
ìWhat Reginald de Meister?î
ìYour Reginald de Meister.î
ì My Reg-î

And her face crumpled into tears.
Grew S. MacDunlap (that the S. stands for ìSomeî is a vile untruth spread by his enemies) was alone at the table when Graham Dorn entered. Out of this fact, Graham extracted a few fleeting drops of pleasure.
It was not so much, you understand, the presence of MacDunlap that did it, as the absence of de Meister.
MacDunlap looked at him over his spectacles and swallowed a liver pill, his favorite sweetmeat
ìAha. Youíre here. What is this corny joke youíre putting over on me? You had no right to mix me up with a person like de Meister without warning me he was real. I might have taken precautions. I could have hired a bodyguard. I could have bought a revolver.î
ìHeís not real. God damn it! Half of him was your idea.
ìThat,î returned MacDunlap with heat, ìis libel. And what do you mean, heís not real? When he introduced himself, I took three liver pills at once and he didnít disappear. Do you know what three pills are? Three pills, the kind Iíve got (the doctor should only drop dead), could make an elephant disappear-if he werenít real. I know.î
Graham said wearily, ìJust the same, he exists only in my mind.î
ìIn your mind, I know he exists. Your mind should be investigated by the Pure Food and Drugs Act.î
The several polite rejoinders that occurred simultaneously to Graham were dismissed almost immediately as containing too great a proportion of pithy Anglo-Saxon expletives. After all-ha, ha-a publisher is a publisher however Anglo-Saxony he may be.
Graham said, ìThe question arises, then, how weíre to get rid of de Meister.î
ìGet rid of de Meister?î MacDunlap jerked the glasses off his nose in his sudden start, and caught them in one hand. His voice thickened with emotion. ìWho wants to get rid of him?î
ìDo you want him around?î
ìGod forbid,î MacDunlap said between shudders. ìNext to him, my brother-in-law is an angel.î
ìHe has no business outside my books.î
ìFor my part, he has no business inside them. Since I started reading your manuscripts, my doctor added kidney pills and cough syrups to my medicines.î He looked at his watch, and took a kidney pill. ìMy worst enemy should be a book publisher only a year.î
ìThen why,î asked Graham patiently, ìdonít you want to get rid of de Meister?î
ìBecause he is publicity.î
Graham stared blankly.
ìLook! What other writer has a real detective? All the others are fictional. Everyone knows that. But yours-yours is real. We can let him solve cases and have big newspaper writeups. Heíll make the Police Department look silly. Heíll make-î
ìThat, ì interrupted Graham, categorically, ìis by all odds the most obscene proposal I have ever had my ears manured with.î
ìIt will make money.î
ìMoney isnít everything.î
ìName one thing it isnítÖShh!î He kicked a near-fracture into Grahamís left ankle and rose to his feet with a convulsive smile, ìMI. de Meister!î
ìSorry, old dear,î came a lethargic voice. ìCouldnít quite make it, you know. Loads of engagements. Must have been most boriní for you.î
Graham Domís ears quivered spasmodically. He looked over his shoulder and reeled backward as far as a person could reel while in a sitting position. Reginald de Meister had sprouted a monocle since his last visitation, and his monocular glance was calculated to freeze blood.
De Meisterís greeting was casual. ìMy dear Watson! So glad to meet you. Overjoyed deucedly.î
ìWhy donít you go to hell?î Graham asked curiously.
ìMy dear fellow. Oh, my dear fellow.î
MacDunlap cackled, ìThatís what I like. Jokes! Fun! Makes everything pleasant to start with. Now shall we get down to business?î
ìCertainly. The dinner is on the way, I trust? Then Iíll just order a bottle of wine. The usual, Henry.î The waiter ceased hovering, Flew away, and skimmed back with a bottle that opened and gurgled into a glass.
De Meister sipped delicately, ìSo nice of you, old chap, to make me a habitue of this place in your stories. It holds true even now, and it is most convenient. The waiters all know me. Mr. MacDunlap, I take it you have convinced Mr. Dom of the necessity of continuing the de Meister stories.î
ìYes,î said MacDunlap. ì
ìNo,î said Graham.
ìDonít mind him,î said MacDunlap. ìHeís temperamental. You know these authors.î
ìDonít mind him,î said Graham. ìHeís microcephalic. You know these publishers.î
ìLook, old chappie. I take it MacDunlap hasnít pointed out to you the unpleasanter side of acting stubborn.î
ìFor instance what, old stinkie?î asked Graham, courteously.
ìWell, have you ever been haunted?î
ìLike coming behind me and saying, Boo?î
ìMy dear fellow, I say. Iím much more subtle than that. I can really haunt one in modem, up-to-date methods. For instance, have you ever had your individuality submerged?î
He snickered.
There was something familiar about that snicker. Graham suddenly remembered. It was on page 103 of Murder Rides the Range:
His lazy eyelids flicked down and up. He laughed lightly and melodiously, and though he said not a word, Hank Marslowe covered. There was hidden menace and hidden power in that light laugh, and somehow the burly rancher did not dare reach for his guns.
To Graham it still sounded like a nasty snicker, but he cowered, and did not dare reach for his guns.
MacDunlap plunged through the hole the momentary silence had created.
ìYou see, Graham. Why play around with ghosts? Ghosts arenít reasonable things. Theyíre not human! If itís more royalties, you want-î
Graham fired up. ìWill you refrain from speaking of money? From now on, I write only great novels of tearing human emotions.î
MacDunlapís flushed face changed suddenly. ì
ìNo,î he said.
ìIn fact, to change the subject just a moment-î and Grahamís tone became surpassingly sweet, as the words got all sticky with maple syrup-îI have a manuscript here for you to look at.î
He grasped the perspiring MacDunlap by the lapel firmly. ìIt is a novel that is the work of five years. A novel that will grip you with its intensity. A novel that will shake you to the core of your being. A novel that will open a new world. A novel that will-î
ìNo,î said MacDunlap.
ìA novel that will blast the falseness of this world. A novel that pierces to the truth. A novel-î
MacDunlap, being able to stretch his hand no higher, took the manuscript.
ìNo,î he said.
ìWhy the bloody hell donít you read it?î inquired Graham.
ìNow?î
ìWell, start it.î
ìLook, supposing I read it tomorrow, or even the next day. I have to take my cough syrup now.î
ìYou havenít coughed once since I got here.î
ìIíll let you know immediately-î
