MacDunlap read two paragraphs and said, ìIs this laid in a coalmining town?î
ìYes.î
ìThen I canít read it. Iím allergic to coal dust.î
ìBut itís not real coal dust, Mac Idiot.î
ìThat,î pointed out MacDunlap, ìis what you said about de Meister.î
Reginald de Meister tapped a cigarette carefully on the back of his hand in a subtle manner which Graham immediately recognized as betokening a sudden decision.
ìThat is all devastatiníly boriní, you know. Not quite gettiní to the point, you might say. Go ahead, MacDunlap, this is no time for half measures.î
MacDunlap girded his spiritual loins and said, ì All right Mister Dorn, with you itís no use being nice. Instead of de Meister, Iím getting coal dust. Instead of the best publicity in fifty years, Iím getting social significance. All right, Mister Smartaleck Dorn, if in one week you donít come to terms with me, good terms, you will be blacklisted in every reputable publishing firm in the United States and foreign parts.î He shook his finger and added in a shout, ìIncluding Scandinavian.î
Graham Dornlaughed lightly, ìPish,î he said, ìtush. I happen to be an officer of the Authorís Union, and if you try to push me around Iíll have you blacklisted. How do you like that?î
ìI like it fine. Because supposing I can prove youíre a plagiarist.î
ìMe,î gasped Graham, recovering narrowly from merry suffocation.
ìMe, the most original writer of the decade.î
ìIs that so? And maybe you donít remember that in each case you write up, you casually mention de Meisterís notebooks on previous cases.î
ìSo what?î
ìSo he has them. Reginald, my boy, show Mister Dom your notebook of your last case. -you see that. Thatís Mystery of the Milestones and it has, in detail, every incident in your book-and dated the year before the book was published. Very authentic.î
ìAgain so what?î
ìHave you maybe got the right to copy his notebook and call it an original murder mystery?î
ìWhy, you case of mental poliomyelitis, that notebook is my invention.î
ìWho says so? Itís in de Meisterís handwriting, as any expert can prove. And maybe you have a piece of paper, some little contract or agreement, you know, that gives you the right to use his notebooks?î
ìHow can I have an agreement with a mythical personage?î
ìWhat mythical personage?î
ìYou and I know de Meister doesnít exist.î
ìAh, but does the jury know? When I testify that I took three strong liver pills and he didnít disappear, what twelve men will say he doesnít exist?î
ìThis is blackmail.î
ìCertainly. Iíll give you a week. Or in other words, seven days.î
Graham Dorn turned desperately to de Meister. ìYouíre in on this, too. In my books I give you the keenest sense of honor. Is this honorable?î
De Meister shrugged. ìMy dear fellow. All this-and haunting, too.î
Graham rose.
ìWhere are you going?î
ìHome to write you a letter.î Grahamís brows beetled defiantly. ì And this time Iíll mail it. Iím not giving in. Iíll fight to the last ditch. And, de Meister, you let loose with one single little haunt and Iíll rip your head out of its socket and spurt the blood all over MacDunlapís new suit.î
He stalked out, and as he disappeared through the door, de Meister disappeared through nothing at all.
MacDunlap let out a soft yelp and then took a liver pill, a kidney pill, and a tablespoon of cough syrup in rapid succession.
Graham Dorn sat in Juneís front parlor, and having long since consumed his fingernails, was starting on the first knuckles.
June, at the moment, was not present, and this, Graham felt, was just as well. A dear girl; in fact, a dear, sweet girl But his mind was not on her.
It was concerned instead with a miasmic series of flashbacks over the preceding six days:
óSay, Graham, I met your side-kick at the club yesterday. You know, de Meister. Got an awful shock. I always had the idea he was a sort of Sherlock Holmes that didnít exist. Thatís one on me, boy. Didnít know-Hey, where are you going?
óHey, Dorn, I hear your boss de Meister is back in town. Ought to have material for more stories soon. Youíre lucky youíve got someone to grind out your plots ready-made-Huh? Well, goodbye.î
óWhy, Graham, darling, wherever were you last night? Annís affair didnít get anywhere without you; or at least, it wouldnít have, if it hadnít been for Reggie de Meister. He asked after you; but then, I guess he felt lost without his Watson. It must feel wonderful to Watson for such- Mister Dorn! And the same to you, sir!
óyou put one over on me. I thought you made up those wild things. Well, truth is stranger than fiction, ha, ha!
óPolice officials deny that the famous amateur criminologist Reginald de Meister has interested himself in this case. Mr. de Meister himself could not be reached by our reporters for comment. Mr. de Meister is best known to the public for his brilliant solutions to over a dozen crimes, as chronicled in fiction form by his so-called ìWatson,î Mr. Grayle Doone.
Graham quivered and his arms trembled in an awful desire for blood. De Meister was haunting him-but good. He was losing his individuality, exactly as had been threatened.
It gradually dawned upon Graham that the monotonous ringing noise he heard was not in his head, but, on the contrary, from the front door.
Such seemed likewise the opinion of Miss June Billings, whose piercing call shot down the stairs and biffed Graham a sharp uppercut to the ear-drums.
ìHey, dope, see whoís at the front door, before the vibration tears the house down. Iíll be down in half an hour.î
ìYes, dear!î
Graham shuffled his way to the front door and opened it.
ìAh, there. Greetinís,î said de Meister, and brushed past.
Grahamís dull eyes stared, and then fired high, as an animal snarl burst from his lips. He took up that gorilla posture, so comforting to red-blooded American males at moments like this, and circled the slightly-confused detective.
ìMy dear fellow, are you ill?î
ìI,î explained Graham, ìam not ill, but you will soon be past all interest in that, for I am going to bathe my hands in your heartís reddest blood.î
ìBut I say, youíll only have to wash them afterwards. It would be such an obvious clue, wouldnít it?î
ìEnough of this gay banter. Have you any last words?î
ìNot particularly.î
ìItís just as well. Iím not interested in your last words.î
He thundered into action, bearing down upon the unfortunate de Meister like a bull elephant. De Meister faded to the left, shot out an arm and a foot, and Graham described a parabolic arc that ended in the total destruction of an end table, a vase of flowers, a fish-bowl, and a five-foot section of wall.
Graham blinked, and brushed away a curious goldfish from his left eyebrow.
ìMy dear fellow,î murmured de Meister, ìoh, my dear fellow.î
Too late, Graham remembered that passage in Pistol Parade:
De Meisterís arms were whipcord lightning, as with sure, rapid thrusts, he rendered the two thugs helpless. Not by brute force, but by his expert knowledge of judo, he defeated them easily without hastening his breath. The thugs groaned in pain.
Graham groaned in pain.
He lifted his right thigh an inch or so to let his femur slip back into place.
ìHadnít you better get up, old chap?î
ìI will stay here,î said Graham with dignity, ìand contemplate the floor in profile view, until such time as it suits me or until such time as I find myself capable of moving a muscle. I donít care which. And now, before I proceed to take further measures with you, what the hell do you want?î
Reginald de Meister adjusted his monocle to a nicety. ìYou know, I suppose, that MacDunlapís ultimatum expires tomorrow?î
ìAnd you and he with it, I trust.î
ìYou will not reconsider.î
ìHa!î
ìReally,î de Meister sighed, ìthis is boriní no end. You have made things comfortable for me in this world. After all, in your books youíve made me well-known in all the clubs and better restaurants, the bosom friend, yíknow, of the mayor and commissioner of police, the owner of a Park Avenue penthouse and a magnificent art collection. And it all lingers over, old chap. Really quite afIectiní.î
ìIt is remarkable,î mused Graham, ìthe intensity with which I am not listening and the distinctness with which I do not hear a word you say.î
ìStill,î said de Meister, ìthere is no denyiní my book world suits me better. It is somehow more fascinatiní, freer from dull logic, more apart from the necessities of the world. In short, I must go back, and to active participation. You have till tomorrow!î
Graham hummed a gay little tune with flat little notes.
ìIs this a new threat, de Meister?î
ìIt is the old threat intensified. Iím going to rob you of every vestige of your personality. And eventually public opinion will force you to write as, to paraphrase you, de Meisterís Compleat Stooge. Did you see the name the newspaper chappies pinned on you today, old man?î
ìYes, Mr. Filthy de Meister, and did you read a half-column item on page ten in the same paper. Iíll read it for you: ëNoted Criminologist in l-A. Will be inducted shortly draft board says.îë
For a moment, de Meister said and did nothing. And then one, after another, he did the following things: removed his monocle slowly, sat down heavily, rubbed his chin abstractedly, and lit a cigarette after long and careful tamping. Each of these, Graham Dornís trained authorial eye recognized as singly representing perturbation and distress on the part of his character.
And never, in any of his books, did Graham remember a time when de Meister had gone through all four consecutively.
Finally, de Meister spoke. ìWhy you had to bring up draft registrations in your last book, I really donít know. This urge to be topical; this fiendish desire to be up to the minute with the news is the curse of the mystery novel. A true mystery is timeless; should have no relation to current events; should-î
ìThere is one way,î said Graham, ìto escape induction-î
ìYou might at least have mentioned a deferred classification on some vital ground.î
ìThere is one way,î said Graham, ìto escape induction-î
ìCriminal negligence,î said de Meister.
ìLook! Go back to the books and youíll never be filled with lead.î
ìWrite them and Iíll do it.î
ìThink of the war.î
ìThink of your ego.î
Two strong men stood face to face (or would have, if Graham werenít still horizontal) and neither flinched.
Impasse!
And the sweet, feminine voice of June Billings interrupted and snapped the tension:
ìMay I ask, Graham Dom, what you are doing on the floor. Itís been swept today and youíre not complimenting me by attempting to improve the job.î
ìI am not sweeping the floor. If you looked carefully,î replied Graham gently, ìyou would see that your own adored fiance is lying here a mass of bruises and a hotbed of pains and aches.î
ìYouíve ruined my end table!î
ìIíve broken my leg.î
ìAnd my best lamp.î
ìAnd two ribs.î
ìAnd my fishbowl.î
ìAnd my Adamís apple.î
ìAnd you havenít introduced your friend.î
ìAnd my cervical verte-What friend?î
ìThis friend.î
ìFriend! Ha!î And a mist came over his eyes. She was so young, so fragile to come into contact with hard, brutal facts of life. ìThis,î he muttered brokenly, ìis Reginald de Meister.î
De Meister at this point broke a cigarette sharply in two, a gesture pregnant with the deepest emotion.
June said slowly, ìWhy-why, youíre different from what I had thought.î
ìHow had you expected me to look?î asked de Meister, in soft, thrilling tones.
ìI donít know. Differently than you do,-from the stories I heard.î
ìYou remind me, somehow, Miss Billings, of Letitia Reynolds.î
ìI think so. Graham said he drew her from me.î
ìA very poor imitation, Miss Billings. Devastatiníly poor.î
They were six inches apart now, eyes fixed with a mutual glue, and Graham yelled sharply. He sprang upright as memory smote him a nasty smite on the forehead.
A passage from Case of the Muddy Overshoe occurred to him. Likewise one from The Primrose Murders. Also one from The Tragedy of Hartley Manor, Death of a Hunter, White Scorpion and, to put it in a small nutshell, from every one of the others.
The passage read:
There was a certain fascination about de Meister that appealed irresistibly to women.
And June Billings was-as it had often, in Grahamís idler moments, occurred to him-a woman.
And fascination simply gooed out of her ears and coated the floor six inches deep.
ìGet out of this room, June,î he ordered.
ìI will not.î
ìThere is something I must discuss with MI. de Meister, man to man. I demand that you leave this room.î
ìPlease go, Miss Billings,î said de Meister.
June hesitated, and in a very small voice said, ìVery well.î
ìHold on,î shouted Graham. ìDonít let him order you about. I demand that you stay.î
She closed the door very gently behind her.
The two men faced each other. There was that in either pair of eyes that indicated a strong man brought to bay. There was stubborn, undying antagonism; no quarter; no compromise. It was exactly the sort of situation Graham Dom always presented his readers with, when two strong men fought for one hand, one heart, one girl.
The two said simultaneously, ìLetís make a deal!î
Graham said, ìYou have convinced me, Reggie. Our public needs us. Tomorrow I shall begin another de Meister story. Let us shake hands and forget the past.î
De Meister struggled with his emotion. He laid his hand on Grahamís lapel, ìMy dear fellow, it is I who have been convinced by your logic. I canít allow you to sacrifice yourself for me. There are great things in you that must be brought out. Write your coal-mining novels. They count, not I.î
ìI couldnít, old chap. Not after all youíve done for me, and all youíve meant to me. Tomorrow we start anew.î
ìGraham, my-my spiritual father, I couldnít allow it. Do you think I have no feelings, filial feelings-in a spiritual sort of way.î
ìBut the war, think of the war. Mangled limbs. Blood All that.î
ìI must stay. My country needs me.î
ìBut if I stop writing, eventually you will stop existing. I canít allow that.î
ìOh, that!î De Meister laughed with a careless elegance. ìThings have changed since. So many people believe in my existence now that my grip upon actual existence has become too firm to be broken. I donít have to worry about Limbo any more.î
ìOh.î Graham clenched his teeth and spoke in searing sibilants: ìSo thatís your scheme, you snake. Do you suppose I donít see youíre stuck on June?î
ìLook here, old chap,î said de Meister haughtily. ìI canít permit you to speak slightingly of a true and honest love. I love June and she loves me-I know it. And if youíre going to be stuffy and Victorian about it, you can swallow some nitro-glycerine and tap yourself with a hammer.î
ìIíll nitro-glycerine you! Because Iím going home tonight and beginning another de Meister story. Youíll be part of it and youíll get back into it, and what do you think of that?î
ìNothing, because you canít write another de Meister story. Iím too real now, and you canít control me just like that. And what do you think of that?î
It took Graham Dom a week to make up his mind what to think of that, and then his thoughts were completely and startlingly unprintable.
In fact, it was impossible to write.
That is, startling ideas occurred to him for great novels, emotional dramas, epic poems, brilliant essays-but he couldnít write anything about Reginald de Meister.
The typewriter was simply fresh out of Capital Rís.
Graham wept, cursed, tore his hair, and anointed his finger tips with liniment. He tried typewriter, pen, pencil, crayon, charcoal, and blood.
He could not write.
The doorbell rang, and Graham threw it open.
MacDunlap stumbled in, falling over the first drifts of torn paper directly into Grahamís arms.
Graham let him drop. ìHah!î he said, with frozen dignity.
ìMy heart!î said MacDunlap, and fumbled for his liver pills.
ìDonít die there,î suggested Graham, courteously. ìThe management wonít permit me to drop human flesh into the incinerator.î
ìGraham, my boy,î MacDunlap said, emotionally, ìno more ultimatums! No more threats! I come now to appeal to your finer feelings, Graham-î he went through a slight choking interlude-îI love you like a son. This skunk de Meister must disappear. You must write more de Meister stories for my sake. Graham-I will tell you something in private. My wife is in love with this detective. She tells me I am not romantic. I! Not romantic! Can you understand it?î
ìI can,î was the tragic response. ìHe fascinates all women.î
ìWith that face? With that monocle?î
ìIt says so in all my books.î
MacDunlap stiffened. ìAh ha. You again. Dope! If only you ever stopped long enough to let your mind know what your typewriter was saying.î
ìYou insisted. Feminine trade.î Graham didnít care any more. Women! He snickered bitterly. Nothing wrong with any of them that a block-buster wouldnít fix.
MacDunlap hemmed. ìWell, feminine trade. Very necessary. -but Graham, what shall I do? Itís not only my wife. She owns fifty shares in MacDunlap, Inc. in her own name. If she leaves me, I lose control. Think of it, Graham. The catastrophe to the publishing world.î
ìGrew, old chap,î Graham sighed a sigh so deep, his toenails quivered sympathetically. ìI might as well tell you. June, my fiancee, you know, loves this worm. And he loves her because she is the prototype of Letitia Reynolds.î
ìThe what of Letitia?î asked MacDunlap, vaguely suspecting an insult.
ìNever mind. My life is ruined.î He smiled bravely and choked back the unmanly tears, after the first two had dripped off the end of his nose.
ìMy poor boy!î The two gripped hands convulsively.
ìCaught in a vise by this foul monster,î said Graham.
ìTrapped like a German in Russia,î said MacDunlap.
ìVictim of an inhuman fiend,î said Graham.
ìExactly,î said MacDunlap. He wrung Grahamís hand as if he were milking a cow. ìYouíve got to write de Meister stories and get him back where, next to Hell, he most belongs. Right?î
ìRight! But thereís one little catch.î
ìWhat?î
ìI canít write. Heís so real now, I canít put him into a book.î
MacDunlap caught the significance of the massed drifts of used paper on the floor. He held his head and groaned, ìMy corporation! My wife!î
ìThereís always the Army,î said Graham.
MacDunlap looked up. ìWhat about Death on the Third Deck, the novel I rejected three weeks ago?î
ìThat doesnít count. Itís past history. Itís already affected him.î
ìWithout being published?î
ìSure. Thatís the story I mentioned his draft board in. The one that put him in l-A.î
ìI could think of better places to put him.î
ìMacDunlap!î Graham Dorn jumped up, and grappled MacDunlapís lapel. ìMaybe it can be revised.î
MacDunlap coughed hackingly, and stifled out a dim grunt.
ìWe can put anything we want into it.î MacDunlap choked a bit.
ìWe can fix things up.î
MacDunlap turned blue in the face.
Graham shook the lapel and everything thereto attached, ìSay something, wonít you?î
MacDunlap wrenched away and took a tablespoon of cough syrup. He held his hand over his heart and patted it a bit. He shook his head and gestured with his eyebrows.
Graham shrugged. ìWell, if you just want to be sullen, go ahead. Iíll revise it without you.î
He located the manuscript and tried his fingers gingerly on the typewriter. They went smoothly, with practically no creaking at the joints. He put on speed, more speed, and then went into his usual race, with the portable jouncing along merrily under the accustomed head of steam.
ìItís working,î he shouted. ìI canít write new stories, but I can revise old, unpublished ones.î
MacDunlap watched over his shoulder. He breathed only at odd moments.
ìFaster,î said MacDunlap, ìfaster!î
ìFaster than thirty-five?î said Graham, sternly. ìOPA [The Office of Price Administration was in charge of gasoline rationing at this period. Remember ìAîstickers? D.R.B.] forbid! Five more minutes.î
ìWill he be there?î
ìHeís always there. Heís been at her house every evening this week.î He spat out the fine ivory dust into which he had ground the last inch of his incisors. ìBut God help you if your secretary falls down on the job.î
ìMy boy, on my secretary you can depend.î
ìSheís got to read that revision by nine.î
ìIfshe doesnít drop dead.î
ìWith my luck, she will. Will she believe it?î
ìEvery word. Sheís seen de Meister. She knows he exists.î
Brakes screeched, and Grahamís soul cringed in sympathy with every molecule of rubber frictioned off the tires.
He bounded up the stairs, MacDunlap hobbling after.
He rang the bell and burst in at the door. Reginald de Meister standing directly inside received the full impact of a pointing finger, and only a rapid backward movement of the head kept him from becoming a one-eyed mythical character.
June Billings stood aside, silent and uncomfortable.
ìReginald de Meister,î growled Graham, in sinister tones, ìprepare to meet your doom.î
ìOh, boy,î said MacDunlap, ìare you going to get it.î
ìAnd to what,î asked de Meister, ìam I indebted for your dramatic but unilluminatiní statement? Confusiní, donít you know.î He lit a cigarette with a fine gesture and smiled.
ìHello, Gramie,î said June, tearfully. ì
ìScram, vile woman.î
June sniffed. She felt like a heroine out of a book, tom by her own emotions. Naturally, she was having the time of her life.
So she let the tears dribble and looked forlorn.
ìTo return to the subject, what is this all about?î asked de Meister, wearily.
ìI have rewritten Death on the Third Deck.î
ìWell?î
ìThe revision,î continued Graham, ìis at present in the hands of MacDunlapís secretary, a girl on the style of Miss Billings, my fiancee that was. That is, she is a girl who aspires to the status of a moron, but has not yet quite attained it. Sheíll believe every word. ì
ìWell?î
Grahamís voice grew ominous, ìYou remember, perhaps, Sancho Rodriguez?î
For the first time, Reginald de Meister shuddered. He caught his cigarette as it dropped. ìShe was killed by Sam Blake in the sixth chapter. She was in love with me. Really, old fellow, what messes you get me into.î
ìNot half the mess youíre in now, old chap. Sancha Rodriguez did not die in the revision.î
ìDie!î came a sharp, but clear female voice, ìIíll show him if I died. And where have you been this last month, you two-crosser?î
De Meister did not catch his cigarette this time. He didnít even try. He recognized the apparition. To an unprejudiced observer, it might have been merely a svelte Latin girl equipped with dark, flashing eyes, and long, glittering fingernails, but to de Meister, it was Sancha Rodriguez -undead!
MacDunlapís secretary had read and believed.
ìMiss Rodriguez,î throbbed de Meister, charmingly, ìhow fascinatiní to see you.î
ìMrs. de Meister to you, you double-timer, you two-crosser, you scum of the ground, you scorpion of the grass. And who is this woman?î
June retreated with dignity behind the nearest chair.
Mrs. de Meister,î said Reginald pleadingly, and turned helplessly to Graham Dom.
ìOh, you have forgotten, have you, you smooth talker, you low dog. Iíll show you what it means to deceive a weak woman. Iíll make you mince-meat with my fingernails.î
De Meister back-pedaled furiously. ìBut darling-î
ìDonít you make sweet talk. What are you doing with this woman?î
ìBut, darling-î
ìDonít give me any explanation. What are you doing with this woman?î
ìBut darling-î
ìShut up! What are you doing with this woman?î
Reginald de Meister was up in a comer, and Mrs. de Meister shook her fists at him. ì Answer me?î
De Meister disappeared.
Mrs. de Meister disappeared right after him. June Billings collapsed into real tears.
Graham Dorn folded his arms and looked sternly at her. MacDunlap rubbed his hands and took a kidney pill.
ìIt wasnít my fault, Gramie,î said June. ìYou said in your books he fascinated all women, so I couldnít help it. Deep inside, I hated him all along. You believe me, donít you?î
ìA likely story!î said Graham, sitting down next to her on the sofa. ì A likely story. But I forgive you, maybe.î
MacDunlap said tremulously, ìMy boy, you have saved my stocks. Also, my wife, of course. And remember-you promised me one de Meister story each year.î
Graham gritted, ìJust one, and Iíll henpeck him to death, and keep one unpublished story forever on hand, just in case. And youíre publishing my novel, arenít you, Grew, old boy?î
ìGlug,î said MacDunlap.
ìArenít you?î
ìYes, Graham. Of course, Graham. Definitely, Graham. Positively, Graham.î
ìThen leave us now. There are matters of importance I must discuss with my fiancee.î
MacDunlap smiled and tiptoed out the door.
Ah, love, love, he mused, as he took a liver pill and followed it up by a cough-syrup chaser.



***



I might make two points aboutî Author! Author!î It seems to me that I was rather easier about handling romance in this story than in any previous one. Perhaps this is a reflection of the fact that it was the first story I ever wrote as a married man.
Secondly, there are the very dated references to rationing, the draft, and other social phenomena much on the mind of anyone living through World War II. I had warned Bensen of the existence of these references and of the inability of getting them out of the story by revision since they were integral to the plot. Bensen, however, shrugged them off and in his short introduction to the story said to the readers, ì And donít worry about the references to the OPA and Selective Service-consider them as part of the historical setting, just as you would a bodkin or a furbelow in a story of an earlier time.î
And I second that statement here.
Had I rested on the pink cloud of gratification that came with the sale of ì Author! Author!î for a few months, the death of Unknown might have disheartened me. It might have seemed to prove that I was not fated to reignite my career after all, and perhaps-again-everything would have turned out differently.
However, within three weeks of the sale I was at the typewriter again. The new story was ìDeath Sentenceî and it was science fiction. Writing was still slow work; seven weeks to do a 7,200-word story. On June 29, 1943, however, I sent it off to Campbell, and on July 8, it was accepted-one and a quarter cents per word again.
This meant that when the news of Unknownís demise arrived, it was cushioned by the fact that I already had another story written and sold.








Death Sentence


Brand Gorla smiled uncomfortably, ìThese things exaggerate, you know.î
ìNo, no, no!î The little manís albino-pink eyes snapped. ìDorlis was great when no human had ever entered the Vegan System. It was the capital of a Galactic Confederation greater than ours.î
ìWell, then, letís say that it was an ancient capital. Iíll admit that and leave the rest to an archaeologist.î
ìArchaeologists are no use. What Iíve discovered needs a specialist in its own field. And youíre on the Board.î
Brand Gorla looked doubtful. He remembered Theor Realo in senior year-a little white misfit of a human who skulked somewhere in the background of his reminiscences. It had been a long time ago, but the albino had been queer. That was easy to remember. And he was still queer.
ìIíll try to help,î Brand said, ìif youíll tell me what you want.î
Theor watched intently, ìI want you to place certain facts before the Board. Will you promise that?î
Brand hedged, ìEven if I help you along, Theor, Iíll have to remind you that Iím junior member of the Psychological Board. I havenít much influence.î
ìYou must do your best. The facts will speak for themselves.î The albinoís hands were trembling.
ìGo ahead.î Brand resigned himself. The man was an old school fellow. You couldnít be too arbitrary about things.
Brand Gorla leaned back and relaxed. The light of Arcturus shone through the ceiling-high windows, diffused and mellowed by the polarizing glass. Even this diluted version of sunlight was too much for the pink eyes of the other, and he shaded his eyes as he spoke.
ìIíve lived on Dorlis twenty-five years, Brand,î he said, ìIíve poked into places no one today knew existed, and Iíve found things. Dorlis was the scientific and cultural capital of a civilization greater than ours. Yes it was, and particularly in psychology.î
ìThings in the past always seem greater.î Brand condescended a smile. ìThere is a theorem to that effect which youíll find in any elementary text. Freshmen invariably call it the ìCOD Theorem.î Stands for ëGood-Old-Days,í you know. But go on.î
Theor frowned at the digression. He hid the beginning of a sneer, ìYou can always dismiss an uncomfortable fact by pinning a dowdy label to it. But tell me this. What do you know of Psychological Engineering?î
Brand shrugged, ìNo such thing. Anyway, not in the strict mathematical sense. All propaganda and advertising is a crude form of hit-and-miss Psych Engineering-and pretty effective sometimes. Maybe thatís what you mean.î
ìNot at all. I mean actual experimentation, with masses of people, under controlled conditions, and over a period of years.î
ìSuch things have been discussed. Itís not feasible in practice. Our social structure couldnít stand much of it, and we donít know enough to set up effective controls.î
Theor suppressed excitement, ìBut the ancients did know enough. And they did set up controls.î
Brand considered phlegmatically, ìStartling and interesting, but how do you know?î
ìBecause I found the documents relating to it.î He paused breathlessly. ìAn entire planet, Brand. A complete world picked to suit, peopled with beings under strict control from every angle. Studied, and charted, and experimented upon. Donít you get the picture?î
Brand noted none of the usual stigmata of mental uncontrol. A closer investigation, perhaps
He said evenly, ìYou must have been misled. Itís thoroughly impossible. You canít control humans like that. Too many variables.î
ìAnd thatís the point, Brand. They werenít humans.î
ìWhat?î
ìThey were robots, positronic robots. A whole world of them, Brand, with nothing to do but live and react and be observed by a set of psychologists that were Teal psychologists.î
ìThatís mad!î
ìI have proof-because that robot world still exists. The First Confederation went to pieces, but that robot world kept on going. It still exists.î
ìAnd how do you know?î
Theor Realo stood up. ìBecause Iíve been there these last twenty-five years!î
The Board Master threw his formal red-edged gown aside and reached into a pocket for a long, gnarled and decidedly unofficial cigar.
ìPreposterous,î he grunted, ìand thoroughly insane.î
ìExactly,î said Brand, ìand I canít spring it on the Board just like that. They wouldnít listen. Iíve got to get this across to you first, and then, if you can put your authority behind it-î
ìOh, nuts! I never heard anything as-Who is the fellow?î
Brand sighed, ì A crank, Iíll admit that. He was in my class at Arcturus u. and a crack-pot albino even then. Maladjusted as the devil, hipped on ancient history, and just the kind that gets an idea and goes through with it by plain. dumb plugging. Heís poked about in Dorlis for twenty-five years, he says. Heís got the complete records of practically an entire civilization.î
The Board Master puffed furiously. ìYeah, I know. In the telestat serials, the brilliant amateur always uncovers the great things. The free lance. The lone wolf. Nuts! Have you consulted the Department of Archaeology?î
ìCertainly. And the result was interesting. No one bothers with Dorlis. This isnít just ancient history, you see. Itís a matter of fifteen thousand years. Itís practically myth. Reputable archaeologists donít waste too much time with it. Itís just the thing a book-struck layman with a single-track mind would uncover. After this, of course, if the business turns out right, Dorlis will become an archaeologistís paradise.î
The Board Master screwed his homely face into an appalling grimace. ìItís very unflattering to the ego. If thereís any truth in all this, the so-called First Confederation must have had a grasp of psychology so far past ours, as to make us out to be blithering imbeciles. Too, theyíd have to build positronic robots that would be about seventy-five orders of magnitude above anything weíve even blueprinted. Galaxy! Think of the mathematics involved.î
ìLook, sir, Iíve consulted just about everybody. I wouldnít bring this thing to you if I werenít certain that I had every angle checked. I went to Blak just about the first thing, and heís consultant mathematician to United Robots. He says thereís no limit to these things. Given the time, the money, and the advance in psychology- getthat-robots like that could be built right now.î
ìWhat proof has he?î
ìWho, Blak?î
ìNo, no! Your friend. The albino. You said he had papers.î
ìHe has. Iíve got them here. Heís got documents-and thereís no denying their antiquity. Iíve had that checked every way from Sunday. I canít read them, of course. I donít know if anyone can, except Theor Realo.î
ìThatís stacking the deck, isnít it? We have to take his say-so.î
ìYes, in a way. But he doesnít claim to be able to decipher more than portions. He says it is related to ancient Centaurian, and Iíve put linguists to work on it. It can be cracked and if his translation isnít accurate, weíll know about it.î
ìAll right. Letís see it.î
Brand Gorla brought out the plastic-mounted documents. The Board Master tossed them aside and reached for the translation. Smoke billowed as he read.
ìHumph,î was his comment. ìFurther details are on Dorlis, I suppose.î
ìTheor claims that there are some hundred to two hundred tons of blueprints altogether, on the brain plan of the positronic robots alone. Theyíre still there in the original vault. But thatís the least of it. Heís been on the robot world itself. Heís got photocasts, teletype recordings, all sorts of details. Theyíre not integrated, and obviously the work of a layman who knows next to nothing about psychology. Even so, heís managed to get enough data to prove pretty conclusively that the world he was on wasnítÖuhÖnatural.î
ìYouíve got that with you, too.î
ìAll of it. Most of itís on microfilm, but Iíve brought the projector. Here are your eyepieces.î
An hour later, the Board Master said, ìIíll call a Board Meeting tomorrow and push this through.î
Brand Gorla grinned tightly, ìWeíll send a commission to Dorlis?î
ìWhen,î said the Board Master dryly, ìand if we can get an appropriation out of the University for such an affair. Leave this material with me for the while, please. I want to study it a little more.î
Theoretically, the Governmental Department of Science and Technology exercises administrative control over all scientific investigation. Actually, however, the pure research groups of the large universities are thoroughly autonomous bodies, and, as a general rule, the Government does not care to dispute that. But a general rule is not necessarily a universal rule.
And so, although the Board Master scowled and fumed and swore, there was no way of refusing Wynne Murry an interview. To give Murry his complete title, he was under secretary in charge of psychology, psychopathy and mental technology. And he was a pretty fair psychologist in his own right.
So the Board Master might glare, but that was all.
Secretary Murry ignored the glare cheerfully. He rubbed his long chin against the grain and said, ìIt amounts to a case of insufficient information. Shall we put it that way?î
The Board Master said frigidly, ìI donít see what information you want. The governmentís say in university appropriations is purely advisory, and in this case, I might say, the advice is unwelcome.î
Murry shrugged, ìI have no quarrel with the appropriation. But youíre not going to leave the planet without government permit. Thatís where the insufficient information comes in.î
ìThere is no information other than weíve given you.î
ìBut things have leaked out. All this is childish and rather unnecessary secrecy.
The old psychologist flushed. ìSecrecy! If you donít know the academic way of life, I canít help you. Investigations, especially those of major importance, arenít, and canít be, made public, until definite progress has been made. When we get back, weíll send you copies of whatever papers we publish.î
Murry shook his head, ìUh-uh. Not enough. Youíre going to Dorlis, arenít you?î
ìWeíve informed the Department of Science of that.î
ìWhy?î
ìWhy do you want to know?î
ìBecause itís big, or the Board Master wouldnít go himself. Whatís this about an older civilization and a world of robots?î
ìWell, then, you know.î
ìOnly vague notions weíve been able to scrabble up. I want the details.î
ìThere are none that we know now. We wonít know until weíre on Dorlis.î
ìThen Iím going with you.î
ìWhat!î
ìYou see, I want the details, too.î
ìWhy?î
ìAh,î Murry unfolded his legs and stood up, ìnow youíre asking the questions. Itís no use, now. I know that the universities arenít keen on government supervision; and I know that I can expect no willing help from any academic source. But, by Arcturus, Iím going to get help this time, and I donít care how you fight it. Your expedition is going nowhere, unless I go with you-representing the government. ì
Dorlis, as a world, is not impressive. Itís importance to Galactic economy is nil, its position far off the great trade routes, its natives backward and unenlightened, its history obscure. And yet somewhere in the heaps of rubble that clutter an ancient world, there is obscure evidence of an influx of flame and destruction that destroyed the Dorlis of an earlier day-the greater capital of a greater Federation.
And somewhere in that rubble, men of a newer world poked and probed and tried to understand.
The Board Master shook his head and then pushed back his grizzling hair. He hadnít shaved in a week.
ìThe trouble is,î he said, ìthat we have no point of reference. The language can be broken, I suppose, but nothing can be done with the notation.î
ìI think a great deal has been done.î
ìStabs in the dark! Guessing games based on the translations of your albino friend. I wonít base any hopes on that.î
Brand said, ìNuts! You spent two years on the Nimian Anomaly, and so far only two months on this, which happens to be a hundred thousand times the job. Itís something else thatís getting you.î He smiled grimly. ìIt doesnít take a psychologist to see that the government man is in your hair.î
The Board Master bit the end off a cigar and spat it four feet. He said slowly, ìThere are three things about the mule-headed idiot that make me sore. First, I donít like government interference. Second, I donít like a stranger sniffing about when weíre on top of the biggest thing in the history of psychology. Third, what in the Galaxy does he want? What is he after?î
ìI donít know.î
ìWhat should he be after? Have you thought of it at all?î
ìNo. Frankly, I donít care. Iíd ignore him if I were you.î
ìYou would,î said the Board Master violently. ìYou would! You think the governmentís entrance into this affair need only be ignored. I suppose you know that this Murry calls himself a psychologist?î
ìI know that.î
ìAnd I suppose you know heís been displaying a devouring interest in all that weíve veen doing.î
ìThat, I should say, would be natural.î
ìOh! And you know further-î His voice dropped with startling suddenness. ìAll right, Murryís at the door. Take it easy.î
Wynne Murry grinned a greeting, but the Board Master nodded unsmilingly.
ìWell, sir,î said Murry bluffly, ìdo you know Iíve been on my feet for forty-eight hours? Youíve got something here. Something big.î
ìThank you.î
ìNo, no. Iím serious. The robot world exists.î
ìDid you think it didnít?î
The secretary shrugged amiably. ìOne has a certain natural skepticism. What are your future plans?î
ìWhy do you ask?î The Board Master grunted his words as if they were being squeezed out singly.
ìTo see if they jibe with my own.î
ìAnd what are your own?î
The secretary smiled. ìNo, no. You take precedence. How long do you intend staying here?î
ìAs long as it takes to make a fair beginning on the documents involved.î
ìThatís no answer. What do you mean by a fair beginning?î
ìI havenít the slightest idea. Itmight take years.î
ìOh, damnation.î
The Board Master raised his eyebrows and said nothing.
The secretary looked at his nails. ìI take it you know the location of this robot world.î
ìNaturally. Theor Realo was there. His information up to now has proven very accurate.î
ìThatís right. The albino. Well, why not go there?î
ìGo there! Impossible!î
ìMay I ask why?î
ìLook,î said the Board Master with restrained impatience, ìyouíre not here by our invitation, and weíre not asking you to dictate our course of actions, but just to show you that Iím not looking for a fight, Iíll give you a little metaphorical treatment of our case. Suppose we were presented with a huge and complicated machine, composed of principles and materials of which we knew next to nothing. It is so vast we canít even make out the relationship of the parts, let alone the purpose of the whole. Now, would you advise me to begin attacking the delicate mysterious moving parts of the machine with a detonating ray before I know what itís all about?î
ìI see your point, of course, but youíre becoming a mystic. The metaphor is farfetched.î
ìNot at all. These positronic robots were constructed along lines we know nothing of as yet and were intended to follow lines with which we are entirely unacquainted. About the only thing we know is that the robots were put aside in complete isolation, to work out their destiny by themselves. To ruin that isolation would be to ruin the experiment. If we go there in a body, introducing new, unforeseen factors, inducing unintended reactions, everything is ruined. The littlest disturbance-î
ìPoppycock! Theor Realo has already gone there.î
The Board Master lost his temper suddenly. ìDonít you suppose I know that? Do you suppose it would ever have happened if that cursed albino hadnít been an ignorant fanatic without any knowledge of psychology at all? Galaxy knows what the idiot has done in the way of damage.î
There was a silence. The secretary clicked his teeth with a thoughtful fingernail. ìI donít knowÖI donít know. But Iíve got to find out. And I canít wait years.î
He left, and the Board Master turned seethingly to Brand, ì And how are we going to stop him from going to the robot world if he wants to?î
ìI donít see how he can go if we donít let him. He doesnít head the expedition.î
ìOh, doesnít he? Thatís what I was about to tell you just before he came in. Ten ships of the fleet have landed on Dorlis since we arrived.î
ìWhat!î
ìJust that.î
ìBut what for?î
ìThat, my boy, is what I donít understand, eitherÖ
ìMind if I drop in?î said Wynne Murry, pleasantly, and Theor Realo looked up in sudden anxiety from the papers that lay in hopeless disarray on the desk before him.
ìCome in. Iíll clear off a seat for you.î The albino hustled the mess off one of the two chairs in a state of twittering nerves.
Murry sat down and swung one long leg over the other. ìAre you assigned a job here, too?î He nodded at the desk.
Theor shook his head and smiled feebly. Almost automatically, he brushed the papers together in a heap and turned them face down.
In the months since he had returned to Dorlis with a hundred psychologists of various degrees of renown, he had felt himself pushed farther and farther from the center of things. There was room for him no longer. Except to answer questions on the actual state of things upon the robot world, which he alone had visited, he played no part And even there he detected, or seemed to detect, anger that he should have gone, and not a competent scientist
It was a thing to be resented. Yet, somehow, it had always been like that
ìPardon me?î He had let Murryís next remark slip.
The secretary repeated, ìI say itís surprising youíre not put to work, then. You made the original discovery, didnít you?î
ìYes,î the albino brightened. ìBut it went out of my hands. It got beyond me.î
ìYou were on the robot world, though.î
ìThat was a mistake, they tell me. I might have ruined everything.î
Murry grimaced. ìWhat really gets them, I guess, is that youíve got a lot of first-hand dope that they didnít Donít let their fancy titles fool you into thinking youíre a nobody. A layman with common sense is better than a blind specialist You and I-Iím a layman, too, you know-have to stand up for our rights. Here, have a cigarette.î
ìI donít sm-Iíll take one, thank you.î The albino felt himself warming to the long-bodied man opposite. He turned the papers face upward again, and lit up, bravely but uncertainly.
ìTwenty-five years.î Theor spoke carefully, skirting around urgent coughs.
ìWould you answer a few questions about the world?î
ìI suppose so. Thatís all they ever ask me about But hadnít you better ask them? Theyíve probably got it all worked out now.î He blew the smoke as far from himself as possible.
Murry said, ìFrankly, they havenít even begun, and I want the information without benefit of confusing psychological translation. First of all, what kind of people-or things-are these robots? You havenít a photocast of one of them, have you?î
ìWell, no. I didnít like to take ëcasts of them. But theyíre not things. Theyíre people!î
ìNo? Do they look like-people?î
ìYes-mostly. Outside, anyway. I brought some microscopic studies of the cellular structure that I got hold of. The Board Master has them. Theyíre different inside, you know, greatly simplified. But youíd never know that. Theyíre interesting-and nice.î
ìAre they simpler than the other life of the planet?î
ìOh, no. Itís a very primitive planet. AndÖand,î he was interrupted by a spasm of coughing and crushed the cigarette to death as unobtrusively as possible. ìTheyíve got a protoplasmic base, you know. I donít think they have the slightest idea theyíre robots.î
ìNo. I donít suppose they would have. What about their science?î
ìI donít know. I never got a chance to see. And everything was so different. I guess it would take an expert to understand.î
ìDid they have machines?î
The albino looked surprised. ëWell, of course. A good many, of all sorts.î
ìLarge cities?î
ìYes!î
The secretaryís eyes grew thoughtful. ì And you like them. Why?î
Theor Realo was brought up sharply. ìI donít know. They were just likable. We got along. They didnít bother me so. Itís nothing I can put my finger on. Maybe itís because I have it so hard getting along back home, and they werenít as difficult as real people.î
ìThey were more friendly?î
ìN-no. Canít say so. They never quite accepted me. I was a stranger, didnít know their language at first-all that. Butî-he looked up with sudden brightness-îI understood them better. I could tell what they were thinking better. I-But I donít know why.î
ìHm-m-m. Well-another cigarette? No? Iíve got to be walloping the pillow now. Itís getting late. How about a twosome at golf tomorrow? Iíve worked up a little course. Itíll do. Come on out. The exercise will put hair on your chest.î
He grinned and left.
He mumbled one sentence to himself: ìIt looks like a death sentenceî-and whistled thoughtfully as he passed along to his own quarters.
He repeated the phrase to himself when he faced the Board Master the next day, with the sash of office about his waist. He did not sit down.
ìAgain?î said the Board Master, wearily.
ìAgain!î assented the secretary. ìBut real business this time. I may have to take over direction of your expedition.î
ìWhat! Impossible, sir! I will listen to no such proposition.î
ìI have my authority.î Wynne Murry presented the metalloid cylinder that snapped open at a flick of the thumb. ìI have full powers and full discretion as to their use. It is signed, as you will observe, by the chairman of the Congress of the Federation.î
ìSo-But why?î The Board Master, by an effort, breathed normally. ìShort of arbitrary tyranny, is there a reason?î
ìA very good one, sir. All along, we have viewed this expedition from different angles. The Department of Science and Technology views the robot world not from the point of view of a scientific curiosity, but from the standpoint of its interference with the peace of the Federation. I donít think youíve ever stopped to consider the danger inherent in this robot world.î
ìNone that I can see. It is thoroughly isolated and thoroughly harmless.î
ìHow can you know?î
ìFrom the very nature of the experiment,î shouted the Board Master angrily. ìThe original planners wanted as nearly a completely closed system as possible. Here they are, just as far off the trade routes as possible, in a thinly populated region of space. The whole idea was to have the robots develop free of interference.î
Murry smiled. ìI disagree with you there. Look, the whole trouble with you is that youíre a theoretical man. You look at things the way they ought to be and I, a practical man, look at things as they are. No experiment can be set up and allowed to run indefinitely under its own power. It is taken for granted that somewhere there is at least an observer who watches and modifies as circumstances warrant.î
ìWell?î said the Board Master stolidly.
ìWell, the observers in this experiment, the original psychologists of Dorlis, passed away with the First Confederation, and for fifteen thousand years the experiment has proceeded by itself. Little errors have added up and become big ones and introduced alien factors which induced still other errors. Itís a geometric progression. And thereís been no one to halt it.î
ìPure hypothesis.î
ìMaybe. But youíre interested only in the robot world, and Iíve got to think of the entire Federation.î
ìAnd just what possible danger call the robot world be to the Federation? I donít know what in Arcturus youíre driving at, man.î
Murry sighed. ìIíll be simple, but donít blame me if I sound melodramatic. The Federation hasnít had any internal warfare for centuries. What will happen if we come into contact with these robots?î
ìAre you afraid of one world?î
ìCould be. What about their science? Robots can do funny things sometimes.î
ìWhat science call they have? Theyíre not metal-electricity supermen. Theyíre weak protoplasmic creatures, a poor imitation of actual humanity, built around a positronic brain adjusted to a set of simplified human psychological laws. If the word ërobotí is scaring you-î
ìNo, it isnít, but Iíve talked to Theor Realo. Heís the only one whoís seen them, you know.î
The Board Master cursed silently and fluently. It came of letting a weak-minded freak of a layman get underfoot where he could babble and do harm.
He said, ìWeíve got Realoís full story, and weíve evaluated it fully and capably. I assure you, no harm exists in them. The experiment is so thoroughly academic, I wouldnít spend two days on it if it werenít for the broad scope of the thing. From what we see, the whole idea was to build up a positronic brain containing modifications of one or two of the fundamental axioms. We havenít worked out the details, but they must be minor, as it was the first experiment of this nature ever tried, and even the great mythical psychologists of that day had to progress stepwise. Those robots, I tell you, are neither supermen nor beasts. I assure you-as a psychologist.î
ìSorry! Iím a psychologist, too. A little more rule-of-thumb, Iím afraid. Thatís all. But even little modifications! Take the general spirit of combativeness. That isnít the scientific term, but Iíve no patience for that. You know what I mean. We humans used to be combative. But itís being bred out of us. A stable political and economic system doesnít encourage the waste energy of combat. Itís not a survival factor. But suppose the robots are combative. Suppose as the result of a wrong turn during the millennia theyíve been unwatched, theyíve become far more combative than ever their first makers intended. Theyíd be uncomfortable things to be with.î
ìAnd suppose all the stars in the Galaxy became novae at the same time. Letís really start worrying.î
ìAnd thereís another point.î Murry ignored the otherís heavy sarcasm. ìTheor Realo liked those robots. He liked robots better than he likes real people. He felt that he fitted there, and we all know heís been a bad misfit in his own world.î
ìAnd what,î asked the Board Master, ìis the significance of that?î
ìYou donít see it?î Wynne Murry lifted his eyebrows. ìTheor Realo likes those robots because he is like them, obviously. Iíll guarantee right now that a complete psychic analysis of Theor Realo will show a modification of several fundamental axioms, and the same ones as in the robots.
ìAnd,î the secretary drove on without a pause, ìTheor Realo worked for a quarter of a century to prove a point, when all science would have laughed him to death if they had known about it. Thereís fanaticism there; good, honest, inhuman perseverance. Those robots are probably like that!î
ìYouíre advancing no logic. Youíre arguing like a maniac, like a moon-struck idiot.î
ìI donít need strict mathematical proof. Reasonable doubt is sufficient. Iíve got to protect the Federation. Look, it is reasonable, you know. The psychologists of Dorlis werenít as super as all that. They had to advance stepwise, as you yourself pointed out. Their humanoids-letís not call them robots-were only imitations of human beings and they couldnít be good ones. Humans possess certain very, very complicated reaction systems-things like social consciousness, and a tendency toward the establishment of ethical systems; and more ordinary things like chivalry, generosity, fair play and so on, that simply canít possibly be duplicated. I donít think those humanoids can have them. But they must have perseverance, which practically implies stubbornness and combativeness, if my notion on Theor Realo holds good. Well, if their science is anywhere at all, then I donít want to have them running loose in the Galaxy, if our numbers are a thousand or million times theirs. And I donít intend to permit them to do so!î
The Board Masterís face was rigid. ìWhat are your immediate intentions?î
ìAs yet undecided. But I think I am going to organize a small-scale landing on the planet.î
ìNow, wait.î The old psychologist was up and around the desk. He seized the secretaryís elbow. ìAre you quite certain you know what youíre doing? The potentialities in this massive experiment are beyond any possible precalculation by you or me. You canít know what youíre destroying.î
ìI know. Do you think I enjoy what Iím doing? This isnít a heroís job. Iím enough of a psychologist to want to know whatís going on, but Iíve been sent here to protect the Federation, and to the best of my ability I intend doing it-and a dirty job it is. But I canít help.
ìYou canít have thought it out. What can you know of the insight it will give us into the basic ideas of psychology? This will amount to a fusion of two Galactic systems, that will send us to heights that will make up in knowledge and power a million times the amount of harm the robots could ever do, if they were metal-electricity supermen.î
The secretary shrugged. ìNow youíre the one that is playing with faint possibilities.î
ìListen, Iíll make a deal. Blockade them. Isolate them with your ships. Mount guards. But donít touch them. Give us more time. Give us a chance. You must!î
ìIíve thought of that. But I would have to get Congress to agree to that. It would be expensive, you know.î
The Board Master flung himself into his chair in wild impatience. ìWhat kind of expense are you talking about? Do you realize the nature of the repayment if we succeed?î
Murry considered; then, with a half smile, ìWhat if they develop interstellar travel?î
The Board Master said quickly, ìThen Iíll withdraw my objections.î
The secretary rose, ìIíll have it out with Congress.î
Brand Gorlaís face was carefully emotionless as he watched the Board Masterís stooped back. The cheerful pep talks to the available members of the expedition lacked meat, and he listened to them impatiently.
He said, ìWhat are we going to do now?î
The Board Masterís shoulders twitched and he didnít turn. ìIíve sent for Theor Realo. That little fool left for the Eastern Continent last week~
ìWhy?î
The older man blazed at the interruption. ìHow can I understand anything that freak does! Donít you see that Murryís right? Heís a psychic abnormality. We had no business leaving him unwatched. If I had ever thought of looking at him twice, I wouldnít have. Heís coming back now, though, and heís going to stay back.î His voice fell to a mumble. ìShould have been back two hours ago.î
ìItís an impossible position, sir,î said Brand, flatly.
ìThink so?î
ìWell-Do you think Congress will stand for an indefinite patrol off the robot world? It runs into money, and average Galactic citizens arenít going to see it as worth the taxes. The psychological equations degenerate into the axioms of common sense. In fact, I donít see why Murry agreed to consult Congress.î
ìDonít your The Board Master finally faced his junior. ìWell, the fool considers himself a psychologist, Galaxy help us, and thatís his weak point. He flatters himself that he doesnít want to destroy the robot world in his heart, but that itís the good of the Federation that requires it. And heíll jump at any reasonable compromise. Congress wonít agree to it indefinitely, you donít have to point that out to me.î He was talking quietly, patiently. ìBut I will ask for ten years, two years, six months-as much as I can get. Iíll get something. In that time, weíll learn new facts about the world. Somehow weíll strengthen our case and renew the agreement when it expires. Weíll save the project yet.î
There was a short silence and the Board Master added slowly and bitterly, ìAnd thatís where Theor Realo plays a vital part:í
Brand Gorla watched silently, and waited. The Board Master said, ìOn that one point, Murry saw what we didnít. Realo is a psychological cripple, and is our real clue to the whole affair. If we study him, weíll have a rough picture of what the robot is like, distorted of course, since his environment has been a hostile, unfriendly one. But we can make allowance for that, estimate his nature in a-Ahh, Iím tired of the whole subject ì
The signal box flashed, and the Board Master sighed. ìWell, heís here. All right, Gorla, sit down, you make me nervous. Letís take a look at him.î
Theor Realo came through the door like a comet and brought himself to a panting halt in the middle of the floor. He looked from one to the other with weak, peering eyes.
ìHow did all this happen?î
ìAll what?î said the Board Master coldly. ìSit down. I want to ask you some questions.î
ìNo. You first answer me.î
ìSit down!î
Realo sat His eyes were brimming. ìTheyíre going to destroy the robot world.î
ìDonít worry about thatî
ìBut you said they could if the robots discovered interstellar travel. You said so. You fool. Donít you see-î He was choking.
The Board Master frowned uneasily. ëWill you calm down and talk sense?î
The albino gritted his teeth and forced the words out. ìBut theyíll have interstellar travel before long.î
And the two psychologists shot toward the little man.
ìWhat!!î
ìWellÖwell, what do you think?î Realo sprang upward with all the fury of desperation. ìDid you think I landed in a desert or in the middle of an ocean and explored a world all by myself? Do you think life is a storybook? I was captured as soon as I landed and taken to a big city. At least, I think it was a big city. It was different from our kind. It had-But I wonít tell you.î
ìNever mind the city,î shrieked the Board Master. ìYou were captured. Go ahead.î
ìThey studied me. They studied my machine. And then, one night, I left, to tell the Federation. They didnít know I left. They didnít want me to leave.î His voice broke. ì And I would have stayed as soon as not, but the Federation had to know.î
ìDid you tell them anything about your ship?î
ìHow could I? Iím no mechanic. I donít know the theory or construction. But I showed them how to work the controls and let them look at the motors. Thatís all.î
Brand Gorla said, to himself mostly, ìThen theyíll never get it. That isnít enough.î
The albinoís voice raised itself in sudden shrieking triumph. ìOh, yes, they will. I know them. Theyíre machines, you know. Theyíll work on that problem. And theyíll work. And theyíll work. And theyíll never quit. And theyíll get it. They got enough out of me. Iíll bet they got enough.î
The Board Master looked long, and turned away-wearily. ìWhy didnít you tell us?î
ìBecause you took my world away from me. I discovered it-by myself-all by myself. And after I had done all the real work, and invited you in, you threw me out. All you had for me was complaints that I had landed on the world and might have ruined everything by interference. Why should I tell you? Find out for yourselves if youíre so wise, that you could afford to kick me around.î
The Board Master thought bitterly, ìMisfit! Inferiority complex! Persecution mania! Nice! It all fits in, now that weíve bothered to take our eyes off the horizon and see what was under our nose. And now itís all ruined.î
He said, ìAll right, Realo, we all lose. Go away.î
Brand Gorla said tightly, ìAllover? Really all over?î
The Board Master answered, ìReally all over. The original experiment, as such, is over. The distortions created by Realoís visit will easily be large enough to make the plans we are studying here a dead language. And besides-Murry is right. If they have interstellar travel, theyíre dangerous.î
Realo was shouting, ìBut youíre not going to destroy them. You canít destroy them. They havenít hurt anyone.î
There was no answer, and he raved on, ìIím going back. Iíll warn them. Theyíll be prepared. Iíll warn them.î
He was backing toward the door, his thin, white hair bristling, his red-rimmed eyes bulging.
The Board Master did not move to stop him when he dashed out.
ìLet him go. It was his lifetime. I donít care any more.î
Theor Realo smashed toward the robot world at an acceleration that was half choking him.
Somewhere ahead was the dustspeck of an isolated world with artificial imitations of humanity struggling along in an experiment that had died. Struggling blindly toward a new goal of interstellar travel that was to be their death sentence.
He was heading toward that world, toward the same city in which he had been ìstudiedî the first time. He remembered it well. Its name was the first words of their language he had learned.
New York!



***



On July 26, 1943, which was a Monday, I had one of the rare days off I could take during wartime. (It was, after all, my first wedding anniversary.) I was in New York that day, and I visited Campbell just as in the good old days. I discussed with him another story in the ìFoundationî series, as well as another in the ìpositronic robotî series. From then on, I always saw Campbell on the rare days when I was in New York on a weekday, and of course we corresponded regularly.
I was definitely back at writing. Output was low, but during the remaining war years I wrote two positronic robot stories, ìCatch That Rabbitî and ìParadoxical Escape,î which appeared in the February 1944 and August 1945 issues of Astounding, respectively. Both were eventually included in I, Robot. (The latter story appears in I,Robot under the title of ìEscape.î The word ìParadoxicalî had been added by Campbell in one of his few title changes, and I didnít like it.)
I also wrote no less than four stories of the ìFoundationî series during those same years. These were ìThe Big and the Little,î ìThe Wedge,î ìDead Hand,î and ìThe Mule.î All appeared in Astounding, of course, the first three in the August 1944, October 1944, and April 1945 issues, respectively.
ìThe Muleî set several records for me. It was the longest story I had ever written up to that time-fifty thousand words long. Yet even so, and despite the fact that I had to work on it in small scraps of time left over from job and marriage, I managed to complete it in three and a half months. It was submitted on May 21, 1945, and was accepted on the twenty-ninth. (Indeed, throughout the war I never got a single rejection, or even a delayed acceptance. Nor did I submit to anyone but Campbell.)
Whatís more, at the beginning of 1944 Campbell raised his basic rate to one and a half cents a word and some months later to a cent and three quarters. For ìThe Muleî I received a check at the higher rate, for $875. It was by far the largest check I ever received for a single story. By the end of the war, in fact, I was making half as much money writing in my spare time as I was making at my N.A.E.S. job, even though I had been promoted and was receiving sixty dollars a week by the end of the war.
Then, too, ìThe Muleî was the first story I ever had published as a serial. It appeared in two parts in the November and December 1945 issues of Astounding.
Of the wartime ìFoundationî stories, ìThe Big and the Littleî and ìThe Wedgeî are included in Foundation, while ìDead Handî and ìThe Mule,î together, make up all of Foundation and Empire.
During the two years between mid-1943 and mid-1945, I wrote only one story that was neither one of the ìFoundationî series nor one of the ìPositronic robotî series, and that one was inspired directly by the N.A.E.S. This story was ìBlind Alley,î which was written during September and early October of 1944. It was submitted to Campbell on October 10, and accepted on the twentieth.








Blind Alley





Only once in Galactic History was an intelligent race of non-Humans discovered-
ìEssays on History.î by Ligurn Vier

2. The duties of the subject position shall comprise the general supervision of all non-Human internal affairs, co-ordination of authorized government investigating and reporting committees, and the preparation of semiannual reports on all phases of non-Human affairs.



C. Morily, Chief,

BuOuProv, 12/977 G.E.


Loodun Antyok had listened carefully, and now he shook his round head mildly, ìFriend, Iíd like to help you, but youíve grabbed the wrong dog by the ears. Youíd better take this up with the Bureau.î
Tomor Zammo flung himself back into his chair, rubbed his beak of a nose fiercely, thought better of whatever he was going to say, and answered quietly, ìLogical, but not practical. I canít make a trip to Trantor now. Youíre the Bureauís representative on Cepheus 18. Are you entirely helpless?î
ìWell, even as Civilian Supervisor, Iíve got to work within the limits of Bureau policy.î
ìGood,î Zammo cried, ìthen, tell me what Bureau policy is. I head a scientific investigating committee, under direct Imperial authorization with, supposedly, the widest powers; yet at every angle in the road I am pulled up short by the civilian authorities with only the parrot shriek of ëBureau policyí to justify themselves. What is Bureau policy? I havenít received a decent definition yet.î
Antyokís gaze was level and unruffled. He said, ìAs I see it-and this is not official, so you canít hold me to it-Bureau policy consists in treating the non-Humans as decently as possible.î
ìThen, what authority have they-î
ì Ssh! No use raising your voice. As a matter of fact, His Imperial Majesty is a humanitarian and a disciple of the philosophy of Aurelion. I can tell you quietly that it is pretty well-known that it is the Emperor himself who first suggested that this world be established. You can bet that Bureau policy will stick pretty close to Imperial notions. And you can bet that I canít paddle my way against that sort of current.î
ìWell, míboy,î the physiologistís fleshy eyelids quivered, ìif you take that sort of attitude, youíre going to lose your job. No, I wonít have you kicked out. Thatís not what I mean at all. Your job will just fade out from under you, because nothing is going to be accomplished here!î
ìReally? Why?î Antyok was short, pink, and pudgy, and his plump-cheeked face usually found it difficult to put on display any expression other than one of bland and cheerful politeness-but it looked grave now.
ìYou havenít been here long. I have.î Zammo scowled. ìMind if I smoke?î The cigar in his hand was gnarled and strong and was puffed to life carelessly.
He continued roughly, ìThereís no place here for humanitarianism, administrator. Youíre treating non-Humans as if they were Humans, and it wonít work. In fact, I donít like the word ënon-Human.í Theyíre animals.î
ìTheyíre intelligent, ì interjected Antyok, softly.
ìWell, intelligent animals, then. I presume the two terms are not mutually exclusive. Alien intelligences mingling in the same space wonít work, anyway.î
ìDo you propose killing them off?î
ìGalaxy, no!î He gestured with his cigar. ìI propose we look upon them as objects for study, and only that. We could learn a good deal from these animals if we were allowed to. Knowledge, I might point out, that would be used for the immediate benefit of the human race. Thereís humanity for you. Thereís the good of the masses, if its this spineless cult of Aurelion that interests you.î
ìWhat, for instance, do you refer to?î
ìTo take the most obvious-you have heard of their chemistry, I take it?î
ìYes,î Antyok admitted. ìI have leafed through most of the reports on the non-Humans published in the last ten years. I expect to go through more.î
ìHmp. Well-then, all I need say is that their chemical therapy is extremely thorough. For instance, I have witnessed personally the healing of a broken bone-what passes for a broken bone with them, I mean-by the use of a pill. The bone was whole in fifteen minutes. Naturally, none of their drugs are any earthly use on Humans. Most would kill quickly. But if we found out how they worked on the non-Humans-on the animals-î
ìYes, yes. I see the significance.î
ìOh, you do. Come, thatís gratifying. A second point is that these animals communicate in an unknown manner.î
ìTelepathy!î
The scientistís mouth twisted, as he ground out, ìTelepathy! Telepathy! Telepathy! Might as well say by witch brew. Nobody knows anything about telepathy except its name. What is the mechanism of telepathy? What is the physiology and the physics of it? I would like to find out, but I canít. Bureau policy, if I listen to you, forbids.î
Antyokís little mouth pursed itself. ìBut-Pardon me, doctor, but I donít follow you. How are you prevented? Surely the Civil Administration has made no attempt to hamper scientific investigation of these non-Humans. I cannot speak for my predecessor entirely, of course, but I myself-î
ìNo direct interference has occurred. I donít speak of that. But by the Galaxy, administrator, weíre hampered by the spirit of the entire set-up. Youíre making us deal with humans. You allow them their own leader and internal autonomy. You pamper them and give them what Aurelionís philosophy would call ërights: I canít deal with their leader.î
ìWhy not?î
ìBecause he refuses to allow me a free hand. He refuses to allow experiments on any subject without the subjectís own consent. The two or three volunteers we get are not too bright. Itís an impossible arrangement.î
Antyok shrugged helplessly.
Zammo continued, ìIn addition, it is obviously impossible to learn anything of value concerning the brains, physiology, and chemistry of these animals without dissection, dietary experiments, and drugs. You know, administrator, scientific investigation is a hard game. Humanity hasnít much place in it. ì
Loodun Antyok tapped his chin with a doubtful finger, ìMust it be quite so hard? These are harmless creatures, these non-Humans. Surely, dissection-Perhaps, if you were to approach them a bit differently-I have the idea that you antagonize them. Your attitude might be somewhat overbearing.î
ìOverbearing! I am not one of these whining social psychologists who are all the fad these days. I donít believe you can solve a problem that requires dissection by approaching it with what is called the ëcorrect personal attitudeí in the cant of the times.î
ìIím sorry you think so. Sociopsychological training is required of all administrators above the grade of A-4.î
Zammo withdrew his cud of a cigar from his mouth and replaced it after a suitably contemptuous interval, ìThen youíd better use a bit of your technique on the Bureau. You know, I do have friends at the Imperial court.î
ìWell, now, I canít take the matter up with them, not baldly. Basic policy does not fall within my cognizance, and such things can only be initiated by the Bureau. But, you know, we might try an indirect approach on this.î He smiled faintly, ìStrategy.î
ìWhat sort?î
Antyok pointed a sudden finger, while his other hand fell lightly on the rows of gray-bound reports upon the floor just next his chair, ìNow, look, Iíve gone through most of these. Theyíre dull, but contain some facts. For instance, when was the last non-Human infant born on Cepheus 18?
Zammo spent little time in consideration. ìDonít know. Donít care either.î
ìBut the Bureau would. Thereís never been a non-Human infant born on Cepheus 18-not in the two years the world has been established. Do you know the reason?î
The physiologist shrugged, ìToo many possible factors. It would take study.î
ìAll right, then. Suppose you write a report-î
ìReports! Iíve written twenty.î
ìWrite another. Stress the unsolved problems. Tell them you must change your methods. Harp on the birth-rate problem. The Bureau doesnít dare ignore that. If the non-Humans die out, someone will have to answer to the Emperor. You see-î
Zammo stared, his eyes dark, ìThat will swing it?î
ìIíve been working for the Bureau for twenty-seven years. I know its ways.î
ìIíll think about it.î Zammo rose and stalked out of the office. The door slammed behind him.
It was later that Zammo said to a co-worker, ìHeís a bureaucrat, in the first place. He wonít abandon the orthodoxies of paper work and he wonít risk sticking his neck out. Heíll accomplish little by himself, yet maybe more than a little if we work through him. ì

II


There was a loose-jointed gauntness about the news reporter which made him appear somberly tall. He was Gustiv Bannerd, with whose reputation was combined ability-two things which do not invariably go together despite the maxims of elementary morality.
Loodum Antyok took his measure doubtfully and said, ìThereís no use denying that youíre right. But the SciGroup report was confidential. I donít understand how-î
ìIt leaked,î said Bannerd, callously. ìEverything leaks:í
Antyok was obviously baffled, and his pink face furrowed slightly, ìThen Iíll just have to plug the leak here. I canít pass your story. All references to SciGroup complaints have to come out. You see that, donít your
ìNo.î Bannerd was calm enough. ìItís important; and I have my rights under the Imperial directive. I think the Empire should know whatís going onÖ
ìBut it isnít going on,î said Antyok, despairingly. ìYour claims are all wrong. The Bureau isnít going to change its policy. I showed you the lettersÖ
ìYou think you can stand up against Zammo when he puts the pressure on?î the newsman asked derisively.
ìI will-if I think heís wrong.î
ìIf!î stated Bannerd flatly. Then, in a sudden fervor, ìAntyok, the Empire has something great here; something greater by a good deal than the government apparently realizes. Theyíre destroying it. Theyíre treating these creatures like animals.î
ìReally-î began Antyok, weakly.
ìDonít talk about Cepheus 18. Itís a zoo. Itís a high-class zoo, with your petrified scientists teasing those poor creatures with their sticks poking through the bars. You throw them chunks of meat, but you cage them up. I know! Iíve been writing about them for two years now. Iíve almost been living with them.ì
ìZammo says-î
ìZammo!î This with hard contempt.
ìZammo says,î insisted Antyok with worried firmness, ìthat we treat them too like humans as it is.î
The newsmanís straight, long cheeks were rigid, ìZammo is rather animallike in his own right. He is a science-worshiper. We can do with less of them. Have you read Aurelionís worksr The last was suddenly posed.
ìUmm. Yes. I understand the Emperor-î
ìThe Emperor tends towards us. That is good-better than the hounding of the last reign.î
ìI donít see where youíre heading?î
ìThese aliens have much to teach us. You understand? It is nothing that Zammo and his SciGroup can use; no chemistry, no telepathy. Itís a way of life; a way of thinking. The aliens have no crime, no misfits. What effort is being made to study their philosophy? Or to set them up as a problem in social engineering?î
Antyok grew thoughtful, and his plump face smoothed out, ìIt is an interesting consideration. It would be a matter for psychologists-î
ìNo good. Most of them are quacks. Psychologists point out problems, but their solutions are fallacious. We need men of Aurelion. Men of The Philosophy-î
ìBut look here, we canít turn Cepheus 18 intoÖinto a metaphysical study.î
ìWhy not? It can be done easily.î
ìHow?î
ìForget your puny test-tube peerings. Allow the aliens to set up a society free of Humans. Give them an untrammeled independence and allow an intermingling of philosophies-î
Antyokís nervous response came, ìThat canít be done in a day.î
ìWe can start in a day.î
The administrator said slowly, ìWell, I canít prevent you from trying to start:í He grew confidential, his mild eyes thoughtful, ìYouíll ruin your own game, though, if you publish SciGroup 10ís report and denounce it on humanitarian grounds. The Scientists are powerful.î
ìAnd we of The Philosophy as well.î
ìYes, but thereís an easy way. You neednít rave. Simply point out that the SciGroup is not solving its problems. Do so unemotionally and let the readers think out your point of view for themselves. Take the birth-rate problem, for instance. Thereís something for you. In a generation, the non-Humans might die out, for all science can do. Point out that a more philosophical approach is required. Or pick some other obvious point. Use your judgment, eh?î
Antyok smiled ingratiatingly as he arose, ìBut, for the Galaxyís sake, donít stir up a bad smell:í
Bannerd was stiff and unresponsive, ìyou may be right:î
It was later that Bannerd wrote in a capsule message to a friend, ìHe is not clever, by any means. He is confused and has no guiding-line through life. Certainly utterly incompetent in his job. But heís a cutter and a trimmer, compromises his way around difficulties, and will yield concessions rather than risk a hard stand. He may prove valuable in that. Yours in Aurelion.î
