III


If Tomor Zammoís ill-humor lessened within the grounds of SciGroup 10 Experimental Station, his friendliness had not thereby increased. Antyok found himself standing alone at the viewing window into the main field laboratory.
The main field laboratory was a broad court set at the environmental conditions of Cepheus 18 itself for the discomfort of the experimenters and the convenience of the experimentees. Through the burning sand, and the dry, oxygen-rich air, there sparkled the hard brilliance of hot, white sunlight. And under the blaze, the brick-red non-Humans, wrinkled of skin and wiry of build, huddled in their squatting positions of ease, by ones and twos.
Zammo emerged from the laboratory. He paused to drink water thirstily. He looked up, moisture gleaming on his upper lip, ìLike to step in there?î
Antyok shook his head definitely, ìNo, thank you. Whatís the temperature right now?î
ìA hundred twenty, if there were shade. And they complain of the cold. Itís drinking time now. Want to watch them drink?î
A spray of water shot upward from the fountain in the center of the court, and the little alien figures swayed to their feet and hopped eagerly forward in a queer, springy half-run. They milled about the water, jostling one another. The centers of their faces were suddenly disfigured by the projection of a long and flexible fleshy tube, which thrust forward into the spray and was withdrawn dripping.
It continued for long minutes. The bodies swelled and the wrinkles disappeared. They retreated slowly, backing away, with the drinking tube flicking in and out, before receding finally into a pink, wrinkled mass above a wide, lipless mouth. They went to sleep in groups in the shaded angles, plump and sated.
ìAnimals!î said Zammo, with contempt.
ìHow often do they drink?î asked Antyok.
ìAs often as they want. They can go a week if they have to. We water them every day. They store it under their skin. They eat in the evenings. Vegetarians, you know.î
Antyok smiled chubbily, ìItís nice to get a bit of firsthand information occasionally. Canít read reports all the time.î
ìYes?î-noncommittally. Then, ìWhatís new? What about the lacy-pants boys on Trantor?î
Antyok shrugged dubiously, ìYou canít get the Bureau to commit itself, unfortunately. With the Emperor sympathetic to the Aurelionists, humanitarianism is the order of the day. You know that.î
There was a pause in which the administrator chewed his lip uncertainly. ìBut thereís this birth-rate problem now. Itís finally been assigned to AdHQ, you know-and double A priority, too.î
Zammo muttered wordlessly.
Antyok said, ìYou may not realize it, but that project will now take precedence over all other work proceeding on Cepheus 18. Itís important.î
He turned back to the viewing window and said thoughtfully with a bald lack of preamble. ìDo you think those creatures might be unhappy?î
ìUnhappy!î The word was an explosion.
ìWell, then,î Antyok corrected hastily, ìmaladjusted. You understand? Itís difficult to adjust an environment to a race we know so little of.î
ìSay-did you ever see the world we took them from?î
ìIíve read the reports-ì
ìReports!î-infinite contempt. ìIíve seen it. This may look like desert out there to you, but itís a watery paradise to those devils. They have all the food and water they can get. They have a world to themselves with vegetation and natural water flow, instead of a lump of silica and granite where fungi were force-grown in caves and water had to be steamed out of gypsum rock. In ten years, they would have been dead to the last beast, and we saved them. Unhappy? Ga-a-ah, if they are, they havenít the decency of most animals.î
ìWell, perhaps. Yet I have a notion.î
ìA notion? What is your notion?î Zammo reached for one of his cigars.
ìItís something that might help you. Why not study the creatures in a more integrated fashion? Let them use their initiative. After all, they did have a highly-developed science. Your reports speak of it continually. Give them problems to solve.î
ìSuch as?î
ìOhÖoh,î Antyok waved his hands helplessly. ìWhatever you think might help most. For instance, spaceships. Get them into the control room and study their reactions.î
ìWhy?î asked Zammo with dry bluntness.
ìBecause the reaction of their minds to tools and controls adjusted to the human temperament can teach you a lot. In addition, it will make a more effective bribe, it seems to me, than anything youíve yet tried. Youíll get more volunteers if they think theyíll be doing something interesting.î
ìThatís your psychology coming out. Hm-m-m. Sounds better than it probably is. Iíll sleep on it. And where would I get permission, in any case, to let them handle spaceships? Iíve none at my disposal, and it would take a good deal longer than it was worth to follow down the line of red tape to get one assigned to us.î
Antyok pondered, and his forehead creased lightly, ìIt doesnít have to be spaceships. But even so-lf you would write up another report and make the suggestion yourself-strongly, you understand-I might figure out some way of tying it up with my birth-rate project. A double-a priority can get practically anything, you know, without questions.î
Zammoís interest lacked a bit even of mildness, ìWell, maybe. Meanwhile, Iíve some basal metabolism tests in progress, and itís getting late. Iíll think about it. Itís got its points.î

2. It is urgently requested that work on the subject project be expedited by all available means.

IV


The little, bricky creature must have been more uncomfortable than his bearing would admit to. He was carefully wrapped in a temperature already adjusted to the point where his human companions steamed in their open shirts.
His speech was high-pitched and careful, ìI find it damp, but not unbearably so at this low temperature.î
Antyok smiled, ìIt was nice of you to come. I had planned to visit you, but a trial run in your atmosphere out there-î The smile had become rueful.
ìIt doesnít matter. You other worldlings have done more for us than ever we were able to do for ourselves. It is an obligation that is but imperfectly returned by the endurance on my part of a trilling discomfort.î His speech seemed always indirect, as if he approached his thoughts sidelong, or as if it were against all etiquette to be blunt.
Gustiv Bannerd, seated in an angle of the room, with one long leg crossing the other, scrawled nimbly and said, ìyou donít mind if I record all this?î
The Cepheid non-Human glanced briefly at the journalist, ìI have no objection.î
Antyokís apologetics persisted, ìThis is not a purely social affair, sir. I would not have forced discomfort on you for that. There are important questions to be considered, and you are the leader of your people.î
The Cepheid nodded, ìI am satisfied your purposes are kindly. Please proceed.î
The administrator almost wriggled in his difficulty in putting thoughts into words. ìIt is a subject,î he said, ìof delicacy, and one I would never bring up if it werenít for the overwhelming importance of theÖuhÖquestion. I am only the spokesman of my government-î
ìMy people consider the otherworld government a kindly one.î
ìWell, yes, they are kindly. For that reason, they are disturbed over the fact that your people no longer breed.î
Antyok paused, and waited with worry for a reaction that did not come. The Cepheidís face was motionless except for the soft, trembling motion of the wrinkled area that was his deflated drinking tube.
Antyok continued, ìIt is a question we have hesitated to bring up because of its extremely personal angles. Noninterference is my governmentís prime aim, and we have done our best to investigate the problem quietly and without disturbing your people. But, frankly, we-ì
ìHave failed?î finished the Cepheid, at the otherís pause.
ìYes. Or at least, we have not discovered a concrete failure to reproduce the exact environment of your original world; with, of course, the necessary modification to make it more livable. Naturally, it is thought there is some chemical shortcoming. And so I ask your voluntary help in the matter. Your people are advanced in the study of your own biochemistry. If you do not choose, or would rather not-î
ìNo, no, I can help:í The Cepheid seemed cheerful about it. The smooth Hat planes of his loose-skinned, hairless skull wrinkled in an alien response to an uncertain emotion. ìIt is not a matter that any of us would have thought would have disturbed you other-worldlings. That it does is but another indication of your well-meaning Kindness. This world we find congenial, a paradise in comparison to our old. It lacks in nothing. Conditions such as now prevail belong in our legends of the Golden Age.î
ìWell-î
ìBut there is a something; a something you may not understand. We cannot expect different intelligences to think alike.î
ìI shall try to understand.î The Cepheidís voice had grown soft, its liquid undertones more pronounced, ìWe were dying on our native world; but we were fighting. Our science, developed through a history older than yours, was losing; but it had not yet lost. Perhaps it was because our science was fundamentally biological, rather than physical as yours is. Your people discovered new forms of energy and reached the stars. Our people discovered new truths of psychology and psychiatry and built up a working society free of disease and crime.
ìThere is no need to question which of the two angles of approach was the more laudable, but there is no uncertainty as to which proved more successful in the end. In our dying world, without the means of life or sources of power, our biological science could but make the dying easier
ìAnd yet we fought. For centuries past, we had been groping toward the elements of atomic power, and slowly the spark of hope had glimmered that we might break through the two-dimensional limits of our planetary surface and reach the stars. There were no other planets in our system to serve as stepping stones. Nothing but some twenty light-years to the nearest star, without the knowledge of the possibility of the existence of other planetary systems, but rather of the contrary.
ìBut there is something in all life that insists on striving; even on useless striving. There were only five thousand of us left in the last days. Only five thousand. And our first ship was ready. It was experimental. It would probably have been a failure. But already we had all the principles of propulsion and navigation correctly worked out.,.
There was a long pause, and the Cepheidís small black eyes seemed glazed in retrospect.
The newspaperman put in suddenly, from his comer, ìAnd then we came?î
ìAnd then you came,î the Cepheid agreed simply. ìIt changed everything. Energy was ours for the asking. A new world, congenial and, indeed, ideal, was ours even without asking. If our problems of society had long been solved by ourselves, our more difficult problems of environment were suddenly solved for us, no less completely.î
ìWell?î urged Antyok.
ìWell-it was somehow not well. For centuries, our ancestors had fought towards the stars, and now the stars suddenly proved to be the property of others. We had fought for life, and it had become a present handed to us by others. There is no longer any reason to fight. There is no longer anything to attain. All the universe is the property of your race.î
ìThis world is yours,î said Antyok, gently.
ìBy sufferance. It is a gift. It is not ours by right.î
ìYou have earned it, in my opinion.î
And now the Cepheidís eyes were sharply fixed on the otherís countenance, ìYou mean well, but I doubt that you understand. We have nowhere to go, save this gift of a world. We are in a blind alley. The function of life is striving, and that is taken from us. Life can no longer interest us. We have no offspring-voluntarily. It is our way of removing ourselves from your way.î
Absent-mindedly, Antyok had removed the Fluoro-globe from the window seat, and spun it on its base. Its gaudy surface reflected light as it spun, and its three-foot-high bulk floated with incongruous grace and lightness in the air.
Antyok said, ìIs that your only solution? Sterility?î
ìWe might escape still,î whispered the Cepheid, ìbut where in the Galaxy is there place for us? It is all yours.î
ìYes, there is no place for you nearer than the Magellanic Clouds if you wished independence. The Magellanic Clouds-î
ìAnd you would not let us go of yourselves. You mean kindly, I know.î
ìYes, we mean kindly-but we could not let you go.î
ìIt is a mistaken kindness.î
ìPerhaps, but could you not reconcile yourselves? You have a world.î
ìIt is something past complete explanations. Your mind is different. We could not reconcile ourselves. I believe, administrator, that you have thought of all this before. The concept of the blind alley we find ourselves trapped in is not new to you.î
Antyok looked up, startled, and one hand steadied the fluoro-globe, ìCan you read my mind?î
ìIt is just a guess. A good one, I think.î
ìYes-but can you read my mind? The minds of humans in general, I mean. It is an interesting point. The scientists say you cannot, but sometimes I wonder if it is that you simply will not. Could you answer that? I am detaining you, unduly, perhaps.î
ìNoÖno-î But the little Cepheid drew his enveloping robe closer, and buried his face in the electrically-heated pad at the collar for a moment. ìYou other-worldlings speak of reading minds. It is not so at all, but it is assuredly hopeless to explain.î
Antyok mumbled the old proverb, ìOne cannot explain sight to a man blind from birth.î
ìYes, just so. This sense which you call ëmind reading,, quite erroneously, cannot be applied to us. It is not that we cannot receive the proper sensations, it is that your people do not transmit them, and we have no way of explaining to you how to go about it.î
ìHm-m-m.î
ìThere are times, of course, of great concentration or emotional tension on the part of an other-worldling when some of us who are more expert in this sense; more sharp-eyed, so to speak; detect vaguely something. It is uncertain; yet I myself have at times wondered-î
Carefully, Antyok began spinning the Fluoro-globe once more. His pink face was set in thought, and his eyes were fixed upon the Cepheid. Gustiv Bannerd stretched his fingers and reread his notes, his lips moving silently.
The fluoro-globe spun, and slowly the Cepheid seemed to grow tense as well, as his eyes shifted to the colorful sheen of the globeís fragile surface.
The Cepheid said, ìWhat is that?î
Antyok started, and his face smoothed into an almost chuckling placidity, ìThis? A Galactic fad of three years ago; which means that it is a hopelessly old-fashioned relic this year. It is a useless device but it looks pretty. Bannerd, could you adjust the windows to non-transmission?î
There was the soft click of a contact, and the windows became curved regions of darkness, while in the center of the room, the fluoro-globe was suddenly the focus of a rosy effulgence that seemed to leap outward in streamers. Antyok, a scarlet figure in a scarlet room, placed it upon the table and spun it with a hand that dripped red. As it spun, the colors changed with a slowly increasing rapidity, blended and fell apart into more extreme contrasts.
Antyok was speaking in an eerie atmosphere of molten, shifting rainbow, ìThe surface is of a material that exhibits variable fluorescence. It is almost weightless, extremely fragile, but gyroscopically balanced so that it rarely falls, with ordinary care. It is rather pretty, donít you think?î
From somewhere the Cepheidís voice came, ìExtremely pretty.î
ìBut it has outworn its welcome; outlived its fashionable existence.î
The Cepheidís voice was abstracted, ìIt is very pretty.î
Bannerd restored the light at a gesture, and the colors faded. The Cepheid said, ìThat is something my people would enjoy.î He stared at the globe with fascination.
And now Antyok rose. ìYou had better go. If you stay longer, the atmosphere may have bad effects. I thank you humbly for your kindness.î
ìI thank you humbly for yours.î The Cepheid had also risen.
Antyok said, ìMost of your people, by the way, have accepted our offers to them to study the make-up of our modem spaceships. You understand, I suppose, that the purpose was to study the reactions of your people to our technology. I trust that conforms with your sense of propriety.î
ìYou need not apologize. I, myself, have now the makings of a human pilot. It was most interesting. It recalls our own efforts-and reminds us of how nearly on the right track we were.î
The Cepheid left, and Antyok sat, frowning.
ìWell,î he said to Bannerd, a little sharply. ìYou remember our agreement, I hope. This interview canít be published.î
Bannerd shrugged, ìVery well.î
Antyok was at his seat, and his fingers fumbled with the small metal figurine upon his desk, ìWhat do you think of all this, Bannerd?î
ìI am sorry for them. I think I understand how they feel. We must educate them out of it. The Philosophy can do it.î
ìYou think so?î
ìYes.î
ìWe canít let them go, of course.î
ìOh, no. Out of the question. We have too much to learn from them. This feeling of theirs is only a passing stage. Theyíll think differently, especially when we allow them the completest independence.î
ìMaybe. What do you think of the fluoro-globes, Bannerd? He liked them. It might be a gesture of the right sort to order several thousand of them. The Galaxy knows, theyíre a drug on the market right now, and cheap enough.î
ìSounds like a good idea,î said Bannerd.
ìThe Bureau would never agree, though. I know them.î
The newsmanís eyes narrowed, ìBut it might be just the thing. They need new interests.î
ìYes? Well, we could do something. I could include your transcript of the interview as part of a report and just emphasize the matter of the globes a bit. After all, youíre a member of The philosophy and might have influence with important people, whose word with the Bureau might carry much more weight than mine. You understand-?î
ìYes,î mused Bannerd. ìYes.î

V


The dinner was over, the wine had been brought in, and the cigars were out. The groups of talkers had formed, and the captain of the merchant fleet was the center of the largest. His brilliant white uniform quite outsparkled his listeners.
He was almost complacent in his speech: ìThe trip was nothing. Iíve had more than three hundred ships under me before this. Still, Iíve never had a cargo quite like this. What do you want with five thousand fluoro-globes on this desert, by the Galaxy!î
Loodun Antyok laughed gently. He shrugged, ìFor the non-Humans. It wasnít a difficult cargo, I hope.î
ìNo, not difficult. But bulky. Theyíre fragile, and I couldnít carry more than twenty to a ship, with all the government regulations concerning packing and precautions against breakage. But itís the governmentís money, I suppose.î
Zammo smiled grimly. ìIs this your first experience with government methods, captain?î
ìGalaxy, no,î exploded the spaceman. ìI try to avoid it, of course, but you canít help getting entangled on occasion. And itís an abhorrent thing when you are, and thatís the truth. The red tape! The paper work! Itís enough to stunt your growth and curdle your circulation. Itís a tumor, a cancerous growth on the Galaxy. Iíd wipe out the whole mess.î
Antyok said, ìYouíre unfair, captain. You donít understand.î
ìYes? Well, now, as one of these bureaucrats,î and he smiled amiably at the word, ìsuppose you explain your side of the situation, administrator.î
ìWell, now,î Antyok seemed confused, ìgovernment is a serious and complicated business. Weíve got thousands of planets to worry about in this Empire of ours and billions of people. Itís almost past human ability to supervise the business of governing without the tightest sort of organization. I think there are something like four hundred million men today in the Imperial Administrative Service alone, and in order to co-ordinate their efforts and to pool their knowledge, you must have what you call red tape and paper work. Every bit of it, senseless though it may seem, annoying though it may be, has its uses. Every piece of paper is a thread binding the labors of four hundred million humans. Abolish the Administrative Service and you abolish the Empire; and with it, interstellar peace, order, and civilization.î
ìCome-î said the captain.
ìNo. I mean it.î Antyok was earnestly breathless. ìThe rules and system of the Administrative set-up must be sufficiently all-embracing and rigid so that in case of incompetent officials, and sometimes one is appointed-you may laugh, but there are incompetent scientists, and newsmen, and captains, too-in case of incompetent officials, I say, little harm will be done. For, at the worst, the system can move by itself.ì
ìYes,î grunted the captain, sourly, ìand if a capable administrator should be appointed? He is then caught by the same rigid web and is forced into mediocrity.î
ìNot at all, ì replied Antyok, warmly. ì A capable man can work within the limits of the rules and accomplish what he wishes.î
ìHow?î asked Bannerd.
ìWellÖwell-î Antyok was suddenly ill at ease. ìOne method is to get yourself an A-priority project, or double-A, if possible.î
The captain leaned his head back for laughter, but never quite made it, for the door was flung open and frightened men were pouring in. The shouts made no sense at first. Then:
ìSir, the ships are gone. These non-Humans have taken them by force.î
ìWhat? All?î
ìEvery one. Ships and creatures-î
It was two hours later that the four were together again, alone in Antyokís office now.
Antyik said coldly, ìTheyíve made no mistakes. Thereís not a ship left behind, not even your training ship, Zammo. And there isnít a government ship available in this entire half of the Sector. By the time we organize a pursuit theyíll be out of the Galaxy and halfway to the Magellanic Clouds. Captain, it was your responsibility to maintain an adequate guard.î
The captain cried, ìIt was our first day out of space. Who could have known-î
Zammo interrupted fiercely, ìWait a while, captain. Iím beginning to understand. Antyok, ì his voice was hard, ìyou engineered this.î
ìI?î Antyokís expression was strangely cool, almost indifferent.
ìYou told us this evening that a clever administrator got an A-priority project assigned to accomplish what he wished. You got such a project in order to help the non-Humans escape.î
ìI did? I beg your pardon, but how could that be? It was you yourself in one of your reports that brought up the problem of the failing birth rate. It was Bannerd, here, whose sensational articles frightened the Bureau into making a double A-priority project out of it. I had nothing to do with it.î
ì You suggested that I mention the birth rate,î said Zammo, violently.
ìDid I?î said Antyok, composedly.
ìAnd for that matter,î roared Bannerd, suddenly, ìyou suggested that I mention the birth rate in my articles.î
The three ringed him now and hemmed him in. Antyok leaned back in his chair and said easily, ìI donít know what you mean by suggestions. If you are accusing me, please stick to evidence-legal evidence. The laws of the Empire go by written, filmed, or transcribed material, or by witnessed statements. All my letters as administrator are on me here, at the Bureau, and at other places. I never asked for an A-priority project. The Bureau assigned it to me, and Zammo and Bannerd are responsible for that. In print, at any rate.î
Zammoís voice was an almost inarticulate growl, ìYou hoodwinked me into teaching the creatures how to handle a spaceship.î
ìIt was your suggestion. I have your report proposing they be studied in their reaction to human tools on file. So has the Bureau. The evidence-the legal evidence, is plain. I had nothing to do with it.î
ìNor with the globes?î demanded Bannerd.
The captain howled suddenly, ìYou had my ships brought here purposely. Five thousand globes! You knew it would require hundreds of craft. ì
ìI never asked for globes,î said Antyok, coldly. ìThat was the Bureauís idea, although I think Bannerdís friends of The Philosophy helped that along.î
Bannerd fairly choked. He spat out, ìYou were asking that Cepheid leader if he could read minds. You were telling him to express interest in the globes.î
ìCome, now. You prepared the transcript of the conversation yourself, and that, too, is on file. You canít prove it.î He stood up, ìYouíll have to excuse me. I must prepare a report for the Bureau.î
At the door, Antyok turned. ìIn a way, the problem of the non-Humans is solved, even if only to their own satisfaction. Theyíll breed now, and have a world theyíve earned themselves. Itís what they wanted.
ìAnother thing. Donít accuse me of silly things. Iíve been in the Service for twenty-seven years, and I assure you that my paper work is proof enough that I have been thoroughly correct in everything I have done. And captain, Iíll be glad to continue our discussion of earlier this evening at your convenience and explain how a capable administrator can work through red tape and still get what he wants.î
It was remarkable that such a round. smooth baby-face could wear a smile quite so sardonic.
