I had one sheet of that foolscap. I donít think anyone man in the world had more than one sheet. And Iím sure that no man in the world but one knew that the loss of his particular sheet and of his particular life would be as nearly simultaneous as the government could make it.
So I tossed the sheet at Keyser, as if it were something Iíd found blowing about the campus.
He stared at it and then looked at the back side, which was blank. His eyes moved down from the top to the bottom, then jumped back to the top.
ìI donít know what this is about,î he said, and the words seemed sour to his own taste.
I didnít say anything. Just folded the paper and shoved it back into the inside jacket pocket.
Keyser added petulantly: ìItís a fallacy you laymen have that scientists can look at an equation and say,, Ah, yes-í and go on to write a book about it. Mathematics has no existence of its own. It is merely an arbitrary code devised to describe physical observations or philosophical concepts. Every man can adapt it to his own particular needs. For instance no one can look at a symbol and be sure of what it means. So far, science has used every letter in the alphabet, large, small and italic, each symbolizing many different things. They have used bold-faced letters, Gothic-type letters, Greek letters, both capital and small, subscripts, superscripts, asterisks, even Hebrew letters. Different scientists use different symbols for the same concept and the same symbol for different concepts. So if you show a disconnected page like this to any man, without information as to the subject being investigated or the particular symbology used, he could absolutely not make sense out of it.î
I interrupted: ìBut you said he was working on quadrupole moments. Does that make this sensible?î and I tapped the spot on my chest where the foolscap had been slowly scorching a hole in my jacket for two days.
ìI canít tell. I saw none of the standard relationships that Iíd expect to be involved. At least I recognized none. But I obviously canít commit myself.î
There was a short silence, then he said: ìIíll tell you. Why donít you check with his students?î
I lifted my eyebrows: ìYou mean in his classes?î
He seemed annoyed: ìNo, for Heavenís sake. His research students! His doctoral candidates! Theyíve been working with him. Theyíll know the details of that work better than I, or anyone in the faculty, could possibly know it.î
ìItís an idea,î I said, casually. It was, too. I donít know why, but I wouldnít have thought of it myself. I guess itís because itís only natural to think that any professor knows more than any student.
Keyser latched onto a lapel as I rose to leave. ì And, besides,î he said, ìI think youíre on the wrong track. This is in confidence, you understand, and I wouldnít say it except for the unusual circumstances, but Tywood is not thought of too highly in the profession. Oh, heís an adequate teacher, Iíll admit, but his research papers have never commanded respect. There has always been a tendency towards vague theorizing, unsupported by experimental evidence. That paper of yours is probably more of it. No one could possibly want toÖer, kidnap him because of it.î
ìIs that so? I see. Any ideas, yourself, as to why heís gone, or where heís gone?î
ìNothing concrete,î he said pursing his lips, ìbut everyone knows he is a sick man. He had a stroke two years ago that kept him out of classes for a semester. He never did get well. His left side was paralyzed for a while and he still limps. Another stroke would kill him. It could come any time.î
ìYou think heís dead, then?î
ìItís not impossible.î
ìBut whereís the body, then?î
ìWell, really-That is your job, I think.ì
It was, and I left.
I interviewed each one of Tywoodís four research students in a volume of chaos called a research laboratory. These student research laboratories usually have two hopefuls working therein, said two constituting a floating population, since every year or so they are alternately replaced.
Consequently, the laboratory has its equipment stack in tiers. On the laboratory benches is the equipment immediately being used, and in three or four of the handiest drawers are replacements or supplements which are likely to be used. In the farther drawers, in the shelves reaching up to the ceiling, in odd corners, are fading remnants of the past student generations-oddments never used and never discarded. It is claimed, in fact, that no research student ever knew all the contents of his laboratory.
All four of Tywoodís students were worried. But three were worried mainly by their own status. That is, by the possible effect the absence of Tywood might have on the status of their ìproblem.î I dismissed those three-who all have their degrees now, I hope-and called back the fourth.
He had the most haggard look of all, and had been least communicative-which I considered a hopeful sign.
He now sat stiffly in the straight-backed chair at the right of the desk, while I leaned back in a creaky old swivel-chair and pushed my hat off my forehead. His name was Edwin Howe and he did get his degree later on; I know that for sure, because heís a big wheel in the Department of Science now.
I said: ìYou do the same work the other boys do, I suppose?î
ìItís all nuclear work, in a way.î
ìBut itís not all exactly the same?î
He shook his head slowly. ìWe take different angles. You have to have something clear-cut, you know, or you wonít be able to publish. Weíve got to get our degrees.î
He said it exactly the way you or I might say, ìWeíve got to make a living.î At that, maybe itís the same thing for them.
I said: ìAll right. Whatís your angle?î
He said: ìI do the math. I mean, with Professor Tywood.î
ìWhat kind of math?î
And he smiled a little, getting the same sort of atmosphere about him that I had noticed in Professor Keyserís case that morning. A sort of, ìDo-you-really-think-I-can-explain-all-my-profound-thoughts-to-stupid-little-you?î sort of atmosphere.
All he said aloud, however, was: ìThat would be rather complicated to explain.î
ìIíll help you,î I said. ìIs that anything like it?î And I tossed the foolscap sheet at him.
He didnít give it any once-over. He just snatched it up and let out a thin wail: ìWhereíd you get this?î
ìFrom Tywoodís safe.î
ìDo you have the rest of it, too?î
ìItís safe,î I hedged.
He relaxed a little-just a little: ìYou didnít show it to anybody, did you?î
I showed it to Professor Keyser.î
Howe made an impolite sound with his lower lip and front teeth, ìThat jackass. What did he say?î
I turned the palms of my hands upward and Howe laughed. Then he said, in an offhand manner: ìWell, thatís the sort of stuff I do.î
ìAnd whatís it all about? Put it so I can understand it.î
There was distinct hesitation. He said: ìNow, look. This is confidential stuff. Even Popís other students donít know anything about it. I donít even think I know all about it. This isnít just a degree Iím after, you know. Itís Pop Tywoodís Nobel Prize, and itís going to be an Assistant Professorship for me at Cal Tech. This has got to be published before itís talked about.î
And I shook my head slowly and made my words very soft: ìNo, son. You have it twisted. Youíll have to talk about it before itís published, because Tywoodís gone and maybe heís dead and maybe he isnít. And if heís dead, maybe heís murdered. And when the department has a suspicion of murder, everybody talks. Now, it will look bad for you, kid, if you try to keep some secrets.î
It worked. I knew it would, because everyone reads murder mysteries and knows all the cliches. He jumped out of his chair and rattled the words off as if he had a script in front of him.
ìSurely,î he said, ìYou canít suspect me ofÖof anything like that. WhyÖwhy, my career-î
I shoved him back into his chair with the beginnings of a sweat on his forehead. I went into the next line: ìI donít suspect anybody of anything yet. And you wonít be in any trouble, if you talk, chum.î
He was ready to talk. ìNow this is all in strict confidence.î
Poor guy. He didnít know the meaning of the word ìstrict.î He was never out of eyeshot of an operator from that moment till the government decided to bury the whole case with the one final comment of ì?î Quote. Unquote. (Iím not kidding. To this day, the case is neither opened nor closed. Itís just ì?î)
He said, dubiously; ìYou know what time travel is, I suppose?î
Sure I knew what time travel was. My oldest kid is twelve and he listens to the afternoon video programs till he swells up visibly with the junk he absorbs at the ears and eyes.
ìWhat about time travel?î I said.
ìIn a sense, we can do it. Actually, itís only what you might call micro-temporal-translation -î
I almost lost my temper. In fact, I think I did. It seemed obvious that the squirt was trying to diddle me; and without subtlety. Iím used to having people think I look dumb; but not that dumb.
I said through the back of my throat: ìAre you going to tell me that Tywood is out somewhere in time-like Ace Rogers, the Lone Time Ranger?î (That was Juniorís favorite program-Ace Rogers was stopping Genghis Khan single-handed that week.)
But he looked as disgusted as I must have. ìNo,î he yelled. ìI donít know where Pop is. If youíd listen to me-I said micro-temporal-translation. Now, this isnít a video show and it isnít magic; this happens to be science. For instance, you know about matter-energy equivalence, I suppose.î
I nodded sourly. Everyone knows about that since Hiroshima in the last war but one.
ìAll right, then,î he went on, ìthatís good for a start. Now, if you take a brown mass of matter and apply temporal translation to it-you know, send it back in time-you are, in effect, creating matter at the point in time to which you are sending it. To do that, you must use an amount of energy equivalent to the amount of matter you have created. In other words, to send a gram-or, say, an ounce-of anything back in time, you have to disintegrate an ounce of matter completely, to furnish the energy required.î
ìHm-m-m,î I said, ìthatís to create the ounce of matter in the past. But arenít you destroying an ounce of matter by removing it from the present? Doesnít that create the equivalent amount of energy?î
And he looked just about as annoyed as a fellow sitting on a bumblebee that wasnít quite dead. Apparently laymen are never supposed to question scientists.
He said: ìI was trying to simplify it so you would understand it. Actually, itís more complicated. It would be very nice if we could use the energy of disappearance to cause it to appear, but that would be working in a circle, believe me. The requirements of entropy would forbid it. To put it more rigorously, the energy is required to overcome temporal inertia and it just works out so that the energy in ergs required to send back a mass, in grams, is equal to that mass times the square of the speed of light in centimeters per second. Which just happens to be the Einstein Mass-Energy Equivalence Equation. I can give you the mathematics, you know.î
ìI know,î I waxed some of that misplaced eagerness back. ìBut was all this worked out experimentally? Or is it just on paper?î
Obviously, the thing was to keep him talking.
He had that queer light in his eye that every research student gets, I am told, when he is asked to discuss his problem. Hell discuss it with anyone, even with a ìdumb flatfootî-which was convenient at the moment.
ìYou see,î he said like a man slipping you the inside dope on a shady business deal, ìwhat started the whole thing was this neutrino business. Theyíve been trying to find that neutrino since the late thirties and they havenít succeeded. Itís a subatomic particle which has no charge and has a mass much less than even an electron. Naturally, itís next to impossible to spot, and hasnít been spotted yet. But they keep looking because, without assuming that a neutrino exists, the energetics of some nuclear reactions canít be balanced. So Pop Tywood got the idea about twenty years ago that some energy was disappearing, in the form of matter, back into time. We got working on that-or he did-and Iím the first student heís ever had tackle it along with him.
ìObviously, we had to work with tiny amounts of material andÖ well, it was just a stroke of genius on Popís part to think of using traces of artificial radioactive isotopes. You could work with just a few micrograms of it, you know, by following its activity with counters. The variation of activity with time should follow a very definite and simple law which has never been altered by any laboratory condition known.
ìWell, weíd send a speck back fifteen minutes, say, and fifteen minutes before we did that-everything was arranged automatically, you see-the count jumped to nearly double what it should be, fell off normally, and then dropped sharply at the moment it was sent back below where it would have been normally. The material overlapped itself in time, you see, and for fifteen minutes we counted the doubled material-î
I interrupted: ìYou mean you had the same atoms existing in two places at the same time.î
ìYes,î he said, with mild surprise, ìwhy not? Thatís why we use so much energy-the equivalent of creating those atoms.î And then he rushed on, ìNow Iíll tell you what my particular job is. If you send back the material fifteen minutes, it is apparently sent back to the same spot relative to the Earth despite the fact that in fifteen minutes, the Earth moved sixteen thousand miles around the Sun, and the Sun itself moves more thousand miles and so on. But there are certain tiny discrepancies which Iíve analyzed and which turn out to be due, possibly, to two causes.
ìFirst, there is a frictional effect-if you can use such a term-so that matter does drift a little with respect to the Earth, depending on how far back in time it is sent, and on the nature of material. Then, too, some of the discrepancy can only be explained by the assumption that passage through time itself takes time.î
ìHowís that?î I said.
ìWhat I mean is that some of the radioactivity is evenly spread throughout the time of translation as if the material tested had been reacting during backward passage through time by a constant amount. My figures show that-well, if you were to be moved backward in time, you would age one day for every hundred years. Or, to put it another way, if you could watch a time dial which recorded the time outside a ëtime-machine,í your watch would move forward twenty-four hours while the time dial moved back a hundred years. Thatís a universal constant, I think, because the speed of light is a universal constant. Anyway, thatís my work.î
After a few minutes, in which I chewed all this, I asked: ìWhere did you get the energy needed for your experiments?î
ìThey ran out a special line from the power plant. Popís a big shot there, and swung the deal.î
ìHm-m-m. What was the heaviest amount of material you sent into the past?î
ìOhî-he sent his eyes upwards-îI think we shot back one hundredth of a milligram once. Thatís ten micrograms.î
ìEver try sending anything into the future?î
ìThat wonít work,î he put in quickly. ìImpossible. You canít change signs like that, because the energy required becomes more than infinite. Itís a one-way proposition.î
I looked hard at my fingernails: ìHow much material could you send back in time if you fissioned aboutÖoh, say, one hundred pounds of plutonium.î Things, I thought, were becoming, if anything, too obvious.
The answer came quickly: ìIn plutonium fission,î he said, ìnot more than one or two percent of the mass is converted into energy. Therefore, one hundred pounds of plutonium when completely used up would send a pound or two back into time.î
ìIs that all? But could you handle all that energy? I mean, a hundred pounds of plutonium can make quite an explosion.î
ìAll relative,î he said, a bit pompously. ìIf you took all that energy and let it loose a little at a time, you could handle it. If you released it all at once, but used it just as fast as you released it, you could still handle it. In sending back material through time, energy can be used much faster than it can possibly be released even through fission. Theoretically, anywayÖ
ìBut how do you get rid of it?î
ìItís spread through time, naturally. Of course, the minimum time through which material could be transferred would, therefore, depend on the mass of the material. Otherwise, youíre liable to have the energy density with time too high.î
ìAll right, kid,î I said. ìIím calling up headquarters, and theyíll send a man here to take you home. Youíll stay there a while.î
ìBut-What for?î
ìIt wonít be for long.î
It wasnít-and it was made up to him afterwards.
I spent the evening at Headquarters. We had a library there-a very special kind of library. The very morning after the explosion, two or three operators had drifted quietly into the chemistry and physics libraries of the University. Experts in their way. They located every article Tywood had ever published in any scientific journal and had snapped each page. Nothing was disturbed otherwise.
Other men went through magazine files and through book lists. It ended with a room at Headquarters that represented a complete Tywoodana. Nor was there a definite purpose in doing this. It merely represented part of the thoroughness with which a problem of this sort is met.
I went through that library. Not the scientific papers. I knew thereíd be nothing there that I wanted. But he had written a series of articles for a magazine twenty years back, and I read those. And I grabbed at every piece of private correspondence they had available.
After that, I just sat and thought-and got scared.
I got to bed about four in the morning and had nightmares.
But I was in the Bossí private office at nine in the morning just the same.
Heís a big man, the Boss, with iron-gray hair slicked down tight. He doesnít smoke, but he keeps a box of cigars on his desk and when he doesnít want to say anything for a few seconds, he picks one up, rolls it about a little, smells it, then sticks it right into the middle of his mouth and lights it in a very careful way. By that time, he either has something to say or doesnít have to say anything at all. Then he puts the cigar down and lets it bum to death.
He used up a box in about three weeks, and every Christmas, half his gift-wraps held boxes of cigars.
He wasnít reaching for any cigars now, though. He just folded his big fists together on the desk and looked up at me from under a creased forehead. ìWhatís boiling?î
I told him. Slowly, because micro-temporal-translation doesnít sit well with anybody, especially when you call it time travel, which I did. Itís a sign of how serious things were that he only asked me once if I were crazy.
Then I was finished and we stared at each other.
He said: ìAnd you think he tried to send something back in time-something weighing a pound or two-and blew an entire plant doing it?î
ìIt fits in,î I said.
I let him go for a while. He was thinking and I wanted him to keep on thinking. I wanted him, if possible, to think of the same thing I was thinking, so that I wouldnít have to tell him
Because I hated to have to tell him-
Because it was nuts, for, one thing. And too horrible, for another.
So I kept quiet and he kept on thinking and every once in a while some of his thoughts came to the surface.
After a while, he said: ìAssuming the student, Howe, to have told the truth-and youíd better check his notebooks, by the way, which I hope youíve impounded-ì
ìThe entire wing of that floor is out of bounds, sir. Edwards has the notebooks.î
He went on: ì All right. Assuming he told us all the truth he knows, why did Tywood jump from less than a milligram to a pound?î
His eyes came down and they were hard: ìNow youíre concentrating on the time-travel angle. To you, I gather, that is the crucial point, with the energy involved as incidental-purely incidental.î
ìYes, sir,î I said grimly. ìI think exactly that.î
ìHave you considered that you might be wrong? That you might have matters inverted?î
ìI donít quite get that.î
ìWell, look. You say youíve read up on Tywood. All right. He was one of that bunch of scientists after World War II that fought the atom bomb; wanted a world state-you know about that, donít you?î
I nodded.
ìHe had a guilt complex, ì the Boss said with energy. ìHeíd helped work out the bomb, and he couldnít sleep nights thinking of what heíd done. He lived with that fear for years. And even though the bomb wasnít used in World War III, can you imagine what every day of uncertainty must have meant to him? Can you imagine the shriveling horror in his soul as he waited for others to make the decision at every crucial moment till the final Compromise of Sixty-Five?
ìWe have a complete psychiatric analysis of Tywood and several others just like him, taken during the last war. Did you know that?î
ìNo, sir.î
ìItís true. We let up after Sixty-Five, of course, because with the establishment of world control of atomic power, the scrapping of the atomic bomb stockpile in all countries, and the establishment of research liaison among the various spheres of influence on the planet, most of the ethical conflict in the scientific mind was removed.
ìBut the findings at the time were serious. In 1964, Tywood had a morbid subconscious hatred for the very concept of atomic power. He began to make mistakes, serious ones. Eventually, we were forced to take him off research of any kind. And several others as well, even though things were pretty bad at the time. We had just lost India, if you remember.î
Considering that I was in India at the time, I remembered. But I still wasnít seeing his point.
ìNow, what,î he continued, ìif dregs of that attitude remained buried in Tywood to the very end? Donít you see that this time-travel is a double-edged sword? Why throw a pound of anything into the past, anyway? For the sake of proving a point? He had proved his case just as much when he sent back a fraction of a milligram. That was good enough for the Nobel Prize, I suppose.
ìBut there was one thing he could do with a pound of matter that he couldnít do with a milligram, and that was to drain a power plant. So that was what he must have been after. He had discovered a way of consuming inconceivable quantities of energy. By sending back eighty pounds of dirt, he could remove all the existing plutonium in the world, End atomic power for an indefinite period.î
I was completely unimpressed, but I tried not to make that too plain. I just said: ìDo you think he could possibly have thought he could get away with it more than once?î
ìThis is all based on the fact that he wasnít a normal man. How do I know what he could imagine he could do? Besides, there may be men behind him-with less science and more brains-who are quite ready to continue onwards from this point.î
ìHave any of these men been found yet? Any evidence of such men?î
A little wait, and his hand reached for the cigar box. He stared at the cigar and turned it end for end. Just a little wait more. I was patient.
Then he put it down decisively without lighting it. ì
ìNo,î he said.
He looked at me, and clear through me, and said: ìThen, you still donít go for that?î
I shrugged, ìWell-It doesnít sound right.î
ìDo you have a notion of your own?î
ìYes. But I canít bring myself to talk about it. If Iím wrong, Iím the wrongest man that ever was; but if Iím right, Iím the rightest.î
ìIíll listen,î he said, and he put his hand under the desk.
That was the pay-off. The room was armored, sound-proof, and radiation-proof to anything short of a nuclear explosion. And with that little signal showing on his secretaryís desk, the President of the United States couldnít have interrupted us.
I leaned back and said: ìChief, do you happen to remember how you met your wife? Was it a little thing?î
He must have thought it a non sequitur. What else could he have thought? But he was giving me my head now; having his own reasons, I suppose.
He just smiled and said: ìI sneezed and she turned around. It was at a street comer.î
ìWhat made you be on that street corner just then? What made her be? Do you remember just why you sneezed? Where you caught the cold? Or where the speck of dust came from? Imagine how many factors had to intersect in just the right place at just the right time for you to meet your wife.î
ìI suppose we would have met some other time, if not then?î
ìBut you canít know that. How do you know whom you didnít meet, because once when you might have turned around. you didnít; because once when you might have been late, you werenít. Your life forks at every instant, and you go down one of the forks almost at random, and so does everyone else. Start twenty years ago, and the forks diverge further and further with time.
ìYou sneezed, and met a girl, and not another. As a consequence, you made certain decisions, and so did the girl, and so did the girl you didnít meet, and the man who did meet her, and the people you all met thereafter. And your family, her family, their family-and your children.
ìBecause you sneezed twenty years ago, five people, or fifty, or five hundred, might be dead now who would have been alive, or might be alive who would have been dead. Move it two hundred years ago: two thousand years ago, and a sneeze-even by someone no history ever heard of-might have meant that no one now alive would have been aliveÖ
The Boss rubbed the back of his head: ìWidening ripples. I read a story once-î
ìSo did I. Itís not a new idea-but I want you to think about it for a while, because I want to read to you from an article by Professor Elmer Tywood in a magazine twenty years old. It was just before the last warÖ
I had copies of the film in my pocket and the white wall made a beautiful screen, which was what it was meant to do. The boss made a motion to turn about, but I waved him back.
ìNo, sir,î I said. ìI want to read this to you. And I want you to listen to it.î
He leaned back.
ìThe article,Ö I went on, is entitled: ëManís First Great Failure!í Remember, this was just before the war, when the bitter disappointment at the final failure of the United Nations was at its height. What I will read are some excerpts from the first part of the article. It goes like this:
ìíÖThat Man, with his technical perfection, has failed to solve the great sociological problems of today is only the second immense tragedy that has come to the race. The first, and perhaps the greater, was that, once, these same great sociological problems were solved; and yet these solutions were not permanent, because the technical perfection we have today did not then exist
ìëIt was a case of having bread without butter, or butter without bread. N ever both togetherÖ
ìëConsider the Hellenic world, from which our philosophy, our mathematics, our ethics, our art, our literature-our entire culture, in fact-stemÖIn the days of Pericles, Greece, like our own world in microcosm, was a surprisingly modem potpourri of conflicting ideologies and ways of life. But then Rome came, adopting the culture, but bestowing, and enforcing, peace. To be sure, the Pax Romana lasted only two hundred years, but no like period has existed sinceÖ
ìëWar was abolished. Nationalism did not exist. The Roman citizen was Empire-wide. Paul of Tarsus and Flavius Josephus were Roman citizens. Spaniards, North Africans, Illyrians assumed the purple. Slavery existed, but it was an indiscriminate slavery, imposed as a punishment, incurred as the price of economic failure, brought on by the fortunes of war. No man was a natural slave-because of the color of his skin or the place of his birth.
ìëReligious toleration was complete. If an exception was made early in the case of the Christians, it was because they refused to accept the principle of toleration; because they insisted that only they themselves knew truth-a principle abhorrent to the civilized RomanÖ
ìëWith all of Western culture under a single polis, with the cancer of religious and national particularism and exclusivism absent; with a high civilization in existence-why could not Man hold his gains?
ìëIt was because, technologically, ancient Hellenism remained backward. It was because without a machine civilization, the price of leisure-and hence civilization and culture-for the few, was slavery for the many. Because the civilization could not find the means to bring comfort and ease to all the population.
ìëTherefore, the depressed classes turned to the other world, and to religions which spurned the material benefits of this world-so that science was made impossible in any true sense for over a millennium. And further, as the initial impetus of Hellenism waned, the Empire lacked the technological powers to beat back the barbarians. In fact, it was not till after 1500 A.D. that war became sufficiently a function of the industrial resources of a nation to enable the settled people to defeat invading tribesmen and nomads with easeÖ
ìëImagine, then, if somehow the ancient Greeks had learned just a hint of modem chemistry and physics. Imagine if the growth of the Empire had been accompanied by the growth of science, technology and industry. Imagine an Empire in which machinery replaced slaves, in which all men had a decent share of the worldís goods, in which the legion became the armored column against which no barbarians could stand. Imagine an Empire which would therefore spread all over the world, without religious or national prejudices
ìí An Empire of all men-all brothers-eventually all freeÖ
ì ëIf history could be changed. If that first great failure could have been prevented-í ì
And I stopped at that point.
ìWell?î said the Boss.
ìWell,î I said, ìI think it isnít difficult to connect all that with the fact that Tywood blew an entire power plant in his anxiety to send something back to the past, while in his office safe we found sections of a chemistry textbook translated into Greek.î
His face changed, while he considered.
Then he said heavily: ìBut nothingís happened.î
ìI know. But then Iíve been told by Tywoodís student that it takes a day to move back a century in time. Assuming that ancient Greece was the target area, we have twenty centuries, hence twenty days.î
ìBut can it be stopped?î
ì I wouldnít know. Tywood might, but heís dead.î
The enormity of it all hit me at once, deeper than it had the night before-
All humanity was virtually under sentence of death. And while that was merely horrible abstraction, the fact that reduced it to a thoroughly unbearable reality was that I was, too. And my wife, and my kid.
Further, it was a death without precedence. A ceasing to exist, and no more. The passing of a breath. The vanishing of a dream. The drift into eternal non-space and non-time of a shadow. I would not be dead at all, in fact I would merely never have been born.
Or would I? Would I exist-my individuality-my ego-my soul, if you like? Another life? Other circumstances?
I thought none of that in words then. But if a cold knot in the stomach could ever speak under the circumstances, it would sound like that, I think.
The Boss moved in on my thoughts-hard.
ìThen, we have about two and a half weeks. No time to lose. Come on.î
I grinned with one side of my mouth: ìWhat do we do? Chase the book?î
ìNo,î he replied coldly, ìbut there are two courses of action we must follow. First, you may be wrong-altogether. All of this circumstantial reasoning may still represent a false lead, perhaps deliberately thrown before us, to cover up the real truth. That must be checked.
ìSecondly, you may be right-but there may be some way of stopping the book: other than chasing it in a time machine, I mean. If so, we must find out how.î
ìI would just like to say, sir, if this is a false lead, only a madman would consider it a believable one. So suppose Iím right, and suppose thereís no way of stopping it?î
ìThen, young fellow, Iím going to keep pretty busy for two and a half weeks, and Iíd advise you to do the same. The time will pass more quickly that way.î
Of course he was right.
ìWhere do we start?î I asked.
ìThe first thing we need is a list of all men and women on the government payroll under Tywood.î
ìWhy?î
ìReasoning. Your specialty, you know. Tywood doesnít know Greek, I think we can assume with fair safety, so someone else must have done the translating. It isnít likely that anyone would do a job like that for nothing, and it isnít likely that Tywood would payout of his personal funds-not on a professorís salary.î
ìHe might, ì I pointed out, ìhave been interested in more secrecy than a government payroll affords.î
ìWhy? Where was the danger? Is it a crime to translate a chemistry textbook into Greek? Who would ever deduce from that a plot such as youíve described?î
It took us half an hour to turn up the name of Mycroft James Boulder, listed as ìConsultant, ì and to find out that he was mentioned in the University Catalogue as Assistant Professor of Philosophy and to check by telephone that among his many accomplishments was a thorough knowledge of Attic Greek.
Which was a coincidence-because with the Boss reaching for his hat, the interoffice teletype clicked away and it turned out that Mycroft James Boulder was in the anteroom, at the end of a two-hour continuing insistence that he see the Boss.
The Boss put his hat back and opened his office door.
Professor Mycroft James Boulder was a gray man. His hair was gray and his eyes were gray. His suit was gray, too.
But most of all, his expression was gray; gray with a tension that seemed to twist at the lines in his thin face.
Boulder said, softly: ìIíve been trying for three days to get a hearing, sir, with a responsible man. I can get no higher than yourself.î
ìI may be high enough,î said the Boss. ìWhatís on your mind?î
ìIt is quite important that I be granted an interview with Professor Tywood.î
ìDo you know where he is?î
ìI am quite certain that he is in government custody.î
ìWhy?î
ìBecause I know that he was planning an experiment which would entail the breaking of security regulations. Events since, as nearly as I can make them out, flownaturally from the supposition that security regulations have indeed been broken. I can presume, then, that the experiment has at least been attempted. I must discover whether it has been successfully concluded.î
ìProfessor Boulder,î said the Boss, ìI believe you can read Greek.î
ìYes, I can,î -coolly.
ìAnd have translated chemical texts for Professor Tywood on government money.î
ìYes-as a legally employed consultant.î
ìYet such translation, under the circumstances, constitutes a crime, since it makes you an accessory to Tywoodís crime.î
ìYou can establish a connection?î
ìCanít you? Or havenít you heard of Tywoodís notions on time travel, orÖwhat do you call itÖmicro-temporal-translation?î
ìAh?î and Boulder smiled a little. ìHeís told you, then.î
ìNo, he hasnít,î said the Boss, harshly. ìProfessor Tywood is dead.î
ìWhat?î Then-îI donít believe you.î
ìHe died of apoplexy. Look at this.î
He had one of the photographs taken that first night in his wall safe. Tywoodís face was distorted but recognizable-sprawled and dead.
Boulderís breath went in and out as if the gears were clogged. He stared at the picture for three full minutes by the electric clock on the wall. ìWhere is this place?î he asked.
ìThe Atomic Power Plant. ì
ìHad he finished his experiment?î
The Boss shrugged: ìThereís no way of telling. He was dead when we found him.î
Boulderís lips were pinched and colorless. ìThat must be determined, somehow. A commission of scientists must be established, and, if necessary, the experiment must be repeated-î
But the Boss just looked at him, and reached for a cigar. Iíve never seen him take longer-and when he put it down, curled in its unused smoke, he said: ìTywood wrote an article for a magazine, twenty years ago-î
ìOh, ì and the professorís lips twisted, ìis that what gave you your clue? You may ignore that. The man is only a physical scientist and knows nothing of either history or sociology. A schoolboyís dreams and nothing more.î
ìThen, you donít think sending your translation back will inaugurate a Golden Age, do you?î
ìOf course not. Do you think you can graft the developments of two thousand years of slow labor onto a child society not ready for it? Do you think a great invention or a great scientific principle is born full-grown in the mind of a genius divorced from his cultural milieu? Newtonís enunciation of the Law of Gravity was delayed for twenty years because the then-current figure for the Earthís diameter was wrong by ten percent. Archimedes almost discovered calculus, but failed because Arabic numerals, invented by some nameless Hindu or group of Hindus, were unknown to him.
ìFor that matter, the mere existence of a slave society in ancient Greece and Rome meant that machines could scarcely attract much attention-slaves being so much cheaper and more adaptable. And men of true intellect could scarcely be expected to spend their energies on devices intended for manual labor. Even Archimedes, the greatest engineer of antiquity, refused to publish any of his practical inventions-only mathematic abstractions. And when a young man asked Plato of what use geometry was, he was forthwith expelled from the Academy as a man with a mean, unphilosophic soul.
ìScience does not plunge forward-it inches along in the directions permitted by the greater forces that mold society and which are in turn molded by society. And no great man advances but on the shoulders of the society that surrounds him-î
The Boss interrupted him at that point. ìSuppose you tell us what your part in Tywoodís work was, then. Weíll take your word for it that history cannot be changed.î
ìOh it can, but not purposefully-you see, when Tywood first requested my services in the matter of translating certain textbook passages into Greek, I agreed for the money involved. But he wanted the translation on parchment; he insisted on the use of ancient Greek terminology-the language of Plato, to use his words-regardless of how I had to twist the literal significance of passages, and he wanted it hand-written in rolls.
ìI was curious. I, too, found his magazine article. It was difficult for me to jump to the obvious conclusion, since the achievements of modem science transcend the imaginings of philosophy in so many ways. But I learned the truth eventually, and it was at once obvious that Tywoodís theory of changing history was infantile. There are twenty million variables for every instant of time, and no system of mathematics-no mathematic psychohistory, to coin a phrase-has yet been developed to handle that ocean of varying functions.
ìIn short, any variation of events two thousand years ago would change all subsequent history, but in no predictable way.î
The boss suggested, with a false quietness: ìLike the pebble that starts the avalanche, right?î
ìExactly. You have some understanding of the situation, I see. I thought deeply for weeks before I proceeded, and then I realized how I must act- must act.î
There was a low roar. The Boss stood up and his chair went over backward. He swung around his desk, and he had a hand on Boulderís throat. I was stepping out to stop him, but he waved me back-
He was only tightening the necktie a little. Boulder could still breathe. He had gone very white, and for all the time that the Boss talked, he restricted himself to just that-breathing.
And the Boss said: ìSure, I can see how you decided you must act. I know that some of you brain-sick philosophers think the world needs fixing. You want to throw the dice again and see what turns up. Maybe you donít even care if youíre alive in the new setup-or that no one can possibly know what youíve done. But youíre going to create, just the same. Youíre going to give God another chance, so to speak.
ìMaybe I just want to live-but the world could be worse. In twenty million different ways, it could be worse. A fellow named Wilder once wrote a play called The Skin of Our Teeth. Maybe youíve read it. Its thesis was that Mankind survived by just that skin of their teeth. No, Iím not going to give you a speech about the Ice Age nearly wiping us out. I donít know enough. Iím not even going to talk about the Greeks winning at Marathon; the Arabs being defeated at Tours; the Mongols turning back at the last minute without even being defeated-because Iím no historian.
ìBut take the Twentieth Century. The Germans were stopped at the Marne twice in World War I. Dunkirk happened in World War II, and somehow the Germans were stopped at Moscow and Stalingrad. We could have used the atom bomb in the last war and we didnít, and just when it looked as if both sides would have to, the Great Compromise happened-just because General Bruce was delayed in taking off from the Ceylon airfield long enough to receive the message directly. One after the other, just like that, all through history-lucky breaks. For every ëif that didnít come true that would have made wonder-men of all of us if it had, there were twenty ëifsí that didnít come true that would have brought disaster to all of us if they had.
ìYouíre gambling on that one-in-twenty chance-gambling every life on Earth. And youíve succeeded, too, because Tywood did send that text back.î
He ground out that last sentence, and opened his fist, so that Boulder could fall out and back into his chair.
And Boulder laughed.
ìYou fool, ì he gasped, bitterly, ìHow close you can be and yet how widely you can miss the mark. Tywood did send his book back, then? You are sure of that?î
ìNo chemical textbook in Greek was found on the scene,î said the Boss, grimly, ìand millions of calories of energy had disappeared. Which doesnít change the fact, however, that we have two and a half weeks in which to-make things interesting for you.î
ìOh, nonsense. No foolish dramatics, please. Just listen to me, and try to understand. There were Greek philosophers once, named Leucippus and Democritus, who evolved an atomic theory. All matter, they said, was composed of atoms. Varieties of atoms were distinct and changeless and by their different combinations with each other formed the various substances found in nature. That theory was not the result of experiment or observation. It came into being, somehow, full-grown.
ìThe didactic Roman poet Lucretius, in his ëDe Rerum Natura,í-ë On the Nature of Thingsí-elaborated on that theory and throughout manages to sound startlingly modem.
ìIn Hellenistic times, Hero built a steam engine and weapons of war became almost mechanized. The period has been referred to as an abortive mechanical age, which came to nothing because, somehow, it neither grew out of nor fitted into its social and economic milieu. Alexandrian science was a queer and rather inexplicable phenomenon.
ìThen one might mention the old Roman legend about the books of the Sibyl that contained mysterious information direct from the gods
ìIn other words, gentlemen, while you are right that any change in the course of past events, however trifling, would have incalculable consequences, and while I also believe that you are right in supposing that any random change is much more likely to be for the worse than for the better, I must point out that you are nevertheless wrong in your final conclusions.
ìBecause THIS is the world in which the Greek chemistry text WAS sent back.
ìThis has been a Red Queenís race, if you remember your ëThrough the Looking Glass.í In the Red Queenís country, one had to run as fast as one could merely to stay in the same place. And so it was in this case! Tywood may have thought he was creating a new world, but it was I who prepared the translations, and I took care that only such passages as would account for the queer scraps of knowledge the ancients apparently got from nowhere would be included
ìAnd my only intention, for all my racing, was to stay in the same place.î
Three weeks passed; three months; three years. Nothing happened. When nothing happens, you have no proof. We gave up trying to explain, and we ended, the Boss and I, by doubting it ourselves.
The case never ended. Boulder could not be considered a criminal without being considered a world savior as well, and vice versa. He was ignored. And in the end, the case was neither solved, nor closed out; merely put in a file all by itself, under the designation ì?î and buried in the deepest vault in Washington.
The Boss is in Washington now; a big wheel. And Iím Regional Head of the Bureau.
Boulder is still assistant professor, though. Promotions are slow at the University.



***



ìThe Red Queenís Race,î my fifty-eighth story, was the first to be written by Dr. Asimov.
In September I began another story, ìMother Earth,î and submitted it to Campbell on October 12, 1948. After a comparatively small revision of the ending, he took that one, too.








Mother Earth


ìBut can you be certain? Are you sure that even a professional historian can always distinguish between victory and defeat?î
Gustav Stein, who delivered himself of that mocking question with a whiskered smile and a gentle wipe at the gray mustache from the neighborhood of which he had just removed an empty glass, was not an historian. He was a physiologist.
But his companion was an historian, and he accepted the gentle thrust with a smile of his own.
Steinís apartment was, for Earth, quite luxurious. It lacked the empty privacy of the Outer Worlds, of course, since from its window there stretched outward a phenomenon that belonged only to the home planet-a city. A large city, full of people, rubbing shoulders, mingling sweat
Nor was Steinís apartment fitted with its own power and its own utility supply. It lacked even the most elementary quota of positronic robots. In short, it lacked the dignity of self-sufficiency, and like all things on Earth, it was merely part of a community, a pendant unit of a cluster, a portion of a mob.
But Stein was an Earthman by birth and used to it. And after all, by Earth standards the apartment was still luxurious.
It was just that looking outward through the same windows before which lay the city, one could see the stars and among them the Outer Worlds, where there were no cities but only gardens; where the lawns were streaks of emerald, where all human beings were kings, and where all good Earthmen earnestly and vainly hoped to go some day.
Except for a few who knew better-like Gustav Stein.
The Friday evenings with Edward Field belonged to that class of ritual which comes with age and quiet life. It broke the week pleasantly for two elderly bachelors, and gave them an innocuous reason to linger over the sherry and the stars. It took them away from the crudities of life, and, most of all, it let them talk.
Field, especially, as a lecturer, scholar and man of modest means quoted chapter and verse from his still uncompleted history of Terrestrian Empire.
ìI wait for the last act, ì he explained. ìThen I can call it the ëDecline and Fall of Empireí and publish it.î
ìYou must expect the last act to come soon, then.î
ìIn a sense, it has come already. It is just that it is best to wait for all to recognize that fact. You see, there are three times when an Empire or an Economic System or a Social Institution falls, you skeptic-î
Field paused for effect and waited patiently for Stein to say, ì And those times are?î
ìFirst,î Field ticked off a right forefinger, ìthere is the time when just a little nub shows up that points an inexorable way to finality. It canít be seen or recognized until the finality arrives, when the original nub becomes visible to hindsight.î
ìAnd you can tell what that little nub is?î
ìI think so, since I already have the advantage of a century and a half of hindsight. It came when the Sirian sector colony, Aurora, first obtained permission of the Central Government at Earth to introduce positronic robots into their community life. Obviously, looking back at it, the road was clear for the development of a thoroughly mechanized society based upon robot labor and not human labor. And it is this mechanization that has been and will yet be the deciding factor in the struggle between the Outer Worlds and Earth.î
ìIt is?î murmured the physiologist. ìHow infernally clever you historians are. What and where is the second time the Empire fell?î
ìThe second point in time,î and Field gently bent his right middle finger backward, ìarrives when a signpost is raised for the expert so large and plain that it can be seen even without the aid of perspective. And that point has been passed, too, with the first establishment of an immigration quota against Earth by the Outer Worlds. The fact that Earth found itself unable to prevent an action so obviously detrimental to itself was a shout for all to hear, and that was fifty years ago.î
ìBetter and better. And the third point?î
ìThe third point?î Down went the ring finger. ìThat is the least important. That is when the signpost becomes a wall with a huge ëThe Endí scrawled upon it. The only requirement for knowing that the end has come, then, is neither perspective nor training, but merely the ability to listen to the video.î
ìI take it that the third point in time has not yet come.î
ìObviously not, or you would not need to ask. Yet it may come soon; for instance, if there is war.î
ìDo you think there will be?î
Field avoided commitment. ìTimes are unsettled, and a good deal of futile emotion is sweeping Earth on the immigration question. And if there should be a war, Earth would be defeated quickly and lastingly, and the wall would be erected.î
ìCan you be certain? Are you sure that even a professional historian can always distinguish between victory and defeat?î
Field smiled. He said: ìYou may know something I do not. For instance, they talk about something called the ëPacific Project.í ì
ìI never heard of it.î Stein refilled the two glasses, ìLet us speak of other things.î
He held up his glass to the broad window So that the far stars flickered rosily in the clear liquid and said: ìTo a happy ending to Earthís troubles.î
Field held up his own, ìTo the Pacific Project.î
Stein sipped gently and said: ìBut we drink to two different things.î
ìDo we?î
It is quite difficult to describe any of the Outer Worlds to a native Earthman, since it is not So much a description of a world that is required as a description of a state of mind. The Outer Worlds-some fifty of them, originally colonies, later dominions, later nations-differ extremely among themselves in a physical sense. But the state of mind is somewhat the same throughout.
It is something that grows out of a world not originally congenial to mankind, yet populated by the cream of the difficult, the different, the daring, the deviant.
If it is to be expressed in a word, that word is ìindividuality.î
There is the world of Aurora, for instance, three parsecs from Earth. It was the first planet settled outside the Solar System, and represented the dawn of interstellar travel. Hence its name.
It had air and water to start with, perhaps, but on Earthly standards it was rocky and infertile. The plant life that did exist, sustained by a yellow-green pigment completely unrelated to chlorophyll and not as efficient, gave the comparatively fertile regions a decidedly bilious and unpleasant appearance to unaccustomed eyes. No animal life higher than unicellular, and the equivalent of bacteria as well, were present. Nothing dangerous, naturally, since the two biological systems, of Earth and Aurora, were chemically unrelated.
Aurora became, quite gradually, a patchwork. Grains and fruit trees came first; shrubs, flowers, and grass afterward. Herds of livestock followed. And, as if it were necessary to prevent too close a copy of the mother planet, positronic robots also came to build the mansions, carve the landscapes, lay the power units. In short, to do the work, and turn the planet green and human.
There was the luxury of a new world and unlimited mineral resources. There was the splendid excess of atomic power laid out on new foundations with merely thousands, or, at most, millions, not billions, to service. There was the vast flowering of physical science, in worlds where there was room for it.
Take the home of Franklin Maynard, for instance, who, with his wife, three children, and twenty-seven robots, lived on an estate more than forty miles away, in distance, from the nearest neighbor. Yet by community-wave he could, if he wished, share the living room of any of the seventy-five million on Aurora-with each singly; with all simultaneously.
Maynard knew every inch of his valley. He knew just where it ended, sharply, and gave way to the alien crags, along whose undesirable slopes the angular, sharp leaves of the native furze clung sullenly-as if in hatred of the softer matter that had usurped its place in the sun.
Maynard did not have to leave that valley. He was a deputy in the Gathering, and a member of the Foreign Agents Committee, but he could transact all business but the most extremely essential, by community-wave, without ever sacrificing that precious privacy he had to have in a way no Earthman could understand.
Even the present business could be performed by community-wave. The man, for instance, who sat with him in his living room, was Charles Hijkman, and he, actually, was sitting in his own living room on an island in an artificial lake stocked with fifty varieties of fish, which happened to be twenty-five hundred miles distant, in space.
The connection was an illusion, of course. If Maynard were to reach out a hand, he could feel the invisible wall.
Even the robots were quite accustomed to the paradox, and when Hijkman raised a hand for a cigarette, Maynardís robot made no move to satisfy the desire, though a half-minute passed before Hijkmanís own robot could do so.
The two men spoke like Outer Worlders, that is, stiffly and in syllables too clipped to be friendly, and yet certainly not hostile. Merely undefinably lacking in the cream-however sour and thin at times-of human sociability which is so forced upon the inhabitants of Earthís ant heaps.
Maynard said: ìI have long wanted a private communion, Hijkman. My duties in the Gathering, this year-î
ìQuite. That is understood. You are welcome now, of course. In fact, especially so, since I have heard of the superior nature of your grounds and landscaping. Is it true that your cattle are fed on imported grass?î
ìIím afraid that is a slight exaggeration. Actually, certain of my best milkers feed on Terrestrial imports during calving time, but such a procedure would be prohibitively expensive, Iím afraid, if made general. It yields quite extraordinary milk, however. May I have the privilege of sending you a dayís output?î
ìIt would be most kind of you.î Hijkman bent his head, gravely. ìYou must receive some of my salmon in return.î
To a Terrestrial eye, the two men might have appeared much alike. Both were tall, though not unusually so for Aurora, where the average height of the adult male is six feet one and one half inches. Both were blond and hard-muscled, with sharp and pronounced features. Though neither was younger than forty, middle-age as yet sat lightly upon them.
So much for amenities. Without a change in tone, Maynard proceeded to the serious purpose of his call.
He said: ìThe Committee, you know, is now largely engaged with Moreanu and his Conservatives. We would like to deal with them firmly, we of the Independents, that is. But before we can do so with the requisite calm and certainty, I would like to ask you certain questions.î
ìWhy me?î
ìBecause you are Auroraís most important physicist.î Modesty is an unnatural attitude, and one which is only with difficulty taught to children. In an individualistic society it is useless and Hijkman was, therefore, unencumbered with it. He simply nodded objectively at Maynardís last words.
ìAnd,î continued Maynard, ëëas one of us. You are an Independent.î
ìI am a member of the Party. Dues-paying, but not very active.î
ìNevertheless safe. Now, tell me, have you heard of the Pacific Project.î
ìThe Pacific Project?î There was a polite inquiry in his words.
ìIt is something which is taking place on Earth. The Pacific is a Terrestrial ocean, but the name itself probably has no significance.î
ìI have never heard of it.î
ìI am not surprised. Few have, even on Earth. Our communion, by the way, is via tight-beam and nothing must go further.î
ìI understand.î
ìWhatever Pacific Project is-and our agents are extremely vague -it might conceivably be a menace. Many of those who on Earth pass for scientists seem to be connected with it. Also, some of Earthís more radical and foolish politicians.î
ìHm-m-m. There was once something called the Manhattan Project.î
ìYes,î urged Maynard, ìwhat about it?î
ìOh, itís an ancient thing. It merely occurred to me because of the analogy in names. The Manhattan Project was before the time of extra-terrestrial travel. Some petty war in the dark ages occurred, and it was the name given to a group of scientists who developed atomic power.î
ìAh,î Maynardís hand became a fist, ìand what do you think the Pacific Project can do, then?î
Hijkman considered. Then, softly: ìDo you think Earth is planning war?î
On Maynardís face there was a sudden expression of distaste. ìSix billion people. Six billion half-apes, rather, jammed into one system to a near-explosion point, facing only some millions of us, total. Donít you think it is a dangerous situation?î
ìOh, numbers!î
ìAll right. Are we safe despite the numbers? Tell me. Iím only an administrator, and youíre a physicist. Can Earth win a war in any way?î
Hijkman sat solemnly in his chair and thought carefully and slowly. Then he said: ìLet us reason. There are three broad classes of methods whereby an individual or group can gain his ends against opposition. On an increasing level of subtlety, those three classes can be termed the physical, the biological, and the psychological.
ìNow, the physical can be easily eliminated. Earth does not have an industrial background. It does not have a technical know-how. It has very limited resources. It lacks even a single outstanding physical scientist. So it is as impossible as anything in the Galaxy can be that they can develop any form of physico-chemical application that is not already known to the Outer Worlds. Provided, of course, that the conditions of the problem imply single-handed opposition on the part of Earth against any or all of the Outer Worlds. I take it that none of the Outer Worlds intends leaguing with Earth against us.î
Maynard indicated violent opposition even to the suggestion, ìNo, no, no. There is no question of that. Put it out of your mind.î
ìThen, ordinary physical surprise weapons are inconceivable. It is useless to discuss it further.î
ìThen, what about your second class, the biological?î
Slowly, Hijkman lifted his eyebrows: ìNow, that is less certain. Some Terrestrial biologists are quite competent, I am told. Naturally, since I am myself a physicist, I am not entirely qualified to judge this. Yet I believe that in certain restricted fields, they are still expert. In agricultural science, of course, to give an obvious example. And in bacteriology. Um-m-m-î
ìYes, what about bacteriological warfare?î
ìA thought! But no, no, quite inconceivable. A teeming, constricted world such as Earth cannot afford to fight an open latticework of fifty sparse worlds with germs. They are infinitely more subject to epidemics, that is, to retaliation in kind. In fact, I would say that given our living conditions here on Aurora and on the other Outer Worlds, no contagious disease could really take hold. No, Maynard. You can check with a bacteriologist, but I think heíll tell you the same.î
Maynard said: ìAnd the third class?î
ìThe psychological? Now, that is unpredictable. And yet the Outer Worlds are intelligent and healthy communities and not amenable to ordinary propaganda, or for that matter to any form of unhealthy emotionalism. Now, I wonder-î
ìYes?î
ìWhat if the Pacific Project is just that? I mean, a huge device to keep us off balance. Something top-secret, but meant to leak out in just the right fashion, so that the Outer Worlds yield a little to Earth. simply in order to play safe.î
There was a longish silence.
ìImpossible,î burst out Maynard, angrily.
ìYou react properly. You hesitate. But I donít seriously press the interpretation. It is merely a thought.î
A longer silence, then Hijkman spoke again: ì Are there any other questions?î
Maynard started out of a reverie, ìNoÖno-î
The wave broke off and a wall appeared where space had been a moment before.
Slowly, with stubborn disbelief, Franklin Maynard shook his head.
Ernest Keilin mounted the stairs with a feeling for all the past centuries. The building was old, cobwebbed with history. It once housed the Parliament of Man, and from it words went out that clanged throughout the stars.
It was a tall building. It soared-stretched-strained. Out and up to the stars, it reached; to the stars that had now turned away.
It no longer even housed the Parliament of Earth. That had now been switched to a newer, neoclassical building, one that imperfectly aped the architectural stylisms of the ancient pre-Atomic age.
Yet the older building still held its great name. Officially, it was still Stellar House, but it only housed the functionaries of a shriveled bureaucracy now.
Keilin got out at the twelfth floor, and the lift dropped quickly down behind him. The radiant sign said smoothly and quietly: Bureau of Information. He handed a letter to the receptionist. He waited. And eventually, he passed through the door which said, ìL. z. Cellioni-Secretary of Information.î
Cellioni was little and dark. His hair was thick and black, his mustache thin and black. His teeth, when he smiled, were startlingly white and even-so he smiled often.
He was smiling now, as he rose and held out his hand. Keilin took it, then an offered seat, then an offered cigar.
Cellioni said: ìI am very happy to see you, Mr. Keilin. It is kind of you to fly here from New York on such short notice.î
Keilin curved the corners of his lips down and made a tiny gesture with one hand, deprecating the whole business
ìAnd now,î continued Cellioni, ìI presume you would like an explanation of all this.î
ìI wouldnít refuse one,î said Keilin.
ìUnfortunately, it is difficult to know exactly how to explain. As Secretary of Information, my position is difficult. I must safeguard the security and well-being of Earth and, at the same time, observe our traditional freedom of the press. Naturally, and fortunately, we have no censorship, but just as naturally, there are times when we could almost wish we did have.î
ìIs this,î asked Keilin, ìwith reference to me? About censorship, I mean?î
Cellioni did not answer directly. Instead, he smiled again, slowly, and with a remarkable absence of joviality.
He said: ìYou, Mr. Keilin, have one of the most widely heard and influential talecasts on the video. Therefore, you are of peculiar interest to the government.î
ìThe time is mine,î said Keilin, stubbornly. ìI pay for it I pay taxes on the income I derive from it I adhere to all the common-law rulings on taboos. So I donít quite see of what interest I can be to the government.î
ìOh, you misunderstand me. Itís my fault, I suppose, for not being clearer. You have committed no crime, broken no laws. I have only admiration for your journalistic ability. What I refer to is your editorial attitude at times.î
ìWith respect to what?î
ìWith respect,î said Cellioni, with a sudden harshness about his thin lips, ìto our policy toward the Outer Worlds.î
ìMy editorial attitude represents what I feel and think, Mr. Secretary.î
ìI allow this. You have your right to your feelings and your thoughts. Yet it is injudicious to spread them about nightly to an audience of half a billion.î
ìInjudicious, according to you, perhaps. But legal, according to anybody.î
ìIt is sometimes necessary to place good of Country above a strict and selfish interpretation of legality.î
Keilin tapped his foot twice and frowned blackly.
ìLook,î he said, ìput this frankly. What is it you want?î
The Secretary of Information spread his hands out before him. ìIn a word-co-operation! Really, Mr. Keilin, we canít have you weakening the will of the people. Do you appreciate the position of Earth? Six billions, and a declining food supply! It is insupportable! And emigration is the only solution. No patriotic Earthman can fail to see the justice of our position. No reasonable human being anywhere can fail to see the justice of it.î
Keilin said: ìI agree with your premise that the population problem is serious, but emigration is not the only solution. In fact, emigration is the one sure way of hastening destruction.î
ìReally? And why do you say that?î
ìBecause the Outer Worlds will not permit emigration, and you can force their hand by war only. And we cannot win a war. î
ìTell me,î said Cellioni softly, ìhave you ever tried emigrating? It seems to me you could qualify. You are quite tall, rather light-haired, intelligent-î
The video-man Hushed. He said, curtly: ìI have hay fever.î
ìWell,î and the secretary smiled, ìthen you must have good reason for disapproving their arbitrary genetic and racist policies.î
Keilin replied with heat: ìI wonít be influenced by personal motives. I would disapprove their policies, if I qualified perfectly for emigration. But my disapproval would alter nothing. Their policies are their policies, and they can enforce them. Moreover, their policies have some reason even if wrong. Mankind is starting again on the Outer Worlds, and they-the ones who got there first-would like to eliminate some of the Haws of the human mechanism that have become obvious with time. A hay fever sufferer is a bad egg-genetically. A cancer prone even more so. Their prejudices against skin and hair colors are, of course, senseless, but I can grant that they are interested in uniformity and homogeneity. And as for Earth, we can do much even without the help of the Outer Worlds.î
ìFor instance, what?î
ìPositronic robots and hydroponic farming should be introduced, and-most of all-birth control must be instituted. An intelligent birth control, that is, based on firm psychiatric principles intended to eliminate the psychotic trends, congenital infirmities-î
ìAs they do in the Outer Worlds-î
ìNot at all. I have mentioned no racist principles. I talk only of mental and physical infirmities that are held in common by all ethnic and racial groups. And most of all, births must be held below deaths until a healthful equilibrium is reached.î
Cellioni said, grimly: ìWe lack the industrial techniques and the resources to introduce a robot-hydroponic technology in anything less than five centuries. Furthermore, the traditions of Earth, as well as current ethical beliefs, forbid robot labor and false foods. Most of all, they forbid the slaughter of unborn children. Now, come, Keilin, we canít have you pouring this out over video. It wonít work; it distracts the attention; it weakens the will.î
Keilin broke in, impatiently: ìMr. Secretary, do you want war?î
ìDo I want war? That is an impudent question.î
ìThen, who are the policy-makers in the government who do want war? For instance, who is responsible for the calculated rumor of the Pacific Project?î
ìThe Pacific Project? And where did you hear of that?î
ìMy sources are my secret.î
ìThen, Iíll tell you. You heard of this Pacific Project from Moreanu of Aurora on his recent trip to Earth. We know more about you than you suppose, Mr. Keilin.î
ìI believe that, but I do not admit that I received information from Moreanu. Why do you think I could get information from him? Is it because he was deliberately allowed to learn of this piece of trumpery?î
ìTrumpery?î
ìYes. I think Pacific Project is a fake. A fake meant to inspire confidence. I think the government plans to let the so-called secret leak out in order to strengthen its war policy. It is part of a war of nerves on Earthís own people, and it will be the ruin of Earth in the end.î
ìAnd I will take this theory of mine to the people.î
ìYou will not, Mr. Keilin,î said Cellioni, quietly.
ìI will.î
ìMr. Keilin, your friend, Ion Moreanu is having his troubles on Aurora, perhaps for being too friendly with you. Take care that you do not have equal trouble for being too friendly with him.î
ìIím not worried.î The video man laughed shortly, lunged to his feet and strode to the door.
Keilin smiled very gently when he found the door blocked by two large men: ìYou mean, I am under arrest right now.î
ìExactly,î said Cellioni.
ìOn what charge?î
ìWeíll think of some later.î
Keilin left-under escort.
On Aurora, the mirror image of the afore-described events was taking place, and on a larger scale.
The Foreign Agents Committee of the Gathering had been meeting now for days-ever since the session of the Gathering in which Ion Moreanu and his Conservative Party made their great bid to force a vote of no confidence. That it had failed was in part due to the superior political generalship of the Independents, and in some part due to the activity of this same Foreign Agents Committee.
For months now, the evidence had been accumulating, and when the vote of confidence turned out to be sizably in favor of the Independents, the Committee was able to strike in its own way.
Moreanu was subpoenaed in his own home, and placed under house arrest. Although this procedure of house arrest was not, under the circumstances, legal-a fact emphatically pointed out by Moreanu-it was nevertheless successfully accomplished.
For three days Moreanu was cross-examined thoroughly, in polite, even tones that scarcely ever veered from unemotional curiosity. The seven inquisitors of the Committee took turns in questioning, but Moreanu had respite only for ten-minute intervals during the hours in which the Committee sat.
After three days, he showed the effects. He was hoarse with demanding that he be faced with his accusers; weary with insisting that he be informed of the exact nature of the charges; throat-broken with shouting against the illegality of the procedure.
The Committee finally read statements at him-
ìIs this true or not? Is this true or not?î
Moreanu could merely shake his head wearily as the structure spidered about him.
He challenged the competency of the evidence and was smoothly informed that the proceedings constituted a Committee Investigation and not a trial
The chairman clapped his gavel, finally. He was a broad man of tremendous purpose. He spoke for an hour in his final summing up of the results of the inquiry, but only a relatively short portion of it need be quoted.
He said: ìIf you had merely conspired with others on Aurora, we could understand you, even forgive you. Such a fault would have been held in common with many ambitious men in history. It is not that at all. What horrifies us and removes all pity is your eagerness to consort with the disease-ridden, ignorant and subhuman remnants of Earth.
ìYou, the accused, stand here under a heavy weight of evidence showing you to have conspired with the worst elements of Earthís mongrel population-î
The chairman was interrupted by an agonized cry from Moreanu, ìBut the motive! What motive can you possibly attribute-î
The accused was pulled back into his seat. The chairman pursed his lips and departed from the slow gravity of his prepared speech to improvise a bit.
ìIt is not,î he said, ìfor this Committee to go into your motives. We have shown the facts of the case. The Committee does have evidence-î He paused, and looked along the line of the members to the right and the left, then continued. ìI think I may say that the Committee has evidence that points to your intentions to use Earth man power to engineer a coup that would leave you dictator over Aurora. But since the evidence has not been used, I will go no further into that, except to say that such a consummation is not inconsistent with your character as displayed at these hearings.î
He went back to his speech. ìThose of us who sit here have heard, I think, of something termed the ëPacific Project,í which, according to rumors, represents an attempt on the part of Earth to retrieve its lost dominions.
ìIt is needless to emphasize here that any such attempt must be doomed to failure. And yet defeat for us is not entirely inconceivable. One thing can cause us to stumble, and that one thing is an unsuspected internal weakness. Genetics is, after all, still an imperfect science. Even with twenty generations behind us, undesirable traits may crop up at scattered points, and each represents a flaw in the steel shield of Auroraís strength.
ìThat is the Pacific Project-the use of our own criminals and traitors against us; and if they can find such in our inner councils, the Earthmen might even succeed.
ìThe Foreign Agents Committee exists to combat that threat. In the accused, we touch the fringes of the web. We must go on-î
The speech did, at any rate.
When it was concluded, Moreanu, pale, wide-eyed, pounded his fist, ìI demand my say-î
ìThe accused may speak, ì said the chairman.
Moreanu rose and looked about him for a long moment. The room, fitted for an audience of seventy-five million by Community Wave, was unattended. There were the inquisitors, legal staff, official recorders-and with him, in the actual flesh, his guards.
He would have done better with an audience. To whom could he otherwise appeal? His glance fled hopelessly from each face it touched, but could find nothing better.
ìFirst,î he said, ìI deny the legality of this meeting. My constitutional rights of privacy and individuality have been denied. I have been tried by a group without standing as a court, by individuals convinced, in advance, of my guilt. I have been denied adequate opportunity to defend myself. In fact, I have been treated throughout as an already convicted criminal requiring only sentence.
ìI deny, completely and without reservation, that I have been engaged in any activity detrimental to the state or tending to subvert any of its fundamental institutions.
ìI accuse, vigorously and unreservedly, this Committee of deliberately using its powers to win political battles. I am guilty not of treason, but of disagreement. I disagree with a policy dedicated to the destruction of the larger part of the human race for reasons that are trivial and inhumane.
ìRather than destruction, we owe assistance to these men who are condemned to a harsh, unhappy life solely because it was our ancestors and not theirs who happened to reach the Outer Worlds first. With our technology and resources, they can yet re-create and redevelop-ì
The chairmanís voice rose above the intense near-whisper of Moreanu, ìYou are out of order. The Committee is quite prepared to hear any remarks you make in your own defense, but a sermon on the rights of Earthmen is outside the legitimate realm of the discussion.î
The hearings were formally closed. It was a great political victory for the Independents; all would agree to that. Of the members of the Committee, only Franklin Maynard was not completely satisfied. A small, nagging doubt remained.
He wondered-
Should he try, one last time? Should he speak once more and then no more to that queer little monkey ambassador from Earth? He made his decision quickly and acted upon it instantly. Only a pause to arrange a witness, since even for himself an unwitnessed private communion with an Earthman might be dangerous.
Luiz Moreno, Ambassador to Aurora from Earth, was, to put not too fine a point on it, a miserable figure of a man. And that wasnít exactly an accident. On the whole, the foreign diplomats of Earth tended to be dark, short, wizen, or weakly-or all four.
That was only self-protection, since the Outer Worlds exerted strong attraction for any Earthman. Diplomats exposed to the allure of Aurora, for instance, could not but be exceedingly reluctant to return to Earth. Worse, and more dangerous, exposure meant a growing sympathy with the demigods of the stars and a growing alienation from the slum-dwellers of Earth.
Unless, of course, the ambassador found himself rejected. Unless he found himself somewhat despised. And then, no more faithful servant of Earth could be imagined, no man less subject to corruption.
The Ambassador to Earth was only five foot two, with a bald head and receding forehead, a pinkish affectation of beard and red-rimmed eyes. He was suffering from a slight cold, the occasional results whereof he smothered in a handkerchief. And yet, withal, he was a man of intellect.
To Franklin Maynard, the sight and sound of the Earthman was distressing. He grew queasy at each cough and shuddered when the ambassador wiped his nose.
Maynard said: ìYour excellency, we commune at my request because I wish to inform you that the Gathering has decided to ask your recall by your government.î
ìThat is kind of you, councilor. I had an inkling of this. And for what reason?î
ìThe reason is not within the bounds of discussion. I believe it is the prerogative of a sovereign state to decide for itself whether a foreign representative shall be persona grata or not. Nor do I think you really need enlightenment on this matter.î
ìVery well, then.î The ambassador paused to wield his handkerchief and murmur an apology. îIs that all?î
Maynard said: ìNot quite. There are matters I would like to mention. Remain!î
The ambassadorís reddened nostrils flared a bit, but he smiled, and said: ìAn honor.î
ìYour world, excellency,î said Maynard, superciliously, ìdisplays a certain belligerence of late that we on Aurora find most annoying and unnecessary. I trust that you will find your return to Earth at this point a convenient opportunity to use your influence against further displays such as recently occurred in New York, where two Aurorans were manhandled by a mob. The payment of an indemnity may not be enough the next time.î
ìBut that is emotional overflow, Councilor Maynard. Surely, you cannot consider youngsters shouting in the streets to be adequate representations of belligerence.î
ìIt is backed by your governmentís actions in many ways. The recent arrest of Mr. Ernest Keilin, for instance.î
ìWhich is a purely domestic affair,î said the ambassador, quietly.
ìBut not one to demonstrate a reasonable spirit toward the Outer Worlds. Keilin was one of the few Earthmen who until recently could yet make their voices heard. He was intelligent enough to realize that no divine right protects the inferior man simply because he is inferior.î
The ambassador arose: ìI am not interested in Auroran theories on racial differences.î
ìA moment. Your government may realize that much of their plans have gone awry with the arrest of your agent, Moreanu. Stress the fact that we of Aurora are much wiser than we have been prior to this arrest. It may serve to give them pause.î
ìIs Moreanu my agent? Really, councilor, if I am disaccredited, I shall leave. But surely the loss of diplomatic immunity does not affect my personal immunity as an honest man from charges of espionage.î
ìIsnít that your job?î
ìDo Aurorans take it for granted that espionage and diplomacy are identical? My government will be glad to hear it. We shall take appropriate precautions.î
ìThen, you defend Moreanu? You deny that he has been working for Earth?î
ìI defend only myself. As to Moreanu, I am not stupid enough to say anything.î
ìWhy stupid?î
ìWouldnít a defense by myself be but another indictment against him? I neither accuse nor defend him. Your governmentís quarrel with Moreanu, like my governmentís with Keilin-whom you, by the way, are most suspiciously eager to defend-is an internal affair. I will leave now.î
